Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated and cited as the "City of Monroe Code." 
(Code 1958,  1-1) 
State Law reference- For method and procedure for adopting a code of ordinances, R.S. 33:1361-33:1363. 
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council: 
    City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if the words "of Monroe" followed it. 
    City clerk or clerk. The clerk of the council. 
    Computation of time. In computing a period of time allowed or prescribed by ordinance, the date of the act, event or default after which the period begins to run is not to be included. The last day of the period is to be included, unless it is a legal holiday, in which event the period runs until the end of the next day which is not a legal holiday. 
    A half-holiday is considered as a legal holiday. A legal holiday is to be included in the computation of a period of time allowed or prescribed, except when: 
(1)  It is expressly excluded; 
(2)  It would otherwise be the last day of the period; or 
(3)  The period is less than seven (7) days. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Civ. Proc. Art. 5089. 
    Council. The words "the city council" or "the council" shall be construed to mean the Council of the City of Monroe. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring an officer of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be construed to authorize the officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Keeper and proprietor. The words "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and include persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or a servant, agent or employee. 
    Mayor. Whenever the word "mayor" is used it shall be construed to mean the mayor of the city. 
    May/Shall. "May" is discretionary; "shall" is mandatory. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
    Oath. The word oath shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The word "owner" applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner or usufructuary of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Parish. The words "the parish" or "this parish" shall mean the Parish of Ouachita. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships, and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The word "property" shall include movable and immovable property as such terms are defined in the Louisiana Civil Code. 
    Public place. The term "public place" shall mean any park, cemetery, school yard or open space adjacent thereto, and all beaches, canals or other waterways. 
    Residence. The term "residence" shall be construed to mean the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation, and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature or subscription includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Louisiana. 
    Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts, and all other public highways in the city. 
    Tenant. The words "tenant" or "occupant" applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease of or who occupies, the whole or a part of such building or land either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Week. The word "week" shall be construed to mean seven (7) days. 
    Written or in writing shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1958,  1-2) 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1958,  1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect: 
(1)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city, or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(2)  The administrative ordinances of the city, not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of such Code; 
(3)  Any ordinance fixing salaries or compensation of officers or employees of the city; 
(4)  Any appropriation or budget ordinance; 
(5)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(6)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city; 
(7)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city or vacating any such plat; 
(8)  Any ordinance annexing property to the city; 
(9)  Any taxation ordinance of the city not inconsistent herewith; 
(10)  Any ordinance rezoning property or granting special uses; 
(11)  Any ordinance relating to local improvements or assessing taxes therefor; 
(12)  Any ordinance fixing rates, charges or fees for garbage, water or sewer services or any combination of such services; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
Cross reference- Mobile sign ordinances saved from repeal,  3-2; alcoholic beverage ordinances saved from repeal,  4-1. 
Sec. 1-5. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance of the city in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. 
Sec. 1-6. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1958,  1-4) 
Sec. 1-7. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
    All ordinances subsequent to this Code of Ordinances which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code of Ordinances, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from said Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code of Ordinances and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the city council. 
    Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section _______ of the Code of Ordinances of Monroe, Louisiana, is hereby amended to read as follows: ..." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
    In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of Ordinances of Monroe, Louisiana, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered _______, which said section reads as follows: ..." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(Code 1958,  1-7) 
Charter reference- Adoption of ordinances,  2-12 et seq. 
Cross reference- Amendments to subdivision regulations,  32-25; amendments to zoning ordinance,  37-56 et seq. 
Sec. 1-8. - Supplementation of Code-Generally. 
(a)  A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _______ to _______" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-9. - Same-Exclusion of special or temporary ordinances. 
    Ordinances hereafter adopted which are not of a general or permanent nature shall be numbered consecutively, authenticated, published and recorded in the book of ordinances, but shall not be prepared for insertion in this Code, nor be deemed a part hereof. 
Sec. 1-10. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation in the city to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1958,  1-7) 
Sec. 1-11. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any provision of this Code and where no specific penalty is provided therefore, the violation of, or failure to comply with, any provision of this Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding six (6) months or by both such fine and imprisonment within the discretion of the court, together with court costs and expenses. Each day any violation of, or failure to comply with, any provision of this Code continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1958,  1-8; Ord. No. 10,397, 5-11-04) 
Cross reference- Responsibility for collection of fines,  11-1; authority to parole or release prisoners,  11-3. 
Sec. 1-12. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the city council without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(Code 1958,  1-5) 
Chapter 1.5 - ADJUDICATED PROPERTIES 

Sec. 1.5-1. - Policy and purpose. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to implement the provisions of R.S. 33:2892.1 through 2892.9 of Subpart G entitled "Tax Adjudications within the City of Monroe" of Part II of Chapter 6 of Title 33 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950, providing procedures for the sale of adjudicated properties. 
(Ord. No. 10,624, 9-26-06) 
Sec. 1.5-2. - Applicable within City of Monroe. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to any tax adjudication of residential and commercial property within the city limits of Monroe, Louisiana. 
(Ord. No. 10,624, 9-26-06) 
Sec. 1.5-3. - Procedure for sales initiated by individuals. 
(a)  Whenever any person desires to purchase any unredeemed property adjudicated to the City of Monroe for unpaid taxes due, charges pursuant to R.S. 33:1236 or paving and other local improvement assessments for which the adjudication was made, he shall, with an application to purchase, deposit with the tax collector of the City of Monroe an amount of money sufficient to cover the expenses of the sale, including advertising, taxes due, and other costs associated with said sale as evidence of good faith in the application. 
(b)  The tax collector shall determine the amount of money to be deposited. The tax collector's determination of the amount of monies to be deposited by the purchaser shall be equal to the expenses of the sale, including advertising, taxes due, and other costs associated with such sale as evidence of good faith in the application. 
(Ord. No. 10,624, 9-26-06) 
Sec. 1.5-4. - Notice requirement. 
(a)  Upon deposit made to purchase unredeemed property, the tax collector shall immediately notify the tax debtor by registered or certified mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the tax debtor at his last known addresses. Other interested parties shall be notified by publication in the official journal of Ouachita Parish, that he through the City of Monroe will take actual corporeal possession of the property so adjudicated to the city for five (5) years or more and that ownership will be transferred to a specifically named individual. The advertisement shall publish on two (2) consecutive days. 
(b)  The mailed notice and advertisement shall set forth the legal description of the property; inclusive of the owner of record, if known, the tax lot, block number, and street addresses; and the terms of the sale. Publication and mailing proof shall be obtained by the City of Monroe. 
(c)  When a mortgagee is identified by public recordation, constructive notice by publication shall be supplemented by notice mailed to the mortgagee's last known available address by certified mail, return receipt requested or by personal service. 
(Ord. No. 10,624, 9-26-06) 
Sec. 1.5-5. - Order of seizure and possession. 
(a)  After a lapse of ten (10) days from the last date of publication of notice described in R.S. 33:2892.3 and section 1.5-3 or from the arrival of the return of service card or from the return of the unopened certified letter(s), the tax collector for the City of Monroe shall declare by affidavit that a certain particularly described property is no longer subject to redemption and that five (5) years or more have lapsed since the recording of the proces-verbal in the conveyance records of the Ouachita Parish Clerk of Court. A certified copy of the proces-verbal shall be attached to the affidavit. 
(b)  The affidavit shall list the last known owners prior to the tax adjudication and any other interested parties. The affidavit shall also state, when applicable, the following: 
(1)  That notice of delinquency had been sent or published on a certain date. 
(2)  That the tax collector provided notice to each person holding a properly recorded mortgage, when applicable. 
(3)  That the advertisement for tax sale occurred on a certain date and was published in the official journal of Ouachita Parish. 
(4)  That the subject property was appraised, advertised, and offered for sale and failed to sell on a certain date. 
(5)  That the subject property was appraised and advertised and offered for sale a second time on a certain date and failed to sell, when applicable. 
(6)  That the proces-verbal was recorded in the conveyance records of the Ouachita Parish clerk of court on a certain date. 
(7)  That a particularly named individual has applied to purchase said property and has deposited the requisite amount to cover the expenses of the sale including advertising, taxes due, and other costs associated with the sale. 
(8)  That notice was provided in accordance with R.S. 33:2892.3 and section 1.5-3. 
(c)  A copy of the proof of publication and the return receipt or a copy of the unopened certified letter(s) shall be submitted with the affidavit when applicable. 
(Ord. No. 10,624, 9-26-06) 
Sec. 1.5-6. - Sale of property adjudicated to municipality; order of possession. 
    Upon the presentation of the affidavit, the attached certified copy of the proces-verbal, the proof of publication to any judge of competent jurisdiction (such jurisdiction to be determined by the value and situs of the immovables therein described and not the amount of the taxes) and when applicable, the return of service card or the unopened certified letter(s), the judge may in chambers grant an ex parte order of possession and transfer of ownership if he is satisfied that all notices and due process of law have been afforded the former owner. The order shall place the City of Monroe in possession of the subject property, thereby authorizing the city to perfect a sale to the named purchaser. 
(Ord. No. 10,624, 9-26-06) 
Sec. 1.5-7. - Placing purchaser in possession of property. 
(a)  The granting of the ex parte order of possession and transfer of ownership shall vest in the purchaser an absolute and perfect title to the property conveyed, without any claim thereto by any former owner and free of all mortgages, liens, privileges and encumbrances whatsoever. 
(b)  Any former owner, including heirs, assignees or other successors, shall be subject to the mortgages, liens, privileges and encumbrances if the former owner possessed the property at the time it became burdened. 
(c)  The ex parte order of possession and transfer of ownership shall have effect against third persons from the time it is filed for registry in the office of the Ouachita Parish Clerk of Court. 
(Ord. No. 10,624, 9-26-06) 
Sec. 1.5-8. - Commercial property. 
    The sale of unredeemed commercial property shall be for no less than two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the appraised value, plus advertising costs, taxes owed and other costs associated with said sale on its advertisement. The minimum price in the second advertisement shall not be less than one-third ( 1/3 ) of the appraised value, plus advertising costs, taxes owed, and other cost associated with the sale. 
(Ord. No. 10,624, 9-26-06) 
Sec. 1.5-9. - Failure to purchase. 
    If after the notice of intent to take actual corporeal possession of property and to transfer ownership has been published in the official journal of Ouachita Parish, but before the signing of the ex parte order of possession and transfer of ownership, the applicant or the potential purchaser declines to purchase the subject property, he shall be responsible for paying the cost of advertisement and any other costs associated with the preparation of the sale of the unredeemed property to him. Said property shall revert to the status of adjudicated property and the last known tax debtor shall be liable for the expenses of the sale, including advertising, taxes due, and other costs associated with the sale of the property. 
(Ord. No. 10,624, 9-26-06) 
Sec. 1.5-10. - Donation of adjudicated property. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the unredeemed property adjudicated to the City of Monroe for five (5) years or more that is subject to donation to a nonprofit organization, which is recognized by the Internal Revenue Service as a 501(c)(3) or 501(c)(4) nonprofit organization. 
(Ord. No. 10,624, 9-26-06) 
Sec. 1.5-11. - Transfer of property fee. 
    A one hundred dollar ($100.00) fee is hereby assessed to complete the legal documents necessary for the transfer of property adjudicated to the City of Monroe. 
(Ord. No. 10,961, 9-8-09)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - City emblem. 
(a)  The emblem which has been designed by L. G. Balfour Company, having as its central figure and theme a replica of the animated-motion color fountain which is to be located in front of the Monroe Civic Center and being complimented by landscaped areas on either side thereof, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk is hereby adopted as the "Emblem of the City of Monroe". 
(b)  The city emblem shall be used only for purposes of promoting and advertising the city and shall not be reproduced by any person for private profit. No person may reproduce the emblem for any purpose without obtaining prior written permission from the mayor. 
(Code 1958,  2-37-2-39) 
Secs. 2-2-2-25. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-26-2-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STATE RETIREMENT SYSTEM 

Sec. 2-41. - Policy and purpose. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend the provisions of Chapter 18 of Title 33, Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950, as amended, providing retirement to eligible officers and employees of the city. 
(Code 1958,  2-15) 
Sec. 2-42. - General authorization to take action. 
    In pursuance of such policy expressed in section 2-41 of this Code, and for such purpose, the officers and employees of the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state laws or regulations, the coverage of eligible officers and employees to be retroactive to June 30, 1956. 
(Code 1958,  2-16) 
Sec. 2-43. - Withholdings from salaries. 
    Withholdings from salaries or wages of officers and employees for the purposes provided in this division hereof and hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by the board of trustees in accordance with Chapter 18 of Title 33, Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950, as amended, and shall be paid over to the board of trustees in such amounts and at such times as are designated by state laws, and regulations of such agency. 
(Code 1958,  2-17) 
Sec. 2-44. - Payment of contributions and assessments. 
    Employee contributions and assessments for administrative expenses shall be paid from amounts appropriated for such purposes to the board of trustees in accordance with applicable state laws and regulations of such board of trustees. 
(Code 1958,  2-18) 
Sec. 2-45. - Records and reports. 
    The city clerk and the director of administration shall maintain such records and submit such reports as may be required by applicable state laws or regulations of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1958,  2-19) 
Secs. 2-46-2-75. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-76. - Residential requirements of fire and police civil service board members. 
    The two (2) members of the Monroe Fire and Police Civil Service Board elected from the Monroe Fire Department and the Monroe Police Department shall be residents of the City of Monroe, Louisiana, for at least five (5) years next preceding their election as provided for Louisiana Revised Statutes 33:2476(B). 
(Ord. No. 7385, 5-11-82) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7385, adopted May 11, 1982, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion as  2-76 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection,  15-1 et seq.; police,  28-1 et seq. 
Secs. 2-77-2-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF MASUR MUSEUM OF ART 

Sec. 2-101. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the board of trustees of the Masur Museum of Art. 
(Code 1958,  2-32) 
Sec. 2-102. - Membership. 
(a)  The membership of the board of trustees of the Masur Museum of Art shall be as follows: 
(1)  The mayor, 
(2)  The president of the city school board, 
(3)  The president of the chamber of commerce, 
(4)  The president of the junior chamber of commerce, 
(5)  The president of the junior charity league, 
(6)  The president of the art center, 
(7)  The president of the little theater, 
(8)  The president of the Northeast Louisiana Archeological Society, 
(9)  The president of Northeast Louisiana State College, 
(10)  Six (6) members at large who are residents of the city. 
(b)  The members at large of the board of trustees shall be appointed by the council. Two (2) of the first six (6) of such members shall be appointed for terms of two (2) years, two (2) for terms of four (4) years, and two (2) for terms of six (6) years. Upon the expiration of any term, successors shall be appointed for terms of six (6) years each. 
(Code 1958,  2-33, 2-34) 
Sec. 2-103. - Organization. 
    The members of the board of trustees of the Masur Museum of Art shall meet as soon as practicable after their appointment for the purpose of organization. At that meeting they shall elect a chairman and such other officers as they may deem necessary or appropriate, and shall adopt such rules and regulations governing the affairs of the board as may be necessary in order for it to carry out the purpose for which it is created. 
(Code 1958,  2-35) 
Sec. 2-104. - Powers and duties. 
    The Board of Trustees of the Masur Museum of Art shall administer, subject to the approval of the mayor, all of the affairs of the Masur Museum of Art. Such general powers and duties shall include, without limitation, the following special powers and duties: 
(a)  To develop a program or plan for the operation of the museum, including the scope of its activities. 
(b)  To make rules and regulations for the operation and use of the museum. 
(c)  To select qualified persons to operate the museum. 
(d)  To prepare and present annually to the mayor of the city a proposed budget for the maintenance and operation of the museum. 
(e)  To foster and encourage an interest in art in the Monroe area. 
(Code 1958,  2-36) 
Secs. 2-105-2-114. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE PROGRAM[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9090,  1-19, adopted September 12, 1989, has been treated as superseding the provisions of former Art. IV, minority business enterprise program. Former Art. IV,  2-115-2-139, derived from Ord. No. 7322, adopted October 13, 1981; Ord. No. 7347, adopted January 19, 1982; and Ord. No. 7932, adopted July 8, 1986. The appendix to Ord. No. 7932, which contains a variety of instructions and forms to be used in all bid solicitations, is not set out herein, but a copy is on file and available for inspection in the offices of the city. 

Sec. 2-115. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section. 
    Contract means a mutually binding legal relationship or any modification thereof obligating the seller to furnish supplies or services, including construction, and the buyer to pay for them. For purposes of this article a lease is a contract. 
    Contracting authority means by city official or group of officials vested with authority to conduct procurement activities. 
    Contractor means one who participates, through a contract or subcontract, in any program covered by this article and includes leases. 
    Joint venture means an association of two (2) or more businesses to carry out a single business enterprise for profit for which purpose they combine their property, capital, efforts, skills and knowledge. 
    Small business concern means a small business as defined pursuant to Section 3 of the Small Business Act and relevant regulations promulgated pursuant thereto; except that a small business concern shall not include any concern or group of concerns controlled by the same socially and economically disadvantaged individual or individuals which have annual average gross receipts in excess of fourteen million dollars ($14,000,000) over a previous three-year period. The secretary of department of transportation shall adjust this figure from time to time for inflation. 
    Small and disadvantaged business (DBE) means a small business concern which is at least fifty-one (51) per cent owned by one or more socially or economically disadvantaged individuals, or, in the case of any publicly owned business, at least fifty-one (51) per cent of the stock of which is owned by one or more socially and economically disadvantaged individuals and whose management and daily business operations are controlled by one or more of the socially and economically disadvantaged individuals who own it. 
    Socially and economically disadvantaged individuals means those individuals who are citizens of the United States (or lawfully admitted permanent residents) and who are women, Black Americans, Hispanic Americans, native Americans, Asian-Pacific Americans, or Asian-Indian Americans, and any other minorities or individuals found to be disadvantaged by the Small Business Administration pursuant to Section 8(a) of the Small Business Act, provided the city shall make a rebuttable presumption (subject to challenge by a third party in accordance with procedures contained elsewhere herein) that individuals in the following groups are socially and economically disadvantaged: 
(1)  "Women." 
(2)  "Black Americans" which includes persons having origins in any of the Black racial groups of Africa. 
(3)  "Hispanic Americans" which includes persons of Mexican, Puerto Rican, Central or South American, or other Spanish or Portuguese culture or origin regardless of race. 
(4)  "Native Americans" which includes persons who are American Indians, Eskimos, Aleuts, or native Hawaiians. 
(5)  "Asian-Pacific Americans" which includes persons whose origins are from Japan, China, Taiwan, Korea, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, the Phillipines, Samoa, Guam, the United States Territories of the Pacific, and Northern Marianas. 
(6)  "Asian-Indian Americans" which includes persons whose origins are from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Sri-Lanka. 
The City of Monroe may determine on a case-by-case basis, that individuals who are not a member of one of the above groups are socially and economically disadvantaged. The City of Monroe may accept as socially and economically disadvantaged any person who has been so certified by the Small Business Administration under its 8(a) program provided, however, that it shall be the responsibility of the person to provide the city acceptable evidence of current 8(a) certification, and provided that the city may require and ask for additional information about the person and his/her business operations. 
    Women-owned business (WBE) means a small business concern which (a) is at least fifty-one (51) per cent owned by one or more women, or in the case of any publicly owned business, at least fifty-one (51) per cent of the stock is owned by one or more women; and (b) whose management and daily business operations are controlled by one or more women who own it. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  4, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-116. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the disadvantaged business enterprise program is to provide guidance in the implementation of the disadvantaged business enterprise plan of the City of Monroe so as to increase the participation of DBE businesses in procurement activities awarded by the city pursuant to DOT-assisted programs. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  1, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-117. - Objectives. 
    The objectives of the disadvantaged business enterprise program is to: 
(1)  Coordinate the implementation of a comprehensive DBE program. 
(2)  Design steps to overcome barriers to increase utilization of DBEs. 
(3)  Provide guidance to personnel in all departments vested with authority to advertise bids and to conduct related procurement activities which may involve DBE businesses. 
(4)  Establish goal-setting methods and reporting systems for DBE programs in each affected department. 
(5)  Ensure a concerted effort to attain projected annual goals for DBE program. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  2, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-118. - Policy statement. 
    It is the policy of the City of Monroe, in compliance with Title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, Part 23, as amended, issued by the United States Department of Transportation to establish procedures by which DBEs will have maximum opportunity to participate in DOT-assisted contracts. Title 49, as amended, requires that the City of Monroe, its bidders and its contractors utilize small and disadvantaged and women-owned businesses to the maximum extent feasible in all phases of its procurement practices. This is done by providing an equal opportunity for DBEs/WBEs identifying and assisting in DBE/WBE certification for maximum contract participation in the areas of construction, professional services, equipment and supplies, and generally fulfilling whatever other procurement requirements the city may have with respect to DOT-assisted contracts. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  3, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-119. - Scope. 
    This procedure applies to all City of Monroe departments, divisions and organizations conducting any type of procurement activity. Women are a protected class, not a minority, although it is recognized that the term "small and disadvantaged business enterprise" refers to both minorities and females. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  5, 6, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-120. - Procedures. 
    To the extent legally practicable, the City of Monroe will ensure that all contractors participating in federally funded or assisted contracts of the city comply with applicable federal prevailing wage laws and that all contractors providing services, materials or supplies to the city provide employment opportunities to minorities and females equal to those provided to all other groups or individuals. Such contractors will also be expected to take positive steps toward the utilization of DBEs and WBEs to the maximum extent feasible, consistent with sound procurement principles and applicable law. 
    Upon request, the city will provide DBEs/WBEs with information on the preparation of bid specifications, fulfillment of general requirements, job performance requirements and procurement opportunities and prerequisites for bidding on contracts. The City of Monroe encourages joint ventures among DBEs/WBEs and between majority and minority firms bidding for city contracts. 
    The City of Monroe will use its best efforts to ensure that DBEs and WBEs are informed of current and future procurement activities through utilization of newspapers (including minority-owned newspapers), local minority chambers of commerce and other DBE/WBE assistance organizations as well as through direct contact with DBE/WBE entrepreneurs. 
    As evidence of its intent to vigorously pursue the object of this DBE program, the city has designed a disadvantaged business enterprise coordinator to operate the DBE office by administering and monitoring the city's DBE program. Each affected city department will designate a liaison to have overall responsibility for promotion of disadvantaged business/women business enterprise in his/her department. This policy statement shall be circulated throughout the city's organization and to minorities, females and the nonminority community. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  7, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-121. - Responsibilities. 
(a)  The general responsibility for administration of the DBE program rests with the mayor. 
(b)  The director of planning and urban development under the direction of the mayor is responsible for the administration, implementation and review of these procedures. 
(c)  The disadvantaged business enterprise office is responsible for meeting with contractors and community groups, participation in conferences, provisions of management and technical assistance, briefing of managers and supervisors, preparation of administrative directives of DBE program operations and coordination of DBE task force. 
(d)  The DBE task force, appointed by the mayor, will serve as an advisory council to assist in DBE policy development. This task force will be made up of eleven (11) persons representing local DBE/WBE businesses, economic development organizations, chamber of commerce representatives, construction industry, national associations, and purchasing officials from private industry, with majority of the task force being selected from DBE/WBE businesses. The task force will review the programs and similar groups in other cities, provide city officials with information and policy decisions made in their organization, and subsequently establish a disadvantaged/women business enterprise purchasing council with the city. 
(e)  The purchasing officials within the office of the chief administrative office (CAO) will maintain a liaison function with the DBE coordinator and other officials responsible for monitoring departmental activities. 
(f)  The DBE coordinator will be responsible for management of the DBE program, identification of priority areas for DBEs/WBEs efforts, identifying goals and maintaining specific information on DBEs/WBEs as to capabilities, areas of need and potential development, assist in arranging joint ventures and in the development of procedures to facilitate maximum utilization of small and disadvantaged women businesses. The DBE coordinator will also participate in seminars, and coordinate with procurement and legal procedures. 
(g)  The purchasing agent is responsible for day-to-day operations through direct utilization of his staff to ensure conformance with DBE policies and procedures. 
(h)  The head of the department will act as or appoint a liaison to represent that department's DBE/WBE activity. 
(i)  A liaison appointed from each department knowledgeable in contracting/procurement activities will be responsible for ensuring departmental participation in the DBE program. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  8, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-122. - Disadvantaged business enterprise (DBE) liaison officer. 
    The City of Monroe has designated the director of planning and urban development as disadvantaged business enterprise coordinator to serve as the city's liaison officer for the disadvantaged business enterprise program. 
    The coordinator reports directly to the mayor. The day-to-day implementation of the DBE program shall be assigned to the EEO/compliance department. This department will be responsible for: 
(1)  Disseminating information on available business opportunities so that DBEs/WBEs are provided an equitable opportunity to bid on city contracts. 
(2)  Carrying out technical assistance to DBEs/WBEs through coordination with other minority assistance programs such as NIRAL, Urban League, United Business Alliance, Minority Contractors' Association, and other organizations which provide assistance in areas of procurement, loan packaging, management services and technical assistance, and construction contractors' assistance. 
(3)  Maintaining and updating a directory of disadvantaged and women-owned business enterprises. 
(4)  Monitoring and reporting on affected city departments' efforts at meeting DBE goals. 
(5)  Performing whatever other tasks necessary to assure the effectiveness of the city's DBE program. 
(6)  Providing technical assistance to bid review committees to determine DBE/WBE utilization for DOT-assisted contract awards. 
The support staff for the DBE coordinator will be the purchasing agent, clerk typist II, the city attorney, the city engineer and the equal opportunity/compliance officer. All department heads will serve, or designate a representative to serve as DBE liaison for their departments. These individuals will report to the coordinator at least on a quarterly basis on the progress made toward achieving the DBE goals. 
(Ord. No. 9090  II, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-123. - Procedure to ensure DBEs/WBEs equitable opportunity to compete for contracts and subcontracts. 
    The City of Monroe shall develop and use affirmative action techniques to facilitate DBE/WBE participation in procurement activities. These techniques shall include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Arranging solicitations, time for the presentation of bids, quantities, specifications and delivery schedules so as to facilitate the participating DBEs and WBEs. 
(2)  Providing technical assistance to DBEs and WBEs in overcoming barriers such as the inability to obtain bonding or financing. 
(3)  The DBE coordinator will verify that all bid packages include the DBE goal statement, provisions for DBE/WBE participation, contractor assurance. Listing of prospective state/national contractors will also be included. Information and communication programs on contracting procedures and specific contracting opportunities will be available, with such programs being bilingual where appropriate. 
(4)  A bid review committee comprised of the DBE coordinator, the city engineer and an attorney of the city's legal department shall be established to review all phases of the bid process, including, but not limited to, the evaluation of good faith efforts, and the consideration and award of each contract under this DBE program. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  III, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-124. - Use of minority and women-owned banks. 
    There are no minority or women-owned banks in the Monroe area. However, there is a minority bank in the planning stage, presently, and should this materialize, the city will thoroughly investigate the full extent of services offered and make the greatest feasible use of these banks. Prime contractors will also be encouraged to use these banks. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  IV, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-125. - Disadvantaged business enterprise (DBE) directory. 
    The City of Monroe maintains a directory to facilitate identifying DBEs and WBEs with capabilities relevant to general contracting requirements and to particular solicitations. The directory is available even though all DBEs/WBEs are not certified. It is available to bidders and proposers to assist in their efforts to meet the DBE/WBE requirements. Included are specific firms which the department of transportation, City of Monroe, Louisiana, minority business registry, or the small business administration have determined to be eligible DBEs and WBEs. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  V, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-126. - DBE/WBE eligibility and joint ventures involving DBEs and WBEs. 
    To ensure that the DBE program only benefits firms owned and controlled by disadvantaged individuals or women, the City of Monroe shall certify the eligibility of DBEs and WBEs and joint ventures involving DBEs and WBEs that are named by competitors by completing the forms in Attachment A and/or B. 
    The city shall require prime contractors to make "good faith efforts" to replace a DBE or WBE contractor that is unable to perform successfully with another DBE or WBE. The city shall reserve the right to approve all substitutions of subcontractor before bid opening and during contract performance, in order to ensure the substitute firms are eligible DBEs or WBEs. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  VI, 9-12-89) 
Editor's note- Attachments and schedules are included in the appendix which was attached to Ord. No. 9090, but not included herein. See the editor's note to Art. IV of this chapter. 
Sec. 2-127. - Percentage goal. 
(a)  Overall goal. The overall goal for the City of Monroe is twelve (12) per cent for DBE participation. These goals relate to the involvement of DBEs/WBEs in all DOT-assisted contracts and purchases made by the City of Monroe. In no case shall this goal constitute a fixed quota. The following factors were considered in arriving at this goal: The overall goal shall be reviewed on an annual basis. The review process shall analyze projected versus actual DBE/WBE participation during the previous fiscal year. Whatever revisions considered necessary shall be recommended by the task force of the city to the city council who shall adopt said recommendations or set said goal. Said goal shall be submitted to the department of transportation for approval. 
(b)  Contract goal. Contract goal will be set on each specific prime contract with subcontracting possibilities in accord with the provisions of 49 CFR, 23.45(g) which the bidder or proposer must meet or exceed or demonstrate that it made good efforts to meet but could not meet. These efforts will be reviewed by a DBE coordinator or on an individual basis. 
(c)  Geographic area. The City of Monroe and contractors shall, at a minimum, seek DBEs and WBEs in the same geographic area in which they seek contractors or subcontractors generally for a given solicitation. If the goal cannot be met by using DBEs and WBEs from this geographic area, the city and contractors shall expand the search to a reasonably wider geographic area. 
(d)  Publication of goal. When the DBE goal is submitted to the department of transportation for approval, it will also be published. The publication will inform the public that the goal and a description of how it is selected will be available for inspection during normal business hours at city hall for thirty (30) days from the date of notice, and comments on the goal will be accepted for forty-five (45) days from the date of publication of this notice. The notice will be published in general circulation media, available minority focus media, and trade association publications and will state that the comments are for informational purposes only. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  VII, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-128. - Procedures to require that DBEs/WBEs be identified by name by competitors for contract prior to award of contract. 
(a)  All bidders/proposers will be required to provide an assurance of meeting the DBE goal at the time of bid opening. Schedule C will be submitted within a reasonable allotted time prior to contract award, to be determined by the DBE liaison officer. Schedule C provides: 
(1)  The names and addresses of DBE and/or WBE subcontractors; 
(2)  A description of the work each is to perform; and 
(3)  The dollar value of the participation by each named DBE and/or WBE firm. 
(b)  Agreements between a bidder/proposer and/or DBE/WBE in which the DBE/WBE promises not to provide subcontracting quotations to other bidders/proposers are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  VIII, 9-12-89) 
Editor's note- Attachments and schedules are included in the appendix which was attached to Ord. No. 9090, but not included herein. See the editor's note to Art. IV of this chapter. 
Sec. 2-129. - Good faith efforts. 
    If the DBE/WBE participation submitted in response to section 2-128 does not meet the DBE contract goal, the apparent successful competitor shall satisfy the recipient that the competitor has made good faith efforts to meet the goal. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  IX, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-130. - Selection criteria to ensure that prime contracts are awarded to competitors that meet DBE goals. 
    To ensure that prime contracts are awarded to competitors who meet DBE goals, the selection criteria, which is outlined in Attachment 3 will be followed. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  X, 9-12-89) 
Editor's note- Attachments and schedules are included in the appendix which was attached to Ord. No. 9090, but not included herein. See the editor's note to Art. IV of this chapter. 
Sec. 2-131. - Compliance of subrecipients, contractors and subcontractors to the DBE requirements. 
    Any time that the City of Monroe has any subrecipients, they all must comply with the DBE requirements outlined in this program. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  XI, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-132. - DBE set-asides pursuant to 49 CFR 23. 
    As used in 49 CFR 23, the term "Set-Aside" refers to an arrangement in which a particular contract is reserved for competition solely among a selected category of bidders (example, disadvantaged business/women's business enterprises). 
    It is the opinion of the City of Monroe that the regulations (49 CFR 23) do not require the use of set-asides on any particular contract but that the use of set-asides are optional and can be used on contracts as a means of meeting DBE goals. 
    The City of Monroe does not view set-asides as currently necessary to meet its DBE goal and elects to seek to attain such goal through awards of prime contracts to DBE/WBE firms by means of contract goal processes elsewhere detailed in this program. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  XII, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-133. - DBE requirements for transit vehicle manufacturers. 
    Transit vehicle manufacturers who wish to bid on UMTA-assisted transit vehicle procurement contracts shall have a UMTA-approved DBE program. Manufacturers will be required by the City of Monroe to certify that they have such program as a condition for bidding on UMTA-assisted contracts. Bid invitations issued for UMTA-assisted transit vehicles shall include the provisions listed below: 
(1)  Policy. It is the policy of the department of transportation that small and disadvantaged business and women's business enterprises as defined in 49 CFR, Part 23, as amended, shall have the maximum opportunity to participate in the performance of contracts financed in whole or in part with DOT financial assistance under this agreement. Consequently, the DBE requirements of 49 CFR, Part 23, as amended, apply to this agreement. 
(2)  DBE obligation. The contractor agrees to ensure that small and disadvantaged business enterprises as defined in 49 CFR, Part 23, as amended, have the maximum opportunity to participate in the performance of DOT-assisted contracts and subcontracts. The contractors shall not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, or sex in the awarding and performance of DOT-assisted contracts. 
(3)  Contractor obligation. Contractors and subcontractors failing to carry out the above requirements are to be advised that failure to meet the provisions in (a) and (b) above shall constitute a breach of contract. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  XIII, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-134. - Policy concerning leases. 
    The following action shall be taken concerning leases: 
(1)  The City of Monroe shall not exclude DBEs or WBEs from participation in business opportunities by entering into long-term exclusive agreements with non-DBEs for the operation of major transportation-related activities or major activities for the provision of goods and services to other city facilities. 
(2)  Such contracting shall be included in the city's overall goal. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  XIV, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-135. - Maintenance of records and reports. 
(a)  In order to monitor the progress of its DBE program, the city shall maintain a record-keeping system which will identify and assess DBE/WBE contract awards, prime contractors' progress in achieving DBE affirmative action efforts. 
(b)  Specially, the city shall maintain records showing: 
(1)  Procedures which have been adopted to comply with the requirements of the article. 
(2)  Awards of DBEs/WBEs. These awards shall be measured against projected DBE/WBE awards and/or goals. To assist in this effort, the city shall obtain regular reports from prime contractors on their progress in meeting contractural DBE/WBE obligations. 
(3)  Specific efforts to identify and award contracts to DBEs/WBEs. 
(c)  Records shall be available upon the request of an authorized officer or employee of the city and appropriate governmental agency and upon the request of members of the public. 
(d)  The city shall submit reports confirming in frequency and format the existing contract-reporting requirements of the applicable department element. Where no such contract-reporting requirements exist, DBE reports shall be submitted quarterly. These reports shall include as a minimum: 
(1)  The number of contracts awarded to DBEs/WBEs; 
(2)  A description of the general categories of contracts awarded to DBEs/WBEs; 
(3)  The dollar value of contracts awarded to DBEs/WBEs; 
(4)  The percentage of the dollar value of all contracts awarded during this period which were awarded to DBEs/WBEs; and 
(5)  An indication to what extent the percentage met or exceeded the goal specified in the application. 
(e)  The records and reports shall provide information relating to firms owned and controlled by disadvantaged persons separately from information relating to firms owned and controlled by women. If the records and reports include SBA 8(a) contractors that are not disadvantaged or women, information concerning these contractors shall also be recorded and reported separately. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  XV, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-136. - DBE Reporting forms. 
(a)  Where prime contractors or suppliers have indicated DBE/WBE participation at a particular rate and for certain tasks or suppliers, actual work performed or supplies provided by the DBEs/WBEs will be reported using the DBE report form and submitted with request for payment. These report forms will be reviewed by the minority business enterprise coordinator subsequent to completion of the project to assess needs for modifications in the contracting procedure which will increase DBE/WBE participation. 
(b)  The city's purchasing agent will prepare a listing indicating goods and services purchased on a quarterly basis. The list will be reviewed by the DBE coordinator to assist in identifying areas where qualified DBEs/WBEs should be considered and to ensure they are properly notified of purchasing activities. 
(c)  Departments will be required to submit a quarterly report indicating dollar ($) amounts and percentage (%) of DBE/WBE utilization in all procurement activities as well as details on anticipated DBE/WBE participation for the following year. 
(d)  DBE participation reports will be compiled by the DBE coordinator to formulate an overall quarterly report of submission to the mayor and of the City of Monroe and in turn to any federal agency requiring this information. 
(e)  The mayor of the City of Monroe will receive a monthly status report from the DBE coordinator outlining potential problem areas, progress made in achieving the goals of the program, and indications of any policy decisions which may be needed. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  XVI, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-137. - Communications programs. 
    The City of Monroe will utilize the following methods of communicating more effectively with interested businesses who desire to participate in the DBE program. These methods will seek to improve the firm compliance with city procedures, particularly the bid process. 
(1)  In order to assist minority and nonminority contractors in meeting the requirements of the bid process, pre-bid conferences will be held where practical, for the purpose of explaining DBE/WBE requirements and for identifying minority and nonminority contractors showing an interest in contracting with the city. 
(2)  Joint venture and subcontractural arrangements between minority and nonminority businesses will be encouraged at these pre-bid conferences. In order that DBEs/WBEs will have sufficient time to review the documents and prepare bids, bidding documents will be made available to minority economic development groups and trade associations in a timely manner at no cost. 
(3)  Additionally, minority economic development groups and social agencies will be contacted for assistance in locating DBEs/WBEs with the expertise or products sought by the City of Monroe. 
(4)  The city will advertise bid requests for proposals and invitations for bids in a minority-owned newspaper in the Monroe area. 
(5)  A "bidder's handbook," which contains valuable information for use by nonminority businesses, will increase the awareness of those interested businesses to the city's procedure and its processes. 
(6)  The City of Monroe will sponsor seminars and workshops designed to acquaint DBEs/WBEs with the procurement personnel and with the local companies; and seminars designed to provide DBEs/WBEs with information about how to do businesses with organizations including the City of Monroe. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  XVII, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-138. - Counting participation toward meeting DBE goal. 
    DBE/WBE participation shall be counted toward meeting goals set in accordance with DOT's DBE regulations at 49 CFR, Part 23 and the City of Monroe's program as follows: 
(1)  Once a firm is determined to be an eligible DBE or WBE in accordance with the provisions specified in this program, the total dollar value of the contract awarded is counted toward the applicable goal. 
(2)  The total dollar value of a contract to a firm owned and controlled by both disadvantaged males and nondisadvantaged females is counted toward the goal for DBEs, in proportion to the percentage of ownership and control of each group in the business. The total dollar value of a contract with a firm owned and controlled by disadvantaged women is counted toward the DBE goal. 
(3)  The City of Monroe or contractor employing a DBE or WBE firm may count toward its goal a portion of the total dollar value of a contract with a joint venture eligible under the DBE/WBE eligibility criteria specified herein equal to the percentage of the ownership and control of the DBE or WBE partner in the joint venture. 
(4)  The city or a contractor will count toward its goal only expenditures to DBEs or WBEs that perform a commercially useful function in the work of a contract. A DBE or WBE is considered to perform a commercially useful function when it is responsible for execution of a distinct element of the work of a contract and carrying out its responsibilities by actually performing, managing and supervising the work involved. To determine whether a DBE/WBE is performing a commercially useful function, the city or a contractor shall evaluate the amount of work subcontracted, industry practices and other relevant factors. 
(5)  Consistent with the normal industry practices, a DBE or WBE may enter into subcontracts. If a DBE or WBE contractor subcontracts a significantly greater portion of the work of the contract than would be expected on the basis of normal industry practices, the DBE/WBE shall be presumed not to be performing a commercially useful function. The DBE/WBE may present evidence to rebut this presumption as final, subject to review by the department of transportation in instances of DOT-assisted contracts. 
(6)  The city or a contractor may count toward its DBE goal expenditures for materials and supplies obtained from DBE/WBE suppliers and manufacturers provided that the DBEs/WBEs assume the actual and contractural responsibility for the provision of the materials and supplies. The city or a contractor may count its entire expenditure to a DBE/WBE manufacturer (i.e., a supplier that produces goods from raw material or substantially alters them before resale). The city will count sixty (60) per cent of its expenditures to DBE/WBE suppliers that are not manufacturers, provided that such suppliers perform a commercially useful function in the supply process. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  XVIII, 9-12-89) 
Sec. 2-139. - Grievance procedure. 
(a)  Types of complaints. In order to assure the effectiveness of this procedure, an individual involved in city procurement activities may file a complaint regarding: 
(1)  Any component of the program which they feel has been administered in a discriminatory manner; 
(2)  Failure of prime contractors to cooperate with DBE/WBE businesses; 
(3)  Failure of DBE/WBE subcontractors to fulfill their contract commitments; and 
(4)  Any other aspect of the contracting procedure which might limit the implementation of the DBE program. 
(b)  Filing date. The complaint shall be filed in writing or communicated directly to the DBE coordinator within thirty (30) days from the date of an alleged violation unless good cause for delay is shown. Good cause to be determined by the DBE coordinator. 
(c)  Complaint processing. When complaints are filed with the DBE program coordinator, the CAO, the department involved, the respondent and the complainant will be notified within ten (10) days if the complaint is to be investigated. The complainant's specific allegations and any data needed are identified in a written communication to the respondent. Complaints filed against the DBE coordinator will be handled pursuant to these procedures by another individual appointed by the mayor. 
(d)  Intimidation. No recipient, contractor or other person shall intimidate, threaten or discriminate against an individual who files a complaint. All files maintained on complaints will be kept confidential whenever possible. 
(e)  Follow-up. Those responsible for initiating any remedial action as a result of a complaint will be required to ensure actions are taken within thirty (30) days from the date findings are issued. 
(f)  Quarterly reports. The DBE program coordinator will submit a quarterly report on the status of complaint activities to the mayor of the City of Monroe, who in turn will submit a report to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 9090,  XIX, 9-12-89) 
Secs. 2-140-2-148. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SMALL BUSINESS PROCUREMENT PROGRAM[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7330, adopted Nov. 24, 1981, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion of  I-VII as Ch. 2, art. V,  2-149-2-156, was at the discretion of the editor. 
State Law reference- Authority for procurement by municipalities from small businesses, R.S. 38:2233. 

Sec. 2-149. - Statement of policy. 
(a)  It is the policy of the city to involve small businesses, small businesses owned and operated by socially or economically disadvantaged persons, and small businesses owned and operated by women in all phases of procurement activities and to afford them the maximum feasible opportunities in the procurement of goods and services, excluding construction, by the city. 
(b)  In order to accomplish this objective, it is the intent of the city to implement a small business procurement program, pursuant to R.S. 38:2233, which designates and sets aside for awarding to small businesses, small businesses owned and operated by socially or economically disadvantaged persons and small businesses owned and operated by women an amount not to exceed ten (10) per cent of the value of the anticipated total city procurements of goods and services, excluding construction, for each prospective fiscal year. This program shall commence with the fiscal year 1982-1983 of the city. The small business set-aside shall be designated and appropriated at the council meeting during which the general operating budget is adopted each fiscal year thereafter. 
(c)  The city and its respective departments, divisions and offices shall urge prime contractors engaged in contractual obligations with the city to seek and use the services of small businesses, small businesses owned and operated by socially or economically disadvantaged persons, and small businesses owned by women to perform subcontractual services and as authorized dealers under the awarded city contracts. 
(d)  The city shall not prohibit or discourage small business from seeking procurement awards through the normal solicitation and bidding processes, but shall encourage all small business to utilize the normal bidding process. 
(Ord. No. 7330, Intro. , 11-24-81) 
Sec. 2-150. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this program and its procedures for implementation, the following definitions shall be employed: 
(a)  Small business means a business entity organized for profit, including an individual, partnership, corporation, joint venture, association or cooperative, which is domiciled in and has its principal place of business in the City of Monroe or Ouachita Parish, Louisiana, and which is not either dominant in its field of operation or an affiliate or subsidiary of a business dominant in its field of operation. 
(b)  Dominant in its field of operation means exercising a controlling or major influence in a business activity in which a number of businesses are engaged. In determining if a business is dominant, the following criteria, among others, shall be considered: Number of employees; volume of business; financial resources; competitive status or position; ownership or control of materials, processes, patents, license agreements and facilities; sales territory; and nature of business activity. The following businesses shall be deemed dominant in their field of operation: 
(1)  Manufacturing businesses which employ more than twenty (20) persons and have in the preceding three (3) fiscal years exceeded a total of three (3) million dollars ($3,000,000.00) in gross receipts. 
(2)  Nonmanufacturing businesses which employ more than ten (10) persons and have in the preceding three (3) fiscal years exceeded a total of three (3) million dollars ($3,000,000.00) in gross receipts. 
(c)  Affiliate or subsidiary of a business dominant in its field of operation means a business which is at least twenty (20) per cent owned by a business dominant in that field of operation or by partners, officers, directors, majority shareholders, or their equivalent of a business dominant in that field of operation. 
(d)  Socially or economically disadvantaged person means a person who has been deprived of the opportunity to develop and maintain a competitive position in the economy because of social or economic disadvantage. This disadvantage may arise from cultural, social or economic circumstances or background or physical location. 
(e)  Women-owned business means a business that is at least fifty-one (51) per cent owned by a woman or women who also control and operate it. "Control" in this context means exercising the power to make policy decisions. "Operate" in this context means being actively involved in the day-to-day management. In determining whether a business is fifty-one (51) per cent owned by a woman or women shall not be diminished because she is part of a community property regime. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  I, 11-24-81) 
Sec. 2-151. - Listing of anticipated goods and services. 
    All departments, divisions and offices of the city shall identify all anticipated goods and services purchased by their respective departments, divisions and/or offices that are eligible for inclusion in the set-aside program. The purchasing office shall collect said information and compile the same into a comprehensive listing identifying said goods and services, showing the quantities of each item purchased during the preceding year. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  II, 11-24-81) 
Sec. 2-152. - Certification of small businesses. 
(a)  The program and urban development department (contract administrators) shall assume the responsibility of identifying and certifying small business, small business owned and operated by socially or economically disadvantaged persons, and small businesses owned and operated by women eligible for this program. 
(b)  An informational data sheet form will be prepared and made available to all interested businesses to be used for identification and certification purposes. This form will provide for all of the information necessary to identify a business as being eligible for this program and will provide for self-certification in affidavit form. It shall also provide for a listing or catalog of the goods and services the business can provide, along with the business's capabilities and experience. 
(c)  The program and urban development contract administrators shall have the authority to verify the eligibility of any business who applies for the program. In the event of disqualification or decertification, the business so disqualified or decertified may appeal to the city council, by written notice to the clerk of the council. 
(d)  The program and urban development contract administrators shall, on a continuing basis, revise and update the listing and profiles of prequalified and eligible small businesses, small businesses owned and operated by social and economically disadvantaged persons, and small businesses owned and operated by women. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  III, 11-24-81) 
Sec. 2-153. - Small business procurement list. 
(a)  In order to provide for the maximum utilization of small businesses, small businesses owned and operated by socially or economically disadvantaged persons, and small businesses owned by women, the department of administration and the purchasing office shall determine what commodities and services anticipated to be procured by the city can be feasibly procured from these businesses. This task will involve using the information generated in sections 2-151 and 2-152 to match goods and services with prospective vendors. 
(b)  Upon completion of this process, the director of administration and the purchasing office shall prepare recommendations regarding purchases that should be procured from small businesses under this program and direct the respective departments of the city to proceed with the implementation of this program. 
(c)  The respective departments, divisions and offices of the city shall refer to the small business procurement listing of eligible small businesses and their capabilities for identifying prospective vendors for the solicitation of goods and services. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  IV, 11-24-81) 
Sec. 2-154. - Procurement through direct solicitation. 
    Individual procurements made under this program from small businesses, small businesses owned and operated by socially or economically disadvantaged persons, and small businesses owned and operated by women which are less than the amount required to be advertised and bid under the provisions of the Public Bid Law (R.S. 38:2212) shall be made by direct solicitation; and the city purchase requisition, purchase order, invoice and delivery form for such eligible procurements shall contain the notation "SBP" at the side of each item price and at the side of the total amount of said procurement. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  V, 11-24-81) 
Sec. 2-155. - Procurements through bid process. 
    In the event that the procurement sought under this program for goods or services is in an amount which must be advertised and bid under the provisions of the Public Bid Law (R.S. 38:2212), the following procedure shall be adhered to: 
(1)  The procuring department shall notify small businesses, small businesses owned and operated by socially or economically disadvantaged persons, and small businesses owned and operated by women that a contract is being let out for bid. In this notice, the type of contract, whom to see for bid documents, the time of the opening and the contract dates should be given. By employing this method in addition to the normal solicitation procedures, a good response should be assured to the invitation to bid and possibly increase the competitiveness of bidding. 
(2)  The normal solicitation procedures for advertising and bidding under the Public Bid Law (R.S. 38:2211, et seq.) will be followed, except that when advertising set-aside contracts the advertisement shall be headed or entitled "Small Business Set-Aside." This notice should appear as the heading and not in the main body of the notice. 
(3)  Bid documents or specifications given to prospective bidders for small business set-aside shall clearly state that all bids must identify the bidder as an eligible small business under the program and that the eligibility shall be subject to verification. 
(4)  In the event all bids are rejected due to economic feasibility or other budget requirements or in the event no bids are received, the procurement involved shall be removed from the program, without detriment to the program, and shall be processed through normal solicitation procedures or rebid under the program, whichever is more feasible. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  VI, 11-24-81) 
Sec. 2-156. - Reports. 
(a)  Each department shall be responsible for filing a monitoring report with the purchasing office on a quarterly basis within five (5) days of the quarter for all goods and materials purchased, except for purchases made through "country store." The department of administration will include purchases made to stock the "country store" in its departmental quarterly report. The report shall be made in conformance with the format in exhibit 1. 
(b)  The purchasing office shall compile the information from the departmental quarterly reports into a summary report and submit the summary report to the city council within fifteen (15) days of the quarter. This summary report shall be made in conformance with the format in exhibit 2. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  VII, 11-24-81) 
Editor's note- Exhibits 1 and 2, referred to in this section, are not printed herein, but are on file and available for inspection in the offices of the city. 
Chapter 3 - ADVERTISING AND SIGNS[1]

Sec. 3-1. - Advertisements, posters, etc., over streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install or cause to be installed, or to hang or cause to be hung any signs or banners, or any form of advertisement or notice across any street in the city, without express authority from the mayor. 
(Code 1958,  23-1)
