(y)  Indemnification: Provider will indemnify, hold harmless and defend the City of Monroe, the advisory board, OCOG and their representatives, officers, agents, servants and employees, from and against any and all liability, suits, actions, legal proceedings, claims, demand, damages, costs, expenses and attorney's fees arising out of or in any way concerning or incident to any work done by provider in the performance of ambulance service under the license or arising out of any willful or negligent act or omission of provider, its officers, agents, servants and employees (including any such individual acting contrary to the conditions of the license). 
(z)  Agreement, modification and governing law: 
(1)  Governing law: Any license issued hereunder shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Louisiana. 
(2)  Partial enforceability: If any provision of this chapter, or the application of any provision to any entity or circumstance shall be held invalid, the remainder of this chapter, or the application of that provision to entities or circumstances other than those with respect to which it is held invalid, shall not be affected thereby. 
(Ord. No. 11,897, Art. III, 11-27-18) 
Secs. 5-55-5-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 

Sec. 5-71. - Applicability of chapter. 
    It is the intent of this chapter to regulate ambulance service within Monroe, Ouachita Parish, Louisiana and to provide for a sole and exclusive private provider of ambulance service for Monroe, Ouachita Parish, Louisiana. This chapter is not intended to preclude any public safety department in Monroe, Ouachita Parish (fire, police, etc.) from operating or providing emergency ambulance services except under the exclusions set forth herein. However, this chapter shall not be interpreted to prohibit, preclude, impede or discourage the emergency medical services provided by the public safety departments within Monroe, Ouachita Parish, Louisiana. 
(Ord. No. 11,897, Art. IV( 3), 11-27-18) 
Chapter 6 - ANIMAL CONTROL AND WELFARE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11,410, adopted Aug. 27, 2013, repealed the former Ch. 6 and enacted a new Ch. 6 as set out herein. The former chapter was entitled "Animals and Fowl" and derived from Code 1958; Ord. No. 7369, 4-13-82; Ord. No. 10,408, 6-8-04. 
Cross reference- Cruelty to animals,  12-129; health and sanitation, Ch. 18; nuisances, Ch. 24. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS/FOWL, HORSES, HOGS 

Sec. 6-1. - Bird sanctuary-City designated. 
    The entire area within the corporate limits of the city is hereby designated as a bird sanctuary. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-2. - Same-Birds not to be harmed, exceptions. 
    It shall be unlawful to trap, hunt, shoot or attempt to shoot or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl or to rob bird nests or wild fowl nests; provided, however, if starlings or similar birds are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality that they constitute a nuisance or a menace to health or property in the opinion of the mayor, he shall meet with representatives of the Audubon Society, Bird Club, Garden Club or Humane Society, or as many of such clubs as are found to exist in the city, after having given at least three (3) days' actual notice of the time and place of such meeting to the representatives of such clubs. If as a result of such meeting no satisfactory alternative is found to abate such nuisance, such birds may be destroyed in such numbers and in such manner as is deemed advisable by such mayor under the supervision of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-3. - Hogs prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or pen any hogs within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-4. - Permit to keep horse, mule or cow. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to keep any horse, mule, or cow within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  The provisions of (a) shall not apply to a specific horse, mule or cow for which a valid permit has been issued prior to the effective date of this chapter pursuant to the following provisions, said permit to contain the following: 
(1)  That a suitable stable be provided. 
(2)  That wholesome and abundant water be provided. 
(3)  That the premises shall be properly drained. 
(4)  That the stable shall be cleaned, and all manure removed once daily, and that said stable shall be sprinkled with lime, oil or creosote dip or other disinfectant, immediately after cleaning. 
(5)  That all manure removed from the stable shall be deposited in a bin, fitted with a tight cover or wire screen, packed in suitable boxes or barrels, also fitted with tight covers or screens. 
(6)  That all manure so collected shall be removed from the premises at least once a week in summer, and once a month in winter, or more often, if in the opinion of the mayor it should become necessary. The term summer months, as used herein, shall mean from the first day of May to the first day of October. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-5. - Running at large. 
(a)  The running at large of animals at any time on the public streets and sidewalks and other public places, or the tying, picketing or tethering of animals so as to go across the sidewalks, streets and other public places within the corporate limits of the city is prohibited and is hereby declared a public and common nuisance. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the police force of the city to impound and turn over to the humane society all animals found running at large or lariated, tied, picketed or tethered so as to go across the sidewalks, streets and other public places within the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  Subsections (a) and (b) shall not apply to dogs. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
State Law reference- For authority to prohibit, see R.S. 3:2531. 
Secs. 6-6-6-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LEASH LAW/DOGS/CATS 

Sec. 6-21. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide regulations within the area of the City of Monroe, Louisiana to control animal conduct. Nothing in this article shall be intended nor construed to create any liability on the part of the city, its officers, employees, agents or contractors. It is not the purpose or intent of this article to create on the part of city employees any special duties to or relationships with specific individuals. This article has been enacted for the welfare of the public as a whole. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-22. - Definitions. 
    [For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them:] 
    Adult dog means any dog, male or female, seven (7) months of age or older. When used throughout this chapter the term "dog" shall include a "cat." 
    Allow means to permit by neglecting to restrain or prevent. 
    Animal shall have its customary common meaning and shall include dogs and cats where applicable. 
    Animal control authority/department means any employee of the animal control department that is deputized by the Monroe Police Department or the Ouachita Parish Sheriff's Office for the purpose of enforcing this title and laws of the state as they pertain to animal control and welfare. 
    Animal shelter means a facility used to care for the homeless, stray or unwanted animals by a governmental entity or authorized animal welfare society, and may include more than one location. 
    At large means to be off the premises of the owner and not under the control of either the owner or a person authorized by the owner. 
    Cat means any member of the feline family, male or female and may be used simultaneously herein with the word "dog." 
    Dangerous animal means any animal which constitutes a physical threat to human beings or other domestic animals by virtue of a known propensity to endanger life by an unprovoked assault or bite so as to cause serious bodily harm. Also, this term shall include an animal trained, owned or harbored for the purpose, primarily or in part, of animal fighting. 
    Exceptions. An animal shall not be deemed dangerous when the following instances occur: 
(1)  It bites, attacks or menaces: 
a.  Anyone assaulting the owner; or 
b.  A trespasser on the property of the owner; or 
c.  Any person or other animal who has tormented or abused it; or 
(2)  It is otherwise acting in defense of an attack from a person or other animal upon the owner or other person; or 
(3)  It is protecting or defending its young or another animal. 
    Dangerous dog/cat means either animal dog or cat that according to the records of the appropriate authority: 
(1)  Has inflicted severe injury on a human being, without provocation, on public or private property, except that of the owner; or 
(2)  Has killed a domestic animal without provocation while off the owner's property; or 
(3)  Has been previously found to be potentially dangerous, the owner having received notice of such and the animal subsequently aggressively bites, attacks, or endangers the safety of humans or domestic animals. 
    Director means the head administrative official of the animal control authority or department that has been authorized by the Monroe City Council. 
    Dog means any member male or female, of the canine family or any cat that is kept as a domestic pet. 
    Harboring means the actions of any occupant of any premises on which an animal remains or to which customarily returns daily for food and care for a period of fourteen (14) days. Such occupant shall be presumed to be harboring or keeping the animal within the means of this article. 
    Kennel means any individual or business with five (5) or more dogs/cats where such animals are capable of breeding. 
    Leash shall mean a chain, rope, leather strap or cord or sufficient tether that will humanely bond the animal directly to the owner or keeper and prevent such animal from moving free of the owner's or keeper's immediate control. 
    Livestock means horses, cattle, sheep, goats, swine, donkeys and mules. 
    Owner means any person, firm, corporation, organization or department possessing, harboring, keeping, having any interest in, or having control or custody of an animal. 
    Pet shop is any establishment or premises maintained for the purchase, sale or exchange of pets of any type. 
    Potentially dangerous dog/cat means either animal that when unprovoked: 
(1)  Inflicts bites on a human other than its owner or on a domestic animal either on public or private property; or 
(2)  Chases or approaches a person upon the streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds in a menacing fashion or apparent attitude of attack, or either animal with a known propensity, tendency, or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury, or to cause injury or otherwise to threaten the safety of humans or domestic animals. 
    Exceptions. An animal shall not be deemed dangerous when the following instances occur: 
(1)  It bites, attacks, or menaces: 
a.  Anyone assaulting the owner; or 
b.  Anyone trespassing on the property of the owner; or 
c.  Any person or other animal who has tormented or abused it; 
(2)  It is otherwise acting in defense of an attack from a person or other animal upon the owner or other person; or 
(3)  It is protecting or defending its young or another animal. 
    Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery to a human being or another animal. 
    Stray animal means any unidentified dog, cat or other animal, whose owner is unknown or who has no owner, which is declared by the animal control authority to be a nuisance. For the purpose of this section stray dog or stray animal means any dog, cat or other animal appearing or remaining in a neighborhood or any public place without an apparent home and/or without a proper vaccination tag attached to a collar being worn by the animal. 
    Tethering means the tying or chaining of an animal for the purpose of keeping the animal secured to a device to prevent escape. 
    Under control means that the owner or keeper by means of a leash restrains the dog to the owner or keeper's immediate proximity, preventing the dog from trespassing upon property or annoying or chasing other persons, animals, or vehicles of any sort. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-23. - Animal control zone established. 
(a)  [Generally.] All of the incorporated areas of the City of Monroe are hereby declared to be an animal control zone. For purposes of this article II, any reference to "dog" shall include a "cat." 
(b)  Dogs off premises to be under control. It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any dog to cause, permit or allow his/her dog to run, stray or otherwise be away from the premises of the owner or keeper within a dog control zone and to be on public property or the private property of another without his permission unless such dog be under control by means of a leash. 
(c)  Exceptions. The under control section shall not apply to dogs while engaged in one of the following activities directly supervised by the owner or keeper so as to keep it from being a nuisance or danger to people or domestic animals: 
(1)  Sanctioned search and rescue missions operated by or through authority of a law enforcement agency. 
(2)  Lawful herding of farm animals. 
(3)  Lawful animal competition sanctioned by a nationally recognized organization or a local chapter thereof. 
(4)  Lawful hunting activities. 
(5)  Lawful training in preparation for such herding, or competition activities. 
(6)  Dog obedience training with the owner or keeper in attendance. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-24. - Dog identification. 
    It shall be unlawful to keep or harbor a dog over six (6) months of age anywhere in the incorporated areas of the City of Monroe unless a rabies license has been procured for the animal from a licensed veterinarian. Such animal must be identified by a rabies tag, or a tag or metal plate bearing the owner's correct name and address on its collar. Dogs at large anywhere in the incorporated areas of the City of Monroe without a rabies tag or an identification name plate shall be deemed nuisances and shall be impounded. Any person harboring, keeping or allowing an unidentifiable dog to be at large when such dog should be identifiable is guilty of a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-25. - Nuisances; infractions. 
    Violations of any of the sections contained herein constitute a nuisance and any infraction of any of the following requirements or standards constitute a nuisance and shall be a violation: 
(1)  The owner or keeper of any dog shall not allow it to be at large and not under control. 
(2)  All female dogs, while in season, shall be confined in a clean, dry place not accessible to male dogs and kept there during the entire period, except for the purpose of planned breeding and with knowledge of the owner of the male dog. 
(3)  No owner or keeper of any dog shall allow it to bark in such a manner as would foreseeably disturb or alarm the public. 
(4)  No person other than the owner, keeper or other authorized person is permitted to release the animal from confinement. 
(5)  Any person violating any provision of this article shall be imprisoned for a term of not more than thirty (30) days or punished by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by performance of community service of not more than forty (40) hours if directed by the court, or any combination of same if directed by the court. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-26. - Crimes; misdemeanors. 
    The following are misdemeanors: 
(1)  Refusal to quarantine. It shall be a misdemeanor for an owner or keeper to refuse to quarantine or permit the quarantine of any animal when and as required by state law and this article. 
(2)  Interfering with impounding and other animal control duties and enforcement. It is a misdemeanor for any person to prevent, obstruct, or hinder the impoundment of an animal or other enforcement duties of officers pursuant to this article. 
(3)  Damage. It is a misdemeanor for the owner or keeper of any domesticated animal to allow it to enter upon private or public property, so as to damage or destroy any real or personal property, including livestock or other animals. 
(4)  Cruelty to animals. The following acts and omissions constitute cruel treatment to animals; therefore, it shall be a misdemeanor for any person, firm, or corporation to: 
a.  Willfully or cruelly kill, injure, poison, torture, torment, tease, bait or in any way molest any animal by any means causing it fright or pain; or 
b.  Lay out or expose any kind of poison or leave exposed any poisoned food or drink for animal or fowl, or any substance or fluid whatever, whereon or wherein there is or shall be deposited or mingled any kind of poisonous or deadly substance or fluid whatever, or any premises, or abet any person in so doing unless in accordance with the lawful work of an exterminator; or 
c.  Neglect or fail to provide minimum care to any animal within his care, custody, or control. For the purpose of this section, "minimum care" means that in each period of twenty-four (24) hours, food and water of sufficient quantity and quality will be provided to allow for the maintenance of body weight and normal growth of an immature animal, and to otherwise preserve the health and well-being of the animal. "Minimum care" also includes at least a three-sided shelter, suited to the size and number of animals and providing each animal within the enclosure with proper protection from the elements including cold, heat, sun, wind and rain; or 
d.  Tether, confine, or restrain any animal in such a way as to permit said animal to become entangled in such tether or render said animal incapable of consuming food and water or from obtaining shelter from the elements or prevent the animal from moving comfortably because of the weight and/or length of the tether or chain. No animal weighing fifteen (15) pounds or under shall be confined by a chain which is greater gauge of one-eighth ( 1/8 ) inch, an animal fifteen (15) to thirty (30) pounds by a chain of greater gauge than three-sixteenths ( 3/16 ) gauge and for any animal larger than thirty (30) pounds by any chain or rope greater than one-quarter (1/4) inch gauge. 
e.  Abandon or leave any animal on a street, road or highway or in a public place or on private property; or 
f.  Confine and leave unattended an animal within or on a motor vehicle or other closure or structure under conditions that endanger the health and well-being of the animal. Such conditions include, but are not limited to dangerous temperatures and lack of food and water; or 
g.  Intentionally run down or otherwise abuse any animal with a bicycle or motor vehicle, including motorcycles or motorbikes; or 
h.  Intentionally trap any domestic animal with a device other than a humane live animal trap. Any practice of good animal husbandry as defined in section 3-42 is not a violation of this section. 
(5)  Penalty. Any person violating any provisions of this article shall be punished by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for a term of not more than thirty (30) days or by the performance of community service of not more than forty (40) hours if directed by the court or any combination of same if directed by the court. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-27. - Dangerous and potentially dangerous dogs; declaration. 
(a)  The animal control authority may find and declare a dog dangerous or potentially dangerous if there is probable cause to believe that the animal falls within the definition set forth in section 3-42. The finding will be based on: 
(1)  The written complaint of a citizen who is willing to testify that the animal has acted in a manner which causes it to fall within the definition of a dangerous or a potentially dangerous dog under section 3-42; or 
(2)  Dog bite reports filed with the animal control officer required by city ordinance; or 
(3)  Actions of the dog witnessed by any animal control officer or other law enforcement officer; or 
(4)  Other substantial evidence which may include the previous history of the dog. 
(b)  The declaration of dangerous or potentially dangerous dog shall be in writing, and shall be served by the animal control authority on the owner by one of the following methods: 
(1)  Certified mail to the owner or keeper's last known address; or 
(2)  Personal service; 
(3)  If the owner or keeper cannot be located by one of the first two (2) methods after reasonable attempts, by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the area of the incident. 
(c)  The declaration shall state at least the following information: 
(1)  A description of the animal. 
(2)  The name and address of the owner or keeper of the animal. 
(3)  The last known whereabouts of the animal if it [is] not in the custody of the owner or keeper. 
(4)  The facts upon which the declaration of dangerous or potentially dangerous dog is based. 
(5)  Notice of the owner's or keeper's right to a hearing to contest the declaration, if the request is made within five (5) days. 
(6)  The restrictions placed on the animal as a result of the declaration of dangerous or potentially dangerous dog. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for a term of not more than thirty (30) days or by the performance of community service of not more than forty (40) hours if directed by the court, or any combination of same if directed by the court. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-28. - Dangerous or potentially dangerous dog declaration; appeal. 
    Following service of a declaration of dangerous or potentially dangerous dog, the owner or keeper may, within five (5) business days of receipt of the declaration, or within five (5) days of the publication of the declaration pursuant to section 3-47 requested in writing a hearing before a three-member panel appointed by the mayor of the City of Monroe. 
(1)  Such request shall contain: 
a.  A brief statement that protests the action and stating reasons it should be reversed or modified; and 
b.  The names, phone numbers and addresses of any witnesses who will appear on the dog owner's behalf; and 
c.  Current day phone number where owner, keeper, or his representative can be contacted. 
(2)  A time and place will be named for the hearing within seven (7) days of the receipt of the appeal, with effort to reasonably accommodate all parties involved. All witnesses will be notified by phone or by letters of the hearing date. If appellant or appellant's representative fails to appear for the hearing, excepting verifiable emergency, the original determination stands. The hearing will take place within thirty (30) days of the director receiving the request for hearing, unless all parties agree to a continuance. 
(3)  At the hearing, the animal control officer will give a full report of the actions and reasons leading to the declaration. Any witnesses who were a part of the determination and declaration shall be present and asked for their testimony. The burden is on the animal control department to show by a preponderance of the evidence that the dog is dangerous or potentially dangerous as defined in section 3-42. The dog owner, keeper or his representative and any witnesses on behalf of the dog or its owner will then be asked for their testimony and be given an opportunity to present any other pertinent evidence. 
(4)  The appointed hearing officer or panel, having heard from both sides will render either an immediate decision or a decision within forty-eight (48) hours if new information is presented that may have a bearing on the decision. 
(5)  The decision will: 
a.  Uphold the original declaration and terms imposed; or 
b.  Reverse the entire decision; or 
c.  Uphold the original declaration but modify the terms and restrictions; or 
d.  Downgrade a declaration of dangerous to potentially dangerous with appropriate terms and restrictions. 
(6)  If the decision is reversed, written recommendations and/or warning concerning the dog's actions may be issued by the director or panel which will become a permanent part of the history of the case. 
(7)  Within seven (7) days of the hearing, the director or chairman of the panel shall prepare a final written decision including his/her findings and conclusions. A copy shall immediately be sent to all applicable parties. Upon receipt of said written decision, the owner may appeal to the proper court by filing notice thereof within thirty (30) days. Such appeals shall be governed by the provisions of the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-29. - Potentially dangerous dogs; requirements. 
(a)  Following a declaration of potentially dangerous dog, it is unlawful for an owner or keeper: 
(1)  To permit it to be other than securely confined inside a locked building, kennel, and pen, or other structure having secure sides, bottom, and top while on the premises of the owner or keeper; and 
(2)  To permit it to be away from the premises of the owner or keeper unless the dog is securely leashed, and under control of a person at least fifteen (15) years of age and physically able to restrain and control the animal; or 
(3)  To fail to comply with any court ordered restrictions on keeping said potentially dangerous dog; or 
(4)  To fail to notify the agency of change of ownership, custody, or residence of the dog within ten (10) days of such change. 
Pending a hearing under section 3-28 or pending any appeals to a court of competent jurisdiction, the animal or animals may be seized and impounded at the cost of the owner or keeper as provided by this article. 
(5)  Following the hearing, the court may rule that: 
a.  There is insufficient evidence of the violation whereupon the animal may be released to its owner subject to any restrictions imposed upon it previously; or 
b.  The animal may be placed in custody of the animal control authority for possible placement with a new owner; or 
c.  The animal may be promptly disposed of by the animal control officer; or 
d.  Under special circumstances, the owner or keeper may be allowed to permanently remove the animal from the parish; provided that adequate security or assurance against its return is given, and the court is convinced that the animal will be kept in such a manner that it is no longer a danger to persons, property, or other animals. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-30. - Control of rabid or potentially rabid animals. 
(a)  A domestic animal of a species which may transmit disease through its bite, which bites and breaks the skin of any person shall be quarantined for a ten-day period to determine if the animal is infected with a disease. The place of quarantine shall be established by the animal control authority, and the animal control authority may, in its discretion, allow the owner and/or keeper of the animal to maintain the quarantine. 
    Quarantine procedure: 
(1)  Any animal that has bitten a human and has broken the skin, regardless of provocation or previous inoculation for diseases shall be confined for a period of not less than ten (10) days in such a manner that it is segregated from any other animals so as to prevent contact with other animals and humans except for the caretaker. 
(2)  If the owner and/or keeper is unable or unwilling to confine the animal, or if the animal control authority determines from the prior history of the animal that confinement is not likely, the animal may be quarantined at the animal control shelter or a veterinarian and/or boarding kennel of the owner's choice, provided that the costs to board the animal shall be borne by the owner, if in a location other than the owner's residence. 
(3)  Should any animal during the observation period manifest any unusual behavior or develop symptoms of illness or die, the owner or veterinarian shall immediately notify the animal control authority and the health department of that condition. 
(b)  In all cases where any animal which has bitten a person or caused an abrasion or puncture of the skin, is slain by any person or dies by other means, and a period of ten (10) days has not elapsed since the day of the bite, it shall be the duty of any person slaying such animal or the owner to forthwith deliver intact the head of such animal to the parish health officer. The animal control authority shall be notified in such case. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of medical doctor, hospital, or other applicable health official to report all dog bites that break the skin, regardless of provocation factors or previous inoculations record of the animal. Such report shall be made to the animal control authority, as promptly as possible so that quarantine procedures can be instituted in a timely fashion. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
State Law reference- Rabies Control Law, R.S. 40:1275 et seq. 
Sec. 6-31. - Impound, redemption and disposition of animals. 
(a)  Animals may be impounded and taken into the care and custody of the animal control authority in the following situations: 
(1)  When the dog is off premises of its owner or keeper and not under the control of its owner, keeper or other authorized person. 
(2)  If the animal is over six (6) months of age and has no current rabies tag or identification tag or plate. 
(3)  When an animal is brought to the animal shelter by a private citizen who has found the animal. 
(4)  When a dog has been declared potentially dangerous or dangerous pursuant to this article and/or state law, and the dog has violated the restrictions placed upon it. 
(5)  When any animal has been subjected to cruel treatment as defined by the provisions of this chapter provided that removal is necessary for the immediate safety and well being of the animal. 
(6)  When the animal's owner or keeper is incapable or unable to continue to care for it because of incarceration, severe illness, death, house fire or other emergency circumstances and an agent for the owner cannot be readily located. These animals will be deemed impounded for safekeeping. 
(7)  When an animal has bitten a person, breaking or puncturing the skin, and the owner and/or keeper is unable, incapable or unwilling to provide the ten-day quarantine requirements. If such dog is found at large, the owner will be deemed unable to quarantine and it shall be impounded. 
(b)  Forthwith, following impoundment, the animal control authority shall notify the owner or keeper, if known, of its impoundment using whatever reasonable means possible. If the animal's owner is unknown or cannot be located, the information and description of the animal shall be available at the animal shelter during regular business hours. 
(c)  All owners or keepers claiming impoundment animals of any kind shall provide identification and shall sign a statement that verifies they are the owner, keeper, or authorized agent of the owner. Names, street or road addresses, city and phone numbers will be required. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-32. - Impounded animals; fees. 
    For every animal impounded pursuant to this article, there shall be paid to the animal control authority, by the owner, keeper, or their authorized representative claiming such animal, the total of the following fees before the animal is released from impoundment: 
(1)  For dogs: 
a.  For the first impoundment in any twelve-month period, twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
b.  For the second impoundment of the same dog in any twelve-month period, thirty-five dollars ($35.00); and 
c.  For the third and subsequent impoundments within any twelve-month period, fifty dollars ($50.00). 
d.  Exception. Fees for second, third and subsequent impoundment shall apply only to dogs in violation of subsection (1)a. and b. 
(2)  For animals other than dogs: 
a.  For any impoundment of cat or other small domestic pet, fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(3)  Impoundment fee can be waived or reduced at the discretion of the director of the animal control authority in case of animals impounded pursuant to subsection 3-53(a)(7), if it can be determined that the owner did not otherwise violate the terms of this article. 
(4)  A charge for the boarding and care for the animals after the first twenty-four (24) hours will be made which will be: 
a.  For dogs, cats, other small domestic pets and small livestock, five dollars ($5.00) per day. 
(5)  In addition, any necessary additional expenses incurred by the animal control authority to care for the pet shall be assessed. These may include but are not limited to necessary veterinary care. Actual copies of these special bills will be made available to the owner. 
(6)  Charges for boarding and care can be reduced at the discretion of the director if special circumstances exist or in the case of several animals belonging to the same owner, such as a litter of pups or kittens. Such reduction will be allowed the same owner only once in any twelve-month period. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-33. - Disposition and disposal of animals. 
(a)  Any unlicensed or unidentified domestic animal impounded pursuant to this article shall be held for at least one hundred twenty (120) hours, not including Sundays or legal holidays. 
(b)  For any identified domestic animal, the holding period shall be one hundred twenty (120) hours, not including Sundays or legal holidays, during which time reasonable attempts will be made to locate and notify the owner or keeper. 
(c)  Should any impounded animal be suffering from serious injury, illness or disease that would endanger the other sheltered pets or cause the animal to endure unnecessary pain and suffering if left untreated or if any impounded animal is feral or wild and thereby humane care and confinement is not possible or poses a threat to caretakers, the animal may be destroyed before the expiration of the required holding. Such action shall be approved by either a licensed veterinarian or by the director. 
(d)  Any animal not redeemed by its owner during the prescribed period, may be humanely destroyed by lethal injection, or placed for adoption to a new owner, provided that the new owner agrees in writing to surgically sterilize any dog or cat within one month or upon maturity and to provide proper identification in the case of a dog. 
(e)  The director of the animal control authority shall have the right to deny adoption to any person of any unredeemed animal if it can be determined that placement would not be in the best interest of the animal or the community. 
(f)  No live animal shall be used, sold, or donated for experimental purposes. 
(g)  Any deceased animal shall be disposed of by the owner of such animal within twenty-four (24) hours of the death of the animal unless the owner is unaware of the death of the animal, but no later than twelve (12) hours after notification of the death of the animal. No animal shall be cremated(burned) within the City of Monroe for the purposes of disposal of a deceased animal. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-34. - Trapping destructive of nuisance animals. 
(a)  Upon written complaint of any party that any cat or other animal, is trespassing upon the premises or property of the complaining party and thereon doing substantial damage to property, trees, shrubs, lawns, or gardens, or creating a substantial nuisance that disturbs the repose of any person and upon the animal control officer finding probable cause exists that the complaint is valid, the animal control officer may humanely trap such cat or animal or allow the owner of the property to humanely trap such cat or other animal. 
(b)  Such trapped animals shall be impounded by the animal control authority and disposed of in accordance with this chapter or in accordance with state law if a game animal; provided that the state wildlife and fisheries department will be notified before wild animals are trapped. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-35. - Law enforcement dogs; exemption. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any dog kept by a law enforcement agency for law enforcement purposes. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-36. - Kennel license. 
(a)  Any owner or keeper of five (5) or more dogs shall procure a kennel license yearly and shall pay a kennel license fee. Use of the dog is irrelevant to obtaining the license. 
    The license can be obtained from the office of code enforcement in the City of Monroe. The cost per dog over five (5) shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
    A licensed veterinarian or a veterinary clinic shall be exempt from this provision in the conduct of their regular business. 
    Any person applying for a kennel license shall be subject to inspections upon notification from the governing authority which inspection shall include: 
(1)  The general living area of the dogs with emphasis on size of enclosure or facility in relation to the number of animals harbored in the home; 
(2)  All places where animals are kept shall be kept clean and wholesome by removal of all ordure, urine and other offensive matters and by suitable cleansing as often as may be necessary; 
(3)  Inspection of equipment used to manage, train or breed such animals; 
(4)  The location of the enclosure or facility in relation to the location of adjoining property. Said enclosure or facility should not infringe upon the right of the adjacent owner to use and enjoy his property without the threat of undue noise, odor or threat for safety. 
(b)  Declaration of non-compliance. Upon notification to a kennel owner that a kennel license is needed or, in event the inspection has found specific violations, the owner/operator of the kennel shall be served by the animal control authority on the owner in writing by one of the following methods: 
(1)  Certified mail to the owner or keeper's last known address or at the address for which the license has been sought; or 
(2)  Personal service; 
(3)  If the owner or keeper cannot be located by one of the first two (2) methods after reasonable attempts, by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the area of the incident. 
(c)  The declaration shall state at least the following information: 
(1)  A description of the license sought, animals involved. 
(2)  The name and address of the owner or keeper of the animal. 
(3)  The last known whereabouts of the animals if it [is] not in the custody of the owner or keeper. 
(4)  The facts upon which the declaration of non-compliance [is] based. 
(5)  Notice of the owner's or keeper's right to a hearing to contest the declaration, if the request is made within five (5) days. 
(6)  The restrictions placed on the owner and/or facility as a result of the declaration of non-compliance. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for a term of not more than thirty (30) days or by the performance of community service of not more than forty (40) hours if directed by the court, or any combination of same if directed by the court and any license sought shall be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-37. - Declaration of non-compliance; appeal. 
    Following service of a declaration of non-compliance, the owner or keeper may, within five (5) business days of receipt of the declaration, or within five (5) days of the publication of the declaration pursuant to section 3-47 requested in writing a hearing before a hearing officer appointed by the mayor of the City of Monroe. 
(1)  Such request shall contain: 
a.  A brief statement that protests the action and stating reasons it should be reversed or modified; and 
b.  The names, phone numbers and addresses of any witnesses who will appear on the part of the requestor; and 
c.  Current day phone number where owner, keeper, or his representative can be contacted. 
(2)  A time and place will be named for the hearing within seven (7) days of the receipt of the appeal, with effort to reasonably accommodate all parties involved. All witnesses will be notified by phone or by letters of the hearing date. If appellant or appellant's representative fails to appear for the hearing, excepting verifiable emergency, the original determination stands. The hearing will take place within thirty (30) days of the director receiving the request for hearing, unless all parties agree to a continuance. 
(3)  At the hearing, the animal control officer will give a full report of the actions and reasons leading to the declaration. Any witnesses who were a part of the determination and declaration shall be present and asked for their testimony. The burden is on the animal control department to show by a preponderance of the evidence that the kennel license is required and/or the kennel conditions are dangerous or potentially dangerous to the lives of the animals or the kennel conditions are deterious to the adjacent property owners. The dog owner, keeper or his representative and any witnesses on behalf of the dog or its owner will then be asked for their testimony and be given an opportunity to present any other pertinent evidence. 
(4)  The appointed hearing officer or panel, having heard from both sides will render either an immediate decision or a decision within forty-eight (48) hours if new information is presented that may have a bearing on the decision. 
(5)  The decision will: 
a.  Uphold the original declaration and terms imposed; or 
b.  Reverse the entire decision; or 
c.  Uphold the original declaration but modify the terms and restrictions. 
(6)  If the decision is reversed, written recommendations and/or warning concerning the kennel requestor's actions may be issued by the hearing officer or panel which will become a permanent part of the history of the case. 
(7)  Within seven (7) days of the hearing, the hearing officer shall prepare a final written decision including his/her findings and conclusions. A copy shall immediately be sent to all applicable parties. Upon receipt of said written decision. The owner may appeal to the proper court by filing notice thereof within thirty (30) days. Such appeals shall be governed by the provisions of the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Secs. 6-38-6-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FEROCIOUS, WILD OR EXOTIC ANIMALS 

Sec. 6-46. - Definitions. 
    Keeper and/or custodian: Any person other than the owner harboring or having in his possession any dog. 
    Owner: Any person owning, possessing, harboring, keeping, maintaining, or having or assuming the care, custody or control of an animal or fowl or permits same on his property. 
    Wild or exotic animals: Any live monkey (nonhuman primate), raccoon, skunk, wolf, squirrel, fox, leopard, panther, tiger, lion, lynx or any other warm-blooded animal, poisonous or constricting snake or tarantula which can normally be found in the wild state or any member of crocodilian, including, but not limited to, alligators, crocodiles, caimans and gavials. Ferrets, nonpoisonous snakes, rabbits, laboratory rats and skunks which have been bred and raised in captivity and which have never known the wild shall be excluded from this definition. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-47. - Wild or exotic animals as pets prohibited. 
    No person shall keep or permit to be kept any wild, exotic or vicious animal as a pet. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-48. - Display of notice where wild or exotic animals are sold. 
    Any person who offers for sale a wild or exotic animal shall post conspicuously at the place of sale or display the following notice: 
No person may lawfully keep or permit to be kept in the City of Monroe any live monkey (nonhuman primate), raccoon, skunk, wolf, squirrel, fox, leopard, panther, tiger, lion, lynx or any other warm-blooded animal, poisonous or constricting snake, tarantula, crocodile or alligator which can normally be found in the wild. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-49. - Keeping ferocious animals in the city. 
    No wild or exotic animal shall be kept within the city limits of the city on the premises of individuals or in menageries. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-50. - Vicious or ferocious animals may be destroyed. 
    The city, through its agents, shall destroy any wild or exotic animal which cannot be safely taken up or impounded, but it shall not be lawful for any other person to willfully kill any animal unless in protection of life or limb. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-51. - Feeding or annoying animals in zoo, park, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to feed any beast, fowl, bird, reptile or animal of any kind whatsoever confined in a cage or enclosure in any zoo, park or other public place or to annoy any animal by throwing or putting any object into any such cage or enclosure. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-52. - Places for animals kept clean. 
    All places where animals are kept shall be kept clean and wholesome by removal of all ordure, urine and other offensive matters and by suitable cleansing as often as may be necessary. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-53. - Soiling of public and private property by animals. 
(a)  If any public or private property is soiled or contaminated by an animal, whether such nuisance shall take place in the presence of the owner or keeper or not, the owner or keeper of the animal, or if the owner or keeper is a minor, the parents or guardian thereof, shall be deemed guilty of violating this section. 
(b)  Any person who is in violation of this section shall be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and no less than three (3) seven-hour days of trash cleanup duties. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-54. - Animals to be confined; exceptions. 
(a)  Except as provided hereinbelow, all animals are to be confined within an enclosure or secured by a chain at all times, unless accompanied by a driver or keeper. 
(b)  Animals, except dogs, which are accompanied by a driver or keeper are restricted to those public areas legally utilized by motor vehicles or specifically designated for animal usage and are not permitted to trespass upon any other public or private property. 
(c)  Dogs which are properly licensed and vaccinated as stipulated in this chapter may be allowed outside of an enclosure if under a secure leash and accompanied by its owner or keeper but are not to be allowed to trespass upon any public property, if so prohibited by another ordinance, or upon private property. 
(d)  Cats which are privately owned, have been spayed or neutered, and are properly licensed, vaccinated, and tagged with an identification tag clearly indicating the owner's name, current address and telephone number, may be allowed outside of an enclosure, but are not to be allowed to trespass upon any public property, if so prohibited by another ordinance, or upon private property other than that belonging to the cat owner. Any cat collected under the provisions of this section shall not be returned to its owner until such time as said owner shall have the cat spayed or neutered. 
(e)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section allowing otherwise, no dogs other than dogs in parades in which dogs are the main attraction or sole participants, dogs confined on the property of their owners, dogs assigned to law enforcement canine units, seeing-eye dogs and/or dogs assisting physically challenged individuals, are allowed within two hundred (200) yards of any parade route one hour before, during, or one hour after a scheduled parade. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-55. - Sale of rabbits and other animals. 
(a)  The sale or donation of rabbits younger than eight (8) weeks of age in quantities of less than four (4) to an individual is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  The auctioning, raffling or giving away as a prize or premium or advertising device of any animal for the purpose of inducing trade or business or competition at public or private events is hereby prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-56. - Sale, etc., of artificially colored or dyed animals. 
    No animal that has been dyed or otherwise colored artificially may be sold or offered for sale, raffled, offered or given as a prize, premium or advertising device; or displayed in any store, carnival or other public place. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-57. - Animal fighting, facilities for same; prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hold, operate, attend, sponsor or in any way further a contest that pits animals against each other and for anyone to maintain facilities for training and/or for view of this purpose. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-58. - Civil, criminal adjudication; misdemeanors. 
(a)  Violations of this chapter shall be deemed to be violations of a public health and environmental ordinance; and shall be subject to civil administrative adjudication or criminal adjudication through any court of proper jurisdiction. 
(b)  Any person who commits any act prohibited or omits the doing of any act required by this chapter for which a lesser penalty is not specifically prescribed herein, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof in the city court shall be liable for a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or for a term of imprisonment not to exceed six (6) months, or for community service or to community service, and/or fine and/or imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 6-59. - Responsibility of association members, partners and corporate officers. 
    When an association of individuals is charged with violation of any provision of this chapter, each individual of such association or, if it is a foreign association, the local agent or person locally in charge thereof shall be deemed to represent such association of individuals for the purpose of enforcing this chapter and shall be held responsible and punishable for each violation thereof. 
    When a firm is charged with such violation, each member thereof or, if it is a foreign firm, the local agent or person locally in charge of such firm shall be deemed to represent such firm for the purpose of enforcing this chapter, and shall be held responsible and punishable for each violation thereof. 
    When a corporation is charged with such violation, all or any officers of such corporation may be held responsible and punishable for each violation of this chapter or if it is a foreign corporation, the local agent or person locally in charge thereof shall be deemed to represent such corporation for the purpose of enforcing this chapter and shall be held responsible and punishable for each violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 11,410, 8-27-13) 
Chapter 7 - AVIATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Public works department,  4-06. 
Cross reference- Obstruction of airport runway,  12-151. 
State Law reference- Aeronautics, R.S. 2:1 etseq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words will be defined as set forth herein, unless otherwise defined in this chapter: 
    Gasoline shall be construed to mean all fuels commonly referred to as gasoline or gasohol and shall include all types of fuel used in aviation whether identified as gasoline, gasohol, aviation fuel, aviation gasoline, AVGAS, kerosene, jet fuel, and any derivatives or distillates thereof. 
(Ord. No. 7626, 12-27-83) 
Secs. 7-2-7-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF AIRCRAFT 

Sec. 7-21. - Definitions. 
    Acrobatic flying as used in this article means any intentional aircraft maneuver or stunt not necessary to air navigation, or operation of aircraft in such manner as to endanger human life or safety by the performance of unusual or dangerous maneuvers. 
    Aircraft as used in this article means any aeroplane, airplane, gas bag, flying machine, balloon, any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used or designed for navigation of or flight in the air, except a parachute or other contrivance used primarily as safety equipment. 
(Code 1958,  3-1) 
State Law reference- For pertinent definitions, see R.S. 2:1. 
Sec. 7-22. - Exemption. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to public aircraft of the federal government, or of a state, or territory, or of a political subdivision of a state or territory, or to aircraft licensed by a foreign country with which the United States has a reciprocal agreement covering operation of such aircraft. 
(Code 1958,  3-2) 
Sec. 7-23. - Minimum flying altitude. 
    Except while taking off or landing at an established landing field or airport, no person shall fly or permit any aircraft to be flown within the corporate limits of the city except at an altitude sufficient to permit of a reasonably safe emergency landing, which in no case shall be less than one thousand (1,000) feet; provided, the provisions of this section may be deviated from when special circumstances render a departure necessary to avoid immediate danger or when such departure is required because of stress of weather conditions or other unavoidable cause. 
(Code 1958,  3-3) 
Sec. 7-24. - Pilot's license and airworthiness certificate. 
    No person shall operate any aircraft within or over the corporate limits of the city unless such person has first been issued a pilot's license by the federal government and unless such aircraft shall have first received a certificate of airworthiness from the federal government. 
(Code 1958,  3-4) 
Sec. 7-25. - Air traffic rules govern. 
    No person shall operate any aircraft over or within the city in violation of any valid air traffic or other rule or regulation established by the federal government. 
(Code 1958,  3-5) 
Sec. 7-26. - Acrobatic flying, prohibited. 
    Acrobatic flying by any person flying over any portion of the city is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1958,  3-6) 
Sec. 7-27. - Landing at other than established airport prohibited. 
    Except in cases of emergency, no person shall land any aircraft within the corporate limits of the city except upon a regularly established airport field or landing place. 
    A medical evacuation heliport approved and permitted under sections 37-98, 37-99, 37-100, 37-101 and 37-102 of this Code shall be deemed a regularly established landing place for purposes of this section. 
(Code 1958,  3-7; Ord. No. 9312, 7-14-92) 
Sec. 7-28. - Night operation, lights and equipment. 
    All aircraft when flying within or over the corporate limits of the city at night shall have lights and other equipment required for such flying by the rules, regulations or orders of the federal government. 
(Code 1958,  3-8) 
Sec. 7-29. - Dropping objects from aircraft. 
    No person in any aircraft shall cause or permit to be thrown out, discharged or dropped within the corporate limits of the city any object or thing, except loose water or loose sand ballast when absolutely essential to the safety of the occupants of the aircraft and except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1958,  3-10) 
Sec. 7-30. - Permit for advertising by banners, loudspeakers, etc. 
(a)  No person shall make exhibition flights by carrying banners on, distribute circulars from, or operate a loudspeaking device from, any aircraft flying within or over the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a permit to do so from the mayor, and payment of a permit fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each flight. 
(b)  The mayor may issue such permit if the person who will operate the aircraft, in carrying out any of the objects named in this section, is duly licensed by the federal government, the aircraft to be used is licensed by the federal government, and the safety or lives of the inhabitants of the city will not be endangered by the proposed flight. 
(c)  The permits provided for in this section may be issued by the city for periods of not longer than six (6) months, rather than for individual flights, if the safety or lives of the inhabitants of the city will not be endangered by such permit and a permit fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) is paid; such a six months' permit shall be revoked by the city upon violation of any provision of this article. 
(Code 1958,  3-11) 
Sec. 7-31. - Operating aircraft under influence of alcoholic beverages. 
    No person shall operate any aircraft while under the influence of any alcoholic liquor or beverage, or any other matter or substance of any kind or description containing alcohol, irrespective of the alcoholic content thereof. When the physical or mental faculties of any aircraft operator have been affected sufficiently to make the driving or operation of an aircraft in any degree less safe, such operator shall be "under the influence" within the meaning of this section. 
(Code 1958,  3-11.1) 
Sec. 7-32. - Operating aircraft under influence of drugs. 
    No person shall operate an aircraft while under the influence of any drug, medicine, narcotic, sedative, potion, opiate, soporific, anesthetic, inhalant, hypodermic, stupefacient, anodyne or other material, commodity or substance of any kind or description. When the physical or mental faculties of any aircraft operator have been affected sufficiently to make the driving or operation of an aircraft in any degree less safe, such operator shall be "under the influence" within the meaning of this section. 
(Code 1958,  3-11.2) 
Sec. 7-33. - Removal of wrecked or damaged aircraft. 
    Any wrecked or damaged aircraft shall be promptly removed from the landing area by the owner or pilot thereof under the supervision and direction of the airport manager. 
(Code 1958,  3-11.3) 
Secs. 7-34-7-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MONROE REGIONAL AIRPORT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Rates for airport taxicabs,  35-301(5). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-46. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply only to the Monroe Regional Airport. 
Sec. 7-47. - Compliance with rules and regulations required. 
    Every person enjoying privileges at the Monroe Regional Airport, whether or not such privileges be in connection with the use of buildings, concessions, or landing rights, shall at all times strictly obey and abide by all of the rules and regulations of the federal government as well as such rules and regulations as may be made by the city governing the use of such airport. 
(Code 1958,  3-17; Ord. No. 7010, 3-14-78) 
Sec. 7-48. - Vehicles on landing area. 
(a)  No person shall enter the airport landing area with a truck, automobile, motor scooter, motorcycle, bicycle, or other vehicles except aircraft, provided that this section shall not apply to airport maintenance vehicles, Federal Aviation Agency vehicles, gasoline trucks engaged in servicing aircraft, or emergency or police vehicles. 
(b)  No vehicle shall park in any area that is not designated a parking area. Parking fees are amended and established as follows: 
Short Term Parking Rates Day 1 Amount Day 2+ Amount 0-1 hour $0.00 0-1 hour $2.00 1-2 hours 3.00 1-2 hours 3.00 2-3 hours 4.00 2-3 hours 4.00 3-4 hours 5.00 3-4 hours 5.00 4-5 hours 7.00 4-5 hours 7.00 5-24 hours 9.00 5-24 hours 9.00  
Long Term Parking Rates Day 1 Amount Day 2+ Amount 0-1 hour $2.00 0-1 hour $2.00 1-2 hours 3.00 1-2 hours 3.00 2-3 hours 4.00 2-3 hours 4.00 3-4 hours 5.00 3-4 hours 5.00 4-5 hours 6.00 4-5 hours 6.00 5-24 hours 7.00 5-24 hours 7.00  
(c)  Any disabled veteran, his conveyance and his passengers shall be allowed to park for free at the Monroe Regional Airport for a period not exceeding ten (10) days provided the disabled veteran provides proof of his disability in the form of a military honor license plate as provided in R.S. 47:490.4 and 47:490.31 or a disabled veteran identification card issued by the United States Department of Veterans Affairs. Such proof shall be required and presented at the time the disabled veteran requests such parking privilege upon leaving the parking areas at the Monroe Regional Airport. 
(Code 1958,  3-11.4; Ord. No. 7010, 3-14-78; Ord. No. 11,234, 10-25-11; Ord. No. 11,700, 7-26-16; Ord. No. 11,800, 9-26-17) 
Sec. 7-49. - Commercial activities. 
    No person shall use the airport for the purpose of any commercial activity, for the carrying for hire of passengers, freight, express or mail, for the instruction in aviation in any of its branches, for the sale of fuels, for the sale of refreshments, or for the conduct of any phase of aviation activity, unless approved by the mayor or his duly authorized representative. 
(Code 1958,  3-17.1; Ord. No. 7010, 3-14-78) 
Sec. 7-50. - Sale and storage of gasoline. 
    No gasoline or other fuel shall be sold and/or stored at or within the Monroe Regional Airport other than under and in compliance with the standards and conditions set forth herein: 
(1)  No gasoline or other fuel shall be stored at the Monroe Regional Airport except in an approved and permitted fuel tank/fuel farm installation. 
(2)  No fuel tank/fuel farm facility shall be approved and permitted unless said fuel tank/fuel farm facility is in conjunction with a land lease at the Monroe Regional Airport with the City of Monroe. Said leasehold must include a building of at least two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet, either existing at the time of the fuel tank/fuel farm permit application or to be constructed prior to the use of the fuel tank/fuel farm, with the plans and specifications for the building to be approved by the city or its agent prior to application for fuel permit. 
(3)  No fuel tank/fuel farm facility, in whole or in part, shall be sublet or assigned without the written approval of the City of Monroe. 
(4)  All fuel tank/fuel farm facilities shall carry liability insurance, property damage insurance, fire and extended insurance coverage, with the City of Monroe as a named insured, in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) single-limit coverage. 
(5)  All fuel tanks must be installed underground. 
(6)  The minimum fuel tank size shall be ten thousand (10,000) gallons. 
(7)  All fuel tank/fuel farm facilities shall be provided with reasonable on-site identification and proper lighting according to the rules and regulations of the Monroe Regional Airport. 
(8)  All fuel tank/fuel farm facilities shall be equipped with sufficient locking devices to prevent unauthorized use and/or tampering while said facility is unattended by the owner, his agents and/or employees. 
(9)  All fuel tank/fuel farm facilities, both commercial and noncommercial, shall be equipped with authorized fire-fighting equipment as required by the applicant fire codes and commensurate with the individual type of operation. 
(10)  All mobile fuel tank vehicles, known as "fuel tenders," shall be equipped with adequate hand fire extinguishers. 
(11)  All fuel tank/fuel farm facilities shall have mobile fire extinguishers out and in position during all fueling operations. 
(12)  The airport director shall have the right to inspect all fire fighting equipment and fire extinguishers as often as he deems necessary. 
(13)  All private, noncommercial, and/or commercial fuel tanks/fuel farm facilities shall be equipped with fuel filters for commercial operation as per American Petroleum Institute Bulletin No. 1500, and any future supplements thereto, and said fuel filters must be approved by the Federal Aviation Administration. 
(14)  All federal, state and city regulations and codes governing the installation and operation of a fuel facility must be adhered to and complied with. 
(15)  All commercial fuel tanks and all fuel tanks belonging to fixed-based operations shall also comply with the "Minimum Standards for Commercial Aeronautical Activities of the Monroe Regional Airport," and any future amendments or supplements thereto. 
(16)  All fuel tanks/fuel farm facilities shall be inspected yearly by the state department of weights and measures for accuracy and fuel contamination. Said inspection shall be the responsibility of the owner. A copy of said inspection report shall be delivered to the airport director. The airport director shall have the authority and right to inspect any fuel tank/fuel farm facility at any time. 
(17)  Operators of commercial and/or private, noncommercial fuel tank/fuel farm may purchase fuel from any source or supplier authorized to sell fuel in the State of Louisiana and the City of Monroe; provided, however, that any such source or supplier must have executed a signed written agreement with the City of Monroe to forward a copy of all invoices of fuel sales and deliveries lessees at the Monroe Regional Airport to the airport director and to pay the fuel flowage on all such sales and/or deliveries within thirty (30) days after such delivery. 
(18)  No gasoline or other fuel shall be delivered to the Monroe Regional Airport except in the manner and in tank vehicles authorized by the Louisiana Department of Public Safety for the commercial transportation of such fuel on the public highways of the State of Louisiana. No fuel shall be delivered to the Monroe Regional Airport in cans, drums, tanks or other containers. 
(19)  All gasoline or other fuel delivered to the Monroe Regional Airport shall be subject to a fuel flowage fee of four cents ($0.04) per gallon, with a minimum fuel flowage fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year. 
(20)  Only commercial operators shall be permitted to maintain and operate mobile fuel tank vehicles, which vehicles known as "fuel tenders" must meet all Federal Aviation Administration standards and be approved by the airport director. Said mobile fuel tank vehicles shall be provided with applicable identification, filters and pumps as set forth for stationary tanks and shall meet all safety requirements. 
(21)  The airport director shall conduct an annual audit at the time of the airport's annual inspection, which will include inspections by the fire prevention bureau and may conduct additional audits at any time. 
(22)  Violations of the provisions of this section may result in fines and/or imprisonment imposed by the Monroe City Court as provided in section 1-11 of this Code, as well as the termination of the fuel tank/fuel farm permit granted herein by the city council. Termination of the permit shall not be dependent upon any decision by the Monroe City Court. 
(Ord. No. 7713-A, 8-28-84) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7713-A, adopted Aug. 28, 1984, which amended  7-50 and 7-51 has been treated as superseding the material in the aforementioned sections. Former  7-50 was concerned with the sale of gasoline to public and derived from Code 1958,  3-15, and Ord. No. 7010, adopted Mar. 14, 1978; and former  7-51 was concerned with wholesalers of gasoline and derived from Code 1958,  3-16; Ord. No. 7010, adopted Mar. 14, 1978; and Ord. No. 7-57, adopted Mar. 27, 1979. 
Sec. 7-51. - Sale of gasoline to public. 
(a)  Fuel sales shall be permitted at commercial operations only. 
(b)  Private and/or self-service fuel tank/fuel farm facilities shall not make fuel sales; and fuel at such facilities shall be dispensed only for the aircraft owner who holds the lease to said facility and only for that lessee's aircraft. 
(Ord. No. 7713-A, 8-28-84) 
Note- See editor's note to  7-50. 
Sec. 7-52. - Obedience to regulations for use of terminal building and airport facilities. 
    Uniform regulations promulgated by the airport manager which regulations shall govern the use of the airport terminal building and the airport facilities by the airlines. 
(Code 1958,  3-17.7) 
Sec. 7-53. - Certain standards and rules adopted by reference. 
(a)  The publication known as the "Minimum Standards for Commercial Aeronautical Activities of the Monroe Municipal Airport" is hereby adopted and incorporated herein as fully as if set out at length. A copy of said publication is on file in the office of the clerk of the council. 
(b)  That publication known as the "Airport Rules and Regulations Governing Tenants, Users, Passengers and Visitors for the Monroe Municipal Airport" is hereby adopted and incorporated herein as fully as if set out at length. A copy of said publication is on file in the office of the clerk of the council. 
(c)  All references to the Monroe Airport Authority in such publications are hereby amended to vest that authority in the council. 
(Code 1958,  3-31, 3-41, Ord. No. 7010, 3-14-78; Ord. No. 10,891, 3-10-09) 
Sec. 7-54. - Special rules for operation of aircraft. 
    The following special rules shall be observed by all persons operating aircraft in, on or near the Monroe Regional Airport: 
(a)  No person shall taxi an aircraft until he has ascertained, through visual inspection, and when available, through information furnished by airport attendants, that there will be no danger of collision with any person or object in the vicinity or area. 
(b)  No person shall operate the engine of any aircraft at any time or at any location on the airport so as to cause damage to persons or property on the airport. 
(c)  All aircraft awaiting take off shall be parked at least one hundred (100) feet from the active runway, and in a position which will enable the pilot to have an unobstructed view of aircraft approaching the field for landing. 
(d)  Runway 17 is designated as the calm wind runway. 
(e)  Normal left-hand air traffic shall be flown in a rectangular pattern at an altitude of eight hundred (800) feet A.G.L., provided that aircraft having flight characteristics which make the above procedure impractical may be flown at an altitude of one thousand (1,000) feet A.G.L., but shall conform to the rectangular pattern unless otherwise directed by the air traffic control tower. 
(f)  The first turn of all aircraft departing Monroe Regional Airport shall be made after reaching the departure end of runway being used, unless otherwise directed by the air traffic control tower. 
(g)  All aircraft arriving at the Monroe Regional Airport shall enter traffic in the middle third or segment of the downward leg of the traffic pattern. 
(h)  No aircraft shall be flown in the traffic pattern in any maneuver other than that which may be necessary for safe operation. 
(i)  All aircraft shall expedite clearance of the runway and shall not come to a stop until after turning off on a taxi strip, and then not less than one hundred (100) feet from the active runway, unless otherwise directed by the air traffic control tower. 
(j)  Student aircraft engaged in touch and go landings, either dual or solo, shall be expedited as much as is practical. 
(k)  No aircraft, except those operated by commercial airlines, shall park in front of the terminal building in the area delineated by yellow lines painted on the ramp. 
(l)  No aircraft shall take off from a runway intersection without permission of the air traffic control tower. 
(m)  No aircraft shall take off from or land upon the ramp at any time. 
(Code 1958,  3-11.5; Ord. No. 7088, 9-11-79) 
Sec. 7-55. - Airport advertising and fees. 
    Advertising space. The city recognizes the need to further maximize the use of the facilities to allow for advertising by commercial or private vendors and, accordingly, management is hereby authorized to lease rental space by use of written signs, billboards or mechanical means for display at the Monroe Regional Airport. The extent of the number and use of advertising space in the airport shall be at the discretion of the director of public works and the fee shall be based on the following:
