    Any grantee awarded a franchise under this article shall allow the director of administration of the City of Monroe or his authorized representative to inspect and audit all data and records of grantee relating to its performance under the provisions of this article or the franchise. Such inspection shall be made during normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. 9245, 9-10-91) 
Sec. 9.5-13. - Penalties. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with the provisions of this article, and unless otherwise provided for in this article, the violation of or the failure to comply with any provisions of this article shall be punished by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day any violation of or failure to comply with any provision of this article continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 9245, 9-10-91) 
ARTICLE II. - CABLE AND VIDEO SERVICES FRANCHISE FEE ORDINANCE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10,882,  1-8, adopted Jan. 27, 2009, did not specify manner of inclusion. In order to facilitate indexing said provisions have been codified as Art. II,  9.5-31-9.5-38. 

Sec. 9.5-31. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known as the "Cable and Video Services Franchise Fee Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 10,882,  1, 1-27-09) 
Sec. 9.5-32. - Adoption of state laws. 
    The provisions of La. R.S. tit 45, ch. 10-A, known as the Consumer Choice for Television Act are hereby adopted by reference as if written herein in extenso. 
(Ord. No. 10,882,  2, 1-27-09) 
Sec. 9.5-33. - Monthly franchise fee. 
(1)  The amount of the quarterly franchise fee shall be three (3) per cent of the gross revenues as defined by La. R.S. 45:1363(8) as fixed, levied and collectible in accordance with the provisions of La. R.S. tit 45, ch. 10-A, and such other amounts as are authorized by law. 
(2)  Nothing in this article shall restrict the right of the City of Monroe to impose on any cable and/or video service ad valorem taxes, service fees, sales and use taxes or other taxes and fees lawfully imposed on other businesses which may be lawfully imposed upon cable and/or video service providers. 
(3)  The franchise fee set further herein shall be in lieu of any permit fee, encroachment fee, degradation fee, inspection fee, or other fees assessed by the city on cable and/or video service providers for occupation of, or work within, the public rights-of-way. 
(4)  Nothing herein shall except any cable and/or video service provider from any ordinance regulating the occupation of or work within the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 10,882,  3, 1-27-09) 
Sec. 9.5-34. - Late fees. 
    All franchise fees levied herein shall be due and payable within forty-five (45) days after the end of the quarter. All unpaid fees shall become delinquent on the forty-sixth day after the end of the quarter for which the fees are due and payable. 
(1)  If any cable and/or video service provider fails to pay the fee set forth in this article, or any portion thereof, on or before the forty-sixth day following the quarter, interest at the rate of one and one-quarter (11/4) per cent per month shall be added to the amount of fee due and such interest shall be computed from the due date until the fee is paid. 
(2)  In addition to the interest charged on delinquent taxes there shall be imposed a penalty of five (5) per cent of the total fee due if the failure or delinquency is for not more than thirty (30) days, with an additional five (5) per cent for each additional thirty (30) days or fraction thereof. 
(3)  The City of Monroe maintains its rights under La. R.S. 45:1367 to audit the business records of any cable and/or video service providers to the extent necessary to ensure payment of the franchise fee in accordance with this article and payment of any applicable service fees, sales and use taxes or other taxes and fees lawfully imposed on other businesses which may be lawfully imposed upon cable and/or video service providers. 
(Ord. No. 10,882,  4, 1-27-09) 
Sec. 9.5-35. - Applicability. 
    The franchise fee herein shall be applicable to any provider of cable and/or video service as defined in La. R.S. 45:1363. 
(Ord. No. 10,882,  5, 1-27-09) 
Sec. 9.5-36. - Registration. 
    Any entity which desires to provide cable and/or video service within the City of Monroe shall register and provide to the permit office for the city a copy of the certificate of franchise issued by the Louisiana Secretary of State pursuant to La. R.S. 45:1364 and proof of insurance as required by La. R.S. 45:1364(B)(4) within thirty (30) days of the effective date of this article or prior to offering cable and/or video services within the City of Monroe, whichever is later. All registering entities are hereby requested to provide capacity for public, educational and governmental access programming streams and channels in accordance with La. R.S. 45:1369. 
(Ord. No. 10,882,  6, 1-27-09) 
Sec. 9.5-37. - Conflicts. 
    Any and all previously adopted ordinances in conflict with this article are hereby repealed. Should any section, subsection, sentence, clause or provision of this article be in conflict with any provision of state or federal law, the same shall not affect the validity of this article as a whole, or parts thereof, other than the part declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be in conflict. 
(Ord. No. 10,882,  7, 1-27-09) 
Sec. 9.5-38. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or provision of this article is held invalid for any reason, the remainder of this article shall not be affected thereby and shall remain in force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 10,882,  8, 1-27-09) 
Chapter 10 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Public works department,  4-06. 
Cross reference- Desecration of graves,  12-130; speed in cemeteries,  33-31. 
State Law reference- For authority to establish and maintain, see R.S. 8:101. 

Sec. 10-1. - Maintenance. 
    The following cemeteries belonging to the city shall be maintained out of the general fund of the city; Monroe City Cemetery, Riverview Burial Park, Magnolia Cemetery. 
(Code 1958,  7-1) 
Sec. 10-2. - Burial permit. 
    It shall be unlawful to inter or bury any dead person within the city limits without first obtaining a burial-transit permit as required by chapter 24 of the Sanitary Code of the State of Louisiana. 
(Code 1958,  7-4) 
Sec. 10-3. - Disinterment of human bodies. 
    No dead human body shall be disinterred, disentombed or otherwise removed from a grave, tomb or vault without the prior approval of the parish health officer. 
(Code 1958,  7-5) 
Sec. 10-4. - Special plots at Riverview Burial Park. 
    There shall be set aside in the Riverview Burial Park three special plots for the following: 
(a)  Plot for the burial of Veterans of World War I and the Spanish-American War. 
(b)  Plot for the burial of members of the Veterans of Foreign Wars. 
(c)  Plot for the burial of paupers. 
(Code 1958,  7-7) 
Sec. 10-5. - Sale of lots. 
    The mayor or his designee is authorized and empowered to pass notarial acts of sale, in the name of the mayor and city council, at the expense of the purchasers, of all lots or parts of lots in the cemeteries, which have not heretofore been sold and paid for. Persons desiring lots or plots in city-owned or city-maintained cemeteries shall pay to the city such fees as are established by ordinance. 
(Code 1958,  7-8, 7-9; Ord. No. 7071, 7-10-79; Ord. No. 7095, 10-23-79) 
Sec. 10-6. - Charges for opening or closing graves-Generally. 
    Charges shall be made for opening or closing graves in city cemeteries as established by ordinance. 
(Code 1958,  7-3; Ord. No. 7071, 7-10-79; Ord. No. 7095, 10-23-79) 
Sec. 10-6.1. - Same-Listed; lot costs. 
    [The cost for lots and for opening or closing graves in city-owned cemeteries are established as follows:] 
(1)  Magnolia Cemetery. Lot cost with opening/closing fee included: 
Adult (weekday) ..... $225.00 
Adult (Saturday, Sunday, holidays) ..... 250.00 
Infant (weekday) ..... 75.00 
Infant (Saturday, Sunday, holidays) ..... 75.00 
(2)  Riverview Cemetery: 
a.  Lot cost: 
Close to road ..... $300.00 
Away from road ..... 250.00 
b.  Opening/closing costs: 
Adult (weekday) ..... 150.00 
Adult (Saturday, Sunday, holidays) ..... 150.00 
Infant (weekday) ..... 150.00 
Infant (Saturday, Sunday, holidays) ..... 150.00 
(Ord. No. 7950, 9-23-86) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7750, adopted Sept. 23, 1986, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of the substantive provisions of the ordinance as  10-6.1 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 10-7. - Illegal burial, removal of corpse. 
    In the event that any corpse shall be buried in any lot or part of a lot in the cemetery, which shall not have been sold by the city, it shall be the duty of the public works director to cause the immediate removal of such corpse and its burial in any part of the cemeteries not divided into lots, at the expense of the city, and to cause suit for such expense to be instituted immediately against the person responsible for the illegal burial thereof, in addition to the punishment prescribed for violations of this Code. 
(Code 1958,  7-11) 
Sec. 10-8. - Prohibited burials in and sales of lots, repurchase of lots. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bury, or cause to be buried in any lot purchased from the city any corpse unless the deceased is the owner of said lot or unless the deceased is a relative by blood, marriage or adoption of the owner of said lot. No lot purchased from the city may be sold to anyone other than the city by said purchaser. The city shall repurchase any lot sold by it and in which no body has been interred, for the price for which said lot was sold by the city. 
(Code 1958,  7-12) 
Sec. 10-9. - Destruction of property; erection of fences. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maliciously cut, mutilate, bruise or injure in any manner the flowers, shrubbery or ornamental trees within any of the cemeteries in the corporate limits of the city, or to maliciously deface or injure any tombstone in any one of such cemeteries. It shall be unlawful to erect private fences within the enclosures of any city cemetery. 
(Code 1958,  7-13) 
Chapter 10.5 - CHARITABLE RAFFLES, BINGO AND ELECTRONIC VIDEO BINGO[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7881, adopted Feb. 11, 1986, amended the Code by adding a new Chapter 15A. In order to maintain Code format and follow the alpha-numeric sequence, Chapter 15A has been redesignated as Chapter 10.5. Additionally, Ord. No. 10,711, adopted June 12, 2007, changed the title of chapter 10.5 from "Charitable Raffles, Bingo and Keno" to "Charitable Raffles, Bingo and Electronic Video Bingo." 
State Law reference- Charitable Raffles, Bingo And Keno Licensing Law, R.S. 4:701 et seq.; powers of local authorities, R.S. 4:706. 

Sec. 10.5-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the "Charitable Raffles, Bingo, and Electronic Video Bingo Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86; Ord. No. 10,711, 6-12-07) 
Sec. 10.5-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Charitable organization shall mean a nonprofit veterans, eleemosynary, benevolent, educational, religious, fraternal or civic and service association or corporation domiciled in this state. Any such organization or corporation shall have qualified with the United States Internal Revenue Service for an exemption from federal income tax under Section 501(c)(3), (4), (8), or (19) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(2)  Pull-tabs shall mean single or banded tickets or cards each with its face covered to conceal one or more numbers or symbols, where one or more cards or tickets in each set have been designated in advance as a winner. 
(3)  Senior citizen recreation club shall mean an organization, which is sanctioned by the local council on aging, composed of a group of persons sixty (60) years of age or older whose only function is to provide amusement and diversion for its members. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-3. - Permitted. 
(a)  Bona fide veterans, charitable, educational, religious, or fraternal organizations, civic and service clubs may conduct charitable raffles, bingo, keno, and/or pull-tab games, as set forth in section 10.5-4, and may sell shares, tickets or rights to participate in such game or games of chance under such conditions and regulations for the supervision and conduct thereof as may be prescribed from time to time by the city, provided: (1) That said organizations, associations, corporations and/or clubs possess the appropriate nonprofit designation as provided for in section 10.5-2(a); (2) that the entire net proceeds of such game or games of chance are to be devoted to educational, charitable, patriotic, religious, or public spirited uses; (3) that said game or games are held, operated, and conducted exclusively by the active members pursuant to the provisions of this chapter; and (4) that said organizations obtain the appropriate license required by section 10.5-4. 
(b)  It shall be lawful for any person or persons to participate in and play such game or games of chance conducted under any such license granted hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-4. - License required. 
    Every bona fide veterans, charitable, educational, religious, or fraternal organization, civic and service club, which possesses the appropriate nonprofit designation issued by the United States Internal Revenue Service is hereby required to obtain from the city for each year an appropriate license to hold and operate the specific kind of game or games of chance commonly known: (1) As raffle or raffles played by drawing for prizes or the allotment of prizes by chance, by the selling of shares or tickets or rights to participate in such game or games and by conducting the game or games accordingly; (2) bingo or keno played for prizes with cards bearing numbers or other designations, five (5) or more in one line, the holder covering numbers, as objects similarly numbered, are drawn from a receptacle and the game being won by the person who first covers a previously designated arrangement of numbers on such card, by the selling of shares or tickets or rights to participate in such game or games and by conducting the game or games accordingly; and (3) pull-tabs played for prizes with cards or tickets and as defined in Louisiana Revised Statutes 33:4861.2, by selling shares or tickets or rights to participate in such games and by conducting the game or games accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-5. - Application for license. 
    Each applicant for such a license shall file with the city a written application therefor on a form prescribed by the city, duly executed and verified, stating the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  Sufficient facts relating to its incorporation and/or organization to enable the city to determine whether or not it is a bona fide organization or association, including evidence of the nonprofit designation issued by the United States Internal Revenue Service; 
(3)  The names and addresses of its officers; 
(4)  The name and address of the active member or members of the applicant under whom the game or games of chance described in the application are to be held, operated and conducted; 
(5)  A statement shall be executed and attached to the application, by the applicant and the members so designated, that he or they will be responsible for the holding, operating and conducting of such game or games of chance in accordance with the terms of the license, the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes 33:4861.1 et seq. and the provisions of this chapter, as well as in accordance with any rules and regulations that may hereafter be prescribed by the city; 
(6)  The specific kind of game or games of chance intended to be held, operated and conducted by the applicant; 
(7)  The place or places where such game or games of chance are intended to be conducted by the applicant; 
(8)  The date or dates when such game or games of chance are intended to be conducted by the applicant; 
(9)  All items of expense intended, anticipated and/or expected to be incurred or paid in connection with the holding, operating and conducting of such game or games of chance and the names and addresses of the persons to whom, and the purposes for which they are to be paid; 
(10)  The specific purposes to which the entire net proceeds of such game or games of chance are to be devoted and in what manner they are to be so devoted; 
(11)  That no commission, salary, compensation, reward or recompense will be paid to any person or persons for holding, operating or conducting or assisting in the holding, operating or conducting of such game or games of chance; 
(12)  A description of all prizes to be offered or given in such game or games of chance to be held, operated or conducted under such license; 
(13)  Any such other information as may be prescribed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-6. - Investigation of qualifications. 
    The city shall make an investigation of the qualifications of the applicant and it shall determine whether the applicant is duly qualified to hold, operate and conduct games of chance under this chapter and under the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes 33:4861.1 et seq.; whether the member or members designated in the application to hold, operate and conduct or assist in the holding, operating or conducting of the game or games of chance for which the license is requested are bona fide active members of the applicant and persons of good moral character and have never been convicted of a crime; whether the game or games of chance are to be held, operated and conducted in accordance with the terms of the license, the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes 33:4861.1 et seq. and the provisions of this chapter, as well as the provisions of any rules and regulations previously promulgated by the city; whether the proceeds thereof are to be disposed of as provided by Louisiana Revised Statutes 33:4861.1 et seq. and this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-7. - Issuance of license. 
    If the city council is satisfied that the applicant meets all of the qualifications set forth in Louisiana Revised Statutes 33:4861.1 et seq. and the provisions of this chapter, and that no commission, salary, compensation, reward or recompense whatsoever will be given or paid to any person holding, operating or conducting or assisting in the holding, operating or conducting of any such game or games of chance, it shall issue a license to the applicant for the holding, operating and conducting of the specific kind, or one or more of the specific kinds, of game or games of chance applied for accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-8. - Duration of license. 
    An annual license for the holding, operating and/or conducting of any game or games of chance issued under this chapter shall be effective for a period of one year, commencing on May 1 and terminating on April 30 of the following year. 
    A monthly license for the holding, operating and/or conducting, of any game or games of chance issued under this chapter shall be effective for a period of one calendar month. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-9. - License fee. 
    There is hereby levied a license fee for the holding, operating and/or conducting of any game or games of chance authorized herein as follows: 
Annual license, sixty dollars ($60.00). 
Monthly license, ten dollars ($10.00). 
A full license fee shall be collected regardless of the date of issuance of the license. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-10. - Additional fees. 
    In the event that the state assesses any administrative charge connected with the issuance of any license hereunder, the applicant shall be responsible for said charges. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-11. - Hearing. 
    No application for the issuance of a license under this chapter shall be refused until after a hearing is held on due notice to the applicant and at which the applicant shall be entitled to be heard upon the qualifications of the applicant and/or its members and upon the merits of the application. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-12. - Amendment of license. 
    Any license issued under the provisions herein may be amended, upon application to the city, provided the subject matter of the proposed amendment could lawfully and properly have been included in the original license, or has become lawful and proper due to subsequent amendments to this chapter. Said application for amendment shall be submitted at least thirty (30) days prior to the event. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-13. - Display of license. 
    Each license issued for the conduct of any game or games of chance shall be conspicuously displayed at the place where any such game or games of chance is to be conducted at all times during the conduct thereof. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-14. - Control and supervision over games. 
(a)  The City of Monroe, through its police department, shall have and exercise control and supervision over all games of chance held, operated or conducted under any license issued hereunder to the end that the same are fairly held, operated or conducted in accordance with the provisions of such license, the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes 33:4861.1 et seq., the provisions of this chapter, and any rules and/or regulations subsequently adopted hereunder. 
(b)  The city shall, by its officers and agents, have the right of entry at all times into any premises where any such game or games of chance is or are being held, operated and/or conducted or where it is intended that any such game or games of chance shall be held, operated or conducted, or where any equipment being used or intended to be used in conduct thereof is found, for the purpose of inspecting the same. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-15. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The city council shall have the authority and power to suspend and/or revoke any license issued hereunder, after a hearing upon due notice to the licensee, for: (1) Any violation of the terms of the license; (2) any violation of the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes 33:4861.1 et seq.; (3) any violation of the provisions of this chapter; (4) any violation of the provisions of any rules or regulations subsequently adopted hereunder; or, (5) any violation of any applicable law of the State of Louisiana or of the United States government. 
(b)  Further the city council may in the exercise of its police power, whenever deemed advisable for the general welfare, for good cause, suspend or revoke any license issued hereunder, after hearing upon due notice to the licensee. 
(c)  Any hearing under this section shall be held upon at least ten-days' notice to the licensee; said notice to contain the purpose and reason for said hearing; the possible consequences of said hearing; and the date, time and place of said hearing. All such hearings shall be open to the public and the licensee shall be given the opportunity to be heard and present evidence directed toward the subject matter of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-16. - Number of games per month. 
    No game or games of chance shall be held, operated or conducted under any license issued hereunder on more than fifteen (15) days in any one calendar month. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86; Ord. No. 10,711, 6-12-07) 
Sec. 10.5-17. - Persons entitled to hold games; equipment; expenses; commissions or salaries. 
    No person shall hold, operate or conduct or assist in holding, operating or conducting of any game or games of chance under any license issued under this chapter except an active member of the organization or association to which the license is issued; and no such game or games of chance shall be conducted with any equipment except such as shall be owned absolutely or used without payment of any compensation therefor by the licensee; and no item of expense shall be incurred or paid in connection with the holding, operating or conducting of any game or games of chance held, operated or conducted pursuant to any license issued under this chapter, except such as are bona fide items of reasonable amount of goods, wares and merchandise furnished or services rendered, which are reasonably necessary to be purchased or furnished for the holding, operating or conducting thereof, under any circumstances whatever; and no commission, salary, compensation, reward or recompense whatever shall be paid or given, directly or indirectly, to any person holding, operating or conducting, or assisting in the holding, operating or conducting of any game or games of chance so held, operated or conducted. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-18. - Statement of receipts; expenditures; books and records. 
(a)  Not later than ten (10) days after the end of the month in which the game or games of chance were held, operated or conducted, the organization or association which held, operated or conducted the game or games of chance and its member or members who were in charge thereof shall furnish to the city the following: 
(1)  A verified statement showing the amount of gross receipts derived from each such game of chance, that shall include receipts from the sale of shares, tickets or rights in any manner connected with the participation in said game or the right to participate therein; 
(2)  Each item of expense incurred, or paid, and each item of expenditure made or to be made in connection therewith; 
(3)  The name and address of each person to whom each such item has been, or is to be paid, with a detailed description of the merchandise purchased or the services rendered therefor; 
(4)  The net profit derived from each game of chance, and the uses to which such net profit has been or is to be applied; 
(5)  A list of prizes offered or given, with the respective values thereof; and 
(6)  The name and address of each person who assisted in the holding, operating and conducting of each game. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each licensee to maintain and keep such books and records as may be necessary to substantiate the particulars of each such report. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-19. - Examination of books and records and personnel. 
    The city, through its officers or agents, shall have the power to examine or cause to be examined the books or records of any organization or association to which such license is issued so far as they may relate to any transaction or transactions connected with the holding and conducting of any game or games of chance thereunder and to examine any manager, officer, director, agent, member or employee thereof under oath in relation to the conduct of any such game or games of chance under any such license but any such information so received shall not be disclosed except in so far as may be necessary for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-20. - Violations. 
    Any person, organization, association or corporation who or which shall make any false statement in any application for a license hereunder or report required hereunder, or shall fail to keep such books and records as shall fully and truly record all transactions connected with the holding, operating or conducting of any game or games of chance under any such license or shall falsify or make any false statement or entry in any books, records or reports required hereunder so far as they relate to any transaction connected with the holding, operating or conducting of any game or games of chance under any such license or shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall, in addition to any other penalty which may be imposed, forfeit any license issued to him or it under this chapter and shall be ineligible to apply for a license under this chapter for one year thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-21. - Immunity. 
    In accordance with the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes 33:4861.15., no person, association or corporation: (1) Possessing, selling or in any manner disposing of any shares, tickets or rights to participate in any game or games of chance conducted or to be conducted, under any license lawfully issued pursuant to this chapter, (2) lawfully conducting or participating in the conduct of any such game or games of chance, or (3) permitting the conduct of any such game or games of chance upon premises owned by him or it, under any license lawfully issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, shall be liable to prosecution or conviction for violation of any provision of Louisiana Revised Statutes 14:90 or of any provision of this Code relating to gambling, provided however, that his immunity shall not extend to any person, association or corporation knowingly conducting or participating in the conduct of any game or games of chance under any license obtained by any false pretense or statement made in any application for such license or otherwise, or possessing, selling or disposing of shares, tickets or rights to participate in, or permitting the conduct upon any premises owned by him or it of any game or games of chance conducted under any license known to him or it to have been obtained by any such false or fraudulent pretense or statement. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-22. - Exemption. 
    A bona fide senior citizens' recreation club, as defined in section 10.5-2(3) herein, upon application shall be exempt from the licensing and reporting procedure set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 7881, 2-11-86) 
Sec. 10.5-23. - Electronic video bingo machines. 
(a)  Permitted at licensed locations. It shall be lawful for any bona fide nonprofit board, association, corporation or other organization domiciled in this state and qualified with the United States Internal Revenue Service for an exemption from federal income tax under section 501(c) (3), (4), (5), (6), (7), (8), (10) or (19) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (as amended) or organizations authorized under LSA-R.S. 4:703, possessing a current, valid city and state bingo permit, to use electronic video bingo machine or machines authorized pursuant to LSA-R.S. 4:701 et seq. at licensed locations for electronic video bingo; and the leasing or placement of such machines from state approved (as defined below) distributors/suppliers shall also be lawful. Any state approved distributor/supplier of such equipment for use in the conduct of any games of chance authorized under this chapter and under the provisions of LSA- R.S. 4:726 shall submit a permit application to the office of the city clerk. "State approved" as used in this chapter shall mean a person or entity specifically licensed or otherwise approved by the state in accordance with LSA-R.S. 4:701 et seq. 
(b)  Application for license. 
(1)  Each state approved manufacturer or distributor, each organization or private contractor qualified to conduct games as authorized under this chapter, and each commercial lessor leasing a premise to a licensee for conducting such bingo, within the city shall apply for and obtain, on an annual basis, an electronic video bingo license (EVBL) from the city. 
(2)  Every bona fide veteran's, charitable, educational, religious, or fraternal organization, civic, service club and carnival organization seeking an EVBL that desires to sponsor or conduct fund raising events using an electronic video bingo machine or machines shall apply for and obtain an EVBL from the city. Such application, shall be in the form prescribed by the office of city clerk, duly executed and verified, shall state the name and address of the applicant, together with such information required by LSA-R.S. 4:708, including but not limited to the place or places, the date or dates, and time or times when such electronic video bingo machine or machines are intended to be used by the applicant or operated by the EVBL, under the license applied for. The majority of the organization's charity work shall be done within the city. 
(c)  Term of license or permit. EVBL's issued by the city shall be effective each year from the period of January 1 through December 31 of the same year. Fees for a partial calendar year shall not be prorated. 
(d)  License processing fee. 
(1)  An annual nonrefundable fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be paid to the city to defray the costs of reviewing and processing an application for licensing a manufacturer, distributor, operator or commercial lessor. 
(2)  EVBLs that seek a charitable organization permit shall pay a nonrefundable fee of ten dollars ($10.00). This fee shall be in addition to occupational license fees that may be owed the city. 
(e)  Machine permit fee. An annual permit fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each machine to be permitted shall be paid to the city and be included with the application or renewal application. 
(f)  Quarterly statement. Not later than twenty (20) days after January 1, April 1, July 1, and October 1, of each year, each EVBL operator shall furnish the city sworn (notarized) and verified statement indicating total payment, cash or coins in, credits played, credits won and credits paid. 
(g)  Maximum number of machines permitted. No one site used by a EVBL under this chapter shall have more than thirty-five (35) electronic video bingo machines in such licensed location. 
(h)  Locations. The operation of electronic video bingo machines as authorized by this chapter shall not be allowed on any property zoned residential or in any location other than those specifically prescribed by the city zoning ordinances. Unless otherwise specified by the mayor and city council, the operation of any electronic video bingo machines by EVBL operators shall only occur on premises by licensed approved commercial lessors. Any commercial lessor who does not have video bingo machines in operation as of May 1, 2008 shall not be allowed to open within a one mile radius of the location of any commercial lessor who has operating machines. 
(i)  Commercial lessors. It shall be unlawful to have more than eight (8) licensed locations utilized by commercial lessors within the city. The site of the bingo hall currently operating at 3000 DeSiard Street, Monroe, Louisiana will be entitled to one commercial lessor license and WhiteCo Gaming LLC, having presented their letter of intent to apply for a commercial lessor license to the clerk of council of the city, will be entitled to two (2) commercial lessor licenses if an EVBL is sought by each lessor within sixty (60) days from the effective date of this section. Notwithstanding the initial limitation of eight (8) commercial lessor sites, the council, upon recommendation of the mayor, may allow additional locations if determined feasible from information submitted by the division of administration of the city. 
(j)  Sessions. A session represents electronic video bingo games played within a time limit not to exceed six (6) hours within a minimum of twelve (12) hours between sessions. Sessions are limited to not more than one session per day per EVBL. No EVBL shall be permitted to operate electronic video bingo games for more than fifteen (15) days in any calendar month. Notwithstanding any provisions contained in any resolution to the contrary, all types of bingo sessions may be allowed to the extent and at the times allowed for electronic video bingo. 
(k)  Net proceeds. For purpose of this chapter, the term "net win" shall mean the sum obtained by subtracting total coins in minus the total amount paid out on ticket vouchers tendered for cash money. Twenty (20) per cent of the net win from each electronic video bingo machine shall be paid as an assessment or tax owed the city. The tax or assessment owed to the city shall be determined on a monthly basis owed and becomes due on the first day of the month that follows the previous month of operations. Taxes or assessments that are not paid to the city by the fifth day of the month in which they become due shall incur a penalty of two (2) per cent per month until paid in. 
(l)  General. Except as specifically provided with respect to electronic video bingo, other requirements and penalties relating to bingo, keno, and raffles shall apply to the operation of electronic video bingo machines. To the extent that any of this section is in conflict with any other section(s) of this chapter, the provisions of the section shall control. 
(m)  Louisiana statutory provisions. Where any provisions hereof conflict with the provisions of LSA-R.S. 4:701 et seq., the applicable provisions of such state law (including provisions contained in the Louisiana Administrative Code promulgated pursuant thereto) shall govern. Each EVBL shall meet all requirements of state law regarding the state licensure of such EVBL, the operation of electronic bingo games and the use of electronic video bingo machines. 
(Ord. No. 10,711, 6-12-07) 
Chapter 11 - CITY COURT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Demonstrations near court buildings occupied by judge, jury, etc.,  12-186. 
State Law reference- Monroe city court, R.S. 13:1952 

Sec. 11-1. - Fines and costs; responsibility for collection. 
    All fines, forfeitures, penalties and costs assessed by the city court for violations of this Code or other city ordinances shall be collected by the clerk of the city court or the marshal, as designated by the city judge, and all such funds so collected, excluding costs, shall be paid to the city treasury by the person collecting same immediately upon receipt thereof, and such person shall take a receipt therefor. 
(Code 1958,  9-1) 
Sec. 11-2. - Court costs; collection, use, audit of account. 
    It is the duty of the person designated by the city judge to collect fines, forfeitures, penalties and costs, when collecting fines assessed by the court or when executing the forfeiture of appearance bonds ordered by the court, to collect the court costs assessed by the court and to pay such costs to the clerk of the city court of the city, to be deposited in a special fund to be known as the "city court operation and expense fund". When an appearance bond is taken by the police department there shall be added to the amount thereof such sum as may be directed and ordered by the city judge as court costs. All costs deposited in the city court operation and expense fund shall be disbursed by the city judge for the operational and maintenance costs of the city court, including stationery, supplies, office equipment, clerical fees and similar expenditures, as may be approved by the judge of said court. An audit of such account shall be made by the regularly employed auditors of the city at such times as the records of the police department are audited. Any surplus, as hereinafter defined, created in such fund in excess of and beyond the needs for which the fund is created shall be paid by the judges into the general fund of the city. The term surplus or excess funds as used herein is defined as the April 30 operation and expense fund balance computed on the modified accrual basis of accounting in excess of ninety thousand dollars ($90,000.00). The method of transfer of any such surplus shall be that the excess funds, if any, will be recorded as a liability on April 30 of each fiscal year in the city court's accounting records and the liability will be liquidated by the transfer of the excess funds to the city within thirty (30) days of the release of the city court's annual audit report. 
(Code 1958,  9-2; Ord. No. 9494, 12-27-94) 
Sec. 11-3. - Parole and release of prisoners, suspending sentence; authority of judge. 
    The presiding judge of the city court is hereby vested with power and authority to parole and release from custody defendants detained, arrested or convicted for violations of this code and the ordinances of the city, and to suspend the whole or any portion of sentences imposed by such court, all in accordance with the provisions of the Louisiana Code of Criminal Procedure, and especially Article 894 thereof, and the Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950, as amended, and especially R.S. 15:81 thereof. 
(Code 1958,  9-3) 
Chapter 11.5 - CIVIC CENTER COMPLEX 

Sec. 11.5-1. - Rates, rentals. 
    The following schedules of rates and/or rentals are hereby established and adopted as the rates and/or rentals for the use of the Monroe Civic Center Complex, which includes the Arena, the Theater, the Conference/Exhibit Hall, the Livestock Pavilion, the Monroe River Market and such other facilities and/or events which are sponsored and/or maintained under the department of community affairs. 
(1)  General. Manager is authorized and shall have the right to negotiate in the name of and on behalf of the City of Monroe, execution and delivery of contracts with promoters and other users of the Facility. Manager shall negotiate for rental rates consistent with this rate schedule and industry standards and with the goal of maximizing use of the facilities. 
(2)  Event related costs. Rental of each of the facilities shall include or exclude, as applicable, the following event related costs: 
(1)  Set up; 
(2)  Ushers; 
(3)  Police; 
(4)  Medical attendants; 
(5)  Occupational license, if applicable; 
(6)  Ticket takers; 
(7)  Security; 
(8)  Doormen; 
(9)  Cleaning; 
(10)  Treasurer; 
(11)  Receptionist/clerk. 
Note: Stagehands, rigging, production staff and costs are specifically excluded therein from the definition of event related costs. The actual costs will be paid by the licensee. 
(3)  Co-Promotions. The manager may contract for the use of the facility by entering into co-promotion contracts with commercial users. The city's designated representative shall approve all contracts for co-promoted events entered into by manager. 
The facility shall receive a fixed or variable percentage of net profits based on a negotiated co-promotion agreement with the applicable user or users. The co-promotion contract may provide or require that the facility's financial participation occur at various levels and thresholds of net profits and be subject to a maximum limit. Co-promotions by nature involve a degree of risk to the facility and licensee and there is no assurance that the promotion or event will be successful. As a result, it is possible that the facility and/or licensee would be required to share in net losses as a result of the unsuccessful promotion or event. 
For purposes of this subsection (3): 
a.  Net profits shall be defined as gross admission receipts less (i) applicable sales and use taxes, (ii) direct building event related expenses, (iii) direct promoter expenses in the production and presentation of the event and (iv) other reasonable mutually agreed show expenses for the co-promoted event. 
b.  Building event related expenses may include but are not limited to minimum rent, box office fees, event services, event staffing, public safety (police, fire, first aid), advertising/promotion, group sales expenses, utilities, costs related to complimentary tickets, furniture rental, equipment rental, miscellaneous expenses mutually agreed to by manager and licensee. 
c.  Promoter expenses may include but are not limited to artist and talent fees, advertising/promotions, ASCAP/BMI, catering expenses, equipment, sound and lighting, other production costs, stagehands, local ground transportation and lodging, runners, miscellaneous expenses mutually agreed to between manager and licensee. 
d.  Net losses shall be defined as that amount of building event related expenses and promoter expenses that exceed net ticket sales. 
(4)  Civic use; no free events. The city objectives for the facilities include providing a vehicle for the presentation of a variety of cultural, educational, entertainment, sporting, social, and other activities for the community. In addition, the city intends to provide fair access to community and civic organizations and therefore has adopted a rate ordinance specifically tailored to address the needs of the civic community while minimizing, to the extent practicable, the net expense to the city of such use. 
The manager shall not allow the use of the facilities without a reasonable charge for such use. The city agrees not to waive rent or other use costs for any users. The use of the facilities for official city business, such as official city functions, commodities give away, city department meetings, mayor's commission, civil service exams, etc., shall not be required to pay rent, however, the city agrees to pay all associated event expenses incurred. 
(5)  Rent waivers and reductions. The city recognizes the need to maximize the use of the facilities by its commercial users and licensees. Therefore, the reasonableness of pre-negotiated rental rates are in part dependent upon the success of an event or promotion. Consequently, subsequent usage of the facility by these licensees is dependent upon the facility's flexibility in re-negotiating previously contracted rental rates when such event or promotion failed to meet licensee and facilities economic expectations. 
Accordingly, manager shall have the right to reduce the amounts to be paid by a user or promoter of all or part of pre-negotiated rental rates when: 
a.  In manager's good faith judgment the event or activity concludes at a loss to a licensee who has historically utilized the facility in a financially successful manner or is likely to be a user of the facility for future events; or 
b.  In the event that an act of God occurs which affects day of event walk up ticket sales; or 
c.  In manager's good faith judgment a licensee discount would induce such licensee to, additional and or future events, book multi-performance events by one or more artists or where the event generated significant ancillary revenues to the facility (food and beverage, merchandise and novelty sales, and parking) whereby a rent reduction would create goodwill for future business. 
Manager agrees to utilize diligent good faith efforts to apply any rent reductions in a fair and equitable manner. The city acknowledges that the operation of the facilities are generally unique to the exhibition, entertainment and sports industries and that judgments and actions of the manager are subjective and susceptible change, variation, and amendment given the applicable circumstances of each decision. 
(6)  Multiple events/performances. The city recognizes the need to maximize the utilization of the facilities with commercial users and licensees. When multiple performances or multiple show days are involved the amount charged for rental rates may vary from the amounts set forth in the rate ordinance. Accordingly the manager shall have the authority to deviate and negotiate daily rental rates for multiple events or events with multiple performances, when in manager's good faith judgment it is deemed appropriate or necessary and in the best interest of the facility customer relationship. 
(7)  Advertising space. The city recognizes the need to further maximize the use of the facilities to allow for advertising by commercial or private vendors and, accordingly, management is hereby authorized to lease rental space by use of written signs, billboards or mechanical means for display at the Monroe Civic Center Complex. The extent of the number and use of advertising space in the complex shall be at the discretion of the director of community affairs and the fee shall be based on current market value.

Sec. 11.5-2. - Parking; fees. 
(a)  Plan authorized. Whenever in the opinion of the management staff of the Monroe Civic Center, the type of event and expected attendance of an event warrant control, management of traffic, parking and security in the parking lot facilities of the Monroe Civic Center, the management staff shall put into effect a parking plan to provided the control, management and security thereof. 
(b)  Whenever the above-mentioned parking plan is put into effect, there is hereby established a fee per vehicle for each vehicle utilizing the parking facilities of the Monroe Civic Center. Fees are as follows: 
(1)  Two dollars ($2.00) per vehicle for "Ticketed Entertainment Events" in the Arena, Theatre and Conference Hall including but not limited to concerts, music and/or dance, theatre productions, pageants, Bingo, etc. 
(2)  One dollar ($1.00) per vehicle for "Nonentertainment Ticketed Events," including dance recitals, music recitals, consumer shows, etc. 
(3)  No charge per vehicle for "Nonprofit and Nonticketed Events," including civic club meetings, approved fund raising events, religious, charitable and educational events, graduations, conventions, seminars, banquets, social balls, etc. 
(4)  There is hereby levied an additional fee of one dollar ($1.00) per ticket at all ticketed events at the Monroe Civic Center Complex, which includes the Arena, the Theater, the Conference/Exhibit Hall, the Convention Center and the Livestock Pavilion for the operation and maintenance of the parking facilities at the complex. 
(Ord. No. 7417, 7-27-82; Ord. No. 9184, 11-27-90; Ord. No. 10,400, 5-25-04; Ord. No. 10,476, 4-12-05) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9184, adopted Nov 27, 1990, has been treated as amendatory of  11.5-2. The fees set out therein shall take effect Dec. 1, 1990. 
Sec. 11.5-3. - Regulation of smoking in the Monroe Civic Center Arena, Theater and Conference Hall. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided herein, smoking is prohibited in all enclosed areas of the Monroe Civic Center Arena, Theater and Conference Hall. 
(b)  Smoking is defined herein as the inhaling, exhaling, burning or carrying of any lighted cigarette, cigar, pipe or other combustible product. 
(Ord. No. 9381, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 11.5-4. - Designated smoking areas in the Monroe Civic Center Arena, Theater and Conference Hall. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions to the contrary, smoking shall be permitted in (a) private enclosed offices and (b) in designated smoking areas which shall be so situated as to allow nonsmoking individuals the opportunity to conduct normal activity in a reasonably smoke-free environment. 
    Areas in which smoking is prohibited shall be conspicuously posted by posting signs to that effect. 
    Designated smoking areas shall be conspicuously identified by posting signs in every place where smoking is permitted. 
    Signs shall be of such color, size and design so as to be conspicuous. The international "smoking" and "no smoking" symbols may be used. 
(Ord. No. 9381, 6-8-93) 
Sec. 11.5-5. - Violation, penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke where smoking is prohibited by the provisions of section 11.5-3. 
(b)  Any person who violates the provisions of sections 11.5-3 and 11.5-5(a) shall be subject to a misdemeanor summons and a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(c)  Any person who refuses to comply with the provisions of section 11.5-3 after being asked to do so by civic center staff, may be escorted from the premises by the civic center staff or by officers of the Monroe Police Department, in addition to the penalty set forth hereinabove. 
(Ord. No. 9381, 6-8-93) 
Chapter 12 - CRIMINAL CODE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Definitions. 
    In this chapter the terms enumerated shall have the designated meanings: 
    Another refers to any person or legal entity, including the State of Louisiana or any subdivision thereof. 
    Anything of value must be given the broadest possible construction, including any conceivable thing of the slightest value, movable or immovable, corporeal or incorporeal, public or private. It must be construed in the broad popular sense of the phrase, and not necessarily as synonymous with the traditional legal term "property." 
    City means the city or any agency, board, commission, department or institution of same. 
    City secretary and treasurer . Whenever the words "city secretary and treasurer," "secretary and treasurer," "city secretary," or "city treasurer" are used, they shall be construed to mean the secretary and treasurer of the city or the director of administration. 
    Dangerous weapon includes any gas, liquid or other substance or instrument which, in the manner used, is calculated or likely to produce death or great bodily harm. 
    Foreseeable refers to that which ordinarily would be anticipated by a human being of average reasonable intelligence and perception. 
    Property refers to both public and private property movable and immovable and corporeal and incorporeal property. 
    Public officer, public office, public employee or position of public authority means and applies to any executive, ministerial, administrative, judicial or legislative officer, office, employee or position of authority respectively, of the State of Louisiana or any parish, municipality, district or other political subdivision. Unless otherwise specified, local references are to those who function in the city. 
    Public place . The term "public place" shall mean any place open to and accessible to the general public. 
    Real property shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    State means the State of Louisiana, or any parish, municipality, district or other political subdivision thereof, or any agency, board, commission, department or institution of said state, parish, municipality, district or other political subdivision thereof. 
    Whoever in a penalty clause refers only to natural persons insofar as imprisonment is provided, but insofar as a fine may be imposed "whoever" in a penalty clause refers to any person. 
(Ord. No. 7450, 10-26-82) 
Editor's note- Only those definitions given in the amendment of  12-1 by Ord. No. 7450 which are not duplicative of definitions given in  1-2 of this Code have been included in  12-1. 
Cross reference- Additional definitions applicable,  1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:2. 
Sec. 12-2. - Interpretation. 
    The provisions of this chapter cannot be extended by analogy so as to create crimes not provided for herein; however, in order to promote justice and to effect the objects of the law, all of its provisions shall be given a genuine construction, according to the fair import of their words, taken in their usual sense, in connection with the context, and with reference to the purpose of the provision. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:3. 
Sec. 12-3. - Civil remedies not affected. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall affect any civil remedy provided by the law pertaining to civil matters, or any legal power to inflict penalties for contempt. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:6. 
Sec. 12-4. - Seizure and disposition of evidence. 
(a)  Any evidence, property or paraphernalia seized as the result of a criminal investigation which does not result in an immediate arrest and wherein a warrant is advised by the investigating agency shall be returned to the party from whom it was seized, provided of course that he has legal right of possession thereto or is the legal owner thereof, at the expiration of thirty (30) days from the date of said seizure, if within said thirty (30) days the complainant has not applied for a warrant for the arrest of the suspected culprit in that matter. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed so as to prevent the seizing authority from, in its discretion, returning the object of seizure prior to the elapse of the above mentioned thirty (30) days. 
(c)  Upon conviction of a person for the crime of gambling, the evidence, property, and paraphernalia seized as instruments of such crime shall, upon order of the court, be destroyed when it is no longer needed as evidence and all such evidence, property, and paraphernalia found to be in use in the conduct of such unlawful activity and having a value for lawful purposes, shall be sold under the orders of the court at the public auction by a duly licensed auctioneer and the proceeds paid to the court. Upon conviction, as aforesaid, any monies and other things of value, except as herein provided, shall be transferred to the city's general fund. 
(Ord. No. 7205, 11-11-80) 
Secs. 12-5-12-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ELEMENTS OF CRIME 

Sec. 12-16. - Crime defined. 
    A crime is that conduct which is defined as criminal in this chapter. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:7. 
Sec. 12-17. - Criminal conduct. 
    Criminal conduct consists of: 
(1)  An act or a failure to act that produces criminal consequences, and which is combined with criminal intent; or 
(2)  A mere act or failure to act that produces criminal consequences, where there is no requirement of criminal intent; or 
(3)  Criminal negligence that produces criminal consequences. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:8. 
Sec. 12-18. - Criminal consequences. 
    Criminal consequences are any set of consequences prescribed in the various articles of this chapter as necessary to constitute any of the various crimes defined herein. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:9. 
Sec. 12-19. - Criminal intent. 
    Criminal intent may be specific or general: 
(1)  Specific criminal intent is that state of mind which exists when the circumstances indicate that the offender actively desired the prescribed criminal consequences to follow his act or failure to act. 
(2)  General criminal intent is present whenever there is specific intent, and also when the circumstances indicate that the offender, in the ordinary course of human experience, must have adverted to the prescribed criminal consequences as reasonably certain to result from his act or failure to act. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:10. 
Sec. 12-20. - Criminal intent; how expressed. 
    The definitions of some crimes require a specific criminal intent, while in others no intent is required. Some crimes consist merely of criminal negligence that produces criminal consequences. However, in the absence of qualifying provisions, the terms "intent" and "intentional" have reference to "general criminal intent." 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:11. 
Sec. 12-21. - Criminal negligence. 
    Criminal negligence exists when, although neither specific nor general criminal intent is present, there is such disregard of the interest of others that the offender's conduct amounts to a gross deviation below the standard of care expected to be maintained by a reasonably careful man under like circumstances. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:12. 
Secs. 12-22-12-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CULPABILITY 

Sec. 12-31. - Insanity. 
    If the circumstances indicate that because of a mental disease or mental defect, the offender was incapable of distinguishing between right and wrong with reference to the conduct in question, the offender shall be exempt from criminal responsibility. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:14. 
Sec. 12-32. - Intoxication. 
    The fact of any intoxicated or drugged condition of the offender at the time of the commission of the crime is immaterial except as follows: 
(1)  Where the production of the intoxication or drugged condition has been involuntary, and the circumstances indicate this condition is the direct cause of the commission of the crime, the offender is exempt from criminal responsibility. 
(2)  Where the circumstances indicate that an intoxicated or drugged condition has precluded the presence of a specific criminal intent or of special knowledge required in a particular crime, this fact constitutes a defense to a prosecution for that crime. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:15. 
Sec. 12-33. - Mistake of fact. 
    Unless there is a provision to the contrary in the definition of a crime, reasonable ignorance of fact or mistake of fact which precludes the presence of any mental element required in that crime is a defense to any prosecution for that crime. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:16. 
Sec. 12-34. - Mistake of law. 
    Ignorance of the provisions of this chapter is not a defense to any criminal prosecution. However, mistake of law which results in the lack of an intention that consequences which are criminal shall follow, is a defense to a criminal prosecution under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Where the offender reasonably relied on an act of this city in repealing an existing criminal provision, or in otherwise purporting to make the offender's conduct lawful; or 
(2)  Where the offender reasonably relied on a final judgment of a competent court of last resort that a provision making the conduct in question criminal was unconstitutional. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:17. 
Sec. 12-35. - Justification generally. 
    The fact that an offender's conduct is justifiable, although otherwise criminal, shall constitute a defense to prosecution for any crime based on that conduct. This defense of justification can be claimed under the following circumstances: 
(1)  When the offender's conduct is an apparently authorized and reasonable fulfillment of any duties of public office; or 
(2)  When the offender's conduct is a reasonable accomplishment of an arrest which is lawful under the laws of the state or of this chapter; or 
(3)  When for any reason the offender's conduct is authorized by law; or 
(4)  When the offender's conduct is reasonable discipline of minors by their parents, tutors or teachers; or 
(5)  When the crime consists of a failure to perform an affirmative duty and the failure to perform is caused by physical impossibility; or 
(6)  When any crime is committed through the compulsion of threats by another of death or great bodily harm, and the offender reasonably believes the person making the threats is present and would immediately carry out the threats if the crime were not committed; or 
(7)  When the offender's conduct is in defense of persons or of property under any of the circumstances described in Articles 19 through 22 of the Louisiana Criminal Code. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:18. 
Sec. 12-36. - Use of force or violence in defense. 
    The use of force or violence upon the person of another is justifiable, when committed for the purpose of preventing a forcible offense against the person or a forcible offense or trespass against property in a person's lawful possession; provided that the force or violence used must be reasonable and apparently necessary to prevent such offense and that this article shall not apply where the force or violence results in a homicide. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:19. 
Sec. 12-37. - Aggressor cannot claim self defense. 
    A person who is the aggressor or who brings on a difficulty cannot claim the right of self-defense unless he withdraws from the conflict in good faith in such a manner that his adversary knows or should know that he desires to withdraw and discontinue the conflict. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:21. 
Sec. 12-38. - Defense of others. 
    It is justifiable to use force or violence in the defense of another person when it is reasonably apparent that the person attacked could have justifiably used such means himself, and when it is reasonably believed that such intervention is necessary to protect the other person. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:22. 
Sec. 12-39. - Principals. 
    All persons concerned in the commission of a crime, whether present or absent, and whether they directly commit the act constituting the offense, aid and abet in its commission, or directly or indirectly counsel or procure another to commit the crime, are principals and are guilty of a crime. 
(Ord. No. 7121, 12-26-79) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:24. 
Secs. 12-40-12-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - INCHOATE OFFENSES 

Sec. 12-51. - Conspiracy. 
(a)  Criminal conspiracy is the agreement or combination of two (2) or more persons for the specific purpose of committing any crime; provided that an agreement or combination to commit a crime shall not amount to a criminal conspiracy unless, in addition to such agreement or combination, one or more of such parties does an act in furtherance of the object of the agreement or combination. 
    If the intended basic crime has been consummated, the conspirators may be tried for either the conspiracy or the completed offense, and a conviction for one shall not bar prosecution for the other. 
(b)  Whoever is a party to a criminal conspiracy to commit any other crime shall be fined or imprisoned, or both, in the same manner as for the offense contemplated by the conspirators; but such fine or imprisonment shall not exceed one-half of the largest fine, or one-half the longest term of imprisonment prescribed for such offense, or both. 
(Ord. No. 7121, 12-26-79) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:26. 
Sec. 12-52. - Attempt. 
(a)  Any person, who, having a specific intent to commit a crime, does or commits an act for the purpose of and tending directly toward the accomplishing of his object is guilty of an attempt to commit the offense intended; and it shall be immaterial whether, under the circumstances, he would have actually accomplished his purpose. 
(b)  Mere preparation to commit a crime shall not be sufficient to constitute an attempt; but lying in wait with a dangerous weapon with the intent to commit a crime, or searching for the intended victim with a dangerous weapon with the intent to commit a crime, shall be sufficient to constitute an attempt to commit the offense intended. 
(c)  An attempt is a separate but lesser grade of the intended crime; and any person may be convicted of an attempt to commit a crime, although it appears on the trial that the crime intended or attempted was actually perpetrated by such person in pursuance of such attempt. 
(d)  Whosoever attempts to commit any crime shall be fined or imprisoned, or both, in the same manner as for the offense attempted; but such fine or imprisonment shall not exceed one-half of the largest fine or one-half of the longest imprisonment prescribed for the offense or attempted, or both. 
(Code 1958,  10-4.1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:27. 
Secs. 12-53-12-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PERSON 

Sec. 12-61. - Simple battery. 
(a)  Defined. Battery is the intentional use of force or violence upon the person of another or the intentional administration of poison or other noxious liquid or substance to another. 
(b)  Declared unlawful. It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the crime of simple battery. Simple battery is a battery, without the consent of the victim, and committed without a dangerous weapon. 
(Ord. No. 7450, 10-26-82) 
Editor's note- Section 12-61 formerly defined "battery" and was derived from Code 1958,  10-6. 
State Law reference- "Battery" defined, R.S. 14:33; simple battery, R.S. 14:35. 
Sec. 12-62. - Simple battery on police officer. 
(a)  Declared unlawful. It shall be unlawful to commit a simple battery upon a police officer. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Battery. Battery is the intentional use of force or violence upon a police officer while in the process of carrying out, or attempting to carry out his official duties; or the intentional administration of poison or other noxious liquid or substance to said officer. 
(2)  Simple battery upon a police officer. Simple battery upon a police officer is a battery without the consent of said officer and committed without a dangerous weapon. 
(Ord. No. 7450, 10-26-82) 
Editor's note- Section 12-62 formerly defined "simple battery" and was derived from Code 1958,  10-6. 
State Law reference- Battery of a police officer, R.S. 14:34.2; simple battery, R.S. 14:35. 
Sec. 12-63. - Simple assault. 
    Assault is an attempt to commit a battery, or the intentional placing of another in reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery. It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the crime of simple assault. Simple assault is an assault committed without a dangerous weapon. 
(Ord. No. 7450, 10-26-82) 
Editor's note- Section 12-63 formerly defined "assault" and was derived from Code 1958,  10-3. 
State Law reference- Assault defined, R.S. 14:36; simple assault, R.S. 14:38. 
Sec. 12-64. - Simple assault on police officer. 
    It shall be unlawful to commit an act of simple assault on a police officer. The crime of simple assault on a police officer is an attempt to commit a battery, or the intentional placing of said officer in reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery, while performing his official duties and committed without a dangerous weapon. 
(Ord. No. 7450, 10-26-82) 
Editor's note- Section 12-64 formerly defined "simple assault" and made the act unlawful. The section was formerly derived from Code 1958,  10-3. 
Sec. 12-65. - Aggravated assault. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the crime of aggravated assault. Aggravated assault is an assault committed with a dangerous weapon. 
(Code 1958,  10-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:37. 
Sec. 12-66. - Aggravated assault on police officer. 
    It shall be unlawful to commit an act of aggravated assault on a police officer. The crime of aggravated assault on a police officer is an attempt to commit a battery, or the intentional placing of said officer in reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery while in the process of carrying out or attempting to carry out his official duties and committed with a dangerous weapon. 
(Ord. No. 7450, 10-26-82) 
Editor's note- Section 12-66 formerly dealt with negligent injuring and was derived from Code 1958,  10-43. Negligent injuring is now covered by  12-69. 
Sec. 12-67. - Aggravated battery. 
    It shall be unlawful to commit the offense of aggravated battery. 
    Battery is the intentional use of force or violence upon the person of another; or the intentional administration of a poison or other noxious liquid or substance to another. 
    Aggravated battery is a battery committed with a dangerous weapon. 
(Ord. No. 7450, 10-26-82) 
Editor's note- Section 12-67 formerly dealt with intimidation by officers, which is now covered in  12-70. 
State Law reference- "Battery" defined, R.S. 14:33; aggravated battery, R.S. 14:34. 
Sec. 12-68. - Aggravated battery on police officer. 
    It shall be unlawful to commit an aggravated battery upon a police officer. 
    Battery on a police officer is the intentional use of force upon a police officer while in the process of carrying out or attempting to carry out his official duties, or the intentional administration of poison or other noxious substance to said officer. 
    Aggravated battery on a police officer is a battery on a police officer committed with a dangerous weapon. 
(Ord. No. 7450, 10-26-82) 
Editor's note- Section 12-68 formerly dealt with terrorizing, which is now covered by  12-71. 
Sec. 12-69. - Negligent injuring. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the crime of negligent injuring. Negligent injuring is the infliction of any injury upon the person of another by criminal negligence. 
(Code 1958;  10-43; Ord. No. 7450, 10-26-82) 
Editor's note- Formerly,  12-66. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:39. 
Sec. 12-70. - Intimidation by officers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any officer to commit the crime of intimidation by an officer. 
    Intimidation by officers is the intentional use by any police officer, or other person charged with the custody of parties accused of a crime or violation or a municipal ordinance, of threats, violence or any means of inhuman treatment designed to secure a confession or incriminating statement from the person in custody. 
(Ord. No. 7450, 10-26-82) 
Editor's note- Formerly,  12-67. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:40. 
Sec. 12-71. - Terrorizing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the crime of terrorizing. 
    Terrorizing is the intentional communication of information, known by the offender to be false, that the commission of a crime of violence is imminent or in progress or that a circumstance dangerous to human life exists or is about to exist, and thereby causing any person to be in sustained fear for his or another person's safety; causing evacuation of a building, a public structure, or a facility of transportation; or causing other serious disruption to the public. 
(Ord. No. 7450, 10-26-82) 
Editor's note- Formerly,  12-68. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:40.1. 
Sec. 12-72. - False imprisonment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the crime of false imprisonment. False imprisonment is the intentional confinement or detention of another, without his consent and without proper legal authority. 
(Ord. No. 7121, 12-26-79; Ord. No. 7450, 10-26-82) 
Editor's note- Formerly,  12-69. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:46. 
Sec. 12-73. - Domestic abuse battery. 
(a)  Domestic abuse battery is the international use of force or violence committed by one household member upon the person of another household member without the consent of the victim. 
(b)  For purposes of this section: 
(1)  "Community service activities" as used in this section may include duty in any morgue, coroner's office, or emergency treatment room of a state-operated hospital or other state-operated emergency treatment facility, with the consent of the administrator of the morgue, coroner's office, hospital, or facility. 
(2)  "Household members" means any person of the opposite sex presently living in the same residence or living in the same residence within five (5) years of the occurrence of the domestic abuse battery with the defendant as a spouse, whether married or not. 
(c)  On a first conviction, notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, the offender shall be fined not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and shall be imprisoned for not less than ten (10) days nor more than six (6) months. Imposition or execution of sentence shall not be suspended unless: 
(1)  The offender is placed on probation with a minimum condition that he serve two (2) days in jail and participate in a court-approved abuse prevention program, and the offender shall not own or possess a firearm throughout the entirety of the sentence; or 
(2)  The offender is placed on probation with a minimum condition that he serve two (2) days in jail and participate in court-approved community service activities and participate in a court-approved domestic abuse prevention program, and the offender shall not own or possess a firearm throughout the entirety of the sentence; or 
(d)  On a conviction of a second offense, notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, regardless of whether the second offense occurred before or after the first conviction, the offender shall be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00) and shall be imprisoned for not less than thirty (30) days nor more than six (6) months. At least forty-eight (48) hours of the sentence imposed shall be served without benefit of parole, probation, or suspension of sentence. Imposition or execution of the remainder of the sentence shall not be suspended unless: 
(1)  The offender is placed on probation with a minimum condition that he serve fifteen (15) days in jail and participate in a court-approved domestic abuse prevention program, and the offender shall not own or possess a firearm throughout the entirety of the sentence; or 
(2)  The offender is placed on probation with a minimum condition that he perform thirty (30) eight-hour days of court-approved domestic abuse prevention program, and the offender shall not own or possess a firearm throughout the entirety of the sentence. 
(e)  (1)  For purposes of determining whether a defendant has a prior conviction for violation of this section, a conviction under this section or a conviction under the laws of any state or an ordinance of a municipality, town, or similar political subdivision of another state which prohibits the intentional use of force or violence committed by one household member upon another household member of the opposite sex presently or formerly living in the same residence with the defendant as a spouse, whether married or not, shall constitute a prior conviction. This determination shall be made by the court as a matter of law. 
(2)  For purposes of this section, a prior conviction shall not include a conviction for an offense under this section if committed more than ten (10) years prior to the commission of the crime for which the defendant is being tried, and such conviction shall not be considered in the assessment of penalties hereunder. However, periods of time during which the offender was incarcerated in a penal institution in this or any other state shall be excluded in computing the ten-year period. 
(f)  An offender ordered to participate in a domestic abuse prevention program required by the provisions of this section shall pay the cost incurred in participation in the program. Failure to make such payment shall subject the offender to revocation of probation, unless the court determines that the offender is unable to pay. 
(g)  Any crime of violence, as defined in R.S. 14:2(13), against a person committed by one household member against another household member, shall be designated as an act of domestic violence. 
(h)  If the victim of domestic abuse battery is pregnant and the offender knows that the victim is pregnant at the time of the commission of the offense, the offender shall be required to serve a minimum of thirty (30) days without the benefit of suspension of sentence for a first conviction. Upon a second or subsequent conviction, the offender shall be imprisoned for not less than six (6) months without benefit of suspension of sentence. 
(Ord. No. 10,398, 5-11-04) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:35.3. 
Secs. 12-74-12-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES AFFECTING PROPERTY RIGHTS 

Sec. 12-86. - Criminal damage to property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the crime of criminal damage to property. Criminal damage to property is the intentional damaging of any property of another, without the consent of the owner. 
(b)  The provisions of subsection (a) shall apply only if the value of the property damages is less than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1958,  10-17) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:56. 
Sec. 12-86.1. - Simple arson. 
    It shall be illegal to commit the offense of simple arson. Simple arson is the intentional damaging by any explosive substance or the setting fire to any property of another, without consent of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 7450, 10-26-82) 
State Law reference- Simple arson, R.S. 14:52. 
Sec. 12-87. - Criminal mischief. 
    Criminal mischief is the intentional performance of any of the following acts:
