(Code 1958,  12-16; Ord. No. 7947, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 10,197, 4-9-02; Ord. No. 10,470, 3-22-05; Ord. No. 11,610, 9-8-15; Ord. No. 11,854, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 14-61. - Refund of fees. 
    If no work has been done under an electrical permit, the planning and urban development director, when formally requested in writing, shall recommend to the city council that a refund of seventy-five (75) per cent of the original fee be made, provided, however, the city shall retain not less than two dollars ($2.00) of the fee paid to cover the cost of auditing the fee and preparing the request for refund. 
(Code 1958,  12-12(i)) 
Sec. 14-62. - Term and revocation. 
    Any regular electrical permit shall be valid for six (6) months from the date of issuance unless such time is extended by the planning and urban development director, provided, however, the director shall have the power to revoke any electrical permit at any time if there has been any misrepresentation of facts or any violation of this Code or for any other just cause. 
(Code 1958,  12-12(j)) 
Sec. 14-63. - Transfer. 
    Electrical permits shall not be transferable. 
(Code 1958,  12-12(i)) 
Sec. 14-64. - Certificates of approval. 
(a)  When the planning and urban development director finds an installation to be in conformity with the provisions of this chapter, he shall issue to the person making the installation a certificate of approval, with a duplicate copy for delivery to the owner, authorizing the use of the installation and connection to the supply of electricity and shall give notice to the office of the general superintendent of electrical distribution that such authorization has been made and that such service may be energized. 
(b)  When a certificate of approval is issued authorizing the connection and use of a temporary installation, such certificate shall expire at a time stated therein, and shall be revoked by the director for cause. 
(c)  Permission may be granted authorizing the connection and use of specified portions of an incomplete installation; such preliminary connection may be revoked by the electrical inspector for cause. No certificate of approval shall be issued unless such work and materials are found to conform with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1958,  12-14) 
Sec. 14-65. - Exemptions. 
(a)  No permit shall be required for the replacement or repair of toggle switches, fuses, lamp sockets, lamps, fluorescent starters, extension cords, or individual units of neon tubing. No permit shall be required for the installation, repair, or alteration of electrical equipment for the operation of signals or for the transmission of intelligence by wire by a communication agency. 
(b)  No permit fees shall be required for the installation, alteration, or repair of electrical equipment installed by or for the city acting as an electrical supply agency for the use of same in the generation, transmission or distribution of electricity. 
(Code 1958,  12-11, 12-12(e)) 
Secs. 14-66-14-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TECHNICAL STANDARDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Building codes, R.S. 33:4771 et seq.;state uniform construction code, R.S. 40:1730.21 et seq. 

Sec. 14-76. - Generally. 
(a)  All electrical work shall be in strict conformance with this chapter, the statutes of the state and the rules and regulations issued under the authority of the statutes, and shall conform to approved standards of construction for the safety of life and property. 
(b)  The National Electrical Code, 2008 Edition, as copyrighted by the National Fire Protection Association, is hereby adopted and incorporated herein as fully as if set out at length. A copy of such code is on file in the office of the clerk of the council of the city. The provisions of the National Electrical Code, 2008 Edition, shall be the standards for all electrical installations, equipment and appliances in the city, except where such code is inconsistent with this Code or applicable statutes, in which case this Code or such statutes shall govern. Conformity of installations of electrical equipment with applicable provisions of the National Electrical Code adopted herein shall be prima facie evidence that such installations are reasonably safe to persons and property. The electrical inspector may authorize the installation of special wiring methods. 
(c)  No electrical apparatus, fittings or material shall be used or placed on sale unless such apparatus, fittings or material is approved by the planning and urban development director as complying the safety requirements of this Code; provided, however, the approval or the appearance of the label of the Underwriters' Laboratories Inc., shall be deemed prima facie evidence to satisfy the requirements of this Code, and the planning and urban development director is authorized to approve such equipment without requiring further tests thereof. 
(Code 1958,  12-19; Ord. No. 7226, 12-23-80; Ord. No. 7683, 5-8-84; Ord. No. 9578, 3-26-96; Ord. No. 10,558, 1-24-06; Ord. No. 11,028, 2-23-10) 
Charter reference- Adoption of technical codes by reference,  2-15. 
State Law reference- Adoption of technical codes by reference, R.S. 33:1368 et seq. 
Sec. 14-77. - Workmanship generally. 
    All electrical work shall satisfactorily fulfill the purpose for which it is installed and shall be executed in a neat workmanlike manner. Slipshod work or work not executed in keeping with good electrical practice shall be classed as defective and shall not be approved. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(4)) 
Sec. 14-78. - Ascertainment of proper standards for existing work. 
    Electrical contractors and/or electrical sign manufacturers making extensions or additions to existing electrical systems shall, before proceeding with such work, ascertain from the planning and urban development director whether any or all of the existing installation shall be brought up to the requirements of this Code. 
(Code 1958,  12-12(f)) 
Sec. 14-79. - Service entrance in rigid metal conduit. 
    All service entrances shall be installed in rigid metal conduit and shall be located on the ground floor of any building; provided, however, in any case where this location is found to be impractical the planning and urban development director shall designate an alternate location. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(5)) 
Sec. 14-80. - Main disconnect. 
(a)  A main disconnect shall be installed in the service conductors of a building and shall be of ample size. Such device shall simultaneously disconnect all ungrounded conductors. This subsection shall apply to all services up to and including four hundred (400) amperes. 
(b)  Services larger than four hundred (400) amperes shall conform to the requirements of section 230-70 of the National Electrical Code. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(6)) 
Sec. 14-81. - Point of connection for overhead service. 
    The point of connection for overhead service shall be of sufficient height to clear anticipated traffic or contact between a person and ground. In general, the height shall not be less than ten (10) feet nor more than twenty-five (25) feet, provided, however, in exceptional cases the connection height may be designated by the electrical inspection. In all cases the point of connection shall be located at the point nearest the pole from which the service is to be made. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(7)) 
Sec. 14-82. - Underground services conduit. 
    All underground services shall be installed in galvanized rigid conduit not less than one inch and shall extend up the pole to a location close to secondary service wire or to a point designated by the planning and urban development director. In downtown business district where served by network system, service will be run to a point designated by the planning and urban development director for best connection by the electrical distribution system. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(8)) 
Sec. 14-83. - Size of service conductor. 
    No service conductor shall be smaller than number eight (8) copper or aluminum equivalent, and no entrance safety switch shall be less than thirty (30) amperes in capacity. Such switch shall not be located in any inaccessible place. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(9)) 
Sec. 14-84. - Meter location. 
    All electric meters shall be installed so as to be accessible to meter readers at all times. No meter shall be installed inside a residence; and no meter and/or metering equipment shall be installed inside a business occupancy except at the direction of the planning and urban development director. Should any meter be rendered inaccessible by future construction, such meter shall be moved by the owner or occupant to a location decided upon by the director. Buildings located on a single property under one ownership shall be supplied through one meter, except: 
(a)  Buildings of multiple occupancy may have a separate meter for each occupant. 
(b)  Where additional or special services are required for different classes of use, additional meters may be used if approved by the director. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(10)) 
Sec. 14-85. - Conduit for wire in fire district. 
    Any installation of electrical equipment in or on any building or premises located within the fire district, as defined by ordinance, shall be wired with rigid metal conduit or electrical metallic tubing and fittings approved for such, except private residences containing not more than two (2) apartments. All conduit or metallic tubing shall be secured in place by approved straps or hangers in such a manner that it will be permanently rigid. Nails may be used in conjunction with two-hole type straps only, and when such straps are attached to wood portions of the building. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(11)) 
Cross reference- Fire districts,  9-1. 
Sec. 14-86. - Installation in places of public assemblage. 
    Any building or premises, regardless of location with respect to the fire district, used as a place of business, church, school, auditorium, theater, or for any other use that assembles large gatherings of persons or public gatherings, shall have all electrical equipment installed in compliance with this Code, and Section 1584 of Title 40 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(12)) 
Cross reference- Fire districts,  9-1. 
Sec. 14-87. - Wiring in residence outside fire district. 
    Any building located outside the fire district and within a residence district as specified in the zoning ordinances, if the same is used or to be used for a one-family, two-family or multiple-family dwelling, or for an accessory use thereto, and if such building does not contain any nonconforming use, may be wired with nonmetallic sheathed cable, knob and tube type, or any type wiring approved for such occupancy by the National Electrical Code, except in no case shall BX cable be approved. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(14)) 
Cross reference- Fire districts,  9-1; zoning, Ch. 37. 
Sec. 14-88. - Size of conductors. 
    All electrical conductors governed by the provisions of this chapter shall be of sufficient size that the drop in voltage shall not be greater than three (3) per cent below that of the voltage supplied at the point of service. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(15)) 
Sec. 14-89. - Circuits in fire district. 
    Within the boundaries of the fire district not more than eight (8) current-consuming outlets shall be installed on any one branch circuit, except on circuits used exclusively for "strip light" fluorescent lighting and provided the fixtures are butted together in one continuous length. In the case of such fluorescent lighting the connected load shall be computed in amperes as designated on the ballast of each unit and the wire size shall be governed accordingly. However, within the fire district no conductor installed as a branch circuit for lights or power shall be smaller than number 12 gauge and no one lighting circuit shall have a combined load of more than two thousand (2,000) watts. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(16)) 
Cross reference- Fire districts,  9-1. 
Sec. 14-90. - Circuits outside fire district. 
    Outside of the fire district no branch circuit shall contain more than eight (8) current-consuming outlets. However, number 14 gauge wire will be permitted for switch legs, all other lighting circuits will be wired in number 12 wire. All circuits for convenience outlet receptacles shall be number 12 gauge or larger conductors. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(17)) 
Cross reference- Fire districts,  9-1. 
Sec. 14-91. - Drop cords from ceilings. 
    Drop cords from ceilings in residence will be permitted when seven and one-half (71/2) feet or more from the door and controlled by a wall switch, however, pull chain receptacles may be used in any room except bathrooms where such fixtures must be controlled by a wall switch. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(18)) 
Sec. 14-92. - Flexible cord lighting. 
    Flexible cord lighting may be used in garages, machine shops and similar locations for bench work, trouble lights, etc., provided the conductors are not smaller than number 16 gauge and a porcelain or other nonconductor type socket is used. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(19)) 
Sec. 14-93. - Joints and splices. 
    All joints or splices shall be soldered or made with suitable connectors approved by the Underwriters' Laboratories for this purpose. Wire nuts will not be permitted as a means of connection except at fixtures and then only when one solid conductor from the branch circuit is connected to the fixture wire. 
(Code 1958,  12-19) 
Sec. 14-94. - Headers and other wood supports for outlet boxes. 
    Headers or other wood supports for outlet boxes shall be a minimum of two (2) inches by four (4) inches and all boxes shall be securely fastened to such supports. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(21)) 
Sec. 14-95. - Distribution centers, etc. 
    Any and all switches, panelboards, control boards, or distribution centers or similar equipment of any and all types shall be completely dead front equipment, or shall be externally operative safety switches. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(22)) 
Sec. 14-96. - Wire service for heavy loads. 
    All commercial and industrial installations, and all residence installations having a connected load of two thousand (2,000) watts or more shall be served by a three-wire service and shall have not less than fifty (50) ampere current limiting main disconnecting device on such installations of eight hundred (800) square feet or more of floor area. The main service device shall be of one hundred (100) ampere capacity and the load on such services shall be balanced. Network voltage in the business district shall be 125/216, three-phase, four-wire. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(23)) 
Sec. 14-97. - Circuit and conductors for attic ventilation. 
    A separate circuit shall be provided for attic ventilation equipment and/or each air conditioner unit, and the conductors shall not be smaller than number 12 gauge. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(24)) 
Sec. 14-98. - Furnishing and location of meter equipment. 
    The current-supplying agency shall furnish the necessary meter socket and metering equipment for any installation to which it furnishes electrical current. Installations having more than one meter shall have each tagged, giving the street or apartment number it serves. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(25)) 
Sec. 14-99. - Outside signs and displays. 
    Outside signs and displays shall comply with the following: 
(a)  All electrical signs extending over the sidewalk shall be erected with a minimum sidewalk clearance of ten (10) feet from the lowest point of the sign to the sidewalk and shall not extend from the building past a point eighteen (18) inches inside the curb line up to a point fourteen (14) feet above the sidewalk; but any portion of the sign which is fourteen (14) feet or more above the sidewalk may extend to the curb line, but not beyond it, provided the sign is a safe distance from utility wires. Underwriters' Laboratories label on such electrical sign or display shall be prima facie evidence of acceptability of such sign or display at the option of the planning and urban development director. The support means of any electrical sign shall be adequate and subject to the approval of the director. All electrical signs shall be connected to a separate circuit or circuits installed in conduit or electrical metallic tubing and not more than thirteen hundred and twenty (1,320) watts shall be allowed on each circuit, provided, however, portable signs with self-contained transformers, and window displays with transformers designed for such, not exceeding two hundred and twenty-five (225) watts may be plugged into suitable receptacles. 
(b)  Lighting reflectors for the illumination of a building or sign board shall not project more than eight (8) feet beyond the building line. 
(c)  When upon inspection or reinspection any sign is found to be in dangerous or unsafe condition and the owner or user thereof fails to place such sign in safe condition after being notified to do so by the planning and urban development director within the time limit specified, the director shall remove such sign at the expense of owner or user. 
(d)  Unless a complete sign circuit is installed at the time of roughing in wiring, each commercial building shall be provided with a raceway from panel board through the front wall of the building. 
(e)  Any luminous tube sign or portion thereof within six (6) feet of the ground must have all high tension connections suitably enclosed to prevent accidental contact. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(26)) 
Cross reference- Advertising and signs, Ch. 3; electrical requirements for mobile signs,  3-25. 
Sec. 14-100. - Service conductors. 
    No service conductors shall be installed through attic or other enclosure except as may be specially designated and approved by the planning and urban development director. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(27)) 
Sec. 14-101. - Installation of nonmetallic sheathed cable. 
    All joists or other structural members of residential buildings shall be bored for the installation of any nonmetallic sheathed cable with the exception of buildings with two (2) by four (4) joists or old jobs having a readily accessible attic. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(28)) 
Sec. 14-102. - Temporary services. 
    All temporary services shall be installed on the equivalent of a four (4) by four (4) timber with point of attachment at a minimum of ten (10) feet above the ground, said timber to be substantially braced in three (3) directions. A weatherproof temporary service disconnect and panel, like or similar to Midwest P-71f, shall be used. This disconnect and panel shall not be lower than five (5) feet above the ground and shall be properly grounded to a driven ground. Said temporary service shall be located as near as possible to the permanent point of attachment. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(29)) 
Sec. 14-103. - Installation of meter sockets. 
    Each meter socket installation shall be on the outside of the building, residence or other structure and shall be mounted not more than seven (7) feet nor less than five (5) feet above the level of the standing space. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(30)) 
Sec. 14-104. - Location of fuse panels, circuit breakers, etc. 
    Fuse panels, circuit breakers and the like shall not be placed in hot water closets, bathrooms, clothes closet or any similar place where articles may be stored, thereby hindering accessibility. They shall be located where they are readily accessible to the occupant. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(31)) 
Sec. 14-105. - Installations of motors. 
    All installations of motors over twenty-five (25) horsepower shall have reduced voltage type starting. All installations of motors over five (5) horsepower shall be three-phase except by special permission when conditions may warrant. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(32)) 
Sec. 14-106. - Termination at point of attachment of service conductor. 
    The property owner shall provide at the point of attachment of the service conductor to the building or any other structure a means of termination. Porcelain screw knobs will not be acceptable. Such point of termination shall conform to Article 230 of the National Electrical Code. Pipe for service mast shall not be less than one and one-quarter (11/4) inches in diameter. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(33)) 
Secs. 14-107-14-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONTRACTORS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate electricians, R.S. 33:4782. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-121. - Mechanics generally. 
    Electrical contractors and/or electrical sign manufacturers shall have competent journeymen mechanics for all jobs. 
(Code 1958,  12-19(4)) 
Sec. 14-122. - Special provisions for firms, corporations, etc.; registration of firm and licensee. 
(a)  A corporation, partnership, or other legal entity (hereinafter referred to as a "firm," whether it be a corporation, partnership, or other legal entity) or an individual shall act as an electrical contractor or electrical sign manufacturer, only if: 
(1)  A full time officer, employee or partner of the firm or individual who is actively engaged in the electrical contracting work or electrical sign manufacturing work of such firm or individual holds a city electrical contractor's license certificate (general or residential) or city electrical sign manufacturer's license certificate, or both, as appropriate; 
(2)  Both such firm or individual and the individual holding the license certificate have signed a registration certificate which shall be provided by the planning and urban development director and maintained on file in its office stipulating that such individual or firm may do electrical contracting work (general, or residential only, depending on the licensee's certificate) or electrical sign manufacturing work in the city under the licensee's supervision; 
(3)  The licensee named in the registration has not filed with the director, or if he has filed he has withdrawn, any other registration which stipulates that any other individual or firm may do electrical contracting work under his supervision. 
(b)  A person desiring registration shall make application to the electrical inspector upon a form provided by the planning and urban development director. The form shall be accompanied by the required fee. 
(c)  Any person seeking a registration certificate shall pay the same fifty dollars ($50.00) initial fee, and thereafter the same twenty-five dollars ($25.00) annual renewal fee, as is provided for a licensee doing the same type of work, and shall be entitled to engage in the same type of business as the licensee signing his or its registration certificate. A registration certificate shall remain in effect, so long as the annual fees are paid timely, until revoked by either the licensee or the registrant or until the licensee on such registration certificate no longer holds a valid license certificate from the city. 
(Code 1958,  12-9(b), (2)) 
Sec. 14-123. - List of employees. 
    Each licensee or registrant hereunder shall furnish the planning and urban development director a list, certified to be correct, of his full time employees engaged in the electrical contracting or electrical sign manufacturing business prior to the issuance of his license or registration certificate, and annually thereafter upon and as a prerequisite to the renewal of such license or registration certificate. The licensee or registrant filing such list shall promptly notify the planning and urban development director, between the annually required list filings, of any changes which should be made in the last list filed by such person because of employees leaving or joining such licensee or registrant. 
(Code 1958,  12-9(i)) 
Sec. 14-124. - Vehicles. 
    All vehicles of licensees and registrants hereunder doing electrical contracting or electrical sign manufacturing work shall be properly identified with the name of the licensee or registrant, as appropriate, and with his license certificate number or registration certificate number, as appropriate. Such identification shall be placed on both sides of each vehicle in letters and figures at least one and one-half (11/2) inches high, shall be of permanent design and shall be maintained in a legible condition at all times. 
(Code 1958,  12-9(j)) 
Sec. 14-125. - Unauthorized use of license or registration certificate. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee or registrant to allow any other person to use the license or registration certificate of such licensee or registrant for the purpose of obtaining a permit or executing any work covered by the provisions of this chapter. If proof of such action be submitted to the city electrical board, the board, after a fair and impartial hearing as more fully provided for hereinafter, shall instruct the planning and urban development director to suspend or revoke the license or registration certificate of such licensee or registrant, and the planning and urban development director shall act accordingly. During any such period of suspension or revocation all work in progress or for which permits have been granted under such license or registration certificate shall cease and shall not be resumed until after the period of suspension has elapsed or until such person has obtained a new license or registration certificate. 
(Code 1958,  12-9(1)) 
Sec. 14-126. - Revocation and suspension of license and registration certificates. 
(a)  The city electrical board shall have the right to suspend or revoke any license or registration certificate required herein when the licensee or registrant has violated any provisions of this chapter. Before such license or registration can be revoked or suspended for more than thirty (30) days: 
(1)  Notice of the particular charge or charges must be given, in writing, to the licensee or registrant; 
(2)  A public hearing must be held; 
(3)  The licensee or registrant must be given an opportunity to answer the charges and to offer any evidence, written or oral, on such charges. 
The licensee or registrant shall have the right to be represented by an attorney of his own choice and the right to cross-examine any witnesses. The examiner or the secretary of the committee or board shall have the right to summon witnesses and to have their testimony recorded. 
(b)  When it deems such action necessary for the protection of the public the board shall have the right to suspend any license or registration certificate for a period not in excess of thirty (30) days without a prior hearing, but, within such time and as soon as can be reasonably held, a hearing shall be scheduled by the board to consider the suspension or revocation of the license or registration certificate, as the case may be, of the person affected by such suspension. 
(c)  When a license or registration certificate has been revoked by the board, the planning and urban development director shall not issue a new license or registration certificate to the affected person until after the expiration of one year from the date of the revocation. 
(d)  The director shall have the authority to suspend any license granted under the provisions of this chapter if it is discovered that any of the provisions of this chapter have been violated by the person holding such license. Such suspension shall be for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days and during such suspension all work, either in progress or for which permits have been issued, shall cease and shall not be resumed until after such period of suspension has lapsed. 
(e)  Prior to the issuance of a new license or registration certificate to the person affected by the revocation, a new application must be filed by the person desiring to be again licensed or registered and such person must prove his qualifications, pay the requisite fees, and, in the case of a person seeking a license, take the examination herein prescribed. The planning and urban development director shall have the right to consider, in determining whether the applicant should be issued a new license or registration, the previous record of the licensee or registrant in his operations in such capacity, including the facts which gave rise to any suspension or revocation of a certificate issued hereunder to such person. 
(Code 1958,  12-5(e), 12-9(m)) 
Secs. 14-127-14-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Occupational licenses,  14-121 et seq. 

Sec. 14-136. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in any electrical business unless such person holds a license issued by the city to cover such operations. 
(Code 1958,  12-9(b)) 
Sec. 14-137. - Types of license. 
    There shall be three (3) types of electrical licenses issued by the city as follows: 
(1)  Electrical contractor's license (general). This license shall entitle the licensee to engage in the business of installing, removing, altering and repairing electrical equipment of all kinds, except that such license shall not include the right to engage in the manufacture, installation, removal, alteration or repair of any electrical sign, display or outline wiring. 
(2)  Residential electrical contractor's license. This license shall entitle the licensee to engage in the business of installing, removing, altering or repairing electrical equipment only in residential buildings, including single and multifamily residences and apartments, but not including hotels and motels. 
(3)  Electrical sign manufacturer's license. This license shall entitle the licensee to engage in the business of the manufacture, installation, removal, alteration, or repair of electrical signs, displays and/or outline lighting of gaseous tube type on what is known as the secondary or high voltage side of the transformers necessary for the operation thereof. Such license certificate, however, does not entitle the holder to install or connect to the primary or low voltage wiring necessary for the operation of such transformers or other supply circuits, except that portable signs or window displays may be plugged in to a permanently installed suitable receptacle located not more than five (5) feet from the transformer and provided that the portable cord is of sufficient size and of an approved type. 
(Code 1958,  12-9(a)) 
Sec. 14-138. - Application. 
    No person shall engage in any electrical business unless such person holds a license or registration certificate to cover such operations. Any person desiring to engage in any of the electrical businesses described in section 14-137 shall make application to the electrical inspector on the form provided by the inspector for such license or registration; and, in the case of an applicant for license certificate, such person shall request an examination to cover operations. The application shall be accompanied by the fees hereinafter provided. 
    If the applicant seeks a license certificate, the electrical inspector shall set a date to give an examination to determine the qualifications of the applicant. 
(Code 1958,  12-9(b); Ord. No. 7412, 7-13-82) 
Sec. 14-139. - Examination. 
(a)  A written and/or oral examination shall be given to each applicant for a license certificate by the planning and urban development director and the answers to the questions shall be reviewed and properly graded by him. A grade of seventy-five (75) per cent shall be the lowest passing grade. The applicant shall be notified as to the results of the examination within seven (7) days after the examination is taken. The examination shall be given in a fair and impartial manner, and shall cover the field of work that the license certificate is to cover. Any applicant failing to pass the examination shall not be given another examination for a period of six (6) months following his last examination. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided herein no license certificate shall be issued to any person who does not pass such examination. 
(Code 1958,  12-9(c)) 
Sec. 14-140. - Expiration and renewal. 
(a)  A license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be valid, unless revoked or suspended as provided in this chapter, from January 1 through December 31 of each year, and shall expire on December 31 of the year for which it is issued. 
(b)  A valid license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be renewable, without examination, upon payment of the required renewal fee by March 1 of the year following its expiration. 
(Code 1958,  12-9(b), (c)) 
Sec. 14-141. - Fees. 
    The examination fee for a license required by the provisions of this chapter shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) and the original license fee shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Any applicant who fails to qualify for such license shall be refunded the latter fee. The annual renewal fee for a license shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Code 1958,  12-9(c), (d)) 
Sec. 14-142. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9068, adopted May 9, 1989, specifically revoked and deleted former  14-142, which pertained to special provisions for nonresidents and derived from Code 1958,  12-9(b). 
Sec. 14-143. - Personal nature of license. 
    Any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be issued only in the name of the individual who applied for the same. Licenses shall not be issued in the names of corporations or partnerships or in trade names. All licenses shall be personal, nontransferable and nonheritable. 
(Code 1958,  12-9(g)) 
Chapter 15 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Fire department,  4-05. 
Cross reference- Residential requirements for fire civil service board members,  2-76. 
State Law reference- State fire marshal, R.S. 40:1561 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Interfering with firemen at fires. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to in any way interfere, meddle with, or obstruct the firemen in the discharge of their duties at a fire. 
(Code 1958,  13-13) 
State Law reference- Obstructing a fireman, R.S. 14:327. 
Sec. 15-2. - Fire hydrants-Generally. 
(a)  No person other than an authorized city employee or a person possessing a permit from the public works director, shall unscrew or remove any cap from any fire hydrant, or open or close or tamper with any fire hydrant, or cause same to be done. 
(b)  No person shall introduce any foreign object into any fire hydrant, or mutilate or destroy or remove any part thereof, or cause same to be done. 
(c)  No person shall open, close or tamper with any fire hydrant with any other tool or appliance than a special five sided wrench which fits the operating nut of such hydrant, or cause same to be done. 
(d)  No person shall leave any fire hydrant open, or partly open, wasting water, unless he is an authorized city employee. 
(Code 1958,  22-5) 
Sec. 15-3. - Same-Obstructions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or set any telegraph, telephone, electric light or other pole, or any post, column or support of any store, or work or structure of any kind whatsoever, within three (3) feet of any fire plug in the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or plant any trees, shrubs, flowers, or plants of any kind whatsoever within five (5) feet of any fire plug in the city. 
(c)  All poles, posts, columns, supports, works and structures of any kind whatsoever within three (3) feet of any fire plug shall be removed after ten (10) days' notice in writing by the fire chief to the owner of such poles, posts, columns, supports, works or structures, or in case of telegraph or telephone poles, to the agent of the company owning same, and in event of the failure to remove such poles, posts, columns, supports, works or structures after the expiration of the delay of ten (10) days, above provided, the city shall cause them to be removed at the expense of the owner of same. 
(Code 1958,  13-14, 13-15; Ord. No. 7090, 9-25-79) 
Secs. 15-4-15-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 9; obstruction of fire prevention,  12-184; gas code,  17-1. 

Sec. 15-16. - Adopted. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted by the city, for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire and explosions, the following publications, save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, corrected, modified, or amended by this chapter, and except such provisions that conflict with this Code of Ordinances: 
(1)  The NFPA 1-Fire Prevention Code, 2012 Edition; 
(2)  The NFPA 101-Life Safety Code, 2012 Edition. 
(b)  The provisions of the above-named codes are adopted and incorporated as if fully set out at length herein, and a copy of the codes are on file in the office of the clerk of the council. 
(Code 1958,  13-1; Ord. No. 7128, 2-12-80; Ord. No. 7272, 4-28-81; Ord. No. 7944, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 9069, 5-9-89; Ord. No. 9500, 1-24-95; Ord. No. 9797, 4-28-98; Ord. No. 11,161, 3-8-11; Ord. No. 11,607, 8-25-15) 
Charter reference- Adoption of technical codes by reference,  2-15. 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, R.S. 33:1368 et seq. 
Sec. 15-17. - Definitions. 
    Except where the contexts in the above-named publications clearly provide to the contrary, the following rules shall apply: Whenever the word "municipality" is used in the above-named publications, it shall be held to mean the City of Monroe, Louisiana; whenever the words "chief of the bureau of fire prevention" are used in the above-named publications, they shall be held to mean the fire marshal; and whenever the term "corporate counsel" is used in the above-named publications, it shall be held to mean the city attorney. 
(Code 1958,  13-2; Ord. No. 9069, 5-9-89) 
Sec. 15-18. - Bureau of fire prevention. 
(a)  The Fire Prevention Code shall be enforced by the bureau of fire prevention in the fire department of the city, which bureau is hereby established and which shall be operated under the supervision of the fire chief. 
(b)  The chief (or fire marshal) in charge of the bureau of fire prevention shall be appointed by the chief of the fire department subject to approval by the mayor and the municipal fire and police civil service board. 
(c)  The chief may detail such members of the fire department as deputy fire marshal as shall from time to time be necessary. 
(Code 1958,  13-6) 
Sec. 15-19. - Amendments. 
(a)  Section 16.75f of the Fire Prevention Code of 1976, as adopted herein, is amended as follows: 
f.  Special Type Dispensers. 
(1)  The dispensing of Class I liquids at a service station available and open to the public by persons other than the service station attendant, shall be allowed, provided there is at least one qualified attendant on duty while the station is open to the public. The attendant's primary function shall be to supervise, observe and control the dispensing of Class I liquids while said liquids are being dispensed. It shall be the responsibility of the attendant to prevent the dispensing of Class I liquids into portable containers not in compliance with Section 16.73e, control sources of ignition, and immediately handle accidental spills and fire extinguishers if needed. 
(b)  Section 28.1 of the Fire Prevention Code of 1976, as adopted hereinabove, is hereby amended as follows: 
(1)  By changing subsection (a) to read as follows: 
"a.  Permit Required. No person shall kindle or maintain any bonfire or rubbish fire or authorize any such fire to be kindled or maintained without a permit or other proper authorization. During construction or demolition of buildings or structures no waste materials or rubbish shall be disposed of by burning." 
(2)  By deleting subsection (b). 
(3)  By relettering subsections (c) and (d) as subsections (b) and (c) respectively. 
(Code 1958,  13-4) 
Sec. 15-20. - Permits for new materials, processes, or occupancies. 
    The council, the fire chief, and the chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies, which shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in the Fire Prevention Code. The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall post such list in a conspicuous place in his office, and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. 
(Code 1958,  13-7) 
Sec. 15-21. - Modifications. 
    The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall have power to modify any of the provisions of the Fire Prevention Code upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided, the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured, and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed and the decision of the chief of the bureau of fire prevention thereon shall be entered upon the records of the department and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Code 1958,  13-3) 
Sec. 15-22. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the fire chief shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a license or permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the Fire Prevention Code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of such code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the chief of the fire department to the council within thirty (30) days from the date of such decision. 
(Code 1958,  13-8) 
Sec. 15-23. - Violations. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the Fire Prevention Code hereby adopted or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the city council, the chief of the fire department, the chief of the fire prevention bureau, or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each such violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in this code. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time; and when not otherwise specified, each ten (10) days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Code 1958,  13-5) 
Chapter 16 - GARBAGE AND TRASH[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Public works department,  4-06. 
Cross reference- Litter, Ch. 21; trash at Forsyth Park West,  25-19. 
State Law reference- Louisiana Solid Waste Management and Resource Recovery Law, R.S. 30: 2151 et seq.; litter control, R.S. 30:2521 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Use of former city dump. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to dump any trash, garbage and refuse at any site that was once designated as a "city dump". "No dumping" signs shall be erected at any site that was once designated as a "city dump". 
(Ord. No. 7169, 9-23-80) 
Secs. 16-2-16-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL REFUSE COLLECTION SERVICE 

Sec. 16-16. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Municipal Refuse Collection Service Ordinance of the City of Monroe, Louisiana." 
(Code 1958,  14-1) 
Sec. 16-17. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. 
    Litter is garbage, refuse or rubbish, as defined herein or as more fully defined in section 21-2 of this Code. 
    Producer is the person, which accumulates refuse within the limits of the city. For the purposes hereof, shopping centers, office buildings and multifamily dwelling complexes shall be considered as single producers. 
    Refuse is all putrescible and nonputrescible waste, solid waste except body waste, including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, leaves, grass cuttings, dead animals, and solid market and industrial waste. 
(Code 1958,  14-1.1; Ord. No. 7251, 3-10-81; Ord. No. 10,814, 6-24-08) 
Sec. 16-18. - Storage. 
    No producer shall place any refuse in any street, alley, boulevard or other public place or upon any private property, whether owned by such producer or not, within the city unless it be in proper containers for collection and approved by the public works director. 
    Every residence or commercial business in the city which has applied for sewer or water service and/or is actually doing business or where persons are residing in a residence/building owned or leased by such persons, or is being leased by another shall have a container or other form of collection which is approved by the director of public works. 
    All commercial(including apartment complexes) shall place their garbage receptacles within the confines of their premises at locations to be approved by the department of public works and, if necessary, behind an enclosure, the size to be determined by the public works director in conjunction with the city code enforcement division. Failure to get approval shall be a violation of this chapter subject to additional collection remedies listed in section 16-20(e). 
(Code 1958,  14-1.2; Ord. No. 7731, 9-25-84; Ord. No. 10,814, 6-24-08) 
Sec. 16-19. - Residential, apartment and small business collections. 
    The following provisions shall be applicable to residential, apartment, and small business refuse collection. 
(1)  The person having authority to control the disposal of refuse collection in any household, apartment, or small business producing less than two (2) cubic yards of refuse per week shall cause all refuse (garbage) collection to be placed only in those receptacles supplied by the city. 
(2)  The city shall retain ownership of all containers which are provided for refuse (garbage) collection. Said containers shall not be removed from the premises. In the event a user changes residence location, he shall notify the city of such address change, and the city will pick up the container from that location. 
(3)  Any container or part thereof provided by the city which becomes lost or stolen shall be replaced by the city and shall be paid for by the users to which the container is assigned. Containers which are damaged through no fault of the city shall be replaced by the city and paid for by the user to which the container is assigned. Garbage pickup service will be suspended until such time a lost, stolen or damaged container is replaced and paid for. 
(4)  It shall be the responsibility of the user to which a container is assigned to maintain his container in a clean, healthy manner, free of obnoxious odors, maggots, insect and rodents, or in any other condition which may render them unhealthy to the environment or the neighborhood. It shall further be the responsibility of the user to which a container is assigned to keep said container in good repair at all times. 
(5)  Receptacles provided by the city shall be placed in the area between the sidewalk and the curb or in an accessible place as near to the street as possible. Containers shall not be placed at the curbside before 4:00 p.m. on the day prior to collection and shall be removed by nightfall on the day of collection. Containers shall also be placed at curbside on the street which the residence using the container fronts on. If this regulation is not adhered to, there will be no refuse pickup for that residence in violation hereof. Exceptions to the above requirements may be granted at the discretion of the public works director for persons with physical limitations which prevent placement of the garbage receptacles at the curb, provided such exception is in writing and provided such exception is approved. 
(6)  Users having containers or receptacles supplied with lid snaps must keep the lid snaps secured and in place at all times. Failure to adhere to this regulation will carry a fine of seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50). 
(7)  Items of refuse that cannot be placed in receptacles provided by the city include poisons, acids, caustic explosives or other dangerous materials, any type of construction materials, paint, paint thinner, kerosene, gasoline, oil or oil filters. In addition, the following nonexclusive items shall not be placed for either trash or garbage collection under any circumstance: furniture (including mattresses), any televisions, stereos, electrical appliances or plumbing fixtures. 
(8)  Leaves and grass cuttings will be picked up by a separate and different truck. Such leaves and grass must be put in bagged containers and placed within six (6) feet of the pavement at the normal location for containers used in garbage pickup and never near a tree, telephone pole, signpost or other obstruction. Tree limbs shall be neatly stacked and shall not exceed four (4) feet in length or six (6) inches in diameter and each limb shall weigh no more than fifty (50) pounds. All other yard waste including vines and small limbs shall be placed in bagged containers. Any items in violation of this section will not be collected by the city and will subject the violator to the additional collection fee set forth in subsection 16-20(e). 
(9)  The city will only pick up trees in residential and commercial areas in situations where they have fallen due to an act of disaster which endangers public health and welfare of the city's citizens. Violations of this section after one warning shall be punishable by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) plus court costs, said fine shall not be subject to suspension or probation. (Warning by the public works department.) 
(10)  Any other violations of this subsection not carrying a specific fine mentioned above will subject the user of a container to a fine of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(11)  There shall be no dumping of any garbage or trash on any public right-of-way, median or boulevard. Any such violation shall subject the violator to in collection/noncompliance fee charged herein or any other civil or criminal penalty allowed by law. 
(Code 1958,  14-1.3(b); Ord. No. 7251, 3-10-81; Ord. No. 7731, 9-25-84; Ord. No. 10,814, 6-24-08) 
Sec. 16-20. - Collection charges. 
(a)  There is hereby levied a service charge to defray the expense of the collection and disposal of all residential refuse, garbage and trash to be assessed and collected promptly from each residence in the city in the amount of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per month per receptacle supplied by the city or approved substitute; provided however that for those residences in which the head of the household is sixty-five (65) years or older, the service charge shall be nine dollars ($9.00) per month per receptacle. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) above, for those residences in which the head of the household is sixty-five (65) years or older and is certified in the SSI Program, the Medi-Caid Program, or the Food Stamp Program (or their successors), the service charge shall be six dollars ($6.00) per month per receptacle. 
(c)  In addition to the service charge set forth in subsections (a) and (b) above, there is hereby levied a rental fee to be assessed and collected promptly from each residence in the city in the amount of one dollar ($1.00) per month per receptacle supplied by the city. 
(d)  All refuse, garbage and trash accumulated in the city by persons, exclusive of residential producers, in quantities of two (2) cubic yards or less a week, shall be collect, conveyed and disposed of by the city, its agents or representatives. There is levied a service charge to defray the expenses of the collection and disposal of such refuse, garbage and trash to be assessed and collected promptly from each such customer receiving service from the city in the amount of twenty-two dollars ($22.00) per receptacle. 
(e)  In addition to any other provision for violation set forth in chapter 21 of this Code, there shall be an additional collection/non compliance fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per residence and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for businesses under the following circumstances, with the collection fee continuing to double for each seven-day period for which the violation is not cured by the resident or business: 
(1)  A violation occurs of the provisions contained herein and/or chapter 21 of this Code. 
a.  The fee charged herein shall be charged to the owner of the residence, the resident or the person under whose name the application for utility services appears for residences or the owner, occupant or person/entity under whose name the application for utility services appears for commercial services; and/or 
b.  The lessor of an apartment complex or residence whose lessees have failed to comply with the provisions of this chapter or those contained in chapter 21 of this Code. Lessor shall include, but not be limited to the resident apartment manager unit or the on unit premises being used as a rental office; and/or 
c.  The owner and/or landlord of property who has allowed or caused personal items from an eviction proceeding or event to be placed at the curbside without the items being placed in containers as set forth in section 16-18 of this chapter. In addition to the collection/noncompliance fee set forth in section 16-20(e) of this chapter, a violation of this provision shall subject the owner/landlord premises where the violation occurs to the inability for water/sewer service until the fee has been paid in full. 
(Code 1958,  14-1.3; Ord. No. 7172, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 9017, 5-12-88; Ord. No. 9822, 7-28-98; Ord. No. 9830, 8-11-98; Ord. No. 10,407, 6-8-04; Ord. No. 10,814, 6-24-08) 
Sec. 16-21. - Collection by producer. 
    All refuse, garbage and trash accumulated in the city by persons in quantities in excess of two (2) cubic yards per week, shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by the producer, his agents or representatives. The city shall not act as the agent or representative of said producer for such purposes and shall not collect refuse, garbage and trash from such producer unless it is necessary to do so in order to protect the public health and safety of the citizens of the city. In such event, the city shall charge the producer for such service at a rate of not less than fifteen dollars ($15.00) per cubic yard of refuse, garbage and trash so collected. All collection under this provision shall be disposed of weekly and any additional charge collected because of a violation of this chapter shall be charged directly to premises through the name of the person/entity who has applied for water, sewage and/or garbage collection services. 
(Code 1958,  14-1.4; Ord. No. 9017, 5-12-88; Ord. No. 10,407, 6-8-04; Ord. No. 10,814, 6-24-08) 
Sec. 16-22. - Collection by actual producer and outside collectors. 
(a)  The actual producers of refuse or the owners of premises upon which refuse is accumulated who desire personally to collect and dispose of such refuse, who have been approved by the director of public works, and persons who desire to dispose of waste material not included in the definition of refuse, and collectors of refuse from outside of the city who desire to haul over the streets of the city shall use a watertight vehicle provided with tight cover and so operated as to prevent offensive odors escaping therefrom or refuse from being blown, dropped or spilled during collection or transit. Any violation in the hauling of such refuse shall cause the violating vehicle to be stopped and not permitted to move forward until the violation has been cured to the approval of the director of public works or a law enforcement official. 
(b)  Disposal of refuse by persons so permitted under the preceding paragraph shall be made outside the city limits unless otherwise specifically authorized by the public works director, who shall also have the authority to make other reasonable regulations concerning individual collection and disposal and relating to the hauling of refuse over city streets for outside collectors. 
(Code 1958,  14-1.5; Ord. No. 10,814, 6-24-08) 
Chapter 17 - GAS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Planning and urban development,  4-08. 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 9; theft of utility services,  12-97; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 15; housing code,  19-16 et seq.; plumbing, Ch. 27; permit to break streets,  31-21. 
State Law reference- Building codes, R.S. 33:4771 et seq.; state uniform construction code, R.S. 40:1730.21 et seq. 

Sec. 17-1. - Standards adopted. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted by the City of Monroe, Louisiana, for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the construction, alteration, removal, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy, location and maintenance of gas piping and gas appliances and equipment within the City of Monroe, Louisiana, the Standard Gas Code-1997 edition, prepared by the Southern Building Code Congress International, Inc. 
(b)  This code is adopted and incorporated herein by reference as fully as if set out at length herein, except such portions as may be in conflict with federal, state, or local law, or which may be specifically deleted and shall be controlling for the construction, alteration, removal, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy, location and maintenance of gas piping and gas appliances and equipment with the City of Monroe, Louisiana. Copies of this code shall be on file in the office of the clerk of the city council of the City of Monroe, Louisiana. 
(Code 1958,  22-42; Ord. No. 9257, 11-26-91; Ord. No. 9501, 1-24-95; Ord. No. 9803, 5-12-98) 
Charter reference- Adoption of technical codes by reference,  2-15. 
State Law reference- Building codes, R.S. 33:4771 et seq.; state uniform construction code, R.S. 40:1730.21 et seq.; adoption by reference authorized, R.S. 33:1368 et seq. 
Sec. 17-2. - Unsafe structures. 
    In any instance in which the planning and urban development director finds that natural gas equipment or fixtures in any premises are in such condition that the health or the safety of the general public or the occupants of the premises, is in danger, it shall be authorized to cause such premises to be immediately vacated and to remain so vacated until the condition or conditions creating the danger are corrected and such danger to the general public or occupants of the premises eliminated. Any person who refuses to obey such an order to vacate premises which the inspector has found to be in dangerous condition as set forth above shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1958,  22-35) 
Sec. 17-3. - Gas permit and fees. 
(a)  No gas piping shall be constructed, reconstructed or repaired within the city, until a permit to do such work shall have first been obtained from the planning and urban development director. The permit application shall be filed on blanks furnished by the planning and urban development director in triplicate, one of which is to be issued to the person applying for the permit, one to the gas company supplying the gas, and one to be retained by the director. 
(b)  For inspection of piping in one building or structure serving not more than fifteen (15) outlets, the plumbing inspector shall charge and collect from the person applying for such inspection the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(c)  Where more than one inspection is required for any reason the director shall charge an additional fee of three dollars ($3.00) each additional inspection, such fee to be turned over to the director of administration. 
(d)  For inspection of floor furnaces, wall furnaces, central heating boilers and furnaces, suspended type unit heaters, duct and attic furnaces, or any other gas fired heating appliance other than a space heater, the director shall charge and collect from the person applying for such inspection the sum of three dollars ($3.00) for each such fixture. 
(e)  For medical gas piping a minimum fee of seventy dollars ($70.00) shall be charged. 
(Code 1958,  22-39; Ord. No. 7252, 3-10-81; Ord. No. 10,197, 4-9-02; Ord. No. 10,470, 3-22-05; Ord. No. 11,610, 9-8-15) 
Sec. 17-4. - Inspections, certificates; tests. 
(a)  When gas house piping has been installed in a building or structure, whether the same be new construction, repairs or extensions, the same must be inspected and tested in the presence of the planning and urban development director and a certificate of inspection issued as herein provided and an inspection tag attached to such piping by such official. 
(b)  When the system of piping and all extensions thereto have been completed and all openings firmly closed, the person installing such piping shall make the test above provided, and if the piping is found tight, shall make application for test to the planning and urban development director. Upon such application the director will inspect the piping and witness the test, and if the piping is found tight and the work done is in accordance with the provisions of this article, then the director shall issue and deliver a certificate in the following form: 
GAS INSPECTION CERTIFICATE No. _____ 
    This is to certify that I have inspected and witnessed the test of the gas piping in _____ 
Building No. _______, ___________ Street, and certify that the same is installed in compliance with City Ordinance. 
_____
Inspector 
Date: ________, 19 _______ . 
 By  _____ 
Gas Fitter 
    Any additional gas piping or outlets installed, after the above certificate has been issued, must be reported for inspection and test in the same manner as pipe originally installed. 
(Code 1958,  22-40) 
Sec. 17-5. - Deciding controversies. 
    The planning and urban development director shall decide all controversies which may arise under this article, and in so doing shall be subject to the control and direction of the council and the attorney. 
(Code 1958,  22-41) 
Chapter 18 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Ambulances, Ch. 5; animals and fowl, Ch. 6; plumbing code, Ch. 27; sewers and drains, Ch. 30; water, Ch. 36. 

Sec. 18-1. - State Sanitary Code adopted. 
    The city hereby adopts the Sanitary Code of the State of Louisiana as prepared and promulgated by the Louisiana State Board of Health in accordance with Act 79 of 1921, as amended, insofar as the same is applicable and does not conflict with the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1958,  15-1) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, R.S. 13:1368 et seq.; Sanitary Code, R.S. 40:11. 
Chapter 18.5 - HISTORICAL PRESERVATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18.5-1. - Creation and delineation of historical districts. 
    The following described three (3) historical districts, to be known as "The Don Juan Filhiol Historical District", "The Henry Bry Historical District" and "The Louis Alexander de Breard Historical District" are hereby created: 
(1)  Don Juan Filhiol Historic District: Beginning at the intersection of Telemaque Street and St. John Street: thence northwesterly along St. John to Oak street; thence northeasterly along Oak Street to Catalpa Street; thence northwesterly along Catalpa to Wood Street; thence northeasterly along Wood Street to South 6 th Street; thence northwesterly along South 6 th Street to DeSiard Street; thence easterly along the Illinois Central Railroad Track to the intersection with the southwesterly extended centerline of Grammont Street; thence northeasterly along said extension and Grammont Street to South 11 th Street; thence northwesterly along South 11 th Street to the intersection of Elysian Fields Road at the southwest corner of the Congregation B'Nai Israel Cemetery; thence easterly down Elysian Fields Road along the southern line of said Cemetery to the intersection of Grammont Street; thence northeasterly along Grammont street to a point even with the southeast corner of the Cemetery; thence northwesterly along the east edge of the Cemetery to the northeast corner of the Cemetery; thence southwesterly along the northern edge of the Cemetery to the northwest corner of the Cemetery and the intersection of Manassas Street; thence northerly along Manassas Street to DeSiard Street; thence northeasterly along DeSiard Street for a distance of approximately 465 feet to a point extended to the centerline of DeSiard where a common property line exist between east 24 feet, Lot 3 and all Lot 5, Filhiol's Second Addition and Lot in Lot 7, frontage 25 feet on north side DeSiard Street, depth 140 feet, Filhiol's Second or Guinea Addition; thence northwesterly along this property line and the property line common to Lot 4 in Filhiol's Second or Guinea Addition, frontage 60 feet on Adams, depth 140 feet and Lot 6, Filhiol's Second or Guinea Addition to the centerline of Adams Street; thence southwesterly along Adam Street to North 6 th Street; thence northwesterly along North 6 th Street to Washington Street; thence southwesterly along Washington Street to Walnut Street; thence northwesterly along Walnut Street to Arkansas Street; thence southwesterly along Arkansas Street to the Centerline of the Ouachita River; thence continuing along the Centerline of the Ouachita River in a southerly direct to a point in the river corresponding to an intersection with Telemaque Street; The historic district designated above shall include all structures, houses, or other buildings facing any of the streets on the perimeter of the area. Note that all boundary lines along the designated traffic routes/streams run down the centerlines of said traffic routes/streams. 
(2)  Henry Bry Historical District. The historical district designated above shall include all structures, houses, or other buildings facing any of the streets on the perimeter of the area.
