(b)  Duration of sale; supplemental license. The application shall specify the proposed period of time over which the sale is to continue, which period shall not exceed three (3) months. If it appears, upon a sworn subsequent application to the director of administration at any time during the three-month period, that all of the goods, described and inventoried in the original application, have not been sold, and if the application is accompanied by an inventory of what remains, a supplemental license, granting authority to continue the sale for a further period of three (3) months, shall be issued by the director of administration upon the same terms and conditions as the original license. 
(Ord. No. 7992,  2, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 20-316. - Issuance; fee. 
    If the director of administration is satisfied from the application that the proposed sale is of the character which applicant desires to conduct and advertise, he shall issue a license, upon the payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), to the person applying, authorizing that person to advertise and conduct a sale of the particular kind mentioned in the application according to the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 7992,  3, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 20-317. - Record of issuance or refusal; record of application; abstract. 
    The director of administration shall endorse upon the application the date of its filing, preserve it as a record of his office, make an abstract of the facts set forth in the application in a book, properly indexed and kept for that purpose, which abstract shall contain the name of the person asking for a license, the nature of the proposed sale, the place where the sale is to be conducted, its duration, the inventory value of the goods to be sold, and a general statement as to where the goods came from, and make in the book a notation as to the issuance or refusal of the license applied for, together with the date of issuance of refusal and endorse on the application the date that the license, as applied for, is granted or refused. The application and abstract shall be prima facie evidence of all statements contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 7992,  4, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 20-318. - Removal of goods; loss of identity. 
    The license required by this article shall be valid only for a sale of the goods inventoried and described in the application for the license, in the manner and at the time and place mentioned and set forth in the application. Any removal of the goods so inventoried and described in the application from the place of sale mentioned in the application, shall cause the goods to lose their identity as an insurance, bankrupt, mortgaged, insolvent's, assignee's, executor's, administrator's, receiver's or trustee's stock of goods, or a damaged stock of goods, and thereafter no license shall be issued for the conducting of a sale of any goods so removed from the place set forth and described in the application, under the provisions of this article, at any other place. 
(Ord. No. 7992,  5, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 20-319. - Prior purchase of additional goods for resale prohibited. 
    No person intending to conduct a going-out-of-business, fire, bankruptcy, or fiduciary sale under the license shall order any goods for the purpose of selling and disposing of the same at the sale, and any unusual purchase and additions to the stock of goods within sixty (60) days prior to the filing of the application for license to conduct the sale mentioned, shall be presumptive evidence that the purchases and additions to stock were made in contemplation of the sale and for the purpose of selling the purchases and additions at the sale. 
(Ord. No. 7992,  6, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 20-320. - Additional goods not to be added during the sale; offense. 
(a)  No person carrying on or conducting a going-out-of-business, fire, bankruptcy or fiduciary sale under this license shall, during the continuance of the sale, add any goods to the stock of goods described and inventoried in his original application, and no goods shall be sold at or during the sale, except the goods described and inventoried in such original application. 
(b)  Each and every addition of goods to the stock of goods described and inventoried in the application, and each sale of the goods not inventoried and described in the application shall constitute a separate offense under this article. 
(Ord. No. 7992,  7, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 20-321. - Compliance required; false advertising; penalty. 
(a)  No person shall advertise, represent or hold out any sale of goods to be a going-out-of-business, fire, bankruptcy or fiduciary without having complied with the provision of this article. 
(b)  Whoever violates this section shall be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned for not less than thirty (30) days nor more than six (6) months, or both. 
(Ord. No. 7992,  8, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 20-322. - Violations; penalty. 
(a)  No person shall hold, conduct or carry on any sale of goods as a going-out-of-business, fire, bankruptcy or fiduciary sale contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Whoever violates any of the provisions of this section shall be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned for not less than three (3) months nor more than six (6) months, or both. 
(Ord. No. 7992,  9, 4-28-87) 
Chapter 21 - LITTER[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10,585, adopted Apr. 25, 2006, amended Ch. 21 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 21,  21-1-21-15, pertained to similar subject matter, and was derived from Code 1958,  14-5 and 24-67, and Ord. No. 7278, adopted May 12, 1981. 
Cross reference- Dropping objects from aircraft,  7-29; garbage and trash, Ch. 16; nuisances, Ch. 24; trash and Forsyth Park West,  25-19. 

Sec. 21-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Monroe Anti-litter Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words used in the plural number include the singular number, and words used in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely discretionary. 
    Authorized private receptacle is a litter storage and collection receptacle as required and authorized in the City of Monroe Code. 
    City is the City of Monroe, Louisiana. 
    Garbage is putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Litter is garbage, refuse, and rubbish, as defined herein, and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. Litter is also any used or unconsumed substance or waste material which has been discarded, whether made of aluminum, glass, plastic, rubber, paper, or other natural or synthetic material, or any combination thereof, including, but not limited to, any bottle, jar or can, or any top, cap or detachable tab of any bottle, jar or can, any unlighted cigarette, cigar, match or any flaming or glowing material or any garbage, trash, 
    Park is a reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other public area in the city, owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Person is any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, organization of any kind or political subdivision of this state subject to municipal jurisdiction. 
    Private premises is any dwelling, house, building, or other structure, designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, or any commercial establishment, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging to or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building, commercial establishment or other structure. 
    Public place is any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds, and buildings. 
    Receptacle is a container suitable for the depositing of litter. 
    Refuse is all solid wastes (except body wastes) liable to decay, spoil or become putrid or solid wastes not liable to decay, spoil or become putrid, including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, and solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish is solid wastes not liable to decay, spoil or become putrid, consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, property and similar materials. 
    Vehicle is every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
    Vessel is a watercraft. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-3. - Litter in public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the city except in public receptacles, in authorized private receptacles for collection, or in official city dumps. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-4. - Placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevent scattering. 
    Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-5. - Sweeping or blowing litter into gutters prohibited. 
    Except when authorized by the city at specified times, no person shall sweep or blow into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-6. - Merchants' duty to keep sidewalks free of litter. 
    No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying places of business within the city shall keep the sidewalk in front of their business premises free of litter. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-7. - Litter thrown by persons in vehicles. 
    No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the city, or upon private property. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-8. - Removal of deposited material. 
(a)  Any person who drops, or permits to be dropped or thrown, upon any highway or upon any other public or private property without the consent of the owner thereof or into or on any waters of this city, from a vehicle, any waste paper, sweepings, ashes, household waste, glass, metal, refuse or rubbish, or any dangerous or detrimental substance shall immediately remove the same or cause it to be removed. 
(b)  Whenever any litter is thrown or discarded or allowed to fall from a vehicle or boat in violation of this chapter, the operator or owner, or both, of the motor vehicle or boat shall also be deemed to have violated this chapter. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, a "person who permits to be dropped or thrown" from a vehicle any of the items described in subsection (a) shall include the driver of the vehicle and the registrant of any vehicle lawfully registered from which any of the items are dropped or thrown, either by the registrant or any person operating, in possession of or present within the vehicle with the permission of the registrant, regardless of the registrant's intent or lack of knowledge with respect to the disposal of such items in violation of this section where the registrant of the vehicle does not, with reasonable certainty, identify the driver of the vehicle at the time the violation occurred. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-9. - Truck loads causing litter. 
    No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-10. - Dumping raw human waste prohibited. 
    Unless otherwise authorized by law or permit, it is unlawful for any person to dump raw human waste from any train, aircraft, motor vehicle or vessel/boat upon the public or private lands or waters of the city. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-11. - Uncovered vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in commercial or for-hire hauling to operate any truck or other vehicle within this city to transport merchandise, litter, trash, or garbage unless the vehicle is covered to prevent its contents from blowing, dropping, fall off or otherwise departing from the vehicle. In addition, any person operating his own truck or other vehicle to transport merchandise, litter, trash or garbage shall take reasonable steps to prevent its contents from blowing dropping, fall off, otherwise departing from the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-12. - Discarding certain items prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, or cause to be placed any junk motor vehicle, old vehicle tire, or inoperative or abandoned household appliance, or part thereof, upon the right-of-way of any public highway, upon any other public or private property which he or she does not own, lease, rent or otherwise control unless it is at a permitted salvage yard, a permitted disposal site, or at the business establishment of a demolisher. Deposit of the aforementioned items on the owner's private property is also prohibited if they become a threat to the aesthetics, safety or public health of the community or become a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-13. - Litter in parks. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city except in public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-14. - Litter in bodies of water. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, stream, or any other body of water in a park or elsewhere within the city. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-15. - Litter on occupied private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-16. - Owner to maintain premises free of litter. 
    The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter. Provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-17. - Litter on vacant lots. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property within the city whether owned by such person or not. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-18. - Posters and temporary signs. 
(a)  It is hereby declared unlawful for any person to drive any nails or tacks into utility poles, trees, fences, sign columns, or building walls. 
(b)  Campaign posters and other temporary notices or signs placed in rights-of-way, alleys, servitudes, on streets or other public property, whether freestanding or attached to existing structures, shall be considered litter. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-19. - Prima facie evidence against drivers. 
    If the throwing, dumping, or depositing of litter was done from a motor vehicle, except a motor bus, it shall be prima facie evidence that the throwing, dumping, or depositing was done by the driver of the motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-20. - Prima facie evidence against violator. 
    If the litter discarded can be identified with a person's name, it shall be prima facie evidence that the throwing, dumping, or depositing was done by the person whose name appears on the litter. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-21. - Rental property. 
    A landlord shall be responsible for any violation occurring at his rental property even when it is caused by his tenants. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-22. - Notice. 
    The city may erect signs containing pertinent portions of this chapter along its public highways, in parks, recreational areas and at other places where persons are to be informed of the existence and content of this law and the penalties for violating its provisions. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-23. - Enforcement. 
    This chapter shall be enforced by the city attorney's office, the code enforcement division, the Monroe Police Department, the public works department, the beautification division and the Monroe City Court. The named enforcement officers are empowered to issue citations to, or, if authorized, to arrest persons violating any provisions of this chapter. All enforcement officers, who are duly authorized, shall serve and execute all warrants, citations and other process issued by the courts in enforcing the provisions of this chapter. In addition, mailing by certified mail of such process to an alleged violator's last place of residence shall be deemed as personal service upon the person charged. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-24. - Disposition of litter citations. 
(a)  The original litter citation shall be signed by the issuing officer, or other duly qualified agent of the city, and shall be processed in accordance with this chapter and such other procedures as may be established and promulgated by the City of Monroe. 
(b)  A litter citation may be dismissed by the city attorney, or his designee, only upon his written statement for good cause shown, which statement shall be made a part of the disposition record thereof. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-25. - Citation as legal demand and prima facie evidence. 
    The original litter citation or any true copy thereof shall constitute an ordinary business record of the city and prima facie evidence of the facts contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-26. - Answering litter citation; failure to answer. 
(a)  A person to whom a litter citation has been issued under this chapter may answer to the same in the manner and within the delays indicated on the citation. An answer may take the form of: 
(1)  Admission of the violation with payment of the scheduled penalty; or 
(2)  Request for administrative review; or 
(3)  Appeal of administrative review findings. 
(b)  If the owner, his agent or the operator fails to appear on or prior to the court date, there shall be assessed additional delinquent penalties, as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-27. - Failure to pay; civil action. 
    Whenever a person charged with a litter violation fails to pay his penalty, the city attorney, or his designee, may file a civil action against the accused violator in the Monroe City Court. Service of process and all other civil procedures and delays shall be followed as in other civil matters before the Monroe City Court. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-28. - Response to citation. 
    The person to whom a litter citation has been issued for a violation of this chapter shall discharge the summons within ten (10) days after the time such notice was issued by delivering or mailing the appropriate sum to the City of Monroe's Tax and Revenue Division at 316 Breard Street or at Post Office Box 123, Monroe, Louisiana 71210. Such payment may be made by cash, money order or personal, business or cashier's checks or credit cards and made payable to the City of Monroe. Payment of the penalty established herein shall operate as a final disposition of the case. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-29. - Citation challenges. 
(a)  Administrative review generally. 
(1)  If the alleged violator wishes to challenge the issued citation, he should request an administrative review, which is conducted by the city attorney, or his designee, who is well-versed in the City of Monroe Litter Code. Said request must be made within three (3) days of receipt of the citation. The purpose of this step is to screen out those citations where the alleged violator is clearly not liable for the citation. 
(2)  If administrative review is requested, the alleged violator will be required to post the penalty amount of his citation and a nonrefundable ten dollar ($10.00) processing fee prior to being scheduled for review. He must submit a written declaration to the city attorney or his designee. Request for administrative review forms will be available at the City of Monroe's Code Enforcement Division. The form must be completed and returned, along with a copy of the citation and any other applicable proof to the office of the City Attorney, Civil Division, at Post Office Box 123, Monroe, Louisiana 71210. Any documentation submitted with the administrative review request form will not be returned nor will copies be provided for the requestor. 
(3)  A self-addressed stamped envelope must also be included for notification of the finding of the review. An accused violator will be notified in writing of the finding(s) of the review. 
(4)  If the alleged violator is found not liable, then his penalty funds will be refunded. If the citation is upheld, the alleged violator may appeal the findings of the review to the Monroe City Court. If he chooses not to appeal, then the penalty amount previously posted will be forfeited. 
(5)  A litter citation may be dismissed if it is determined, after review, it was either factually incorrect or issued in error. 
(b)  Appeal. 
(1)  The final step in the challenge process is an appeal to the civil division of the Monroe City Court. The appeal must be filed at least five (5) days after the findings of the administrative review are completed. 
(2)  The appellant will be responsible for paying any necessary filing fees for the appeal hearing. If he prevails, his posted penalty amount will be refunded. If the citation is upheld, the litter penalty will be forfeited. 
(3)  Litter penalties are to be remitted to the City of Monroe's Taxation and Revenue Division. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-30. - Failure to respond to citation. 
(a)  Any person guilty of violating the provisions of this chapter, unless otherwise stated, shall be subject to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) if paid within ten (10) days from the date of receipt of the citation. However, any person guilty of violating the provisions of this section more than once in any day shall be subject to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each violation, if paid within ten (10) days. 
(b)  If said fine(s) is/are not paid within ten (10) days, then each violation will result in a fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). This amount shall be paid within twenty (20) days from the date of receipt of the citation. 
(c)  Upon the lapse of twenty (20) days, and if payment has not been received by the city, a certified letter will be mailed to the person in violation, notifying said person of a fine increase of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. 
(d)  If the person fails to pay the amount due, or fails to appear in court on or before the scheduled court date, a default judgment may be entered both for the sanction amount and any additional fees, including any imposed collection fees. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-31. - Judgment. 
(a)  Court finding of a litter violation is the same as a personal judgment; therefore, the court can issue garnishments to collect fines and costs. 
(b)  A person against whom a judgment has been rendered may be directed by the court to pick up and remove litter from public property or private property, or both, with prior permission of the legal owner. If the person has no other judgments against him for violation of this chapter, he may be ordered to pick up and remove litter for not less than eight (8) hours but not for more than sixteen (16) hours. Upon the rendering of a second judgment, the person may be ordered to pick up and remove litter for not less than sixteen (16) hours and not more than thirty-two (32) hours. Upon the third and subsequent judgments against said person, he may be ordered to pick up and remove litter for not less than forty (40) hours and not more than eighty (80) hours. The court shall schedule the time to be spent on such activities in such a manner that it does not interfere with the person's employment and does not interfere substantially with the person's family responsibilities or religious obligations. 
(c)  The court should also consider the person's infirmity, if any, or age or other circumstance which would create a hardship. 
Sec. 21-32. - Penalties for violations. 
(a)  Whoever violates the provisions of this chapter shall: 
(1)  Upon first conviction, be fined two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and sentenced to serve eight (8) hours of community service in a litter abatement work program as approved by the court. 
(2)  Upon second conviction, be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00) and sentenced to serve sixteen (16) hours of community service in a litter abatement work program as approved by the court. 
(3)  Upon third or subsequent conviction, be fined one thousand, two hundred fifty dollars ($1,250.00), have his motor vehicle driver's license suspended for one year, and be sentenced to serve eighty (80) hours of community service in a litter abatement work program as approved by the court, or all or any combination of the penalties provided by this chapter. 
(b)  Whoever violates the provisions of this chapter shall pay special court costs of one hundred dollars ($100.00) in lieu of other costs of court and the special court costs shall be disbursed as follows: 
(1)  Twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be paid to the judicial expense fund for the Monroe City Court. 
(2)  Twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be paid to the office of the city prosecutor. 
(3)  Ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid to the clerk of the Monroe City Court. 
(4)  Twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be paid to the Keep Monroe Beautiful, Inc., Fund. 
(5)  Twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be paid to the law enforcement agency that issued the citation. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-33. - Citation. 
    The person shall be cited for the offense by means of a citation, summons, or other means provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-34. - Liability. 
    A person may be found guilty or held liable and fined under this chapter although the commission of the offense did not occur in the presence of a law enforcement officer if the evidence presented to the court establishes that the defendant has committed the offense. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-35. - Occurrence. 
    For the purposes of this section, each occurrence shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-36. - Additional penalties. 
    In addition to penalties otherwise provided, a person convicted or held liable under this chapter shall: 
(1)  Repair or restore property damaged by or pay damages for any damage arising out of the violation of this chapter. 
(2)  Pay all reasonable investigative expenses and costs to the investigative agency or agencies. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-37. - Exemptions. 
    Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary, this chapter shall not apply to any activity by persons owning or operating duly licensed commercial vehicles engaged in the collection and transportation of solid waste, construction, or demolition debris or wood waste, as such terms are defined by the rules and regulations of the Department of Environmental Quality, occurring in the course of servicing scheduled pickup routes pursuant to commercial or local government contracts or en route to an authorized pickup station, transfer station, or disposal facility. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-38. - Burden of proof. 
    In the criminal trial of a person charged with violating this chapter, the alleged violator has the burden of proving that he had the right or authority to dump the litter for which he has been cited. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-39. - Record of violations. 
    It shall be the duty of the City of Monroe Code Enforcement Division to keep account of all violations of the litter regulations contained in this chapter. There shall be shared efforts among the Code Enforcement Division, the Monroe Police Department, the Public Works Department and the Beautification Division of the city to ensure the accuracy of the records of litter violations. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-40. - Adopt-a-Spot Program. 
(a)  The Adopt-a-Spot Program, which has grown out of the "Keep America Beautiful" organization of the 1950's, may be implemented in the city as a leadership opportunity to systematically invite and recognize volunteers for helping the city enhance and maintain its natural beauty and cleanliness. 
(b)  The mayor, or his designee, is authorized to establish, administer and promote an "Adopt-a-Spot" Program, which is promoted by Keep Monroe Beautiful, Inc., whereby businesses and civic organizations agree to maintain certain designated city streets, intersections or designated locations in the city by removing litter, cutting weeds or similar activity for a designated time and under certain standards of participation, to provide for limitations on and/or waiver of liability in favor of the city, its employees, agencies and contractors, and otherwise providing for the establishment, operation and promotion of such voluntary program. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 21-41. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this chapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof. 
(Ord. No. 10,585, 4-25-06) 
Chapter 21.5 - MARSHAL'S OFFICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Police, Ch. 28. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 21.5-1-21.5-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERSONNEL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Personnel system, App. A. 

Sec. 21.5-26. - Incentive pay program. 
(a)  The program herewith established shall be known as the "City Marshal Incentive Pay Program." 
(b)  The objective of the incentive pay program herein established is to raise the educational level of the officers of the city marshal's office in order to assure the continuance of a modern, efficient and effective office. 
(c)  All officers now or hereafter serving on active duty with, and as regular, full-time employees of the city marshal's office shall be eligible to participate in this program. Personnel employed primarily to perform purely clerical or nonenforcement duties, including but not necessarily restricted to the following types of duties or persons: Secretaries, filing clerks, office machine operators, switchboard operators, stenographers, and similar employees of the office shall not be eligible to participate in this program. 
(d)  The new incentive pay program shall commence May 1, 1984. This program shall include all current and new eligible employees of the office subsequent to its enactment, and shall thereafter progress in annual increments upon each anniversary of the employee's employment with the office, as follows: 
(1)  Upon his employment with the eligible office, an employee with one (1) year of college credits (thirty-two (32) semester hours) or more in an approved curriculum shall be paid fifty dollars ($50.00) per month above his base pay. 
(2)  Upon the first anniversary of his employment with the office, an eligible employee with two (2) years of college credits (sixty-four (64) semester hours) or more in an approved curriculum, shall be paid one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month above his base pay. 
(3)  Upon the second anniversary of his employment with the office, an eligible employee with a bachelor's degree in an approved curriculum shall be paid one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per month above his base pay. 
(4)  Upon the third anniversary of his employment with the office, an eligible employee with a master's degree in an approved curriculum shall be paid two hundred dollars ($200.00) per month above his base pay. 
No eligible employee shall be paid more than one (1) of the above categories of incentive pay at the same time. All eligible employees who are now members or who are hereafter employed by the office shall be allowed credit, for purposes of computing incentive pay, for college work completed prior to the initiation of this program and for all college work completed prior to employment by the department if such college work otherwise meets the standards herein specified or authorized to be established by action of the city marshal. 
(e)  An employee must present to the city marshal a transcript from an accredited college which satisfactorily evidences the successful completion of the requisite college work to entitle him to the receipt of incentive pay. At any time that an employee has earned sufficient college credits to entitle him to the receipt of a higher rate of incentive pay, a new transcript must be presented to the city marshal. 
(f)  The college credits for which credit will be allowed in the incentive pay program must be in courses required in an accredited degree curriculum, other than the following degree curriculums: Education, home economics, library science, pharmacy, medical technology, music, and nursing. However, upon petition of an officer, the city marshal is hereby empowered to waive this requirement and allow credit for purposes of this program for one (1) or more courses in the above curriculums. 
(g)  College incentive pay shall be considered for the purposes of calculating pension and relief benefits. Deductions for pension and relief purposes shall be made from the incentive pay of all officers and the city shall appropriate said deductions as the employees' contribution to the pension and relief fund. 
(h)  The city marshal's office is hereby empowered to promulgate such rules as he may deem advisable to provide for proper administration of the city marshal's office incentive pay program so long as such rules do not conflict with the provisions of this section. Such rules may include, but shall not be limited to, provisions concerning what colleges shall be deemed accredited for purposes of this program, what college credits shall be accepted for purposes of this program, what courses shall be and/or shall not be accepted for purposes of this program. 
(i)  In the event any question should arise as to the interpretation of any provision of this section or of any rule promulgated under the authority of this section, the decision of the city attorney as to the correct interpretation thereof shall be final, subject only to the power of the mayor to overrule such decision. 
(Ord. No. 7691, 6-12-84) 
Cross reference- Police incentive pay program,  28-1. 
Sec. 21.5-27. - Supervisory personnel. 
(a)  Supervisors employed in the city marshal's office shall include those individuals who occupy the ranks of sergeant, lieutenant, captain and administrative assistant. There shall be only the above-named supervisory positions in the city marshal's office and there shall be no more than one position allocated for each of the above ranks or classifications at any one time. 
(b)  The salary (base pay) of the individuals employed in the city marshal's office as supervisors, i.e., sergeant, lieutenant, captain and administrative assistant shall be supplemented by the following provisions: 
(1)  Each supervisor of the office employed in the position, grade or class of sergeant shall receive an amount equal to one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month above his/her base pay. 
(2)  Each supervisor of the office employed in the position, grade or class of lieutenant shall receive an amount equal to one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per month above his/her base pay. 
(3)  Each supervisor of the office employed in the position, grade or class of administrative assistant shall receive an amount equal to one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per month above his/her base pay. 
(4)  Each supervisor of the office employed in the position, grade or class of captain shall receive an amount equal to three hundred dollars ($300.00) per month above his/her base pay. 
(c)  The supplemental supervisory pay herein shall be considered for the purposes of calculating pension and relief benefits. 
(Ord. No. 7691, 6-12-84) 
Sec. 21.5-28. - Incentive and supplemental, pay changes. 
(a)  College incentive pay and supplemental supervisory pay shall not be considered as base salary for purposes of raises or other salary increases or adjustment. 
(b)  Any change in the amount of college incentive pay or supplemental supervisory pay established herein shall only be made by an amendment hereto. 
(Ord. No. 7691, 6-12-84) 
Chapter 22 - MONROE AIR-INDUSTRIAL PARK DEVELOPMENT ORDINANCE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9685, adopted Apr. 8, 1997, amended Ch. 22 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 22 derived from the 1958 Code and Ord. No. 7336, adopted Dec. 8, 1981. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Established; description of property. 
    The following described property, situated at the Monroe Regional Airport, City of Monroe, Ouachita Parish, Louisiana, is hereby officially named as the Monroe Air-Industrial Park: 
    A certain tract or parcel of land situated in the Section 34, Township 18 North, Range 4 East and also being a portion of the property depicted on the "Survey of the Monroe Industrial Park" filed in Plat Book 15, page 113 of the Records of Ouachita Parish, Louisiana and being more particularly described as follows, to wit: 
Beginning at the southwest corner of the survey of the Monroe Industrial Park as per plat recorded in Plat Book 15, page 113, of the records of Ouachita Parish, Louisiana; thence North 8;deg; 26;min; 00;sec; East, along the west line of said survey of the Monroe Industrial Park, a distance of 6062.99 feet to the south right-of-way line of the Union Pacific Railroad; thence North 88;deg; 47;min; 42;sec; East, along the south right-of-way line of said Union Pacific Railroad, a distance of 5172.02 feet to the northeast corner of said survey of the Monroe Industrial Park; thence South 5;deg; 09;min; 00;sec; West along the east line of said survey of the Monroe Industrial Park and its projection thereof, (also being along the centerline of Airline Boulevard), a distance of 5030.98 feet to the easterly projection of the south lease line of Fiber Products Corporation; thence North 84;deg; 53;min; 18;sec; West, along the projection of and the south line of said Fiber Products lease, a distance of 1616.51 feet to the east right-of-way line of Kansas Lane as per the construction plans and monuments set for the "Kansas Lane Project (Millhaven Road to Central Avenue)", State Project No. S 742-06-15 and 742-06-17; thence southerly along the east right-of-way line of said Kansas Lane, the following courses: 
South 2;deg; 01;min; 36;sec; East West 171.70 feet; thence along a curve to the right (curve having a radius of 1209.56 feet, a chord bearing of South 13;deg; 09;min; 00;sec; West, a chord distance of 337.11 feet) an arc distance of 338.21 feet; thence South 17;deg; 56;min; 20;sec; West 103.60 feet; thence South 24;deg; 48;min; 48;sec; West 73.82 feet; thence along a curve to the left (curve having a radius of 1035.27 feet, a chord bearing of South 17;deg; 24;min; 53;sec; West, a chord distance of 267.73 feet) an arc distance of 268.48 feet; thence South 10;deg; 14;min; 36;sec; West 41.65 feet; thence South 5;deg; 42;min; 35;sec; West 200.05 feet; thence South 10;deg; 11;min; 46;sec; West 100.09 feet; thence South 3;deg; 37;min; 27;sec; West 221.09 feet; thence South 83;deg; 46;min; 06 ;sec; East 5.04 feet; thence South 11;deg; 32;min; 48;sec; West 94.74 feet to the north right-of-way line of the Kansas City Southern Railroad; thence North 84;deg; 47;min; 42;sec; West, along the north right-of-way line of Kansas City Southern Railroad, a distance of 3714.69 feet to the point of beginning. Containing a gross area of 709.75 acres, more or less. 
Less and Except 
That certain 12.96 acre tract or parcel of land conveyed to the Ouachita Parish School Board from the United States of America as described in Conveyance Book 428, page 315 of the Records of Ouachita Parish, Louisiana, and being shown on the survey of the Monroe Industrial Park filed in Plat Book 15, page 113 of the Records of Ouachita Parish, Louisiana. 
Leaving a net area of 696.79 acres in the Monroe Air-Industrial Park. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-2. - Scope. 
    The real property known as the Monroe Air-industrial Park which is, and shall be occupied subject to the conditions, covenants, restrictions, reservations and easements set forth herein in this article. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-3. - Purpose. 
    The Monroe Air-industrial Park shall be developed with the intentions and goals of fostering economic development, increasing public revenues, providing a positive environment for job creation, and improving the general quality of life for citizens in the Monroe and surrounding area, and in particular: 
(1)  To encourage the future growth and expansion of existing commercial and industrial ventures within the Northeast Louisiana Region; 
(2)  To attract and secure the relocation of new enterprise to the area and encourage private investment in the Monroe Air-Industrial Park; and 
(3)  To generate, provide for, and sustain an increased number of quality and stable jobs. 
    The park is subjected to the conditions, covenants, restrictions, reservations and easements herein declared: 
(1)  To insure proper use and appropriate development and improvement of each building site thereof; 
(2)  To protect the owners/occupants of building sites against such improper use of surrounding building sites as will depreciate the value of their property; 
(3)  To guard against the erection thereon of structures built of improper or unsuitable materials; 
(4)  To insure adequate and reasonable development of said property; 
(5)  To encourage the erection of attractive improvements thereon, with appropriate locations thereof on building sites; 
(6)  To prevent haphazard and inharmonious improvements of building sites; 
(7)  To secure and maintain proper setbacks from streets, and adequate open spaces between structures; and 
(8)  In general to provide adequately for a high type and quality of improvement on said property. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-4. - Use of property. 
(1)  Except as hereinafter expressly permitted, the building sites within the park shall be used for commercial, office space, retail, food and beverage, hospitality, industrial, manufacturing, fabricating, warehousing, or distribution purposes with related administrative offices as secondary use associated with another primary permitted use; and 
(2)  Building sites within the park shall be used for any business devoted primarily to the retail sale of consumer-type merchandise or services that have been expressly approved and authorized by the advisory board, and provided further, that the retail sale of food, beverage and other convenience items are offered for sale to the general public as long as they have been expressly approved and authorized by the advisory board. 
(3)  No industry or other business shall be established, maintained or permitted on any building site within the park which produces objectionable smoke, dust, noise, light, odor, vibration, or electrical disturbance or interference. Determination of whether an industry or business is objectionable for any of these reasons shall be at the discretion of the advisory board. 
(4)  No building site within the park shall be used for the manufacture, storage, distribution or sale of any materials or products which shall increase the insurance rates of the adjoining property, or for any purpose which constitutes a nuisance under the law of the State of Louisiana. 
(5)  No building site within the park shall be used for the discharge, storage or burial of any liquid, solid waste or airborne particulate matter, defined as hazardous by federal, state, parish or local law. 
(6)  No building site within the park shall be used for the drilling for and/or removal of oil, gas or other subterranean substances; the operation of junkyards; the dumping, disposal, incineration or reduction of garbage, sewage, offal, or dead animals; the smelting of ores; the refining or storage of petroleum products or other highly combustible materials; the manufacture or storage of explosives, the manufacture of acid; the manufacture of fertilizer. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97; Ord. No. 11,619, 11-10-15) 
Sec. 22-5. - Fines for noncompliance. 
    Noncompliance with any and all parts of this ordinance will result in fines of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and no less than twenty-five (25) hours of community service, recommendations of which will be made by the advisory board. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Secs. 22-6-22-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - THE ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 22-16. - The advisory board established; appointments. 
    The advisory board for the Monroe Air-Industrial Park shall be established to oversee all development within the park boundaries according to the following conditions: 
(1)  The advisory board shall consist of fifteen (15) members, appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. 
(2)  In making appointments, members shall be: 
a.  One representative from the Monroe City Attorney's Office. 
b.  One representative from the Monroe Department of Administration. 
c.  One representative from the Monroe Department of Engineering. 
d.  One representative from the Monroe City Planning Office. 
e.  One representative from the Monroe City Council. 
f.  One representative from the Monroe Regional Airport. 
g.  One representative from the Ouachita Enterprise Corporation. 
h.  One representative from the Monroe Chamber of Commerce. 
i.  One representative from the Northeast Louisiana African-American Chamber of Commerce. 
j.  One local realtor. 
k.  Two (2) owner/occupants from the Monroe Air-Industrial Park. 
l.  Three (3) representatives from the city at large. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97; Ord. No. 9710, 7-10-97) 
Sec. 22-17. - Membership; terms. 
(1)  Members of the board shall serve four-year terms, except that members of the first appointed board shall serve respectively as follows: three (3) members for one year; three (3) members for two (2) years; three (3) members for three (3) years; and four (4) members for four (4) years. 
(2)  All members shall serve without compensation. 
(3)  Members shall serve until successor is appointed. 
(4)  Any member may be recalled at any time by the mayor for gross inefficiency, fraud, absenteeism or study neglect. 
(5)  Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-18. - Officers; meetings; procedures. 
(1)  The board shall elect annually among its members a chairman, a vice-chairman, and such other officers as it may deem necessary. The chairman or, in his absence, the vice-chairman shall preside over meetings. 
(2)  No review, approval, disapproval, or recommendation shall be made by the board until it has adopted rules, regulations, policies, procedures, and standards following a public hearing. 
(3)  Said rules, regulations, policies and procedures shall be recorded and shall be made available to applicants and any other interested person. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-19. - Powers and duties of the advisory board. 
(1)  The advisory board shall recognize as its primary purpose the establishment and advocacy of standards criteria which supports the purposes of development within the Monroe Air-Industrial Park. 
(2)  The board shall develop specific guidelines for the design, implementation, and maintenance of a master plan for development for the park. 
(3)  The board shall review and rule on all applications and plans submitted for sale and/or land development within the park. The board shall determine appropriateness of all proposed uses. The board will use as guide and model the rules and conditions set forth in the Monroe Air-Industrial Park Development Ordinance and the master plan for development. 
(4)  The board shall make recommendations to the mayor and city council on any decisions which directly or indirectly affect the short and long term planning, development, use, appearance, maintenance, access, quality and integrity, or economic potential of the park, including the retention of specialists or consultants, and the appointment of citizen advisory committees or park occupant committees as may be required. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Secs. 22-20-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SALES AND LEASE POLICY 

Sec. 22-31. Policy on commission for realtors as brokers. 
    Any real estate broker licensed to conduct business within the State of Louisiana (broker) shall be eligible for a sales commission not to exceed seven (7) per cent computed on the gross purchase price for lands sold in the Monroe Air-Industrial Park located in Ouachita Parish, Louisiana, subject to the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  Broker shall represent either the seller (City of Monroe) or the buyer and must register the prospect (buyer) with the city by forwarding a letter from the prospect (addressed to the city attorney) outlining and confirming the broker's participation with said prospect. To receive commission, broker and buyer must not be one in the same. All prospect names will be kept in confidence. 
(2)  A preliminary proposal for development of the property must first be reviewed and approved by the advisory board according to requirements set forth in section 22-32, before the sale is completed. To assure confidentiality, the name of the prospect need not appear on the proposal. 
(3)  The city shall approve all commission payments. The sale must be successfully closed and title of the land passed to the registered prospect. Commissions shall be paid at the time of closing. 
(4)  Any prospect registered with the city will remain registered unless the prospect notifies the city attorney in writing that the broker no longer represents said prospect. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-32. - Preliminary proposal. 
    Prior to the sale or lease of any property within the Monroe Air-Industrial Park, a preliminary proposal for development must be submitted to the Monroe Air-Industrial Park Advisory Board, P.O. Box 123, Monroe, Louisiana, 71210. Preliminary proposals should include, at a minimum: 
(1)  A written description of the character and scope of the enterprise, including sector of commerce served and marketing strategy. 
(2)  Number of employees, job classifications, the general wage scale, and skill levels required. 
(3)  Building type and square footage of the planned facility. 
(4)  The specific use of the property. 
(5)  A graphic conceptual site plan and schematic renderings of the proposed property improvements. 
(6)  An outline of infrastructure, utility, service, communication and any other requirements for development. 
(7)  A time line for property development, and if the development is planned in stages, the time schedule for each successive stage. 
(8)  A description of any future plans for expansion, refinement, redevelopment, property improvements, and any anticipated facility or employment changes. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-33. - Sales. 
(1)  The advisory board must recommend the sale of the property and it must be approved by city council. All sales shall be subject to the covenants, restrictions and conditions for the Monroe Air-Industrial Park and other policies established by the board. 
(2)  In the event the prospect does not make use of the property as set forth in the preliminary proposal for development, it is to be sold back to the city, and the purchase price paid by the city will be equal to seventy-five (75) per cent of the original purchase price. 
(3)  All option contracts shall have a time limitation of one year unless otherwise approved by the board. Cost for an option contract shall be one per cent per month of the purchase price of the building site, payable in advance and nonrefundable if the option is not exercised within the allotted time frame of the agreements. If an option is exercised, option costs shall apply to the purchase of the property. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-34. - Survey. 
    All boundary surveys for building sites in the Monroe Air-Industrial Park shall be provided by the city. Surveys for option contracts shall be paid when the execution of an option contract occurs. Cost for the survey shall be paid by the city. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Secs. 22-35-22-44. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONSTRUCTION POLICY 

Sec. 22-45. - Construction review. 
    Prior to the commencement of construction of any improvements on a building site in the Monroe Air-Industrial Park, written approval for site development shall be provided by the advisory board along with a stamped engineering plat of the property to the City of Monroe Office of Planning and Zoning. 
    Two (2) complete sets of plans and specifications shall be submitted for site and construction review to the Monroe City Office of Planning and Zoning, 313 Breard Street, P.O. Box 123, Monroe, Louisiana, 71210. 
(1)  Plans and specifications submitted for review shall be finished in all respects and shall conform to the covenants, restrictions and conditions for the Monroe Air-Industrial Park and requirements set forth in the submission of plans, section 22-46. 
(2)  All improvements shall, as a minimum, comply with the construction standards of The Southern Standard Building Code (latest edition) or other applicable standards established by statute, regulation or other ordinance, and be approved where required by ordinance. 
(3)  Prior to the issuance of any building permit for improvements, as defined herein, for any building site in the park: 
a.  The building or other improvement plans, including elevations, specifications, and site plans showing the location of such improvements on the particular building site should be approved by the planning and zoning office; 
b.  Federal Aviation Administration, Form 7460-1, Notice of Proposed Construction or Alteration, should be completed and filed with the Director's Office of the Monroe Regional Airport, 5400 Operations Road, Suite 200, Monroe, Louisiana, 71203. 
(4)  After commencement of construction of any improvements on any building site, the owner/occupant shall diligently pursue completion of the work to the end that the improvements shall not remain in a partly finished condition any longer than reasonably necessary for completion. All improvements shall be completed within eighteen (18) months after approval of plans by the planning and zoning office. 
(5)  During construction, the owner/occupant shall cause the building site to remain in a reasonably neat and orderly condition, preventing the accumulation of trash, and shall prevent runoff of surface water and soil from the building site onto adjacent property or streets. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-46. - Submission of plans. 
    All plans and specifications submitted shall include specific information as to construction materials, construction methods to be used and diagrams of the number, type and configuration of parking spaces necessary. 
    The objective of the Monroe Air-Industrial Park Covenants, restrictions, and conditions is to obtain consistency and quality in architectural design to protect and enhance values in the park. In order to maintain consistence, yet permit interest and variety and the use of new materials as they develop, all architectural designs, including those for alterations, additions or remodeling, are subject to review and approval by city planning and zoning. 
    Buildings should be considered as three-dimensional objects and attention should be given to the compatible treatment of all exterior surfaces. 
(1)  No improvement(s) shall be erected, placed or altered on any building site until the construction plans and specifications, and other requirements as may be required as to quality of workmanship and materials, harmony of external design with existing structures, as to location with respect to topography and finish grade elevation, and as to other such specifications as may be required. 
(2)  No building site improvement(s) shall be allowed until the office of planning and zoning approves the proposed plans and specifications as being in compliance with these covenants, restrictions and conditions. 
(3)  Plans should be at a scale clearly legible, and include, at a minimum: 
a.  Dimensioned site plans showing building footprint and any other structural improvements including fences, property and utility easements and rights-of-way, use areas including loading docks and trash collection, paved areas and landscaped open space, traffic circulation and parking. 
b.  Site elevations, in context, showing all improvements. 
c.  Building elevations. 
d.  Landscape plans with planting list. 
e.  Exterior building material specifications. 
(4)  Accompanying the plans should be a stamped drainage impact statement, reviewed and approved by the engineering department of the City of Monroe, 400 Lea Joyner Memorial Expressway, Monroe, Louisiana, 71201. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Secs. 22-47-22-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - COVENANTS, RESTRICTIONS AND CONDITIONS 

Sec. 22-58. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them below: 
    Accessory structure shall mean a detached subordinate building located on the same building site with the main building, the use of which is incidental to that of the main building. 
    Board shall mean the Monroe Air-Industrial Park advisory board. 
    Building setback line or lines shall mean the minimum distance which commercial or industrial buildings and accessory structures or any structures of any type or kind located above ground shall be set back from the property lines. 
    Building site shall mean any lot, or portion thereof, or two (2) or more contiguous lots or portions thereof or a parcel of land upon which a commercial or industrial building or buildings and appurtenant structures may be erected in conformance with the requirements of these covenants. 
    Grantor shall mean the City of Monroe, Louisiana, its successors and assigns, unless the contract indicates otherwise. 
    Improvements shall mean and include a commercial or industrial building or buildings, accessory structures appurtenant thereto, parking areas, driveways, loading areas, service areas, fences, masonry walls, hedges, lawns, mass plantings and other landscaping, site excavation, signage, transmission tower, and any structures of any type or kind located above ground. 
    Mobile building shall mean any covered portable structure consisting of a permanent chassis constructed on a skid form foundation and/or placed on concrete piers and anchored by tie-downs and which is to be used for the enclosure of persons, articles or chattels. 
    Park shall mean the Monroe Air-Industrial Park as hereinafter described. 
    Side building site line shall mean the boundary or property line dividing two (2) adjoining building sites. 
    Side corner building site line shall mean the boundary or property line dividing a property located at the intersection of two (2) streets from the side or subordinate street right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-59. - Type of construction. 
(1)  No building shall be erected within the park which is of wooden or frame construction. All structures shall be of attractive design and construction so as not to detract from the general appearance of the park as a whole. Walls fronting public streets should be finished with face brick, finished metal or other attractive trim material. 
(2)  All buildings shall be of permanent construction. No mobile buildings or other temporary structures shall be allowed, except for temporary purposes for a specified period of time, and only as approved by the advisory board. 
(3)  All utility lines shall be placed underground. Adequate lighting of appropriate intensities for building illumination, signage, parking lots and driveways shall be installed. Lighting shall be attractive in design to complement building site improvements. Light sources shall be hooded or controlled, and arranged so as to deflect light away from adjacent properties and public streets. Bare incandescent bulbs shall not be permitted in view of adjacent property or public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-60. - Building lines. 
(1)  No part of any building shall be constructed on any building site within the park closer than fifty (50) feet from the right-of-way of any street designated for public use. 
(2)  No building shall be constructed on any building site within the park closer than fifteen (15) feet to the rear or side building site lines. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-61. - Loading docks. 
(1)  Irrespective of the other requirements set forth in this article pertaining to building lines, no truck dock or loading space shall be constructed upon any building site within the park so that trucks, tractors, trailers or any combination thereof will, while either being maneuvered, or being loaded or unloaded, project beyond twenty (20) feet of any public street right-of-way. 
(2)  No loading docks shall be constructed on the front of any building within the park unless approved by the advisory board. The front of any building, for the purposes of this provision, is defined to mean any side of a building which faces a street designated for public use. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-62. - Parking. 
(1)  No parking shall be permitted upon any street designated for public use. 
(2)  Each occupant of a building site within the park shall provide approved off-street automobile parking facilities to be based generally, but not specifically, at the minimum rate of one parking space for each one and one-half (11/2) employees to be employed on the premises by the occupant thereof. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-63. - Open storage areas and fences. 
(1)  No goods, equipment, supplies or other materials shall be stored in the open upon any building site in the park except on the rear two-thirds ( 2/3 ) thereof, and then only when such open storage area is fenced with a screening fence at least six (6) feet in height, and of adequate height to screen storage from visibility. 
(2)  All fencing for screening, security or other purposes shall be attractive in appearance and shall be an all metal industrial type fence or galvanized or nonferrous material, or shall be of brick, masonry, or other material of nondeteriorating nature. No wood fence shall be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-64. - Landscaping. 
(1)  All open areas upon each building site within the park shall be attractively landscaped with lawn, trees and shrubs according to landscape plans first approved in writing by the advisory board. 
(2)  Street trees shall be included in the landscape plan along any public street, planted in a uniform line of regular and appropriate spacing, and should be of a long-lived variety native to north Louisiana. 
(3)  Massive areas of concrete or asphalt not used for vehicular access, circulation or maneuvering, including parking areas, should have internal areas of landscaping, spaced at appropriate intervals to provide visual relief, and should include trees. 
(4)  All visible building mechanical and service equipment, fences bordering public streets, and any other objectionable view shall be screened with a landscape planting, 
(5)  Provision should be made for the adequate watering of all landscaping. 
(6)  All areas shall be maintained in an attractive and well-kept condition. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-65. - Signage. 
(1)  No billboards or advertising signs, other than those identifying the name, products and business of the person or firm occupying a building site within the park shall be permitted. 
(2)  All signage shall be of professional design, with appropriate content, pleasing in appearance, of sound construction, and properly lighted. 
(3)  Without board consent, no sign shall exceed the height of ten (10) feet. Sign size should be appropriate in proportion to the building, and should be no larger than eighty (80) square feet. 
(4)  Signage shall not be erected in any public right-of-way. 
(5)  All signage shall be maintained in a neat and orderly fashion, and updated and painted regularly where appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-66. - General cleanliness and upkeep. 
(1)  Each building site shall be kept in a safe, clean, healthful and presentable condition at all times. 
(2)  All open trash collection areas shall be on the rear two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the building site, fenced with a screening fence or combination of fence and landscape screening at least six (6) feet in height, and of adequate height to screen area from visibility. 
(3)  No occupant of a building site within the park shall maintain or operate an incinerator for disposing of trash and debris. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-67. - Applicability of other laws. 
(1)  Each occupant of a building site within the park shall, at all times, be subject to the laws of the United States, the State of Louisiana, and the ordinances of the City of Monroe, as well as the rules and regulations of the Federal Aviation Administration or its successor agency concerning the use, occupancy and operations of the airport facility known as the Monroe Regional Airport. 
(2)  Each occupant of a building site within the park shall be subject to all of the ordinances of the City of Monroe, without limitation, but particularly including the building code, plumbing code, electrical code, sewer pretreatment code, and life safety code of the city. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-68. - Waiver or modification of article. 
    Any or all of the restrictions in this article may be waived or modified for any or all existing owner/occupants or for a new owner/occupant by a favorable vote of seventy-five (75) per cent in number of the owner/occupants occupying spaces within the park at the time said waiver or modification is to be granted, to be evidenced by written instrument signed by the assenting owner/occupants, and by the unanimous written consent of the advisory board. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 22-69. - Reservation of powers to city. 
    The council of the City of Monroe hereby reserved unto itself the right, power and authority to impose additional covenants, restrictions and conditions upon the property located in the park provided that such additional covenants, restrictions and conditions which may be hereafter imposed may not be so construed as to require any owner/occupant to change the location of or to abandon, any structure located on the premises, or to change the nature and manner of operating its business. Provided, that this section shall not in any way operate as an abridgment or restriction of the police power of the City of Monroe. 
(Ord. No. 9685, 4-8-97) 
Chapter 23 - NOISE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9439, adopted Apr. 26, 1994, amended the Code by repealing former Ch. 23,  23-1-23-3 and adding a new Ch. 3,  23-1-23-11. Former Ch. 3 pertained to similar provisions and derived from the Code of 1958,  19-2-19-6. 
Cross reference- Advertising and signs, Ch. 3; disturbing the peace,  12-153. 

Sec. 23-1. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply to the interpretation of the provisions of this chapter: 
(a)  All technical terms, unless the context otherwise requires, shall be defined in accordance with the American National Standards Institute publications, as revised. (American Standards Institute, 1430 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10018) 
(b)  "A" band level shall mean the total sound level of all noise as measured with a sound level meter using the "A" weighting network. The unit is the dbA. 
(c)  Ambient noise shall mean the all-encompassing noise associated with a given environment, usually being a composite of sounds with many sources near and far. 
(d)  Commercial district shall mean the following: 
(1)  An area where offices, clinics and the facilities needed to serve them are located; 
(2)  An area with local shopping and service establishment; 
(3)  A tourist-oriented area where hotels, motels, and gasoline stations are located; 
(4)  A business strip along a main street containing offices, retail businesses, and commercial enterprises; 
(5)  Other commercial enterprises and activities which do not involve the manufacturing, process or fabrication of any commodity. "Commercial district" shall include, but not be limited to, any parcel of land zoned commercial or business under the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(e)  Commercial purpose shall mean and include the use, operation, or maintenance of any sound-amplifying equipment for the purpose of advertising any business, any goods, or any services, or for the purpose of attracting the attention of the public to, or advertising for or soliciting the patronage of customers to or for any performance, show, entertainment, exhibition, or event, or for the purpose of demonstrating any such sound equipment. 
(f)  Construction activities shall mean any and all activity incidental to the erection, demolition, assembling, altering, installing or equipping of building, structure, roads or appurtenances thereto, including land clearing, grading, excavating and filling. 
(g)  Continuous noise shall mean a steady, fluctuating, or impulsive noise which exists, essentially without interruption, for a period of ten (10) minutes or more. 
(h)  Decibel (db) shall mean a unit of level which denotes the ratio between two (2) quantities which are proportional to power; the number of decibels corresponding to the ratio of two (2) amounts of power is ten (10) times the logarithm to the base ten of this ratio. 
(i)  Device shall mean any mechanism which is intended to produce or which actually produces sound when operated or handled. 
(j)  Emergency work shall mean work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity or work required to protect persons or property from an imminent exposure to danger. 
(k)  Industrial district shall mean an area in which enterprises and activities which involve the manufacturing, processing or fabrication of any commodity are located. "Industrial district" shall include but not be limited to, any parcel of land zoned as an industrial district, under the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(l)  Motor vehicle shall mean any vehicle such as but not limited to, a passenger vehicle, truck, truck-trailer, trailer or semi-trailer propelled or drawn by mechanical power, and shall include motorcycles, minibikes, go-carts, and any other vehicle which is self-propelled. 
(m)  Noncommercial purpose shall mean the use, operation, or maintenance of any sound equipment for other than a commercial purpose. Noncommercial purpose shall mean and include, but shall not be limited to, educational, philanthropic, political, patriotic, and charitable purposes. 
(n)  Residential district shall mean an area of single or multiple-family dwellings and shall include areas where multiple unit dwellings, high-rise apartments and high-density residential districts are located. "Residential district" shall also include, but is not limited to, hospitals, nursing homes, homes for the aged, schools, courts and similar institutional facilities. 
(o)  Sound-amplifying equipment shall mean any machine or device for the amplification of the human voice, music, or any other sound. Sound-amplifying equipment shall not include standard automobile radios when used and heard only by the occupants of the vehicle in which the automobile radio is installed. Sound-amplifying equipment, as used in this chapter shall not include warning devices or authorized emergency vehicles or horns or other warning devices on any vehicle used only for traffic safety purposes. 
(p)  Sound level meter shall mean an instrument or apparatus including a microphone, an amplifier, an output meter, and weighting networks for the measurement of sound pressure. The output meter reads sound pressure level when properly calibrated, and the instrument is of type 2 or better, as specified by the American National Standards Institute Publication. 
(q)  Sound truck shall mean any motor vehicle, or any other vehicle regardless of motive power, whether in motion or stationary, having mounted thereon, or attached thereto, any sound-amplifying equipment. 
(Ord. No. 9439, 4-26-94; Ord. No. 9511, 4-25-95) 
Sec. 23-2. - Unnecessary noise prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make or continue, or cause to be made or continued, any unnecessary noise within the city. 
(b)  Except as otherwise permitted herein, the maximum permissible sound pressure levels of any source of sound shall be as herein established for the time period and district listed in Table A of this section. This includes, but is not limited to, sound from such activities as production, processing, cleaning, servicing, testing, operating, or repairing either vehicles, materials, goods, products or devices. This subsection (b) shall not apply to any source of sound proscribed or restricted by subsection (c) of this section. Sound pressure levels in excess of those established for the districts of the city, at times herewith listed, shall constitute prima facie evidence that such sound is an unnecessary noise. Sound pressure levels shall be measured at the approximate location of the property line or the boundary of the public way, at a height of at least four (4) feet above the immediate surrounding surface, on a sound level meter of standard design and operated on the "A" weighting network. 
TABLE A 
Sound Pressure Level Limit 
dB(A) Day Night District (7 a.m.-10 p.m.) (10 p.m.-7 a.m.) Residential 65 60 Commercial 70 65 Industrial 85 80  
When a noise source can be identified and its noise measured in more than one district, the sound pressure level limits of the most restrictive district shall apply. 
The sound pressure level limits, and provisions hereof, applicable to commercial districts shall also apply to any parcel of land zoned agricultural district under the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(c)  Except as otherwise permitted herein, it shall be unlawful for any person to make or continue, or cause to be made or continued, any unnecessary noise within the city which can be heard by any person at a distance of more than fifty (50) feet. This subsection (c) shall apply to televisions, radios, stereos, CD players, phonographs, or tape players which are being used or played while in transit, including but not limited to, transit by means of carriage by a pedestrian, animal, bicycle, or any motor vehicle, whether private or commercial. 
(Ord. No. 9439, 4-26-94; Ord. No. 9511, 4-25-95; Ord. No. 9982, 8-10-99) 
Sec. 23-3. - Construction, power equipment. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no person shall engage in, cause or permit any person to be engaged in construction activities in any residential or commercial district between the hours of 9:00 p.m. of one day and 7:00 a.m. of the following day. 
Construction projects shall be subject to the maximum permissible noise level specified for industrial districts for the periods within which construction is to be completed pursuant to any applicable building permit. 
Construction activities directly connected with the abatement of an emergency are excluded from the provisions of this section. 
(b)  No person shall operate on any property within a residential or commercial district or on any public way within a residential or commercial district, any power equipment, such as but not limited to, chain saws, pavement breakers, log chippers, riding tractors, powered hand tools, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. of one day and 7:00 a.m. of the next day or within residential, commercial or industrial noise districts between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. which emits a noise level in excess of the levels set in section 23-2. 
(Ord. No. 9439, 4-26-94; Ord. No. 9511, 4-25-95) 
Sec. 23-4. - Sound amplifiers. 
(a)  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any loudspeaker or amplifier connected with any television, radio, stereo, CD player, phonograph, microphone, or other device by which sounds are magnified and made heard over any public street or public place without having first secured a permit therefor. 
(b)  Registration. 
(1)  Every user of sound-amplifying equipment shall file a registration statement with the director of administration five (5) days prior to the date on which the sound-amplifying equipment is intended to be used, which statement shall contain the following information: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of both the owner and user of the sound-amplifying equipment; 
b.  The maximum sound-producing power of the sound-amplifying equipment which shall include the wattage to be used, the volume in decibels of sound which will be produced, and the approximate distance for which sound will be audible from the sound-amplifying equipment; 
c.  The license and motor number if a sound truck is to be used; 
d.  A general description of the sound-amplifying equipment which is to be used; and
