(a)  Whenever it comes to the attention of the police department, the fire department or the office of code enforcement that any nuisance as described in section 24.5-72 appears to exist on public property, such department or office shall cause a written notice to be affixed to the subject item, declaring the existence of the nuisance and ordering whoever has interest in the subject item to comply with this article by removing the subject item within forty-eight (48) hours of receipt of the notice. 
    Whenever it comes to the attention of the police department, the fire department or the office of code enforcement that any nuisance as described in section 24.5-73 appears to exist on private property or utility rights-of-way or on public property, such department or office shall cause a written notice to be affixed to the subject item, declaring the existence of the nuisance and ordering whoever has an interest in the subject item to comply with this article by removing the subject item within forty-eight (48) hours of receipt of the notice. 
    Additionally, if such nuisance is found to exist on private property, in addition to the foregoing notice, a copy of such notice shall be delivered to the owner or occupant of the property. If a copy of the notice cannot be delivered to such owner or occupant, a copy of the notice shall be left at the property, with a duplicate copy sent to the owner or occupant of the property by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(b)  The notice described in subsection (a) shall contain the request for removal within the time specified in this section; and the notice shall advise that upon failure to comply with the notice of removal, the police department, the fire department or the office of code enforcement shall undertake such removal, with the cost of removal to be levied against the owner of the subject item. 
    The notice shall also advise the person to whom the notices are applicable of his right to contest the determination of the police department, the fire department or the office of code enforcement that a violation under this article exists by requesting a hearing before the city's administrative hearing officer, and that, if such a hearing is desired, the request can be made by filing a written request with the director of code enforcement. A request for hearing must be made within the time for removal set forth in this section. 
(Ord. No. 11,733, 9-27-16) 
Sec. 24.5-76. - Hearing. 
    Upon receiving a request for hearing pursuant to section 24.5-75, the director of code enforcement shall set the hearing before its next regular meeting environmental court hearing. Notice of the hearing shall be given to the person requesting the hearing and to the citing department or office. No other notices are required. A request for a hearing under this section stays all enforcement proceedings until an order of the city's administrative hearing officer is entered. 
(Ord. No. 11,733, 9-27-16) 
Sec. 24.5-77. - Reserved. 
Sec. 24.5-78. - Issuance of order by administrative hearing officer. 
    After a hearing, the city's administrative hearing officer shall issue a written order, either finding the existence of a nuisance or finding that a nuisance does not exist. It shall state in its order the findings of fact on which it based its decision. 
(Ord. No. 11,733, 9-27-16) 
Sec. 24.5-79. - Removal of subject item. 
(a)  Within the time for removal set forth in the notice for removal, or within forty-eight (48) hours of the date on which an order is entered by the administrative hearing officer affirming the determination of the citing department or office, the owner of the abandoned, wrecked or inoperable subject item and the owner or occupant of the private property on which the subject item is located, either of or both of them, shall cause the removal of the subject item. 
(b)  If the violation is not remedied within the time set forth in the notice, the police department or the office of code enforcement shall have the right to take possession of the subject item and remove it from the premises. 
(c)  In the event of removal and disposition of the subject item, the owner of the subject item shall be liable for the expenses incurred in so doing. 
(Ord. No. 11,733, 9-27-16) 
Sec. 24.5-80. - Notice of possession. 
    The police department or the office of code enforcement, after taking possession of subject item pursuant to this article, shall furnish notice in accordance with this section by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the registered owner of subject item at his last known address within fifteen (15) days of the date on which possession of subject item is taken, with a copy of the notice to the owner or occupant of the property from which subject item is taken. 
(Ord. No. 11,733, 9-27-16) 
Sec. 24.5-81. - Exceptions to prior notice requirement; grounds. 
    The requirement that notice be affixed to an abandoned or inoperable vehicle at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to removal may, as determined by the police department or the office of code enforcement, be omitted in those circumstances where there is a special need for prompt action to eliminate traffic obstructions or to otherwise maintain and protect the public safety and welfare. Such findings shall, in all cases, be entered by the police department or the office of code enforcement in the appropriate records. Circumstances justifying the removal of vehicles without prior notice include: 
(a)  Vehicles abandoned on the streets. For vehicles left on the public streets and highways, such circumstances include that immediate removal of such vehicles may be warranted when they are: 
(1)  Obstructing traffic. 
(b)  Other abandoned or inoperable vehicles. With respect to abandoned or inoperable vehicles left on city-owned property other than the streets and highways, and on private property, such vehicles may be removed without giving prior notice only in those circumstances where the police department or the office of code enforcement finds a special need for prompt action to protect and maintain the public health, safety and welfare. By way of illustration but not limitation, such circumstances include vehicles blocking or obstructing ingress or egress to businesses and residences, vehicles parked in such a location or manner as to pose a traffic hazard, and vehicles causing damage to public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 11,733, 9-27-16) 
Secs. 24.5-82-24.5-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - WEEDS AND NOXIOUS GROWTH[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Weeds in railroad ditches, etc.,  29-6; trees and shrubs, Ch. 34. 

Sec. 24.5-86. - Prohibited; duty to remove. 
    The owner of any lot, place or area within the limits of the city shall cut and destroy all weeds or grass or deleterious or unhealthful growth, or other obnoxious matter, growing, lying or being in or upon any sidewalk or upon any lot, place or area within the city, and remove such weeds, grass, growth or matter from his premises. Such cutting and removal shall be done as often as necessary in order to ensure that such lots, places or areas do not constitute a hazard to the health of the citizens of the community, but in no event less than twice each month between April 1, and October 1 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 11,733, 9-27-16) 
Sec. 24.5-87. - Notice to owner, failure to comply. 
    In the event any owner of any lot, place or area within the limits of the city fails to cut, destroy and remove such weeds, grass or other unhealthful growth or obnoxious matter in the manner required by this article, the city shall cut, destroy and/or remove the same and the city shall charge the costs, charges or expenses incurred in the cutting, destruction or removal of such noxious weeds, grass or other growth as set forth in a schedule of costs adopted by the city council. 
    No such work shall be undertaken by the city until the owner of the lot, place or area, where the weeds or growth are to be removed, as shown on the last assessment roll of the city, has an opportunity of doing the work himself with at least five (5) days after notice has been given him by advertisement in the official journal of the city for two (2) consecutive days or after notice has been given him by certified mail, addressed in accordance with the tax rolls of the city. 
(Ord. No. 11,733, 9-27-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 33:5062. 
Sec. 24.5-88. - Mailing statement showing expense incurred; addition to tax liability. 
    If, after the cutting, destruction or removal of weeds, grass or growths by the city, after due notice as provided in this article, the cost or expense thereof has not been paid within ten (10) days, the director of administration shall furnish the owner, as shown on the last assessment roll of the city, by registered mail a written statement showing the cost or expense incurred for the work, and the place or property on which the work was done. If said statement is not paid within one month thereafter, the amount thereof shall be included in and form part of the taxes due by the owner of said property and when collected shall be credited to the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 11,733, 9-27-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 33:5063. 
Sec. 24.5-89. - Penalties. 
(a)  The Monroe police and fire departments and the office of code enforcement shall have the authority to enforce the ordinances in this chapter, including the authority to issue summons and/or a notice to appear in environmental court for violations of such ordinances. The administrative hearing officer(s) for the City of Monroe environmental court shall have jurisdiction to hear cases relative to such violations and to impose penalties for such violations in accordance with applicable ordinances. 
(b)  The offender shall be cited for the offense by means of summons and/or a notice to appear in environmental court as provided by ordinance. 
(c)  Reserved. 
(d)  Whoever violates the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the penalties provided in this section and in chapter 24: 
(1)  Upon first conviction be ordered to bring the property into compliance with city ordinances. 
(2)  Upon second conviction be ordered to bring the property into compliance and be sentenced to thirty (30) hours of community service. 
(3)  Upon third or subsequent conviction be ordered to serve fifty (50) hours of community service or in a work detail, as approved by the court, or any combination of the aforementioned penalties. 
(e)  The court may require an individual convicted of a violation of this article to remove the weeds, grass, or other noxious matters which have accumulated on his property in disregard of the health and safety of others in lieu of or in addition to the penalties prescribed in this section and chapter 24. 
(Ord. No. 11,733, 9-27-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 33:4770.11. 
Sec. 24.5-90. - Grass and weed cutting; abutting owner's liability; notice; waiver of notice. 
(a)  Property shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition, including ordinances providing for the cutting, destruction, or removal of noxious weeds or grass or other deleterious, unhealthful, or noxious matters on any sidewalks or banquettes and on any lot, place, or area within the city. The charges, costs, and expenses incurred by the city in enforcing such ordinances, shall, to the extent of the actual cost thereof be a charge, cost, or expense of the property abutting the sidewalk or banquette or of the lot, place, or area, and the owner thereof. 
(b)  If an owner of property fails to cut, destroy, or remove such grass or other matter from his property or from any abutting sidewalk or banquette, the city shall notify the property owner of its intent to perform such work after five (5) days and to charge the property owner for the work. Such notice may be given by advertisement in the official journal of the city for two (2) consecutive days, by certified mail, addressed in accordance with the tax rolls of the city, or served on the property owner, by domiciliary or personal service, by a representative of the city. 
(c)  The city may undertake the cutting, destruction, or removal of noxious weeds or grass or other deleterious, unhealthful, or noxious matters on any property within its jurisdiction on a monthly basis without the notice required in subsection (b) of this section if the property owner liable has been notified pursuant to said subsection at any time during the immediately preceding twelve (12) months and has failed to do the work himself after opportunity to do so. However, prior to undertaking such work, the city shall file and record an affidavit, signed by the mayor or his designee, at the administrative office. Such affidavit shall include the following: 
(1)  A description of the property sufficient to reasonably identify it. 
(2)  A photograph of the property sufficient to reasonably identify its unsafe or unsanitary conditions and to justify the necessity for cutting, destroying, or removing weeds, grass, or other noxious matters. 
(3)  A statement that the property owner liable has within the past twelve (12) months failed to do such work after notification and opportunity to do so pursuant to subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  Once the city has undertaken such actions, pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, it shall have the bill for the work delivered by registered mail, addressed in accordance with the tax rolls of the municipality, or served on the property owner, by domiciliary or personal service, by a representative of the city. 
(e)  Upon failure of the property owner to pay the charges within thirty (30) days of receipt of the bill, the city may file a certified copy of said charges with the recorder of mortgages, and the same, when so filed and recorded, shall operate as a lien and privilege in favor of the city against the property on which the work was done or against the property abutting the sidewalk or banquette on which the work was done. The lien and privilege granted under this subsection shall have the same ranking as an ad valorem tax lien on immovable property as provided in R.S. 9:4821(1). 
(Ord. No. 11,733, 9-27-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 33:4770.12. 
Chapter 25 - PARKS, RECREATION AND BOATING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Community affairs department,  4-09. 
Cross reference- Board of trustees of the Masur Museum of Art,  2-101 et seq.; litter in parks,  21-9; parks in subdivisions,  32-75; speed in parks,  33-31. 
State Law reference- Exercise of police powers in parks, R.S. 33:4558; boat safety, R.S. 34:851.1 et seq.; local boat safety regulations, R.S. 34:851.27. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-1. - Landing of watercraft on banks of Ouachita River. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or operator of any vessel, boat, houseboat, shantyboat, or other watercraft whatsoever, to land upon, tie up, anchor, fasten at or adjacent to, or to occupy with such vessel, boat, houseboat, shantyboat or any other watercraft whatsoever, any portion of or to permit any such vessel, boat, houseboat, shantyboat or any other watercraft whatsoever, to land upon, tie up, anchor, fasten to or to occupy any portion of the east bank of the Ouachita River, at any point within the corporate limits of the city without the express permission or consent of the owner of the land or premises fronting along such river at the point or place at which such watercraft shall be sought to be landed, anchored, tied up or fastened; provided that nothing in this section shall apply to the landing of watercraft for a period not to exceed twenty-four (24) hours. 
(b)  None of the provisions of this section shall apply to that portion of the east bank of the Ouachita River, lying south of the north line of Pine Street and north of the south line of Calypso Street. 
(Code 1958,  26-4) 
Sec. 25-2. - Resident boats and timber rafts in certain area. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to moor, anchor or in any manner attach to the banks, or near the same, of the Ouachita River, in front of the city from the south side of the head of Calypso Street to the northern limits of the city, any houseboat or structure built upon floating logs, used for residence or for the keeping and selling of fish, or any floating watercraft or like character, or of any timber raft or parts thereof; provided, this section shall not apply to any wharfboat used exclusively for receiving, discharging or transferring freight, or to rafts of timber to be used in piling when moved at or opposite the point at which piles are to be used. 
(Code 1958,  26-5) 
Sec. 25-3. - Maximum boat speeds. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any boat in the Ouachita River at a speed in excess of idling speed for such boat within an area bounded on the south by the north line of Texas Avenue extended, on the west by the centerline of the Ouachita River, and on the north by the south line of the Interstate 20 highway bridge. 
(Code 1958,  26-24; Ord. No. 7293, 6-23-81) 
Secs. 25-4-25-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FORSYTHE PARK WEST AND FORSYTHE BOAT DOCK 

Sec. 25-16. - Names and descriptions. 
    The area bounded on the east side by Riverside Drive, on the south side by the north line of Forsythe Avenue as extended westward, on the west side by the Ouachita River, and on the north side by the north line of Park Avenue as extended westward shall be known as "Forsythe Park West" and the system of docks owned by the city and located in the Ouachita River adjacent to Forsythe Park West shall be known as "Forsythe Boat Dock". 
(Code 1958,  26-20) 
Sec. 25-17. - Swimming. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to swim or wade in the Ouachita River in the water area adjoining Forsythe Park West and bounded on the south by the north line of Forsythe Avenue as extended westward and on the north by the north line of Park Avenue as extended westward, except as may be necessary for the purpose of launching or retrieving boats in the areas designated by the city for such purposes or except for emergency purposes. 
(Code 1958,  26-21) 
Sec. 25-18. - Parking areas and street system. 
    The police department shall designate appropriate parking areas for motor vehicles and boat trailers within Forsythe Park West and shall also establish speed limits and street systems, for either one-way or two-way traffic for the movement of motor vehicles and boat trailers in Forsythe Park West. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or operate any motor vehicle or boat trailer in Forsythe Park West in violation of any traffic signs, signals or other visual indicator devices established by the police department. 
(Code 1958,  26-22) 
Sec. 25-19. - Trash, garbage, refuse, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any trash, rubbish, refuse or garbage of any nature or kind whatsoever in Forsythe Park West except in receptacles established and appropriately marked for such deposits by the city. 
(Code 1958,  26-23) 
Sec. 25-20. - Docking or mooring of boats. 
    It shall be unlawful to tie any boat to the Ouachita River bank bounding the west side of Forsythe Park West, or to dock any boat on said bank, or to launch into or retrieve from the water abutting said bank any boat, except for emergency purposes, in any location or locations other than those which may be designated by the city for one or more of such purposes. 
(Code 1958,  26-25) 
Sec. 25-21. - Rules and regulations for Forsythe Boat Dock. 
    The following rules and regulations shall govern the operation of Forsythe Boat Dock: 
(a)  No boat shall be moored, parked at or tied to the Forsythe Boat Dock unless the owner or lessee of said boat has made application for and obtained a permit for such purpose from the city except that forty (40) feet on the south end of the Forsythe Boat Dock shall be reserved and may be used for the purpose of loading passengers in or unloading passengers from small craft. Within said forty (40) foot area, no boat shall be parked, moored or tied except temporarily for the purposes above stated. 
(b)  No permit for the docking of a boat at Forsythe Boat Dock shall be issued except upon the payment of a dock permit fee. This fee shall be calculated at the rate of seventy-five cents ($0.75) per month for each running foot of boat length, with a minimum monthly fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per month and a maximum monthly fee of sixty dollars ($60.00). This fee shall be payable every six (6) months, in advance, and should said fee at any time become thirty (30) days delinquent, such permit shall be deemed revoked, cancelled and voided. 
(c)  No small boats, drink stands, or articles of any other kind or nature whatsoever shall be stored or permanently placed on the Forsythe Boat Dock except as such may be placed there by the city. 
(d)  All necessary cables, ropes, and other necessary devices to properly secure and tie a boat to the Forsythe Boat Dock shall be supplied by the boat owner and must be approved by the city employee in charge of such dock. 
(e)  No boat dock permit shall be issued for any boat in excess of seventy (70) feet in length. 
(f)  No person shall be allowed to loiter around the Forsythe Park Boat Dock in such a manner as to impede or obstruct passage to and from the area where boats are moored. 
(Code 1958,  26-26) 
Secs. 25-22-25-31. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LEVEES 

Sec. 25-32. - Motorized vehicles. 
(a)  Restricted. All motorized traffic on the Ouachita River Levee from the toe of the levee to the crown inside the city limits, including but not limited to three-wheelers, motorcycles, trucks, cars, etc., is prohibited. All designated crossways approved by the Tensas Levee District can be used in their normal fashion. 
(b)  Exceptions. this article shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles involved with health and safety of the citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 7396, 5-25-82) 
Secs. 25-33-25-42. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MONROE BOAT DOCK AND RECREATION AREA[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7397, adopted May 25, 1982, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion as Ch. 25, art. IV,  25-43, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 25-43. - Admission fee. 
(a)  Levied. An admission or entrance fee in the amount of one dollar ($1.00) per vehicle, with an additional fee of twenty-five cents (25) per person for every person in excess of four (4) persons per vehicle, is hereby levied and established for all vehicles entering the Monroe Boat Dock and Recreation Area adjacent to Forsythe Park in the city. 
(b)  Exemptions. The owners of boats moored in the rental spaces of the Monroe Boat Dock, the patrons and passengers of the Twin City Queen, and all authorized vehicles of the City of Monroe, Ouachita Parish, State of Louisiana, the U.S. Corps of engineers or the Tensas Levee District while on official business are exempt from the admission or entrance fee. 
(c)  Use of Proceeds. All proceeds from the admission or entrance fee established herein shall be and are hereby dedicated to the recreation department. 
(d)  Implementing of Provisions. The mayor is hereby authorized to take whatever steps necessary to implement the provisions herein, including but not limited to the installation of gates, barriers, fences or other structures, subject to applicable provisions in the Charter and/or applicable provisions of state and federal laws. 
(Ord. No. 7397, 5-25-82) 
Secs. 25-44-25-53. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BAYOU DeSIARD[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Bayou DeSiard as principal water supply for city,  36-1 et seq. 

Sec. 25-54. - Maximum boat speeds. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any boat in Bayou DeSiard within the city limits of the City of Monroe in excess of thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 7725, 9-11-84) 
Sec. 25-55. - No-wake zone. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any boat in Bayou DeSiard at a speed in excess of idling speed for such boat within the area southeast, between the Edgewater Garden Dam and the Northeast Louisiana University footbridge. 
(Ord. No. 7725, 9-11-84) 
Sec. 25-56. - Speed limit-Portion of Bayou DeSiard. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor boat or vessel on that portion of Bayou DeSiard, between the extension of Chatham Drive and its intersection with Bayou DeSiard, eastward to the Midway Dam in excess of ten (10) miles per hour. Any person or persons who violate the provision of this section, shall be fined by a sum not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), or imprisoned for a term not to exceed ten (10) days or both. 
(Ord. No. 9205, 3-12-91) 
Secs. 25-57-25-60. - Reserved.

Sec. 25-63. - Municipal Golf Course. 
    The general fees set forth herein and established by ordinance of the Monroe City Council shall remain in effect until such time as there may be a contract entered into between the City of Monroe and a lessee for the maintenance and operation of the municipal golf course and, in such an event, the fee schedule may be set by the director of community affairs in conjunction with the needs of the lessee based upon costs and improvements. In the event the director of community affairs and the lessee cannot resolve any dispute which may arise as to the establishment of fees, the lessee shall have the right to appeal to the Monroe City Council for the establishment fees.

ARTICLE VII. - PARK HOURS 

Sec. 25-71. - Closing hours. 
    All parks and recreation areas maintained, operated and/or owned by the city of Monroe shall be closed to the public between the hours of 12:00 midnight until 5:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 9144, 6-25-90) 
Sec. 25-72. - Exceptions. 
    The closing hours set forth in section 25-71 shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  To any park or recreational area of the City of Monroe for which different hours of operation have been enacted; or 
(2)  For any approved function or event which has obtained written permission for extended hours from the Office of the Mayor or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 9144, 6-25-90) 
Secs. 25-73-25-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - FORSYTHE PARK 

Sec. 25-81. - Name and description. 
    The area bounded by Forsythe Avenue, by Riverside Drive, Park Avenue, and by the municipal golf course shall be known as Forsythe Park. 
(Ord. No. 9434, 4-12-94) 
Sec. 25-82. - No alcohol zone. 
    The display, possession and/or consumption of alcoholic beverages is prohibited in the following areas of Forsythe Park: 
(1)  The All Children's Park; 
(2)  The area fronting on Sycamore Street between the natatoriums and the Golf Pro Shop, extending eastward to the golf course proper; 
(3)  The natatoriums and all streets and parking areas adjacent thereto; 
(4)  Sycamore Street and all parking areas adjacent thereto; 
(5)  All parking areas adjacent to the tennis courts; and 
(6)  All parking areas within the park fronting on Forsythe Avenue and Riverside Drive. 
(Ord. No. 9434, 4-12-94) 
Sec. 25-83. - Designation; blue zone. 
    The area described in section 25-82 shall be known as the blue zone and shall be indicated as such by blue paint on curbing or street surface, and by appropriate signage on other surfaces. 
(Ord. No. 9434, 4-12-94) 
Sec. 25-84. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of section 25-82 shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned for more than thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 9434, 4-12-94) 
Sec. 25-85. - Exceptions. 
    The prohibition set forth in section 25-82 shall not apply to the premises of the American Legion Building nor to any special event or function which has obtained a written permit for such exception from the mayor or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 9434, 4-12-94) 
Secs. 25-86-25-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - CHARLES H. JOHNSON CHILDREN'S PARK 

Sec. 25-90. - Name and description. 
    The area on the east side of Wilson Street between Bernstien Park Drive and Standifer Street shall be known as Charles H. Johnson Children's Park.

    The display, possession and/or consumption of alcoholic beverages is prohibited in all areas of Charles H. Johnson Children's Park, including but not limited to the playground area and the parking areas. 
(Ord. No. 9599, 5-28-96) 
Sec. 25-92. - Designation; blue zone. 
    The area described in section 25-91 shall be known as the blue zone and shall be indicated as such by blue paint on curbing or street surfaces, and by appropriate signage on other surfaces. 
(Ord. No. 9599, 5-28-96) 
Sec. 25-93. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of section 25-91 shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than two hundred fifty ($250.00) or imprisoned for more than thirty (30) days or both. 
(Ord. No. 9599, 5-28-96) 
Sec. 25-94. - Exceptions. 
    The prohibition set forth in section 25-91 shall not apply to any special event or function which has obtained a written permit for such exception from the mayor or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 9599, 5-28-96) 
Chapter 25.4 - PAWNBROKERS AND SECONDHAND DEALERS 
ARTICLE I. - PAWNBROKERS 

Sec. 25.4-1. - Pawnbroker defined. 
    "Pawnbroker" means a person who lends money on deposit of pledge, or who takes other things as security for the money advanced, or who purchases property for the purpose of selling it back at a stipulated price, or who makes a public display at his place of business of the sign generally used by pawnbrokers to denote their business, namely, three gilt or yellow balls, or who publicly exhibits a sign that money is to be loaned on personal property or deposit. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Pawnbroker defined, R.S. 37:1782. 
Sec. 25.4-2. - License required. 
    No person shall do business as a pawnbroker without having first obtained the license required by the City of Monroe's Occupational License Ordinance. Any person desiring a license as pawnbroker shall make application, in writing, stating the full name(s) and residence(s) of the applicant(s), if an individual or a partnership; and if a corporation, the name and residence of each of its officers and the location at which the business will be conducted. 
    If the business is being carried on, conducted or engaged in more than one location then each location must have a separate license. 
    Upon the payment of the license fee and the filing of the bond hereafter provided for, the applicant shall be licensed to carry on, conduct, or engage in the business of pawnbroker at the place designated in the license. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
Cross reference- Occupational license tax,  20-21 et seq. 
Sec. 25.4-3. - Change in location. 
    If, after issuance and delivery of a license under the provisions of this article, any change is made in the location of the place of business designated therein, the business shall not be conducted at the location or under such license, until the official issuing the license notes the change on the license and the chief of police is notified in writing of the change. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 25.4-4. - Bond. 
    Every person making application for a license under the provisions of this article shall submit with the application a bond in favor of the City of Monroe in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), with security, conditioned for the due observance of all provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 25.4-5. - Book to be kept; entries required. 
    Every pawnbroker shall keep a book which shall be a bound volume, in which shall be fairly written in ink at the time of each loan an accurate description in the English language of the person making the loan or selling any goods, as well as an accurate description of the goods, article, or item pawned, pledged or sold, the amount of money loaned thereon, and the time of pledging the same. When a watch is pawned, the number, name of maker, all letters or marks thereon must also be entered in the book; and whenever any articles manufactured from gold or silver are pawned, all letters or marks thereon must also be entered in the same book. 
    The name, address, sex, race, height, weight, and driver's license number of the person or persons making the loan, pledging, pawning, selling, or delivering said merchandise to the pawnbroker shall be obtained and included with each ledger entry. 
    Records of each transaction shall be preserved for a period of at least three (3) years. No entry made in such book shall be erased, obliterated, defaced or removed. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Required records, R.S. 37:1796. 
Sec. 25.4-6. - Photographic and other records; exceptions. 
    In addition to the information required in section 25.4-5, every pawnbroker shall be required to obtain a photograph of a person selling or delivering merchandise to the dealer. The quality of such photograph shall be sufficient to readily identify the person depicted. In lieu of the photograph of the person selling or delivering the merchandise, secondhand dealers may obtain a thumbprint of such person, the quality of which thumbprint shall be sufficient to readily identify the person. Each photograph or thumbprint shall be cross-referenced with the ledger entry required by section 25.4-5, and shall be preserved for a period of at least three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 25.4-7. - Book to be open for inspection. 
    The book containing records of loans, pledges, purchases and deliveries required in sections 25.4-5 and 25.4-6 and the various articles pledged and referred to therein shall at all times be opened to the inspection of law enforcement officers of the Louisiana State Police, the Ouachita Parish Sheriff's Office and the Monroe Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Inspection of records, R.S. 37:1797. 
Sec. 25.4-8. - Copy of entries to be furnished daily. 
    Every person licensed under the provisions of this article shall make and deliver to the Monroe Police Department, every day before the hour of twelve o'clock noon, a legible and correct copy of the entries made in the book required by section 25.4-5 during the previous day. The name given by the person making the loan shall also be furnished to the Monroe Police Department when specially requested in writing by the chief of police of the Monroe Police Department or his authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Required daily information, R.S. 37:1798. 
Sec. 25.4-9. - Sale of property; lapse of time required; record. 
    No pawnbroker shall sell any jewelry pledged to him as collateral security for loans made before a lapse of twelve (12) months from the time of the loan; neither shall he sell other property other than jewelry pledged to him for a loan before the lapse of three (3) months. 
    All sales of property by a pawnbroker, whether acquired through forfeiture or purchase, shall be recorded in the same manner as required in sections 25.4-5 and 25.4-6. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Sale of property, R.S. 37:1800. 
Sec. 25.4-10. - Hours of pawnbrokers. 
    A pawnbroker shall neither open his place of business before the hour of 7:30 a.m. nor keep it open after the hour of 7:00 p.m., except Saturdays and the month of December, during which time the hour of 7:00 p.m. shall be extended to 10:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Pawnbroker hours, R.S. 37:1790. 
Sec. 25.4-11. - Minors; taking property in payment or pledge. 
    No pawnbroker shall take or receive in payment or pledge for money loaned, any property, bonds, notes, securities, articles, or other things of value from any minor. Lack of knowledge of age shall not be a defense to a violation of the section. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Pledges by minors, R.S. 37:1802. 
Sec. 25.4-12. - Violations by pawnbrokers; penalty. 
    Any pawnbroker who shall violate, neglect, or refuse to comply with any provision of this article shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or imprisoned for not less than ten (10) days or more than thirty (30) days, or both, for the first offense. For the second and subsequent offenses, the pawnbroker shall be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned for not less than thirty (30) days nor more than sixty (60) days, or both. If convicted three (3) times, his license shall be revoked and he shall thereafter not be permitted to engage in the business of pawnbroker in the City of Monroe. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 25.4-13. - Failure to comply; penalty. 
    Anyone acting as a pawnbroker without complying with the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned for not less than thirty (30) days nor more than sixty (60) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 25.4-14. - Pledgor's liability prohibited. 
    A pledgor shall have no obligation to redeem pledged goods or make any payment of a pawn transaction. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 37:1803. 
Sec. 25.4-15. - Prohibited practices. 
    A pawnbroker shall not: 
(1)  Accept a pledge from a person under the age of eighteen (18) years, lack of knowledge of age shall not be a defense; 
(2)  Make any agreement requiring the personal liability of the pledgor in connection with a pawn transaction; 
(3)  Accept any waiver, in writing or otherwise, of any right or protection accorded a pledgor under this article or under the provisions of any applicable state law; 
(4)  Fail to exercise reasonable care to protect pledged goods from loss or damage; 
(5)  Enter any pawn transaction which has a maturity date of more than ninety (90) days after the date of transaction on miscellaneous items and one year on jewelry items; 
(6)  Accept for pledge, pawn or security any articles prohibited under this article or prohibited under the provisions of any applicable state law; 
(7)  Display to the public any pistol, dirk, dagger, blackjack, hand chain, sword cane, knuckles made of any hard substance, switchblade knife, spring blade knife, or throwable knife, or depict the same on any sign or advertisement which may be viewed from the street; 
(8)  Violate, neglect, or refuse to comply with any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 25.4-16. - Presentation of ticket; presumption. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article or in the applicable provisions of state law, any person properly identifying himself and presenting a pawn ticket to the pawnbroker shall be presumed to be entitled to redeem the pledged goods described therein. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 37:1794. 
Sec. 25.4-17. - Lost or destroyed ticket. 
    In the event the pawn ticket has been lost, destroyed or stolen, a pawnbroker shall deliver the pledged goods or issue a new pawn ticket. Before delivering the pledged goods or issuing a new pawn ticket, the pawnbroker shall require the pledgor to attest to the loss, destruction, or theft or the original ticket. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 37:1795. 
Sec. 25.4-18. - Accepting pawn of certain articles forbidden. 
    No pawnbroker shall buy, sell, or take for pledge, pawn or security, any razor, except a safety razor, any dirk, bowie knife, or other knife of like kind or size, any sword cane, slingshot, blackjack, knuckles made of a hard substance, or Spanish stiletto. Firearms, which shall include pistols, handguns, shotguns, and rifles, shall be exempt from this provision. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 25.4-19. - Posting of maximum compensation. 
    The maximum charge of compensation charged by a pawnbroker pursuant to the authority herein shall be posted in a place clearly visible to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 25.4-20. - Pawn ticket. 
    The pawnbroker, at the time the pawn transaction is entered, shall deliver to the pledgor a memorandum or ticket which shall clearly set forth the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the pawnshop; 
(2)  The name and address of the pledgor and pledgor's description, or the distinctive number from the pledgor's driver's license or military identification; 
(3)  The date of the transaction; 
(4)  A brief but complete description of the pledged goods as set forth in section 24.4-5; 
(5)  The amount of cash advanced for the credit extended to the pledgor which shall be designated as the amount financed; 
(6)  The total amount, which shall include the amount financed plus the finance charge to be paid on a monthly basis to redeem the pledged goods, and the total of payments if paid on the maturity date; 
(7)  The annual percentage rate; 
(8)  The maturity date of the pawn transaction; 
(9)  A statement to the effect that the pledgor is not obligated to redeem the pledged goods, and a further statement that the pledged goods may be forfeited to the pawnbroker one year after the specified maturity date of any jewelry pledged or may be forfeited after three (3) months in the case of property other than jewelry; and 
(10)  The service charges which shall be incurred upon entering the pawn transaction and any other service charges which may accrue during the period of pawn. 
(11)  No more than four (4) items shall be listed on each ticket. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Pawn ticket, R.S. 37:1793. 
Sec. 25.4-21. - Stolen items. 
    Notwithstanding any provision of the Louisiana Civil Code or of any other provision of law to the contrary, when the operator of a pawn shop has acquired a stolen item, the operator or the pawn shop shall return the item to the owner at no cost to the owner, upon presentation by the owner of proof of ownership of the item and a certified copy of the police report in which the item was reported stolen. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Stolen things, R.S. 37:1805. 
Sec. 25.4-22. - Maximum rate of interest for pawn transactions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, a person licensed as a pawnbroker, pursuant to this article and Louisiana Revised Statute Section 37:1751 et seq., may charge a maximum rate of interest of ten (10) per cent per month on pawn transactions. In addition to the interest charged on loans, the pawnbroker may charge a one-time fee not to exceed ten (10) per cent for all other services, including storage. Any transaction whereby property transferred to the pawnbroker and later redeemed by the previous owner shall be considered a loan for the purpose of this section. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Maximum rate of interest, R.S. 37:1491. 
Secs. 25.4-23-25.4-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SECONDHAND DEALERS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Secondhand dealers, R.S. 37:1861 et seq. 

Sec. 25.4-31. - Secondhand dealer defined. 
(a)  (1)  Every person in this state engaged in the business of buying, selling, trading in, or otherwise acquiring or disposing of used or secondhand property, including but not limited to jewelry, silverware, diamonds, precious metals, furniture, pictures, objects of art, clothing, mechanic's tools, carpenter's tools, automobile hubcaps, automotive batteries, automotive sound equipment such as radios, CB radios, stereos, speakers, cassettes, compact disc players, and similar automotive audio supplies, used building components, and items defined as cemetery artifacts is a secondhand dealer. 
(2)  For purposes of this section "cemetery artifacts" means any object produced or shaped by human workmanship or tools, including ornaments of archaeological, historical, cultural, or sentimental significance or interest, which may be used to memorialize the dead and shall include but not be limited to all cemetery items, objects, and properties including but not limited to any type of religious or sentimental addition or adornment, inside or outside of a tomb, gravesite, plot, mausoleum, vault or interment location, whether placed privately or by assignment, regardless of monetary worth, age, size, shape, or condition including but not limited to statues, bricks, signage, plaques, tablets, urns, pots, planters, benches, chairs, crosses or other religious symbols, vases, gates, fences, or any portions thereof. 
(3)  For purposes of this section, a "used building component" shall mean any object produced or shaped by human workmanship or tools that is an element of structural, architectural, archaeological, historical, ornamental, cultural, utilitarian, decorative, or sentimental significance or interest, which has been and may be used as an adjunct to, or component or ornament of any building or structure, regardless of monetary worth, age, size, shape, or condition, that is immovable property or fixture, including but not limited to bricks, siding, gutters, downspouts, lightning rods, chimney roofs, lights, chandeliers, stoves, tubs, sinks, faucets, faucet handles, toilets, bidets, showers, fans, furnaces, air conditioners, water heaters, sprinkling systems, shelving, countertops, cabinets, built-in speakers, shutters, trim, rafters, roof tiles, roofing, studs, foundation, barge boards, paneling, stairs, risers, banisters, wiring, plumbing, hinges, door latches, door knobs, medallions, mantles, flooring, carpet, tiles, molding, wainscoting, pavers, doors, windows, sills, transoms, joists, mailboxes, signage, fountains, decking, gates, fences, planters, landscaping, plantings or portions thereof, or component parts of immovable property of any nature or kind whatsoever. 
(4)  For purposes of this section, a "lot of used building components" shall mean a group of like used building components. 
(b)  Except as provided for in R.S. 37:1869.1, the provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Dealers in coins and currency, dealers in antiques, nor to gun and knife shows or other trade and hobby shows. 
(2)  Persons solely engaged in the business of buying, selling, trading in, or otherwise acquiring or disposing of motor vehicles and used parts of motor vehicles, and shall not apply to wreckers or dismantlers of motor vehicles who are licensed under the provisions of R.S. 32:771 et seq. 
(3)  Private residential sales commonly known as "garage sales" or "yard sales" as long as such sales take place at a residential address. 
(4)  Any bona fide charity possessing a valid exemption under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89; Ord. No. 10,619, 9-12-06; Ord. No. 10,953, 8-25-09) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 37:1861. 
Sec. 25.4-32. - License required; application; bond; exemptions. 
    No person shall do business as a secondhand dealer in this city without having first obtained the license required by the City of Monroe's Occupational License Ordinance. Any person desiring a license as a secondhand dealer shall make application in writing, specifying the street address of the building where the business is to be carried on. The application shall be signed by at least three (3) property taxpayers of the City of Monroe, certifying that the applicant is of good moral character. The applicant shall also submit with his application a bond in favor of the city in the sum of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) with security, conditioned for the due observance of all provisions of this article. 
    The provisions of this section shall not apply to a retail tire outlet or to an automobile dealer dealing in tires. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
Cross reference- Occupational license tax,  20-21 et seq. 
Sec. 25.4-33. - Change in location. 
    If, after issuance and delivery of a license under the provisions of this article, any change is made in the location of the place of business designated therein, the business shall not be conducted at the location or under such license, until the official issuing the license notes the change on the license and the chief of police is notified, in writing, of the change. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 25.4-34. - Comprehensive record of secondhand goods or objects purchased. 
    Every secondhand dealer as defined in this article shall be required to maintain a book or ledger setting forth each purchase or sale of secondhand or used merchandise for each transaction. Each ledger entry shall be entered at the time of each transaction and shall contain an accurate description in the English language of the merchandise or article received, including serial numbers, model numbers, brand names, colors, sizes, initials, style and any other distinguishing letters, number or marks, numbers of said objects and the amount paid for the merchandise or article. 
    In addition to the above requirements on the merchandise or article, the secondhand dealer is required to keep the name, address, sex, race, height, weight, and driver's license number of the person or persons selling or delivering said merchandise to the secondhand dealer along with a description of how the merchandise was delivered. If the merchandise was delivered by vehicle the dealer shall obtain the license plate number of the vehicle. No dealer shall purchase or accept any merchandise by any other method unless the seller provides picture identification with a valid state driver's license, an armed forces identification card or a state identification card issued by the motor vehicle office of the state police department. The state driver's license number or the military identification card number or the state identification card number shall be recorded on the daily report. Any information required herein and not provided by the dealer shall automatically become a violation as per section 25.4-41. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89; Ord. No. 10,620, 9-12-06) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 37:1864. 
Sec. 25.4-35. - Photographic and other records; exceptions. 
    In addition to the information required in section 25.4-34, every secondhand dealer shall be required to obtain a photograph of the person selling or delivering merchandise to the dealer. The quality of such photograph shall be sufficient to readily identify the person depicted. In lieu of the photograph of the person selling or delivering the merchandise, secondhand dealers may obtain a thumbprint of such person, the quality of which thumbprint shall be sufficient to readily identify the person. Each photograph or thumbprint shall be cross-referenced with the ledger entry required by section 25.4-34, and shall be preserved for a period of at least three (3) years. 
    The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  A transaction between dealers who are licensed under Article I of this chapter, Part I of Chapter 21 of Title 37 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950; 
(2)  The sale or purchase of manufactured registered bullion bars, coins, or other numismatic items; or 
(3)  A retail tire outlet or an automobile dealer dealing in tires. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 37:1864.1. 
Sec. 25.4-36. - Purchase of precious metals and stones from minors. 
    No secondhand dealer shall purchase gold, silver, copper, brass, or other precious metals, jewelry, precious stones or objects composed of such precious metals or stones from a person under the age of eighteen (18). Lack of knowledge of age shall not be a defense to a violation of this section. 
    The provisions of this section shall not apply to the sale or purchase of manufactured registered bullion bars, coins, or other numismatic items; or, a retail tire outlet or an automobile dealer dealing in tires. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 37:1864.2. 
Sec. 25.4-37. - Book to be open for inspection. 
    The book containing records of purchase required in section 25.4-34 and section 25.4-35, and the various articles purchased and referred to therein shall, at all times, be opened to the inspection of law enforcement officers of the Louisiana State Police, the Ouachita Parish Sheriff's Office and the Monroe Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 37:1865. 
Sec. 25.4-38. - Daily reports of entries. 
    Every person licensed under the provisions of this article shall make and deliver to the Monroe Police Department, every day before the hour of 12:00 noon, a legible and correct copy of the entries made in the book required by section 25.4-34 during the previous day. The name given by the person making the loan shall also be furnished to the Monroe Police Department when specially requested in writing by the chief of police of the Monroe Police Department or his authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 37:1866. 
Sec. 25.4-39. - Disposal or changing identity prohibited during thirty-day period; exceptions. 
    No secondhand dealer shall sell or dispose of or change or destroy the identity of any goods, articles, or things purchased by him before an interval of thirty (30) calendar days from the date of purchase has elapsed. Any secondhand dealer may sell, dispose of, change, or destroy any goods, articles or things purchased by him from a client known to him without any delay, and the secondhand dealer shall certify his knowledge of the client in the book set forth in section 25.4-34. 
    The provisions of this section shall not apply to a retail tire outlet or an automobile dealer dealing in tires. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 37:1867. 
Sec. 25.4-40. - Hours of business. 
    A secondhand dealer shall neither open his place of business before the hour of 7:30 a.m. nor keep it open after the hour of 7:00 p.m., except Saturdays and the month of December, during which time the hour of 7:00 p.m. shall be extended to 10:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 37:1868. 
Sec. 25.4-41. - Violations; penalty. 
    Any secondhand dealer who shall violate, neglect or refuse to comply with any provision of this article shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00), nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or imprisoned for not less than ten (10) days nor more than thirty (30) days, or both for the first offense. For the second and subsequent offenses, the pawnbroker shall be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned for not less than thirty (30) days nor more than sixty (60) days, or both. If convicted three (3) times his license shall be revoked and he shall thereafter not be permitted to engage in the business of secondhand dealer in the City of Monroe. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
Sec. 25.4-42. - Failure to comply; penalty. 
    Anyone acting as a secondhand dealer without complying with provisions of this article shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned for not less than thirty (30) days nor more than sixty (60) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 9110, 12-12-89) 
Chapter 25.5 - PEDDLERS, TRANSIENT MERCHANTS, ETC.[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7678,  1-10, adopted May 8, 1984, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, codification as 25.5-21-25.5-30 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Licenses and taxation, ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Local regulation of peddlers, R.S. 33:4832. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 25.5-1-25.5-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRANSIENT AND OPEN-AIR MERCHANTS 

Sec. 25.5-20. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect the public from improper sales techniques by transient and open-air merchants, to discourage the sale of inferior quality merchandise by such merchants, to require posting of a security bond by all transient and open-air merchants in order to satisfy valid warranty claims of purchasers, and to provide a method for enforcement of violations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 7801, 5-28-85) 
Sec. 25.5-21. - Annual license tax. 
    There is hereby levied an annual license tax, as hereinafter specified, upon each person acting as a transient merchant or open-air merchant, as hereinafter defined, in the City of Monroe, who may be subject to such license under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 7678,  1, 5-8-84; Ord. No. 7801,  1, 5-28-85) 
Sec. 25.5-22. - Definitions. 
(a)  A "transient merchant" is any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other association, including agents, representatives and employees thereof, who exhibits merchandise, including models or samples thereof, in any hotel or motel room, rooming house, store, club, storehouse, house or other permanent building structure, for the purpose of selling, offering to sell or taking orders for the sale of such merchandise, and who in connection with such business advertises in the City of Monroe using one or more of the common media of newspapers, radio or television. 
(b)  An "open-air merchant" is any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other association, including agents, representatives and employees thereof, who exhibits merchandise, including models or samples thereof, in, upon or about an automobile, truck, trailer, mobile home or other mode of conveyance, or who exhibits such merchandise on any public or private street, driveway, lot, parking lot or other outdoor property within the City of Monroe, for the purpose of selling, offering to sell or taking orders for the sale of such merchandise. 
(c)  "Merchandise" shall mean any consumer item, new or used, except for the items listed below. 
(d)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other unincorporated association having a licensed permanent retail location in the City of Monroe, provided that: 
(1)  The name of such licensed retail business is used in connection with all merchandise sold or offered for sale; 
(2)  All vendees are notified that all merchandise is sold under the auspices of said licensed permanent retail business; 
(3)  The name of the licensed permanent establishment is clearly included in all advertisements in connection with the sale of such merchandise; 
(4)  The owner or owners of the licensed retail establishment expressly assume responsibility for all merchandise in the same manner as if the merchandise had been sold at the licensed permanent retail establishment. 
(e)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Sales of meat, seafood, vegetables, fruit or perishable farm products. 
(2)  Sales of handcrafted items at arts and crafts shows, fairs or festivals sponsored by a Louisiana nonprofit corporation. 
(3)  Sales made at events commonly known as flea markets, stamp shows, coin shows, arts and crafts shows, trade shows or other exhibitions, provided the manager, promoter, coordinator, or other persons in authority for such market, show or exhibition has complied with all applicable requirements of the sponsor of the market, show or exhibition and with the applicable requirements of the City of Monroe. 
(4)  Authorized sales by participating vendors on fairgrounds during a local or parish fair. 
(5)  Sales of soft drinks or refreshments. 
(6)  Sales of second-hand or used clothing. 
(7)  Sales of cut flowers. 
(8)  Sales of balloons and other trinket items at parades and circuses, provided that the sponsor of the parade or circus has obtained the proper permit and authorization from the City of Monroe. 
(9)  Sales of handcrafted items made or produced by an individual who has obtained a valid home-occupation license from the City of Monroe as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 7678,  2, 5-8-84; Ord. No. 7801,  2, 5-28-85) 
Sec. 25.5-23. - License required; fee. 
    It shall be unlawful for any transient merchant to transact any phase of business in the City of Monroe, including advertising, without first applying to the department of administration for a license. The fee for this license shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per annum. 
(Ord. No. 7678,  3, 5-8-84) 
Sec. 25.5-24. - Application for permit. 
(a)  Every transient merchant and/or open-air merchant subject to the provisions of this section, before selling at retail, or offering for sale at retail, within the incorporated limits of the City of Monroe any goods, wares or merchandise, either from stock or by sample, shall make application with the department of administration for a permit to carry on such business within the City of Monroe. Such application shall be in writing, duly sworn by the applicant in person, or by the applicant's duly authorized representative, and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name of the person having the management or supervision of such business during the time it shall be carried on in the city; 
(2)  The address of such person while engaged in such business in the city; 
(3)  The capacity in which such person will act; that is, whether as proprietor or agent; 
(4)  The name of the person for whose account the business shall be carried on, and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is incorporated; 
(5)  Three (3) business references; 
(6)  The place where the owner of such business conducts or maintains an established place of business; 
(7)  The place in the city where it is proposed to carry on such business, and the length of time during which it is expected or proposed that such business shall be conducted; 
(8)  The place, other than the permanent place of business of the owner, where such transient merchant or open-air merchant within the six (6) months next preceding the date of such application conducted or carried on a temporary or transitory business, stating the nature there of and giving the post office and street addresses of any building or office in which such business was so conducted; 
(9)  A statement of the nature, character and quantity of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold at retail or offered for sale at retail in the city and the invoice value of such goods; 
(10)  A statement as to whether the goods are to be sold at retail from stock in possession or by sample, and whether the same are to be sold at retail at auction or public outcry, or by personal solicitation, or otherwise; 
(11)  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or to be done in order to attract customers; 
(12)  The number, either of arrests or convictions of misdemeanors or crimes, and the nature of the offenses for which arrested or convicted, if any; 
(13)  To the application must be appended a letter from the firm for which the applicant purports to do business, authorizing the application to act as its representative; 
(14)  Written evidence of permission from the owner of the property where the retail activities are proposed to be conducted. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any transient vendor, solicitor, canvasser or merchant to engage in business until he shall have first applied to and obtained a permit to engage in business, in accordance with the above provisions and has paid all taxes and fees required by law for the transaction of such business in the incorporated limits for the City of Monroe; the director of administration shall issue such permit in writing which shall state the date same was issued, the nature of the business authorized to be carried on and the expiration date of such permit, the place where such business may be carried on under such permit, and the name of the person or persons authorized to carry on the same, which permit shall be signed by the director of administration or his authorized representative. 
(c)  The permit so issued shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. In the event the person applying for such permit shall desire to do business in more than one place, then separate permits shall be applied for and issued for each place of business, and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business, and the fee herein provided for shall be paid for each permit. 
(Ord. No. 7678,  4, 5-8-84) 
Sec. 25.5-25. - Violation. 
    The violation of any of the foregoing provisions or the doing of business otherwise than provided in the application and permit issued thereon, shall constitute a forfeiture of the permit and the mayor of the City of Monroe, or his authorized representative may suspend the operation of such permit not to exceed ten (10) days, and upon the request of the holder of such permit, grant a hearing and rule upon such forfeiture. Should the department of administration find that there has been a violation of the conditions of the permit, working a forfeiture of the permit, such permit may be immediately forfeited, surrendered and cancelled. A forfeiture of the permit shall not entitle the permittee to any refund of taxes or fees paid. 
(Ord. No. 7678,  5, 5-8-84) 
Sec. 25.5-26. - Inspections. 
    Immediately upon issuing any permit provided for as above, the director of administration or any of his representatives shall at any time thereafter and at all reasonable hours make an inspection of the place of business as provided in said permit and shall determine whether or not such business is carried on or conducted by the person or persons and in the manner provided in the permit, and the application upon which the permit was issued, and whether the permit is posted as provided by section 25.5-25 and whether or not the other provisions of said section are being observed in the carrying on of such business. 
(Ord. No. 7678,  6, 5-8-84) 
Sec. 25.5-27. - Issuance of permit. 
    No permit shall be issued until the expiration of ten (10) days from date of application and after proper investigation of said applicant and provided said applicant meets all requirements herein set forth and has complied with all other applicable ordinances. The permit issued shall be valid for a period of duration of the sale. 
(Ord. No. 7678,  7, 5-8-84) 
Sec. 25.5-28. - Bonding. 
    Before such license is issued by the director of administration, the applicant will be required to furnish a performance bond in an amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). Such bond will be held by the director of administration for a period of ninety (90) days after all orders of goods, wares and clothing merchandise have been delivered to the persons from whom the orders are taken, to assure delivery of said orders to the satisfaction of such persons, and to be in compliance with the specifications stated in the order and meeting the requirements of the solicitations and advertisements. 
(Ord. No. 7678,  8, 5-8-84) 
Sec. 25.5-29. - Report by hotel or motel keeper. 
    Report by hotel or motel keeper. The owner, proprietor or manager of any hotel, motel, rooming house or other place of public accommodation shall report, within six (6) hours after renting, to the chief of police, the name of any person who has rented a room or other space for the sale and display of merchandise of a transient merchant, giving the location of the room so rented. 
(Ord. No. 7678,  9, 5-8-84) 
Sec. 25.5-30. - Penalties. 
    Any person who fails to obtain said permit or to comply with any regulations contained herein shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be imprisoned for a period of not more than thirty (30) days or fined the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or both, at the discretion of the judge. A permittee so convicted shall forfeit said permit and not be entitled to a refund of the fees paid thereof. Every day that a violation of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 7678,  10, 5-8-84) 
Secs. 25.5-31-25.5-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MOBILE FOOD VENDORS 

Sec. 25.5-40. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Mobile food vendor means a person, natural or juridical, that has obtained the required permits under this section to operate a mobile food operation to serve or distribute victuals on the public right-of-way or private property. Mobile vendors will include food trailers and carts. 
    Mobile food vendor [vehicle] means any vehicle that is completely mobile with no permanent fixed location and which qualifies as a mobile vendor under the rules and regulations of the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals, the vendor of which prepares all or most of its victuals on board the vehicle to serve or distribute to customers, in a form suitable for immediate ingestion or consumption. 
    Modular kitchen food vendor means any food unit that is factory built and delivered to a permanent fixed location and which qualifies as a food vendor under the rules and regulations of the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals, the vendor of which prepares all or most of its victuals on board the vehicle to serve or distribute to customers, in a form suitable for immediate ingestion or consumption. 
    Food court means any area, public or private that is zoned by the City of Monroe for the selling of prepared food, the foods may be prepared either on site or in any kitchen approved by the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals, said area to be used by one or more mobile food vendors or modular kitchen food vendors. 
    Food courts may establish non-food accessory businesses such as games, face areas or stages for music talents, painting, arcade play, exhibits and the like. Each of these accessory businesses must secure any City of Monroe and State of Louisiana sales tax permits as required. 
    Permittee means the recipient of a mobile vending permit under the terms and provisions of this article. 
    Private property means any private residence or business that is allowing the sale of victuals from a mobile food vendor. 
    Public right-of-way means any city street, alley, road, sidewalk, neutral ground, or other passageway whereby pedestrians or vehicles traverse. 
    Serve or distribute means soliciting the sale of or offering for sale victuals. 
    Victuals means food of any kind that is prepared, packaged or in a form that is suitable for immediate ingestion or consumption by human beings and shall not include any non-food items. 
    Defined permitted areas means those areas set forth in section 25.5-41 based upon such criteria as distance from fixed-based restaurants, valid concerns by other businesses or private citizens about specific areas or such other concerns as may be necessary to protect the rights of private citizens and land-based businesses. If a permit has been granted for a particular location and valid concerns are brought to the attention of tax and revenue and deemed to be valid, the permittee may be required to locate to another approved location. 
(Ord. No. 11,520, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 25.5-41. - Permitted locations. 
(a)  River Market East to Civic Center from Interstate 20 at River to Louisville Ave.; 
(b)  DeSiard Street from River East to 18th Street; 
(c)  Washington Street from Walnut east to 18th Street; 
(d)  Eighteenth Street from Forsythe south to DeSiard; 
(e)  Louisville from the River to DeSiard and along DeSiard to Kansas Lane; 
(f)  Highway 165 from DeSiard north to Monroe City limits; 
(g)  Tower Armand from 18th Street to Highway 165; 
(h)  Air Industrial Park area; 
(i)  Private land for commercial use, parties and events and construction sites in permitted areas; 
(j)  ULM property including "The Grove" with permission of ULM; 
(k)  Forsythe Park, Forsythe Landing along the river; Louisiana Purchase Gardens and Zoo, Masur Museum and the Cooley House. 
(l)  To those areas south of Interstate 20 which are permitted pursuant to all other regulations as set forth in article III, sections 25.5-40 through 25.5-47. 
(Ord. No. 11,520, 10-28-14; Ord. No. 11,746, 12-27-16) 
Sec. 25.5-42. - Permit required and authorized. 
    Every person, whether natural or juridical, who desires to use the public right-of-way, public places or private property to conduct any of the businesses or callings hereinafter set forth, shall first apply for and be granted a mobile vending permit from the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals pursuant to Title 51, Chapter XXIII of the Administrative Code and a mobile vending permit from the City of Monroe as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 11,520, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 25.5-43. - Permit requirements. 
(a)  A mobile vending permit shall be applied for with the department of taxation and revenue and shall be on forms provided by the city and in the format and number of copies as required by the instructions. No permit shall be issued until all requisite approvals by the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals are finalized and received by the department of taxation and revenue. 
(b)  Any permit that is issued shall in each instance state the occasion and location for which it is issued, the location of the mobile food vendor activity and the date upon which it will expire. Permits may be issued on an annual basis if applied for. Nothing contained herein precludes the prorating of permit fees. Annual permits may be issued that cover all permitted locations within the City of Monroe. 
(c)  Permits shall be conspicuously displayed and be clearly visible from outside the mobile food unit at all times during operation. 
(d)  The director of the administration for the City of Monroe may prescribe such other policies and procedures as to the issuance of permits as may be required to carry out the full intent and purpose of this article. 
(e)  The provisions of this article III shall not be applicable to those areas and events which are otherwise exempted by the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals for events such as recognized fairs and festivals. 
(Ord. No. 11,520, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 25.5-44. - Permit and franchise fees. 
    There shall be a permit fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). An annual permit fee shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 11,520, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 25.5-45. - Rules and regulations for all mobile food vendors. 
    In addition to all other applicable laws pertaining to permits and franchises, all mobile vendors operating pursuant to this article shall also be subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  All mobile food vendors shall be registered in the State of Louisiana and the driver of any truck shall have a valid driver's license permit. 
(2)  All mobile vendors shall comply with all applicable parking, traffic and vehicle safety laws, regulations and restrictions; 
(3)  No mobile vendor shall operate within twenty (20) feet of any intersection. 
(4)  No mobile vendor shall operate within twenty (20) feet of any stop sign, flashing beacon, yield sign or other traffic control signal located on the side of a roadway. 
(5)  No mobile vendor shall operate within three (3) feet of any public or private driveway, wheelchair ramp or bicycle ramp. 
(6)  No mobile food vendor shall be more than thirty-six (36) feet in length or eight and one-half (81/2) feet in width, however, mobile food establishments solely located on private or public property which are not used as traffic thoroughfares, may exceed the size stated herein with approval of the director of administration. 
(7)  No mobile vendor shall sell alcoholic beverages, controlled substances, or any other item the possession or use of which is deemed illegal under any federal, state or local law. 
(8)  No mobile vendor shall place any chairs, stools, tables or other fixtures, furniture or other obstructions on any portion of the public street, sidewalk or right-of-way, except as provided in subpart (10) of this section. 
(9)  All mobile vendors shall provide a trash receptacle within three (3) feet of the front or back of the mobile food vendor but out of streets or public walkways, which shall be large enough to contain all refuse generated by operation. 
The location shall be kept clean and free of trash and debris. All mobile vendors shall be responsible for cleaning all debris and refuse generated by such operation within a fifty-foot radius of the mobile food vendor upon ceasing operation. It shall be unlawful for any mobile vendor to leave any location without first picking up, removing and properly disposing of all trash or refuse remaining at a location. 
After dispensing victuals, at any location, a food truck operator, prior to leaving the location, shall pick up, remove and dispose of all trash of refuse within twenty-five (25) feet of the food operation which consists of materials originally dispensed from the food vendor, including packages or containers or parts of either used with or for dispensing the victuals. 
Any trash, garbage, refuse or other debris generated by the mobile vendor or relating to the operation of the mobile vendor shall be disposed of at approved locations. 
Existing liter laws will be invoked in distances outside the vendor's responsibility. 
Any mobile food vendor found to be or have been in violation of the permit location regulation or any other provision of this article shall have his license revoked by the department of taxation and revenue by delivery of such notice to the operator of the food truck. If such vendor has applied for a yearly license, then a pro-rated share of the cost of the license shall be returned. 
(10)  It shall be unlawful for any mobile vendor to operate in a defective, unsafe or unsanitary condition in violation of any applicable law or regulation. 
No mobile food vendor, whether through a local commissary or otherwise, shall discharge into the City of Monroe wastewater system without first having a commercial wastewater permit and all mobile food vendors must adhere to the provisions set forth in chapter 30, article III of the Monroe City Code. 
(11)  No mobile vendor shall operate any horn, sound amplification system, or other sound-producing device or music system which violates the existing municipal noise ordinance found in chapter 23 of the Monroe City Code. 
(12)  All mobile vendors must comply with all other applicable conditions and requirements imposed upon mobile vendors under the law, and must comply with all applicable city and state health laws and regulations and shall make such sales tax returns and other reports as required by provisions of the Code of the City of Monroe. 
(13)  Mobile food operations held on private property will be exempted from these regulations. 
(14)  No mobile food vendor shall operate within three hundred (300) feet of the outermost boundary of any private or public school property or within three hundred (300) feet of any location where a not for profit events where a sponsored school event is being held unless specifically requested in writing by the governing authority of such private or public school.
