(Ord. No. 11,520, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 25.5-46. - Insurance requirements. 
    At the time of application for, and prior to the issuance of, any permit or franchise pursuant to this division, each and every applicant shall provide written proof of commercial vehicle insurance coverage on any mobile food vehicle or trailer in compliance with state law naming the City of Monroe as an additional insured for the operations of the business. 
(Ord. No. 11,520, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 25.5-47. - Fines and forfeitures-Process and procedure. 
(a)  Any violation of any applicable provision of this article may be grounds for revocation of any permit or franchise issued under this article and shall be an infraction punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation. 
(b)  Violations of the provisions of this article shall be brought by the appropriate department or agency to Monroe Municipal Court. 
(Ord. No. 11,520, 10-28-14) 
Chapter 26 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Planning and urban development,  4-08. 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 9; flood hazard areas,  13-21 et seq.; electricity, Ch. 14; housing code,  19-16 et seq.; Monroe Industrial Park, Ch. 22; subdivisions, Ch. 32; zoning, Ch. 37. 
State Law reference- Planning, R.S. 33:101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 26-1-26-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10,919, adopted Apr. 28, 2009, deleted the former Art. II, Div. 1,  26-16, Div. 2,  26-26-26-29 and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to regional planning and derived from Code 1958,  2-24-2-28.1. 
State Law reference- Planning commissions, R.S. 33:101 et seq. 

Sec. 26-26. - Created. 
    Pursuant to authority granted in Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950, as amended, sections 33:102 through 33:119, there is hereby created the Monroe Planning Commission. 
(Ord. No. 10,919, 4-28-09) 
Sec. 26-27. - Membership. 
(a)  The Monroe Planning Commission shall consist of nine (9) members to be appointed by the mayor with the advice and approval of the city council. All members of the planning commission shall reside within the city limits of the City of Monroe. 
(b)  The members of the planning commission shall serve without compensation and shall hold no other public office. Members shall be appointed for a term of five (5) years from and after the expiration of the term of their predecessors in office. If a vacancy occurs otherwise than by expiration of the term, it shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term by the mayor of the city, subject to the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 10,919, 4-28-09) 
State Law reference- Planning commission membership, R.S. 33:103. 
Sec. 26-28. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The Monroe Planning Commission shall have such powers and duties as provided by law, and in particular the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950, as amended, section 33:106, and shall have such other powers and duties as may hereafter be lawfully conferred upon such commission by the city council. 
(b)  The Monroe Planning Commission shall also serve as the municipal zoning commission, and when acting as such, it shall hold separate meetings with separate minutes and records. 
(Ord. No. 10,919, 4-28-09) 
Secs. 26-29-26-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DISPLAY OF AUTHORIZED MUNICIPAL STREET ADDRESSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10,701, adopted Apr. 27, 2007, repealed the former Art. III,  26-41, 26-42, and enacted a new Art. III,  26-41-26-50, as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to house numbering, and derived from the Code of 1958,  23-15, 23-16. 
Cross reference- Approval of numbering system in subdivisions,  32-71(i). 

Sec. 26-41. - Required. 
    The owner of every house or building in the city, or occupant or agent in charge thereof, has a duty to display a building/residence number in accordance with the provisions herein. 
(Ord. No. 10,701, 4-27-07) 
Sec. 26-42. - Owner to provide and affix. 
    The owner, agent of the owner or the occupant of such building/residence shall provide himself with the number designated by the zoning administrator and shall conspicuously place the same as follows: 
(1)  The number shall be displayed in a location visible from the road upon which the address number is assigned. 
(2)  If such building/residence has a mailbox on the same side of the road as the physical building/residence, numbers shall be placed on both sides of the mailbox. However, under the following circumstances, display of the number on a mailbox is not sufficient to meet the requirements herein and shall be governed by the requirements of subsection (3): 
a.  There is no mailbox; 
b.  The mailbox is on the opposite side of the road from the home; 
c.  There are multiple mailboxes at the location. 
(3)  Numbers must be placed on the house or building, preferably at front doors, but only if they are readily visible from the road (within fifty (50) feet) and the view of the numbers is not blocked by trees or shrubs. 
As used in this section, "front" means that side of the building which faces or aligns with the main or primary street or parking lot on which such building is situated. 
(4)  Numbers may be placed on a private sign or post at the entrance to the driveway, at a height of three (3) to four (4) feet. 
(5)  Numbers should be at least three (3) inches high for residences and at least two (2) inches high on mailboxes. 
(6)  Numbers should be plain block numerals, not script or written numbers. 
(7)  Numbers should be set on a background of contrasting color, preferably black on white. Reflective numbers are desirable. 
    House or building numbers shall not be placed on utility poles, parish road sign posts, or anywhere within the road. 
(Ord. No. 10,701, 4-27-07) 
Sec. 26-43. - Design, size, etc. 
    Numbers provided for in this article shall be of neat design and not less than three (3) inches in height for residences, and not less than six (6) inches in height for businesses, and shall be of such material as to ensure durability, and shall be of such color and nature as to ensure visibility. 
    If a number is not legible or visible from the street, the number shall be installed near the street and be legible and visible at all times. 
(Ord. No. 10,701, 4-27-07) 
Sec. 26-44. - Specific numbering system. 
(a)  Apartment house. A residential building in which the rooms are arranged and rented as apartments. An apartment is a room or set of rooms fitted especially with housekeeping facilities and leased as a dwelling. Apartment houses shall be numbered as follows: the apartment house shall be given one street number, and each individual apartment shall be given an apartment number. 
It shall be the responsibility of the apartment owner to number and to display the individual apartment numbers on apartment buildings. 
For example, 5352 (Name) Street, Apartment 1802; 5352 (Name) Street, Apartment 1803; etc. 
(b)  Residential condominium complex. A building or buildings with individually owned units. Each building shall be given a street number and each condominium unit shall be given a unit number. Unit numbers shall be assigned by the property owner in accordance with emergency 911 guidelines and approved by the zoning administrator. 
For example, 62 (Name) Street, Unit 1. 
(c)  Commercial complex. A building or buildings used for commercial or industrial use. Each building shall be given its own street number and each unit within that building shall be given its own unit or suite number. 
For example, 107 (Name) Street, Suite 1. 
Where there are multiple roads in a complex, each road shall be given a street name, and each building shall have its own street number. In the case of commercial condominiums, each unit in a building shall have its own unit number, and further subdivisions shall be given a letter. 
For example, 113 (Name) Street, Unit 3; 113 (Name) Street, Unit 3A; etc. 
(d)  Combined commercial and apartment complex. A building or buildings used for commercial use in which there may also be apartments. Each building shall be given its own street number; each commercial unit shall be given its respective unit or suite number; and each apartment shall be given its respective apartment number. At no time shall any unit or apartment in the same building be given the same number. 
For example, 58 (Name) Street, Unit 1; 58 (Name) Street, Unit 2; 58 (Name) Street, Apartment 3; etc. 
(e)  Duplex house. A dwelling consisting of two (2) separate family units which are separated from each other by a wall that extends from ground to floor. Each family unit shall be given its own street number. That in a situation where the dwelling units along a street are numbered in such a way that addressing the units in a new duplex house with a unique street number is not possible, the duplex units should be designated as Unit 1 and Unit 2 or Unit A or Unit B. 
For example, 5 (Name) Street; 7 (Name) Street. In certain situations 5 (Name) Street Unit 1 or A; 5 (Name) Street Unit 2 or B. 
(f)  Single-family dwelling. A detached one-family house which shall be given its own street number. 
For example, 1436 (Name) Street. 
(g)  Single-family dwelling with apartment. A primary residence with an accessory apartment. The primary residence shall be given a street number, and the accessory apartment shall be given that street number along with an apartment number. 
For example, 2502 (Name) Street; 2502 (Name) Street, Apartment 1. 
(Ord. No. 10,701, 4-27-07; Ord. No. 11,162, 3-8-11) 
Sec. 26-45. - Separate numbering. 
    Every structure with more than one principal use or occupancy shall have a separate number for each use or occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 10,701, 4-27-07) 
Sec. 26-46. - When to be affixed. 
(a)  For new constructions, the property owner shall display the assigned address number before requesting a final building inspection. 
(b)  For existing structures, within thirty (30) days after receiving written notification that the official number has changed or that any building/residence number is not properly displayed, the owner or tenant shall display the number in compliance with section 26-42 and shall remove any obsolete number. 
(c)  If the owner, occupant or agent fails to comply with this provision within ten (10) days of notice of noncompliance, the department of public works shall be entitled to affix such numbering, and to charge the owner, occupant or agent of the building or property the sum of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for such affixation, said sum to be affixed to the next monthly water bill addressed to the owner and or occupant of the service address. 
(d)  Whenever any number is put on a building or structure in accordance with this article and the same afterwards becomes illegible or defaced or is in any way destroyed, it shall be replaced within ten (10) days after such occurrence by the owner, occupant or agent of the premises. Failure to comply shall entitle the department of public works to affix such numbering and to charge the owner, occupant or agent of the building or property the sum of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for such affixation, said sum to be affixed to the next monthly water bill addressed to the owner and/or occupant of the service address. 
(Ord. No. 10,701, 4-27-07) 
Sec. 26-47. - Enforcement. 
    The zoning administrator is hereby designated as the person responsible for approving the official number of each building and lot assigned by the property owner within the city. Said assignments shall be in accordance with emergency 911 guidelines. 
(Ord. No. 10,701, 4-27-07) 
Sec. 26-48. - Enforcement agencies. 
    The city code enforcement division, as well as the police department, the fire department and the inspections division shall be empowered to issue citations for violations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 10,701, 4-27-07) 
Sec. 26-49. - Naming system. 
    All new and existing streets that serve two (2) or more properties shall be named regardless of whether the ownership is public or private. All private streets that serve one or two (2) properties shall be named upon request of a street owner and approval of the authorized city official. A "street" refers to any highway, road, street, avenue, lane, private way, or similar paved, gravel or dirt thoroughfare. "Property" refers to any property on which a more or less permanent structure has been erected or could be placed. All proposed names for streets within proposed new subdivisions shall be reviewed by the planning and zoning division and the planning commission. A street name assigned by the city shall not constitute or imply acceptance of the street as a public way. 
The following criteria shall govern the naming system of new streets: 
(1)  No two (2) streets shall be given the same name within the local 911 service area (e.g., no Pine Road and Pine Lane); 
(2)  No two (2) streets should have similar-sounding names within the local 911 service area (e.g., Beech Street and Peach Street); 
(3)  Each street shall have the same name throughout its entire length. 
(Ord. No. 10,701, 4-27-07) 
Sec. 26-50. - Naming of streets outside of subdivisions. 
    Property owners or developers of property associated with new or unnamed streets or access easements may petition the city to name such streets. In some cases, an existing named street may be considered for renaming if it is deemed by the zoning administrator that such renaming is necessary for efficient operation of the 911 system. The following procedures and criteria shall be followed: 
Applications by individuals or developers for naming or renaming of streets shall be made to the planning and zoning division office, and shall include the proposed street name and a vicinity location map. The proposed street name must be reviewed and approved by the zoning administrator based upon a public need for the renaming. 
(Ord. No. 10,701, 4-27-07) 
Chapter 27 - PLUMBING CODE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Planning and urban development,  4-08. 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 9; gas, Ch. 17; housing code, Ch. 19; sewers and drains, Ch. 30; permit to break streets,  31-21; water, Ch. 36. 
State Law reference- Building codes, R.S. 33:4771 et seq.;state uniform construction code, R.S. 40:1730.21 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 27-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the plumbing code of the city, and may be cited as such. 
(Code 1958,  22-12) 
Sec. 27-2. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter the following terms shall have the meanings assigned to them below: 
    Apprentice plumber: A person engaged in learning the plumbing trade by working under the direct supervision of a registered plumber licensed by the state, and in the employ of a plumbing contractor, and shall be indentured in the five-year apprentice training program approved by state laws relating to apprenticeship. 
    Journeyman plumber: A natural person who possesses the necessary qualifications and knowledge to install, alter, and/or repair plumbing systems. 
    Master plumber: A master plumber is a natural person who possesses the necessary qualifications and knowledge to plan, lay out and supervise the installation, alteration, and/or repair of plumbing systems. 
    Plumbing: The work or business of installing in buildings and on premises the pipes, fixtures, and other apparatus for supplying water and for removing liquid and water-borne wastes. 
(Code 1958,  22-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 37:1377. 
Sec. 27-3. - Condemned fixtures. 
    Whenever any plumbing fixtures in any building or serving any building are condemned by the planning and urban development director on account of their foul, unwholesome, imperfect or unsanitary condition, they shall be replaced by such fixtures and equipment as is required by this chapter. 
(Code 1958,  22-34) 
Sec. 27-4. - Unsafe conditions. 
    In any instance on which the planning and urban development director finds that the sewage disposal or plumbing equipment or fixtures in any premises are in such condition that the health or the safety of the general public or the occupants of the premises, is in danger, he shall be authorized to cause such premises to be immediately vacated and to remain so vacated until the condition or conditions creating the danger are corrected and such danger to the general public or occupants of the premises eliminated. Any person who refuses to obey an order of the planning and urban development director to vacate premises which the inspector has found to be in dangerous condition as set forth above shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1958,  22-35) 
Sec. 27-5. - Plans and specifications. 
(a)  The plumbing, drainage and ventilation of all buildings, both public and private, erected in the city shall be executed in accordance with plans previously approved by the planning and urban development director in writing. Such approval shall be given if such plans and specifications comply with the provisions of this chapter. Suitable drawings and descriptions of such plumbing and drainage and means of ventilation shall, in each case, be submitted and placed on file in the office of the planning and urban development director. 
(b)  Plans for plumbing work filed with the planning and urban development director for approval shall state within what time the work therein described will be begun. If such work is not begun under the approved plans within the time specified, such plans must again be presented to the director for consideration. Plans shall be approved upon the condition that such approval expires by its own limitation within six (6) months from the date of the permit unless the work under it is then in progress. Plans and specifications shall be approved or rejected within five (5) days, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays, from the date of filing with the director. 
(c)  Plans of the plumbing and drainage of buildings must be drawn in ink on heavy paper or on tracing cloth, seven (7) by eleven (11) inches, or multiples thereof. One vertical drawing is sufficient for a building when it can be made to show all the work; if such work cannot be shown on one drawing, others must be submitted. Where the buildings are situated together on one street and the plumbing is the same in each, the plans for one building in the block will be sufficient. 
(d)  Every plan must be accompanied by a clear description thereof, or abstract of the specifications, on a blank prescribed and supplied for that purpose by the planning and urban development director, showing location and street number of each building, and the size, kind and weight of pipes, and the kind of traps, closets and fixtures to be used in such building. 
(e)  No change or modification of plans will be permitted unless such change or modification is submitted to the planning and urban development director, approved and placed on file, as in the case of original work, and no alteration of the original plan will be allowed except on the written application of the owner of the property or his duly authorized agent. 
(Code 1958,  22-28) 
Sec. 27-6. - Adoption of Chapter XIV, Plumbing, of state sanitary code. 
    Chapter XIV of the Sanitary Code of the State of Louisiana, entitled "plumbing," as amended through March 20, 1984, and as it may be amended in the future, is hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference as fully as if set out at length herein, except such portions as may be specifically hereinafter deleted, modified, excepted or amended. The provisions of said Chapter XIV of the Sanitary Code of the State of Louisiana, entitled "plumbing," shall constitute and be the standards for all plumbing installations, equipment, fixtures and appliances in the city, except such portions as may be specifically hereinafter deleted, modified, excepted or amended herein. A copy of said Chapter XIV of the Sanitary Code of the State of Louisiana, entitled "plumbing," is on file in the office of the clerk of the city council for the City of Monroe, Louisiana. 
(Code 1958,  22-13; Ord. No. 9258, 11-26-91) 
Charter reference- Adoption of technical codes by reference,  2-15. 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference authorized, R.S. 33:1368 et seq. 
Sec. 27-7. - Plumbing code adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted the Louisiana Plumbing Code, 2013 Edition, as promulgated by the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals except such portions as may be hereinafter specifically deleted, modified, excepted or amended and codified into a subsequent yearly edition. 
(Ord. No. 10,559, 1-24-06; Ord. No. 11,494, 8-26-14) 
Secs. 27-8-27-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 27-21-27-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PLUMBING BOARD 

Sec. 27-31. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a plumbing board. 
(Code 1958,  22-15(a)) 
Sec. 27-32. - Members. 
(a)  The plumbing board shall consist of one master plumber, one journeyman plumber, the planning and urban development director or his delegate, the city engineer and three (3) members who are not city employees and who are not connected with the plumbing business. All members of the plumbing board, other than the ex officio members, shall be appointed by the council. 
(b)  Appointments to the plumbing board shall be for terms of one year's duration, subject to the pleasure of the city council. Members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1958,  22-15(a), (b), (e)) 
Sec. 27-33. - Meetings. 
    A majority of the members of the plumbing board shall constitute a quorum. The board shall meet on call of the chairman or a majority of its members. 
(Code 1958,  22-15(c), (d)) 
Sec. 27-34. - Records. 
    A minute book shall be kept in which shall be recorded all business and transactions of the plumbing board. 
(Code 1958,  22-15(f)) 
Sec. 27-35. - Chairman. 
    The planning and urban development director or his delegate shall be the chairman of the plumbing board. 
(Code 1958,  22-15) 
Sec. 27-36. - Functions. 
    The plumbing board which shall constitute and act as a board of examiners to conduct all examinations required by this chapter and which shall perform such other functions as are imposed on it by ordinance. 
(Code 1958,  22-15(a)) 
Secs. 27-37-27-43. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS 

Sec. 27-44. - Required. 
(a)  Before starting any plumbing work covered by this chapter the plumber who is to do the work must obtain a permit from the planning and urban development director to do such work. Permits must be obtained for all extensions, alterations or other work to be done in connection with the house drain, the plumbing or the water supply in old buildings, except for minor repairs. "Minor repairs" shall mean stopping leaks in pipes, traps and cocks or faucets; opening up waste pipes, traps and drains through cleanouts only; and repairing broken fixtures and pipes. 
(b)  No property owner shall cause or permit any connection to be made to any drain, soil or water pipe, or to any pipe connected thereto, before the person doing such work shall have first obtained a permit from the planning and urban development director to do the same. The mere fact that such work has been done shall be considered prima facie evidence that such property owner authorized the same to be done without such permit. 
(Code 1958,  22-26, 22-27, 22-30(d)) 
Sec. 27-45. - Application. 
    A plumbing permit application shall be filed in triplicate on blanks furnished by the planning and urban development director. One of such copies shall be issued to the person applying for the permit, one shall be issued to the appropriate city department or agency, and one shall be retained by the director. 
(Code 1958,  22-29(a)) 
Secs. 27-46-27-53. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 27-54. - Applications for inspection. 
    Applications for plumbing inspections must be filed at the office of the planning and urban development director by the plumber, on blanks furnished by the city. Applications for roughing-in inspections must be made when roughing-in is complete (this includes water supply, unless the same is exposed on the walls or the ceiling), and before any of the work is covered up or made inaccessible to the director. For sewer inspections, applications must be made, stating the time when the sewer will be complete and before the same has been covered. For final inspections, applications must be made when all fixtures are complete and before the house drain is connected or any portion of the system is used. 
(Code 1958,  22-30(b)) 
Sec. 27-55. - Plumbing fees. 
    The following fees shall be paid to the city for the inspection of plumbing fixtures, buildings connections or work, as indicated: 
Permit fee ..... $ 75.00 
For each fixture/miscellaneous drains ..... 10.00 
Convenience re-inspection fee ..... 20.00 
Re-inspection fee for initial inspection failure: 
First re-inspection ..... $ 35.00 
Second re-inspection ..... 50.00 
Third and subsequent re-inspections ..... 75.00 
per re-inspection until 
inspection is passed 
Fees are to be assessed and collected prior to issuance of final certificate of occupancy. No final certificate of occupancy or final plumbing inspection certificate shall be issued for a project with outstanding fees. 
Grease trap/oil separator ..... $ 25.00 
Penalty fees: 
First offense ..... $ 75.00 
Second offense ..... 250.00 
Third offense ..... 500.00 
and suspension of Monroe 
occupational license for one year 
Fees to be collected per this section: 
Buildings, move from one property to another (not to include sewer tap, inspection fee or added fixtures) ..... $ 50.00 
Single-family ..... 50.00 
Multifamily: first unit ..... 50.00 
Each additional unit ..... 25.00 
Minimum inspection ..... 20.00 
Moving fixtures ..... 10.00 
Extra sewer connections, within property lines: 
Residential ..... $ 25.00 
Commercial ..... 40.00 
For the issuance of a permit for underground sprinkler systems, the following fees shall be charged: 
Domestic backflow preventer ..... $ 60.00 
Irrigation backflow preventer ..... 60.00 
Fire main backflow preventer ..... 60.00 
(Code 1958,  22-29(c); Ord. No. 7252, 3-10-81; Ord. No. 10, 197, 4-9-02; Ord. No. 10,470, 3-22-05; Ord. No. 11,610, 9-8-15; Ord. No. 11,855, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 27-56. - Inspection of plumbing in relocated buildings. 
    When a building is moved from one location to another, the planning and urban development director shall make such generally recognized tests as may be necessary to insure that the plumbing and fixtures in said building comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1958,  22-30(e)) 
Sec. 27-57. - Presence of plumber. 
    All plumbing work must be tested by the plumber in the presence of the planning and urban development director before it is accepted. When it is inconvenient or impracticable to test the entire work at one time, it may be tested in sections, but each new portion tested must include all portions of the work previously tested. 
(Code 1958,  22-30) 
Secs. 27-58-27-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PLUMBERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- State regulation of plumbers, R.S. 37:1361 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 27-61. - Persons eligible to do plumbing work. 
    No person shall do, or be allowed to do, plumbing work unless he is a master plumber or a journeyman plumber working under the supervision and control of such a master plumber, or an apprentice plumber working under the direct supervision and control of a master plumber or a journeyman plumber; provided that a journeyman plumber, or an apprentice plumber working under the direct supervision and control of a journeyman plumber, shall be allowed to do and engage in the business of doing, the installation, removal, alteration and repair of any kind of plumbing with respect to residential buildings only, including single and multi-family residences and apartments, but not including hotels and motels. 
(Code 1958,  22-16) 
Sec. 27-62. - Special permits. 
    Engineers of buildings, firemen or porters, and general workmen around hotels, motels, factories, office buildings and other industrial and business establishments will not be allowed to do any plumbing work covered by this chapter, except the repairing of leaks and unstopping of pipes where it is not necessary to remove any part of the work or fixtures. Such parties may by special permit issued by the planning and urban development director, do pipe fitting mentioned in such permit in connection with water pipes. 
(Code 1958,  22-27) 
Sec. 27-63. - Place of business sign, etc. 
    Every licensed master plumber must have and maintain an established place of business and have a sign displayed and shall have someone in attendance to receive complaints or notices from the planning and urban development director or the plumbing board and where he can be contacted by patrons. 
(Code 1958,  22-23) 
Sec. 27-64. - Unauthorized use of name. 
    No person holding a master plumber's certificate or a journeyman plumber's license and no firm or corporation holding a certificate authorizing it to do plumbing work within the city shall allow his or its name to be used by any other person, firm or corporation, directly or indirectly either to obtain permits, to send in notices, to make returns, or to do any work under his or its certificate or license. The plumbing board may suspend or revoke any master plumber's certificate or the certificate of any firm or corporation authorizing it to do business in the city in the event such person, firm or corporation allows the use of his or its name as aforesaid, and may issue an order prohibiting any journeyman plumber from doing any further work within the city in the event such journeyman plumber violates the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1958,  22-24) 
Sec. 27-65. - Journeyman to register state license. 
    No journeyman plumber shall do plumbing work in the city unless he has first registered his state license with the planning and urban development director. 
(Code 1958,  22-18) 
Sec. 27-66. - Certificate fee for journeyman plumbers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any journeyman plumber who is not working under the supervision and control of a master plumber to engage in the business of installing, removing, altering and repairing any kind of plumbing with respect to residential buildings, in addition to registering his state license with the city as required by this division, such journeyman plumber has paid an annual certificate fee to the city of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Each such certificate issued to a journeyman shall expire on December 31 following its issuance, and, if a renewal certificate fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) is not paid by March 1 of the succeeding year, a penalty of two dollars ($2.00) per month or fraction thereof, from March 1 until paid, shall be due and payable in addition to the certificate fee. Any journeyman plumber holding such a certificate who does not pay the renewal certificate fee shall not be entitled to a permit to do any residential plumbing work within the city until such fee is paid. This fee shall be in addition to the annual occupational license levied by the city on any business carried on by plumbing contractors. 
(Code 1958,  22-22) 
Sec. 27-67. - Qualifying agents for firms and corporations engaged in plumbing work; filing statement. 
(a)  Any firm or corporation wishing to engage in plumbing work in the city shall file with the plumbing board a statement showing the composition of such firm, or, if it is a corporation, a copy of its charter and a statement showing its present officers. At least one active member of such firm, officer of such corporation, or employee of such firm or corporation shall be a master plumber who has been issued a certificate by the plumbing board and shall be designated in writing to represent such firm or corporation in its dealings with the planning and urban development director and the plumbing board. Upon making a satisfactory filing and designation, such firm or corporation shall be issued a certificate by the plumbing inspector authorizing it to do work within the city. Should the designated representative of such firm or corporation cease to represent it actively in its dealings with the director and the plumbing board or cease to be a firm member, corporate officer, or employee of such firm or corporation, the certificate of such firm or corporation shall be void until a new filing as above described has been made, and a new representative has been designated to represent such firm or corporation. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the other provisions of this section, any firm or corporation wishing to engage in plumbing work in the city, with respect to residential buildings only, shall file with the director a statement showing the composition of such firm, or, if it is a corporation, a copy of its charter and a statement showing its present officers. At least one active member of such firm, officer of such corporation, or employee of such firm or corporation shall be a journeyman plumber as defined in this article and shall be designated in writing to represent such firm or corporation in its dealings with the director and the plumbing board. Upon making a satisfactory filing and designation, such firm or corporation shall be issued a certificate by the director authorizing it to do residential plumbing work within the city. Should the designated representative of such firm or corporation cease to actively represent it in its dealings with the director and the plumbing board or cease to be a firm member, corporate officer, or employee of such firm or corporation, the certificate of such firm or corporation shall be void until a new filing as above described has been made, and a new representative has been designated to represent such firm or corporation. 
(c)  All work done by any firm or corporation issued a certificate by the department director in accordance with the provisions of this section shall be supervised and controlled by the master plumber or journeyman plumber named in the designation filed with the planning and urban development director. 
(Code 1958,  22-19) 
Sec. 27-68. - Revocation of certificates, suspension or revocation of journeyman's right to work. 
(a)  The certificate of any master plumber or the certificate of any firm or corporation authorized to do plumbing work in the city may be suspended for not more than one year or revoked by the plumbing board for any one or more of the following causes: 
(1)  Noncompliance with or violation of any provision of this chapter or any lawful order or requirement of the plumbing inspector or the plumbing board. 
(2)  Conviction of a felony in the courts of the United States or any state thereof. 
(3)  Failure to promptly pay any fee or charge due under this Code. 
(4)  The making of material representations or statements known to be fraudulent or false to any person for whom plumbing work is being performed or to the plumbing inspector with respect to any such plumbing work. 
(5)  Unreasonable delay in completing, installing, or repairing any plumbing work or fixtures. 
(6)  Refusal to install fixtures or appliances which comply with this article or discrimination against any line of fixtures or appliances complying with this chapter. 
(b)  Before any certificate is suspended by the plumbing board: 
(1)  Notice of the particular charge or charges must be given, in writing, to the certificate holder; 
(2)  A public hearing must be held; and 
(3)  The certificate holder must be given an opportunity to answer the charges and to offer any evidence, written or oral, on such charges. 
The certificate holder shall have the right to be represented by an attorney of his own choice and shall have the right to cross examine any witnesses. The plumbing board, through its chairman or secretary, shall have the right to summon witnesses, and the board may have all testimony recorded. The chairman or secretary of the board shall be empowered to administer oaths or affirmations to all witnesses appearing before the board. 
(c)  If the certificate of any person, firm or corporation is revoked, the board shall not authorize the issuance to such person, firm or corporation of a new certificate until at least one year following the date of revocation, and a new application must be filed, a new examination fee must be paid, and a new examination must be taken and passed before a new certificate may be issued to any person whose certificate has been revoked. The board shall have the right, without assigning any cause, to refuse to issue a certificate to any person, firm or corporation whose certificate has been previously revoked by action of the plumbing board. 
(d)  The plumbing board may issue an order suspending or revoking the right of any journeyman plumber to perform plumbing work within the city for any of the reasons hereinabove specified and in accordance with the provisions of this section pertaining to the suspension or revocation of the certificate of a master plumber. If the board issues an order suspending or prohibiting any journeyman plumber from doing plumbing work within the city, such journeyman plumber shall not thereafter be permitted to do any plumbing work within the city unless and until the period of suspension has expired or the board revokes its prohibitory order, as appropriate. 
(Code 1958,  22-25) 
Secs. 27-69-27-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATION OF MASTERS 

Sec. 27-76. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the plumbing business as a master plumber without a current and valid certificate issued by the plumbing board. 
(Code 1958,  22-21) 
Sec. 27-77. - Fee. 
    No person shall be issued a master plumber's certificate unless he pays a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) to the city. 
(Code 1958,  22-21) 
Sec. 27-78. - Examination. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, any person who desires a master plumber certificate shall: 
(1)  Submit an application on forms provided by the plumbing board; 
(2)  Certify that he will pay the fees and conform to the rules and regulations of the plumbing board if his application is favorably acted upon; 
(3)  Pay a fifty dollar ($50.00) examination fee to the city; and 
(4)  Stand and satisfactorily pass an examination conducted by the plumbing board. 
(b)  The application forms prepared by the plumbing board shall require, among other information, the following: 
(1)  The name, age and residence address of the applicant; 
(2)  The number of years the applicant has been engaged in plumbing work; 
(3)  The name of the last employer of the applicant; and 
(4)  References as to the ability and reliability of the applicant. 
(c)  An examination of an applicant for a certificate as a master plumber shall be conducted by the plumbing board and shall be oral or written, or both, shall be given in a fair and impartial manner, and shall be sufficient to determine that the applicant has the necessary qualifications, knowledge and ability to properly plan, draw, lay out and supervise the installation, alteration and repair of plumbing systems and that the applicant has a proper knowledge and understanding of the plumbing regulations of the city. Examinations may be given by any four (4) members of the plumbing board. A percentage of seventy (70) shall be the minimum passing score on the examination, and any person who fails to make such score shall not be eligible for another examination for a period of six (6) months from the date of his last examination. 
(Code 1958,  22-17) 
Sec. 27-79. - Age requirements. 
    Any person applying to be designated as a master plumber shall be at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Code 1958,  22-17(b)) 
Sec. 27-80. - Issuance. 
(a)  Each application for a master plumber's certificate shall be acted upon by the plumbing board with all reasonable speed. If the plumbing board finds that an applicant has satisfactorily passed the examination for the designation of master plumber, and such board does not find such applicant unqualified for any of the causes mentioned in this article, then, upon payment by the applicant to the city of the required certificate fee, the plumbing inspector shall issue a certificate to such person showing that he is qualified as a master plumber. 
(b)  The plumbing board may find an applicant unqualified for a master plumber's certificate for one or more of the following causes: 
(1)  Furnishing on his application to the board any false or intentionally misleading information, or failing to respond completely to any question or request for information contained in such application. 
(2)  Conviction of the applicant on a felony charge in the courts of the United States or any state thereof. 
(3)  The existence of record of unsatisfied money judgments against such person. 
(4)  Revocation by the proper authority of this state or any other state or city of a master's certificate of competency in the field of plumbing held by the applicant. 
(Code 1958,  22-17(e)-(g)) 
Sec. 27-81. - Expiration and renewal. 
(a)  Each master plumber's certificate shall expire on December 31 following its issuance, and, if a renewal certificate fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) is not paid by March 1 of the succeeding year, a penalty of two dollars ($2.00) per month, or fraction thereof, from March 1 until paid shall be due and payable in addition to the certificate fee. 
(b)  A certificate issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be renewable, without examination by March 1 of the year following its expiration. 
(Code 1958,  22-17(f), 22-21) 
Sec. 27-82. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7405, adopted June 8, 1982, repealed  22-20 of the 1958 Code, included herein as  27-82, relating to nonresident master plumbers. 
Chapter 28 - POLICE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Police department,  4-04. 
Cross reference- Bicycle registration,  8-21 et seq.; criminal code, Ch. 12; intimidation by officers,  12-67; false report of crime,  12-87(5); resisting an officer,  12-181; escape,  12-182; impersonation of officer,  12-224; traffic, Ch. 33; enforcement of provisions relative to vehicles for hire,  35-2. 
State Law reference- Police departments, R.S. 33:1941 et seq. 

Sec. 28-1. - Incentive pay program. 
(a)  The program herewith established shall be known as the "Monroe Police Department Incentive Pay Program". 
(b)  The objective of the incentive pay program herein established is to raise the educational level of the officers of the city police department in order to assure the continuance of a modern, efficient and effective department. 
(c)  All officers now or hereafter serving on active duty with, and as regular, fulltime employees of, the city police department shall be eligible to participate in this program. Personnel employed primarily to perform purely clerical or nonenforcement duties, including but not necessarily restricted to the following types of duties or persons: secretaries, filing clerks, office machine operators, switchboard operators, stenographers, meter maids, school crossing guards, dog pound keepers, and similar employees of the department shall not be eligible to participate in this program. 
(d)  The new incentive pay program shall commence January 16, 1980. This program shall include all new and old classified employees of the police department subsequent to its enactment, and shall thereafter progress in annual increments upon each anniversary of the employee's employment with the police department, as follows: 
(1)  Upon his employment with the department, a classified employee with one year of college credits (32 semester hours) or more in an approved curriculum shall be paid fifty dollars ($50.00) per month above his base pay. 
(2)  Upon the first anniversary of his employment with the department, a classified employee with two (2) years of college credits (64 semester hours) or more in an approved curriculum, shall be paid one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month above his base pay. 
(3)  Upon the second anniversary of his employment with the department, a classified employee with a Bachelor's Degree in an approved curriculum shall be paid one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per month above his base pay. 
(4)  Upon the third anniversary of his employment with the department, a classified employee with a Master's Degree in an approved curriculum shall be paid two hundred dollars ($200.00) per month above his base pay. 
No classified employee shall be paid more than one of the above categories of incentive pay at the same time. All classified employees who are now members or who are hereafter employed by the police department shall be allowed credit, for purposes of computing incentive pay, for college work completed prior to the initiation of this program and for all college work completed prior to employment by the department if such college work otherwise meets the standards herein specified or authorized to be established by action of the chief of police. 
(e)  An employee must present to the chief of police a transcript from an accredited college which satisfactorily evidences the successful completion of the requisite college work to entitle him to the receipt of incentive pay. At any time that an employee has earned sufficient college credits to entitle him to the receipt of a higher rate of incentive pay, a new transcript must be presented to the chief of police. 
(f)  The college credits for which credit will be allowed in the incentive pay program must be in courses required in an accredited degree curriculum, other than the following degree curriculums. Home Economics, Library Science, Pharmacy, Medical Technology, Music and Nursing. However, upon petition of an officer, the chief of police is hereby empowered to waive this requirement and allow credit for purposes of this program for one or more courses in the above curriculums. 
(g)  College incentive pay shall be considered for the purposes of calculating pension and relief benefits. Deductions for pension and relief purposes shall be made from the incentive pay of all officers and the city shall appropriate said deduction as the employees' contribution to the police and relief fund. 
(h)  The chief of the police department is hereby empowered to promulgate such rules as he may deem advisable to provide for proper administration of the police department incentive pay program so long as such rules do not conflict with the provisions of this section. Such rules may include, but shall not be limited to, provisions concerning what colleges shall be deemed accredited for purposes of this program, what college credits shall be accepted for purposes of this program, what courses shall be and/or shall not be accepted for purposes of this program. 
(i)  In the event any question should arise as to the interpretation of any provision of this section or of any rule promulgated under the authority of this section, the decision of the chief of police as to the correct interpretation thereof shall be final, subject only to the power of the mayor to overrule such decision. 
(Code 1958,  20-15; Ord. No. 7038, 12-12-78; Ord. No. 7130, 2-26-80; Ord. No. 7179, 10-14-80) 
Sec. 28-2. - Supervisory personnel. 
(a)  Supervisors employed in the police department of the city shall include those individuals who occupy the ranks of sergeant, lieutenant, captain, major, assistant chief and chief. 
(b)  No individual employed as a supervisor in the police department shall be prohibited from becoming a member of a labor organization, but the city shall not recognize any employee organization as the collective bargaining representative for the supervisors employed in the police department and said supervisors shall be excluded from any bargaining unit for which an employee organization is the recognized collective bargaining representative. 
(c)  The salary increases of the individuals employed in the police department as supervisors, i.e., sergeants, lieutenants, captains and majors shall be governed by the following provisions: 
(1)  Each supervisor of the police department employed in the position, grade or class of sergeant shall receive salary increases in an amount equal to one hundred twenty (120) percent of any salary increase received by the individuals employed in the classification of patrolman who have completed their second year of active continuous service in the police department. 
(2)  Each supervisor of the police department employed in the position, grade or class of lieutenant shall receive salary increases in an amount equal to one hundred thirty (130) percent of any salary increase received by the individuals employed in the classification of patrolman who have completed their second year of active continuous service in the police department. 
(3)  Each supervisor of the police department employed in the position, grade or class of captain shall receive salary increases in an amount equal to one hundred forty (140) percent of any salary increase received by the individuals employed in the classification of patrolman who have completed their second year of active continuous service in the police department. 
(4)  Each supervisor of the police department employed in the position, grade or class of major shall receive salary increases in an amount equal to one hundred fifty (150) percent of any salary increase received by the individuals employed in the classification of patrolman who have completed their second year of active continuous service in the police department. 
(Code 1958,  20-16; Ord. No. 7039,  3, 12-12-78) 
Chapter 29 - RAILROADS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Occupational licenses,  12-21 et seq.; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 31. 

Sec. 29-1. - Obstructing crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railway company to obstruct or cause to be obstructed the public street crossings and causeways, within the city limits, with cars or engines of any description whatever, and they are hereby required to clear such crossing within five (5) minutes after the obstruction is so placed. 
(Code 1958,  21-4) 
Sec. 29-2. - Speed limit. 
    The maximum rate of speed at which any railroad locomotive, train, car or handcar may be driven or run by any person or persons along and on any railroad or tracks within the corporate limits of the city shall not exceed thirty (30) miles per hours; and any railroad engineer or engine-driver or conductor or other person who shall drive or run, or cause the same to be done, any railroad locomotive, train, car or handcar at a greater rate of speed than thirty (30) miles per hour within the city limits shall be responsible and punishable for such violation. 
(Code 1958,  21-8) 
Sec. 29-3. - Signals and flagging when switching over public crossings. 
    No car shall be kicked or dropped over a public crossing in the city. When cars are shoved, kicked, or dropped in a switching movement over a public crossing, a member of the crew must protect the crossing from a point on the ground near the center of the crossing and each movement over the crossing shall be made only on his signal except: 
(1)  When crossing is protected by manually controlled gates, watchman, or manually controlled crossing signals and they are functioning (automatic flasher lights and automatic gates are not within this exception); 
(2)  When cars are shoved over crossing and lead car is occupied by member of the crew and the movement is made only on his signal, and when the lead car is equipped with breakhose or pipe and air whistle from which brakes can be applied and whistle blown. 
(Code 1958,  21-3) 
Sec. 29-4. - Installation and maintenance of crossings. 
(a)  The owner of any railroad track or tracks, occupying any portion of any street within the city, shall install, occupy and maintain, in an efficient, proper, safe, suitable and good condition, appropriate crossing or crossings of the tracks of such railroad. The installation, occupation and maintenance of such crossings shall be at all times at the expense of the owner of the railroad track or tracks, and the type of construction, material, width and other specifications for such crossings shall be prescribed by the city engineer. 
(b)  Whenever it is deemed necessary by the city council that a crossing be installed, or that any existing crossing be repaired, renewed or replaced, the mayor shall give notice to the owner of the railroad track or tracks to do the work deemed necessary, as aforesaid, such notice to be in writing and to set forth the work deemed necessary, as aforesaid, and in the event the owner of the railroad track or tracks aforesaid fails to comply with the requirements of such notice within the period of time prescribed in such notice, the mayor shall have the work done, at the expense of the owner or owners of the railroad track or tracks aforesaid. 
(Code 1958,  21-2) 
Sec. 29-5. - Maintenance of drains and ditches. 
(a)  All railroad companies operating within the corporate limits of the city are required to keep all drains and ditches along both sides of their right-of-way, within the corporate limits, open and in such condition that they will carry off all water flowing into them, and shall not permit water to stand in the same. 
(b)  Whenever any drain or ditch of any railroad company within the city shall become filled up or obstructed, so that it will not permit water to flow along the same, it shall be the duty of the city engineer to give written notice, by service thereof by any police officer, to the section foreman in charge of the track in the city, which notice shall direct that the ditch or drain shall be open or cleaned out or the obstruction removed within ten (10) days from the service of said notice; and in the event of the failure of the company to open or clean out such drain or ditch or to remove the obstruction without delay, the city shall cause the same to be done at the expense of the railroad company, to be recovered by suit in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1958,  21-7) 
Sec. 29-6. - Rights-of-way maintenance and clearing of obstructions. 
    All railroad companies operating within the corporate limits of the city shall keep both sides of their rights-of-way, within the corporate limits, cut and free of all weeds and grass or other obnoxious matter, growing, lying or being in or upon any such rights-of-way. Such cutting and removal shall be done as often as necessary in order to insure that such rights-of-way do not constitute a hazard to the health of the citizens of the community; provided, however, that it shall be unlawful for any railroad company to start or set any fire in order to burn off weeds, grass or other obnoxious matter on said rights-of-way. 
(Code 1958,  21-7.1; Ord. No. 7170, 9-23-80) 
Sec. 29-7. - Responsibility for violations. 
    Any conductor, flagman, engineer, railroad official or other person in charge of any train, engine or cars of any railroad within the limits of the city who shall violate the provisions of this chapter, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1958,  21-10; Ord. No. 7170, 9-23-80) 
Chapter 29.5 - SEXUALLY-ORIENTED BUSINESSES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 29.5-1. - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this chapter to regulate sexually-oriented businesses in order to promote the health, safety, morals, and general welfare of the citizens of the city, and to establish reasonable and uniform regulations to prevent the deleterious secondary effects of sexually-oriented businesses within the city. The provisions of this chapter have neither the purpose nor effect of imposing a limitation or restriction on the content or reasonable access to any communicative materials, including sexually-oriented materials. Similarly, it is neither the intent nor effect of this chapter to restrict or deny access by adults to sexually-oriented materials protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution or the corresponding provisions of the Louisiana Constitution, or to deny access by the distributors and exhibitors of sexually-oriented entertainment to their intended market. Neither is it the intent nor effect of this chapter to condone or legitimize the distribution of obscene material. 
(Ord. No. 10,874, 12-23-08) 
Sec. 29.5-2. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the words and phrases defined in the sections hereunder, whether or not such terms are capitalized in the text of the chapter, shall have the meanings therein respectively ascribed to them unless a different meaning is clearly indicated by the context: 
    Adult arcade means any place to which the public is permitted or invited wherein coin-operated or slug-operated or electronically, electrically, or mechanically controlled still or motion picture machines, projectors, or other image-producing devices are regularly maintained to show images to five (5) or fewer persons per machine at any one time, and where the images so displayed are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis upon matter exhibiting or describing specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult bookstore, adult novelty store, or adult video store means a commercial establishment that devotes twenty-five (25) per cent or more of its interior sales or display space to the sale or rental, for any form of consideration, of any one or more of the following: 
(1)  Books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, or photographs, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, compact discs, digital video discs, slides, or other visual representations which are characterized by their emphasis upon the exhibition or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas; 
(2)  Instruments, devices, or paraphernalia which are designed for use or marketed primarily for stimulation of human genital organs or for sadomasochistic use or abuse of themselves or others. 
The term "adult bookstore, adult novelty store, or adult video store" shall also include a commercial establishment which regularly maintains one or more adult arcades. Floor space shall be measured by dividing the floor space where patrons or customers of the establishment are permitted where the primary sales or displays are of the materials described above by the total floor space where patrons or customers of the establishment are permitted regardless of the materials. 
    Adult cabaret means a nightclub, bar, juice bar, restaurant, bottle club, or other similar commercial establishment, whether or not alcoholic beverages are served, which features persons who appear semi-nude. Regularity of such appearances is not required for an establishment to constitute an adult cabaret; a single occasion of such appearance or appearances shall be sufficient to cause the establishment to be classified as an adult cabaret. 
    Adult motel means a motel, hotel, or similar commercial establishment which: 
(1)  Offers accommodations to the public for any form of consideration; provides patrons with closed-circuit television transmissions, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, other photographic reproductions, or live performances which are characterized by the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas; and which advertises the availability of such material by means of a sign visible from the public right-of-way, or by means of any on or off-premises advertising, including but not limited to, newspapers, magazines, pamphlets or leaflets, radio or television; or 
(2)  Offers a sleeping room for rent for a period of time that is less than ten (10) hours; or 
(3)  Allows a tenant or occupant of a sleeping room to subrent the room for a period of time that is less than ten (10) hours. 
    Adult motion picture theater means a commercial establishment where films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides, or similar photographic reproductions which are characterized by their emphasis upon the exhibition or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas are regularly shown for any form of consideration. 
    Chief of police means the chief of police of the city or his or her designee. 
    Child pornography means material depicting a person under the age of eighteen (18) engaged in sexual activity. Child pornography is not protected by the First Amendment even if it falls short of the legal standard for obscenity and those directly involved in its distribution can be criminally punished. 
    Controlling interest means the power, directly or indirectly, to direct the operation, management or policies of a business or entity, or to vote twenty (20) per cent or more of any class of voting securities or ownership interests of a business. The ownership, control, or power to vote twenty (20) per cent or more of any class of voting securities or ownership interests of a business shall be presumed, subject to rebuttal, to be the power to direct the management, operation or policies of the business. 
    Distinguished or characterized by an emphasis upon means the dominant or principal theme of the object described by such phrase. For instance, when the phrase refers to films which are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis upon the exhibition or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, the films so described are those whose dominant or principal character and theme are the exhibition or description of specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities. 
    Dual-purpose business means a commercial establishment that devotes at least twenty (20) per cent of its interior sales or display space to the sale or rental, for any form of consideration, of any one or more of the following: 
(1)  Books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, or photographs, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, compact discs, digital video discs, slides, or other visual representations which are characterized by their emphasis upon the exhibition or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas; 
(2)  Instruments, devices, or paraphernalia which are designed for use or marketed primarily for stimulation of human genital organs or for sadomasochistic use or abuse of themselves or others; and which does not meet the definition of adult bookstore, adult novelty store or adult video store set forth above. Floor space shall be measured by dividing the floor space where patrons or customers of the establishment are permitted where the primary sales or displays are of the materials described above by the total floor space where patrons or customers of the establishment are permitted regardless of the materials. 
    Employ, employee, and employment describe and pertain to any person who performs any service on the premises of a sexually-oriented business, on a full time, part time, or contract basis, whether or not the person is denominated an employee, independent contractor, agent, or otherwise. Employee does not include an independent contractor or a person working for an independent contractor who performs any service on the premises exclusively for repair or maintenance of the premises or for the delivery of goods to the premises, or for the rendition of services incidental to the business of the establishment but not an integral part thereof, such as accounting or legal services. 
    Escort means a person who, for compensation, agrees or offers to engage in any of the following acts: 
(1)  Act as a social companion, guide, or date for another person; 
(2)  Privately model lingerie with the intention of and for the purpose of providing sexual stimulation or sexual gratification to the customer; 
(3)  Privately disrobe for another person with the intention or providing sexual stimulation or sexual gratification to the customer; 
(4)  Agree to come to a specified location for the purpose of disrobing and for the purpose of providing sexual stimulation or sexual gratification to the customer; 
(5)  To perform an act where one or more of the persons is nude, semi-nude or in a state of nudity or for the purpose of providing sexual stimulation or sexual gratification to the customer. 
    Escort agency means a person or business association who, whether on or off the licensed premises, furnishes, offers to furnish, or advertises to furnish escorts, as defined herein, for compensation. 
    Establish or establishment means and include any of the following: 
(1)  The opening or commencement of any sexually-oriented business as a new business; 
(2)  The conversion of an existing business, whether or not a sexually-oriented business, to any sexually-oriented business; or 
(3)  The addition of any sexually-oriented business to any other existing sexually-oriented business. 
    Exotic dancer means a male or female dancer that performs semi-nude or nude for compensation. 
    Exotic dance service means any business or person who provides exotic dancers to perform at a private residence, business or other location (other than an adult cabaret) within the city limits. 
    Licensee means a person in whose name a license to operate a sexually-oriented business has been issued, as well as the individual or individuals listed as an applicant on the application for a sexually-oriented business license. In case of an employee, it shall mean the person in whose name the sexually-oriented business employee card has been issued. 
    Massage center means a commercial business which is not licensed by the state as a massage business and which allows any person, including but not limited to its employees, for compensation, to manipulates soft tissue including effleurage (stroking), patrissage (kneading,) tapotement (percussion), compression, vibration, friction, (active/passive range of motion), Shiatsu, and acupressure, either by hand, forearm, elbow, foot, or with mechanical appliances for the purpose of body massage. 
    Massagist means a person that is not licensed by the state as a massage therapist, and who, for compensation, manipulates soft tissue including effleurage (stroking), patrissage (kneading,) tapotement (percussion), compression, vibration, friction, (active/passive range of motion), Shiatsu, and acupressure, either by hand, forearm, elbow, foot, or with mechanical appliances for the purpose of body massage. 
    Nudity or a state of nudity means the showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area, vulva, or anus with less than a fully opaque covering, or the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any part of the nipple and areola. 
    Obscene is something extremely offensive under contemporary community standards of morality and decency; grossly repugnant to the generally accepted notions of what is appropriate. Under the Supreme Court's three-part test, materially is legally obscene -- and therefore not protected under the First Amendment -- if, taken as a whole, the material: 
(1)  Appeals to the prurient interest in sex, as determined by the average person applying contemporary community standards; 
(2)  Portrays sexual conduct, as specifically defined by the applicable state law, in a patently offensive way; and 
(3)  Lacks serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value. 
    Obscenity means the characteristic or state of being morally abhorrent or socially taboo, especially as a result of referring to or depicting sexual or excretory functions. 
    Operate or cause to operate means to cause to function or to put or keep in a state of doing business. 
    Operator means any person on the premises of a sexually-oriented business who is authorized to exercise overall operational control of the business or who causes to function or who puts or keeps in operation the business. A person may be found to be operating or causing to be operated a sexually-oriented business whether or not that person is an owner, part owner, or licensee of the business. 
    Person shall mean individual, proprietorship, partnership, corporation, association, or other legal entity. 
    Pornography means material (such as writings, photographs, or movies) depicting sexual activity or erotic behavior in a way that is designed to arouse sexual excitement. Pornography is protected speech under the First Amendment unless it is determined to be legally obscene. 
    Prostitute means a person who has been convicted of prostitution or prostitution by massage, or who engages in activities, that, if prosecuted, would constitute the criminal offense of prostitution or prostitution by massage under the Louisiana Revised Statutes; provided, however, that a person shall not be considered a prostitute if he or she is not currently engaging in activities, that, if prosecuted, would constitute the criminal offense of prostitution or prostitution by massage under the Louisiana Revised Statutes, and if: 
(1)  More than two (2) years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement imposed for such person's last conviction of prostitution or prostitution by massage, whichever is the later date, if the conviction was for a misdemeanor offense; or 
(2)  More than five (5) years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement imposed for such person's last conviction of prostitution or prostitution by massage, whichever is the later date, if the conviction was for a felony offense. 
    Regularly features or regularly shown means a consistent or substantial course of conduct, such that the films or performances exhibited constitute a substantial portion of the films or performances offered as a part of the ongoing business. 
    Semi-nude or state of semi-nudity means a state of dress in which opaque clothing covers no more than the genitals, anus, pubic area, vulva, and nipple and areola of the female breast, as well as portions of the body covered by supporting straps or devices. This definition shall not include any portion of the cleavage of the human female breast exhibited by a dress, blouse, skirt, leotard, bathing suit, or other wearing apparel provided that the areola and nipple are not exposed in whole or in part. 
    Semi-nude model studio means any place where a person, who regularly appears in a state of semi-nudity, is provided for money or any form of consideration to be observed, sketched, drawn, painted, sculptured, photographed, or similarly depicted by other persons. It is a defense to prosecution for any violation of this chapter that a person appearing in a state of nudity or semi-nudity did so in a modeling class operated: 
(1)  By a college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; 
(2)  By a private college or university which maintains and operates educational programs in which credits are transferable to a college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; or: 
(3)  In a structure: 
a.  Which has no sign visible from the exterior of the structure and no other advertising that indicates a nude or semi-nude person is available for viewing; and 
b.  Where, in order to participate in a class a student must enroll at least three (3) days in advance of the class. 
    Sexually-oriented business means any establishment that is an adult arcade, adult bookstore, adult novelty store, adult video store, adult cabaret, adult motel, adult motion picture theater, dual purpose business, escort agency, exotic dance service, or semi-nude model studio as defined in this section. 
    Sexually-oriented entertainment activity means the sale, rental, or exhibition for any form of consideration, of books, films, video cassettes, digital video discs, magazines, periodicals, or live performances which are characterized by an emphasis on the exposure or display of specific sexual activity. 
    Specified anatomical areas means the human genitals, anus, and the female breast areola or nipple. 
    Specified criminal activity means any of the following offenses: 
(1)  La. R.S. 14:41-43.5 (rape and sexual battery offenses); La. R.S. 14:80-81.2 (sexual offenses affecting minors); La. R.S. 14:82-86 (offenses concerning prostitution); La. R.S. 14:104-6.1 (offenses concerning disorderly places and obscenity); La. R.S. 14:281-284 (operating places of prostitution, voyeurism); La. R.S. 40:961, et seq. (Uniform Controlled Dangerous Substances Law); engaging in organized criminal activity relating to a sexually-oriented business, specifically La. R.S. 14:230 (money laundering) La. R.S. 33:2845 (tax evasion); criminal attempt, conspiracy or solicitation to commit any of the foregoing offenses; or offenses in other jurisdictions that, if the acts would have been committed in Louisiana, would have constituted any of the foregoing offenses; for which: 
a.  Less than two (2) years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement imposed for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a misdemeanor offense; 
b.  Less than five (5) years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a felony offense; or 
c.  Less than five (5) years have elapsed since the date of the last conviction or the date of release from confinement for the last conviction, whichever is the later date, if the convictions are of two (2) or more misdemeanor offenses or combination of misdemeanor offenses occurring within any twenty-four-month period. 
(2)  The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on the disqualification of the applicant. 
    Specified sexual activity means any of the following: 
(1)  Sex acts, normal or perverted, including intercourse, oral copulation, masturbation or sodomy; or 
(2)  Excretory functions as a part of or in connection with any of the activities described in subsection (1) above. 
    Transfer of ownership or control of a sexually-oriented business means any of the following: 
(1)  The sale, lease, or sublease of the business; 
(2)  The transfer of securities (including interests in a limited liability company or partnership) or other ownership interests which constitute a controlling interest in the business, whether by sale, exchange, or similar means; or 
(3)  The establishment of a trust, gift, or other similar legal device which transfers the ownership or control of the business, except for transfer by bequest or other operation of law upon the death of the person possessing the ownership or control. 
    Valid photographic ID means a driver's license, selective service card or other lawful federal or state issued photographic identification, which, on its face, establishes the age and identity of the bearer, and leaves no reasonable doubt as to the authenticity or correctness of the identification. No form of identification mentioned above shall be accepted as proof of age if it is expired, defaced, mutilated or altered. If the identification submitted is a duplicate, the person shall submit additional identification which contains the name, date of birth and photograph of the person. In addition, an educational institution identification card, check cashing identification card, or employee identification card shall not be considered as a valid photographic ID. 
    Video includes image reproduction and display by videotape or any other medium, such as digital video disk or compact disk, that produces moving or still images on a screen, wall, or other similar display. 
    Viewing room shall mean the room, booth, or area where a patron of sexually-oriented business would ordinarily be positioned while watching a film, videocassette, or other video or visual reproduction. 
    Virtual child pornography means material that includes a computer-generated image that appears to be a minor engaged in sexual activity but that in reality does not involve a person under the age of eighteen (18). 
(Ord. No. 10,874, 12-23-08) 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSING AND FEES 

Sec. 29.5-3. - License or employee card required. 
(a)  Sexually-oriented business license. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a sexually-oriented business in the city without a valid sexually-oriented business license. Separate sexually-oriented business licenses shall be required for each place of business of an operator. 
(2)  An applicant for a sexually oriented business license shall file at the office of the chief of police a completed application made on a form provided by the chief of police which includes an attestation to the authority of the applicant to act. The application shall be signed by the applicant. An application shall be considered complete when it contains the following information and is accompanied by all of the documents required by this section: 
a.  The applicant's full true name and any other names used in the preceding five (5) years. 
b.  Current home address and, if desired by the applicant, another mailing address of the applicant. 
c.  Written proof of age, in the form of a valid photographic ID. 
d.  The business name, location, legal description, mailing address and phone number of the sexually-oriented business. 
e.  The name and business address of the statutory agent or other agent authorized to receive service of process. 
f.  A statement whether the applicant has been convicted or has pled guilty or nolo contendere to a specified criminal activity as defined in this chapter, and if so, the specified criminal activity involved, including the date, place, and jurisdiction of each as well as the dates of conviction and release from confinement, where applicable. 
g.  A statement whether the applicant, or any entity in which the applicant owns a controlling interest, has had a license or permit to operate a sexually-oriented business or to be an employee of a sexually-oriented business issued by the united states, any state, or by any political subdivision of any state, authorized to issue permits or licenses, revoked within two (2) years prior to the application, or been convicted or had a judgment of court rendered against him involving violation of sexually-oriented business ordinances by this or any other state or local government or by the United States within one year prior to the application. 
The information provided pursuant to subsections (a)(2)a-g. of this section shall be supplemented in writing by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the chief of police within ten (10) working days of a change of circumstances which would render the information originally submitted false or incomplete. 
(3)  An application for a sexually-oriented business license shall be accompanied by a sketch or diagram showing the configuration of the premises, including a statement of total floor space occupied by the business.
