(c)  Whenever a complaint is made to the mayor or the mayor becomes aware of a violation of this section, the mayor shall cause to be served upon the owner of the real property upon which such inoperable vehicle is located, a written notice which shall inform such person of the violation and direct that he comply with the provisions of this section within ten (10) days from receipt of notice or the city shall enter upon such property and cause the vehicle to be removed and all costs for the removal of said vehicle shall be assessed against the property upon which the vehicle is located. 
(d)  Notice to the owner of the real property upon which an inoperable vehicle is located shall be by certified mail to the person identified in the last published tax role of the parish tax collector or by attaching the written notice informing the occupant and/or owner of the real property of the violation to the: 
(1)  Front door of such real property two (2) times within a period of ten (10) working days; or 
(2)  On the front of each inoperable vehicle two (2) times within a period of ten (10) working days. If notice is by attachment of the notice to the doors of the premise or the front of each inoperable vehicle, the delivery by such method shall be attested to by a marshal and shall be attached to the record of the matter. If the inoperable vehicle has not been removed by the occupant and/or owner of the real property upon which the inoperable vehicle is located within ten (10) days of the receipt of notice through certified mail or within ten (10) days of the last date of the second attachment to the door of the real property or the inoperable vehicle, the city shall have the authority to enter upon such property and cause the inoperable vehicle to be removed. The notice shall include language notifying the property owner that costs incurred shall be assessed against the property upon which the vehicle is located. 
(Code 1958,  24-51.3; Ord. No. 10,734, 8-28-07) 
Sec. 33-16. - Sale of abandoned vehicles by city. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle belonging to a known or unknown person has been seized or is otherwise held by the police department for illegal parking, stationing, or abandoning of such motor vehicle on the public streets, ways, roads and highways within the city, and the same has not been claimed for a period of six (6) months or more, the motor vehicle shall be considered as having been abandoned to the city and the police department may dispose of such motor vehicle and collect the costs and charges of removing and storing said vehicle in the following manner: 
(1)  After the six-month period has elapsed, the police department shall send a registered or certified letter, return receipt requested, to the last known owner of said vehicle at his last known address, informing him that the city is holding said vehicle and will sell said vehicle to the highest bidder, unless said owner, on or before the date of sale, claims the vehicle and pays to the city all costs and charges imposed by the city for the removal and detention of the vehicle. A copy of said letter shall also be sent to any person or firm known to be the holder of a mortgage on said vehicle. 
(2)  Before the sale of any such vehicles, the police department shall have them appraised by a competent appraiser and shall publish a notice of the proposed sale of said vehicle or vehicles in the official journal of the city not less than three (3) times within a ten-day period prior to the date of said sale. The published notice shall contain a complete list of the vehicles to be sold, the date, time and place of said sale, and notification that said vehicles will be sold individually to the highest bidder therefor. 
(3)  All funds received from the sale of a motor vehicle under the provisions hereof shall be set aside and placed in a separate account established therefor. If, within one year following the date of the sale, the owner of or lienholder on any of said vehicles shall present sufficient proof to the city of his ownership or lien, the said owner or lienholder shall be entitled to the amount received for such vehicle less his pro rata share of the costs and expenses of the sale, as well as all charges and costs due and owing for removal and storage of said vehicle, provided that in no case shall a lienholder be entitled to receive more than the amount due and owing under his lien. Any funds not claimed within one year following the date of sale shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1958,  24-51.1) 
State Law reference- Abandoned vehicles, R.S. 33:4876; 32:473.1 et seq. 
Sec. 33-17. - Disposal of abandoned bicycles and tricycles. 
    Whenever any bicycle or tricycle belonging to a known or unknown owner has been seized for a violation of this Code, or is otherwise held by the police department, and the same has not been claimed for a period of six (6) months or more by the owner thereof, such bicycle or tricycle shall be considered as having been abandoned to the city, and the police department may dispose of the same by donating it to a charitable organization for distribution to an underprivileged child or may sell it, without public advertisement or bids. In the event the same is sold, the proceeds of such sale shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1958,  24-51.2) 
Sec. 33-18. - Summons, arrest, bond. 
    For any violation of this chapter the offending person may be given a summons to appear in the city court to answer same, or in the sound discretion of the police officer, the offender may be placed under arrest and caused to make bond in the manner prescribed by law; provided, any violator below the age of seventeen (17) years shall be summoned to appear before the juvenile division of such court, or in flagrant violations, may be delivered into the custody of the juvenile probation officer. 
(Code 1958,  24-52) 
Sec. 33-19. - Stop signs and yield signs. 
(a)  Preferential right-of-way at an intersection may be indicated by stop signs or yield signs. 
(b)  Except when directed to proceed by a police officer or traffic-control signal, every driver and operator of a vehicle approaching a stop intersection indicated by a stop sign shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersection. After having stopped, the driver shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles which have entered the intersection from another highway or which are approaching so closely on said highway as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(c)  The driver or operator of a vehicle approaching a yield sign shall slow down to a speed reasonable for the existing conditions, or shall stop, if necessary, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection; or, in the event there is no crosswalk, at a clearly marked stop line; but if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway. Having slowed or stopped in this manner, the driver shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian legally crossing the roadway on which he is driving and to any vehicle in the intersection or approaching on another highway so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Cross reference- Other provisions relating to parking,  33-46 et seq. 
State Law reference- Stop signs and yield signs, R.S. 32:123. 
Sec. 33-20. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10,443, adopted Oct. 26, 2004, repealed  33-20, which pertained to penalties and was derived from Code 1958,  24-53. 
Sec. 33-21. - Display of plate. 
    Every registration license plate shall at all times be securely fastened to the vehicle to which it is assigned, so as to prevent the plate from swinging, and at a height not less than twelve (12) inches from the ground, measuring from the bottom of such plate, in a place and position to be clearly visible, and shall be maintained free from foreign materials and in a condition to be clearly legible. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Secs. 33-22-33-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - VEHICLE OPERATION 

Sec. 33-31. - Operation in or adjacent to schools, parks, cemeteries or levees. 
(a)  No person shall drive a vehicle upon the grounds of any school, park, cemetery or upon any levee adjacent to or abutting any waterway within the city limits except upon and along marked or designated streets or roadways, and not to exceed a rate of speed of fifteen (15) miles an hour, unless otherwise provided in this Code. 
(b)  No person shall operate a vehicle in excess of fifteen (15) miles an hour past any school ground on any school day between the hours of 7:30 and 8:30 a.m. and between 2:30 and 3:30 p.m., unless a posted speed limit has been erected, in which event the posted speed limit shall prevail; however, at schools where signs with flashing lights and posted speed limits are erected, no person shall operate a vehicle in excess of the posted speed limit when these signs are flashing, regardless of the day or time. 
(Code 1958,  24-30; Ord. No. 7439, 9-14-82) 
Sec. 33-32. - Dangerous situations. 
    When confronted with probable danger or when signaled to stop by another person in event of danger or peril, a vehicle operator must stop immediately and not proceed until danger is past. 
(Code 1958,  24-16) 
Sec. 33-33. - Turning around or reversing direction. 
    No operator shall turn a vehicle around or reverse the direction of travel in any street except as follows: 
(1)  In intersections of streets with boulevards and at improved openings on boulevards, a "U" turn may be made from one side of the boulevard to the other, provided such turn shall not be attempted when a vehicle approaches from any direction sufficiently near to render collision or accident probable; 
(2)  An operator parking a vehicle parallel to the curb where parking is lawfully permitted may execute a backup movement in order to park provided such movement can be accomplished with safety and without unreasonable delay to other vehicles. 
(Code 1958,  24-22) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate turns, R.S. 32:41(A)(8). 
Sec. 33-34. - Blocking intersections. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle into a street intersection until it is possible to entirely clear such intersection without having to stop in the intersection. 
(Code 1958,  24-29) 
Sec. 33-35. - Funeral processions. 
    The following shall apply to all funeral processions in and through the city: 
(1)  No funeral procession shall travel upon or occupy any street unless notification of such proposed procession has been given to the police department by the funeral director or an authorized official of another law enforcement agency at least four (4) hours prior to the funeral services when such services are to be held in the city, or at least four (4) hours prior to the time such procession will enter the city where the funeral services are not to be held in the city. 
(2)  Any person operating a vehicle in a funeral procession shall maintain an interval of not more than twenty-five (25) feet between his vehicle and the preceding vehicle in such procession (except when yielding right-of-way to an emergency vehicle, or when required to stop at a street intersection under the provisions of this article), and shall also have the headlights on his vehicle illuminated. 
(3)  No vehicle in a funeral procession shall be operated at a speed in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour except when such procession is being escorted by a police officer, and, when such procession is escorted by a police officer, said procession shall not travel at a speed in excess of twenty-five (25) miles per hour. 
(4)  No operator of any vehicle other than an emergency vehicle shall: 
(a)  Pass any vehicle in a funeral procession proceeding in the same direction; 
(b)  Drive across the path of any vehicle in a funeral procession except where and when such procession is separated by a police officer for the purpose of permitting such crossing; 
(c)  Cut into a funeral procession. 
(5)  When properly escorted by a police officer and when directed so to do by such police officer, a funeral procession (including every vehicle therein maintaining proper illumination and interval) shall proceed through stop signs and red or yellow traffic signal lights, provided that every operator of a vehicle in such procession shall proceed with caution into or across any intersection where such vehicle would not have right-of-way if not in a funeral procession. 
(6)  Every funeral procession shall move only on and along the route designated by the police officer escorting such procession, or the route prescribed by the police department when such procession is not escorted by a police officer. 
(Code 1958,  24-45.13) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate parades and processions, R.S. 32:41(A)(3). 
Sec. 33-36. - Changing lanes on multilane streets. 
    No driver or operator shall move from one lane to another on a street having more than one lane for traffic moving in the same direction when a vehicle approaches in the lane to be turned into sufficiently near to render collision or accident probable. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
State Law reference- Driving on roadways laned for traffic, R.S. 32:79. 
Sec. 33-37. - Automatic signal light-Proceeding on red. 
    Where and when the movement of vehicles is being controlled by automatic signal lights irrespective of right-of-way otherwise herein conferred, no driver or operator shall operate a vehicle into a street intersection where and when the RED or STOP signal faced by such driver or operator is illuminated, except as follows: 
(a)  When signaled to do so by a police officer who has stationed himself in the intersection and has assumed the direction of traffic, a driver or operator shall proceed into such intersection in accordance with the signals of the police officer. 
(b)  Unless a sign indicates to the contrary, after stopping, a driver of a vehicle may turn right against a steady red light, provided he has yielded the right-of-way to other vehicles and pedestrians and executes the turn safely. 
(c)  Except when a sign prohibits a turn, a driver of a vehicle may turn left from a one-way street into a one-way street, provided he has yielded the right-of-way to other vehicles and pedestrians and executes the turn safely. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82; Ord. No. 9052, 3-28-89) 
State Law reference- Traffic-control signals, R.S. 32:232. 
Sec. 33-38. - Same-Proceeding when light inoperative. 
    A vehicle approaching an automatic signal light not in operation from any cause shall, if moving on a street of lesser or inferior right-of-way, be brought to a complete stop not more than fifteen (15) feet from the intersection to be entered or crossed and not proceed until it has been ascertained that no vehicle approaches sufficiently near to render collision or accident probable; and a vehicle moving on a street of greater or superior right-of-way shall, upon approaching such a signal, be brought under full control and be prepared to stop in an emergency in order to avert collision or accident. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Sec. 33-39. - Same-Flashing signals. 
    At street intersections where electrically illuminated intermittent or flashing signals are displayed, the following rules shall govern the movement of vehicles: 
(a)  When the red lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, the driver of the vehicle facing such lens shall come to a complete stop not more than fifteen (15) feet from the intersection and shall not proceed into such intersection until he has ascertained that no vehicle approaches sufficiently near to render collision or accident probable. 
(b)  When the yellow lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes the driver of the vehicle facing such lens may proceed through such intersection only at a slow speed and under full control. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
State Law reference- Flashing signals, R.S. 32:234. 
Sec. 33-40. - Reckless or negligent driving. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle recklessly, negligently or in any manner whereby the safety of life, limb or property is endangered, whether or not such recklessness or negligence be specifically prohibited by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
State Law reference- Reckless driving, R.S. 14:99. 
Sec. 33-41. - Leaving the scene. 
    When confronted with probable danger or when signaled to stop by another person in event of danger or peril, an operator must stop immediately and not proceed until danger is past. In event of collision, injury or accident, an operator must stop his vehicle at the scene of the accident, give his name, address and vehicle license number to the operator of the other vehicle or to the person injured, and render reasonable aid, and shall immediately report the accident to the police department. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
State Law reference- Hit and run driving, R.S. 14:100. 
Sec. 33-42. - Emergency vehicles, duty upon approach; following; parking near scene of fire. 
    When an emergency vehicle is making an emergency run and while sounding a siren, whistle, bell or other warning device, it shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle within normal hearing of such warning to fail immediately to draw his vehicle to a position parallel with, and as close as possible to, the right edge or curb of street, clear of any intersection, and he shall there stop and remain stopped until all emergency vehicles sounding a warning have passed; provided, no vehicle, other than another emergency vehicle, shall follow an emergency vehicle while engaged in an emergency run, closer than one thousand (1,000) feet in the rear; and at the scene of fire, catastrophe, accident or emergency to which fire apparatus has made an emergency run, no vehicle other than an emergency vehicle shall stop, park, station or stand itself within one thousand (1,000) feet of the nearest fire apparatus attending such scene. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
State Law reference- Procedure upon approach of authorized emergency vehicle, R.S. 32:125. 
Sec. 33-43. - Passing vehicle proceeding in same direction. 
(a)  On streets of two (2) traffic lanes, with opposing traffic in such lanes, and on one-way streets not marked for more than one lane of moving traffic: 
(1)  No operator of a vehicle shall pass or attempt to pass a vehicle proceeding in the same direction except on the left side of such preceding vehicle. 
(2)  No operator of a vehicle shall pass or attempt to pass a vehicle proceeding in the same direction at any street intersection or within fifty (50) feet thereof or when a vehicle approaches from any direction sufficiently near to render collision or accident probable. 
(3)  No operator of a vehicle shall pass or attempt to pass a vehicle proceeding in the same direction when such preceding vehicle is itself traveling at the maximum speed allowed by this chapter. 
(4)  Before passing a vehicle proceeding in the same direction, the operator of the overtaking vehicle shall turn to the left of the preceding vehicle at a distance sufficiently in the rear of the preceding vehicle to ensure safety and shall not again drive to the right side of the street until safely clear of the overtaken vehicle. 
(5)  The operator of the overtaken vehicle shall give way to the overtaking vehicle on audible signal or discovery that he is about to be passed, and shall not in any manner increase his speed, but, as safety requires, reduce speed to allow such overtaking vehicle to pass. 
(6)  No operator of a vehicle shall pass or attempt to pass a preceding vehicle unless there is sufficient unobstructed road width to allow such overtaking vehicle to safely pass such preceding vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
State Law reference- Driving on the right side, overtaking and passing, etc., R.S. 32:71 et seq. 
Sec. 33-44. - Following too closely. 
    No operator of a vehicle shall follow another vehicle in the same lane at a distance nearer or a speed greater than such following vehicle, in event of emergency, may be brought to a complete stop behind such preceding vehicle without collision or accident. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
State Law reference- Following vehicles, R.S. 32:81. 
Sec. 33-45. - Mechanically unsafe condition, such vehicles not to be operated. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle in a mechanically unsafe condition. A vehicle with a part, or parts, so defective, broken, torn or worn that such vehicle has become a hazard to life, limb or property is mechanically unsafe within the meaning of this section. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Sec. 33-45.1. - Speed limits. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle in excess of twenty-five (25) miles per hour upon any street, avenue or roadway within the city limits, unless a posted speed limit has been established, in which event the posted speed limit shall prevail. A posted speed limit shall be deemed to have been established upon the erection and posting of a speed limit sign by the traffic engineer or his authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 7553, 7-12-83) 
State Law reference- Speed limits, R.S. 32:61 et seq. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10,442, adopted Oct. 26, 2004, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. III, consisted of  33-46-33-49, 33-66-33-80, pertained to similar subject matter, and was derived from Code 1958,  24-57-24-59, 24-60.2, 24-71-24-74, 24-75(a), 24-76, 24-77, 24-80, 24-81; Ord. No. 7131, adopted 2-26-80; Ord. No. 7266, adopted 4-14-81; Ord. No. 7413, adopted 7-13-82; Ord. No. 7449, adopted 10-26-82; Ord. No 7839, adopted 10-8-85; Ord. No. 9159, adopted 9-11-90. 
Cross reference- Parking in Monroe Air-Industrial Park,  22-25; off-street parking and loading,  37-166 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate or prohibit standing or parking, R.S. 32:41(A)(1); parking, standing and stopping, R.S. 32:141 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 33-46. - Application of article; regulations not exclusive, reservation of powers to city. 
(a)  The provisions of this article prohibiting the stopping, standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times herein specified or as indicated on official signs except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device. 
(b)  The provisions of this article imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person of the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles in specified places or as specified. 
(c)  Nothing in this division shall be construed as prohibiting the city from providing for bus stops, for taxicab stands and other matters of similar nature, including zones for the loading and unloading of trucks, vans, or other commercial vehicles, nor shall the provisions hereof be construed as prohibiting the city from prohibiting parking during certain hours of the day. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-47. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Curb means an edging (as of concrete) built along a street to form part of a gutter. 
    Edge of street means the outermost border of the paved area of a street. 
    Fire lane means an unobstructed lane to be used as access for fire-fighting and emergency equipment. 
    Fire protection devices shall mean sprinkler and standpipe fire department connections, fire hose cabinets or sheds, fire extinguishers, or any other devices so marked and designated for fire protection or fire department use. 
    Motor vehicle shall mean any automobile, truck, motorcycle, trailer or mobile home. 
    Park or parking shall mean the halting of an occupied or unoccupied vehicle, other than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. 
    Stand or standing shall mean remaining stationary or inactive. 
    Stop or stopping shall mean the halting, even momentarily, of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-48. - Parked vehicles obstructing traffic. 
(a)  Under no circumstances shall a vehicle be parked so as to occupy thirty (30) per cent or more of the width of the surface of any street in the city and/or vehicle more than forty-five (45) feet in length occupy the surface of any street in the city for a period in excess of thirty (30) minutes, unless the parking of the vehicle is necessary for the loading or unloading of any such vehicle. All vehicles under this section shall be moved immediately after being loaded and/or unloaded. 
(b)  Such vehicles shall not block traffic signs or a driver's clear view at intersections. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-49. - Restricted parking; special temporary exemptions. 
(a)  When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle at any time or for a limited time upon any of the streets or parts of streets or any public parking lot so designated. 
(b)  When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle during the times or for a longer period than indicated upon any of the streets or parts of streets or any public parking lot so signed. 
(c)  Special temporary parking and special temporary restrictions may be put into effect by the police department when justified by special temporary or emergency conditions. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-50. - No parking within twenty-five feet of intersection. 
    No vehicle of any type shall be parked at any time on any street in the city within twenty-five (25) feet of an intersecting street, as measured from the intersecting property lines. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-51. - Stopping, standing or parking prohibited during certain hours on certain streets. 
    When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle between the hours specified by ordinance on any day except Sundays and public holidays within the district or upon any of the streets described by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-52. - Parking signs required. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the city traffic engineer to erect appropriate signs giving notice of any parking time limit(s) imposed, special parking designations or parking prohibitions on designated streets. No such regulations shall be effective unless said signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offense. 
(b)  The signs required to be erected pursuant to this section shall clearly designate the person or persons or groups of persons allowed to park in such areas and/or clearly designate the length of time for which parking is permitted. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-52.1. - Parking space or parking area. 
(a)  Parking spaces shall be clearly demarcated by signage or lines painted on or otherwise applied to a street, pavement or a parking lot surface, or by any other means which reasonably identify an area as a parking space or parking area. 
(b)  Parking in areas not distinguished in any manner shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 10,611, 7-8-06) 
Sec. 33-53. - No parking zones. 
    The city traffic engineer shall designate locations within the city where the parking of motor vehicles is prohibited. Painting the curb yellow or red or posting by signs is hereby deemed appropriate marking to prohibit parking along that section of the street on which said curb has been painted or which has been designated by posted signs. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-54. - Two-hour parking on street or in public parking lot. 
(a)  No person shall park any vehicle on any public street or in a public parking lot posted as two-hour parking and leave the same continuously parked for a period greater than two (2) hours. 
(b)  A driver may not return to the same parking space or parking lot until four (4) hours have passed from the time the driver first arrived. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-54.1. - Ouachita Parish Courthouse parking zone. 
(a)  Free parking shall be allowed on both sides of South Grand Street where parking spaces are demarcated. 
(b)  Free parking shall be permitted in the Ouachita River parking lot on South Grand Street. 
(c)  Two-hour parking shall be enforced on Wood Street, St. John Street (both sides before the Calypso Street intersection) and Oak Street (both sides). 
(d)  It shall be unlawful to park on St. John Street beyond the intersection of St. John and Calypso Streets. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful to park on Calypso Street (beyond the intersection of Calypso and St. John Streets to South Grand Street). 
(i)  Judges of the Fourth Judicial District Court of Ouachita Parish should instruct jurors and witnesses to submit citations received by them in conjunction with their public service and their notices to appear at the city attorney's office to have the citations voided. Citations and notices must be presented to the city attorney's office within five (5) business days after the conclusion of the court proceeding in which the person served as either a juror or a witness. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,612, 8-8-06) 
Sec. 33-54.2. - United States District Courthouse parking zone. 
    Jurors and witnesses should be instructed to submit citations and the notices to appear received by them in conjunction with their public service to the Monroe Police Department to have the citations voided. Citations and notices must be presented to the city attorney's office within five (5) business days after the conclusion of the court proceeding in which the person served as either a juror or a witness. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,612, 8-8-06) 
Sec. 33-55. - Parking adjacent to schools. 
    When signs are erected indicating no parking upon that side of the street adjacent to any school property, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-56. - Stopping, standing or parking not to obstruct traffic; parking position generally; one-way roadway and two-way roadway; diagonally. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle upon a street in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway; and if such roadway has designated thereon traffic lanes, no person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle within the marked traffic lane area so as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the right one-half of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, except that a driver may stop temporarily within three (3) feet of the curb line or the edge of the street during the actual loading or unloading of passengers, or when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals or police officer. 
(b)  On those streets where parking is not otherwise prohibited, all vehicles must be parked parallel to the curb or edge of the street and the vehicle's wheels nearest the curb or edge of the street must be within twelve (12) inches of said curb or edge of the street. On those streets where vehicles are allowed to travel in both directions, a vehicle must be parked next to the curb or edge of the street on the same side of the street and to the right of the lane of traffic in which said vehicle is traveling; provided, however, cars or trucks delivering merchandise or servicing businesses, such as express service, laundry service, ice delivery, etc., before 9:30 a.m., shall be permitted to stop temporarily parallel to parked cars, if unable to park in a legal manner, in order to render such delivery or service, for a period not longer than is required to make such delivery or render such service. After 9:30 a.m., no such temporary double parking will be permitted on any roadway without the permission of a police officer on duty. 
(c)  On a one-way roadway such vehicle shall be facing in the direction of authorized traffic movement; on a two-way roadway such vehicle shall be facing in the direction of authorized traffic movement on that portion of the roadway on which the vehicle rests. 
(d)  All vehicles shall be parked parallel to the curb or edge of the street, except where diagonal parking shall be permitted in those certain areas where spaces are marked for said parking. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-57. - Parking in public alley. 
    No vehicle shall be parked in any public alley so as to obstruct traffic thereon. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-58. - Obstruction of driveways prohibited. 
    No vehicle shall be parked on a street so as to obstruct the entrance to or exit from any driveway or other area clearly used for purposes of vehicular ingress and egress to premises, or within ten (10) feet, measured along the curb or edge of the street adjacent to the driveway, in either direction from the centerline of the driveway. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-59. - Vehicle protruding into prohibited parking area. 
    The parking of any vehicle so that any portion thereof is in or protruding over a part of any area in which parking is prohibited shall constitute a misdemeanor, and any violator shall be penalized as provided by section 33-82. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-60. - Street construction area, parking prohibited; removal of illegally parked vehicle. 
(a)  Upon those portions of streets where construction or improvement operations are being conducted, and such operations necessitate the closing of such street to the parking of vehicles, the persons, firms or corporations performing such operations shall erect barricades showing the closing of such street and also showing that parking of any vehicle is prohibited thereon. The persons, firms or corporations performing such operations shall notify the Monroe Police Department and the city traffic engineer prior to the closing of streets. 
(b)  In the event any vehicle is parked upon said closed streets, the person performing such operations may order a local wrecker to remove said parked vehicles. In the event it is necessary to have a vehicle removed, the owner shall bear the expense of such removal including towing and storage charge. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-61. - Standing or parking close to curbs. 
    No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway, headed in the direction of traffic, and with the curbside wheels of the vehicle within twelve (12) inches of the edge of the roadway, unless authorized to do otherwise by appropriate signs. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
State Law reference- Parking near curb, R.S. 32:144. 
Sec. 33-62. - Standing or parking for certain purposes prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to stand or park a vehicle upon any street or highway for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying it for sale. 
(2)  Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle except repairs necessary by emergency. 
(3)  Storage of such vehicle. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, a vehicle shall be deemed to have been left on the street or highway for the principal purpose of storage when that vehicle has been standing in one place on the streets of the city for a longer continuous period than seventy-two (72) hours. The provisions of this paragraph shall apply to a vehicle which is left standing in front of its owner's residence only when the vehicle has no valid inspection sticker, license plates, or expired license plates. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-63. - Standing or parking for advertising purposes prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall stand or park a vehicle on any street or roadway for the purpose of commercial advertising. 
(b)  Advertising notices relating to the business for which a vehicle is used may be put upon a motor vehicle when such vehicle is in use for normal delivery or business purposes and not merely or mainly for the purpose of commercial advertising. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-64. - Stopping, standing or parking prohibited in specific places. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic-control device and except during the occurrence of normal traffic flow, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk; 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway; 
(3)  Within an intersection; 
(4)  On a crosswalk; 
(5)  Within two (2) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; 
(6)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or edge of the street or within twenty (20) feet of the points on the curb or edge of the street immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone unless the traffic authority indicates length by signs or markings; 
(7)  Within fifty (50) feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; 
(8)  Alongside or opposite any street; excavation or obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; 
(9)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the curb or the edge or of a street; 
(10)  Upon any bridge or elevated structure, upon a highway or within a highway tunnel; 
(11)  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping; 
(12)  On a median, unless the vehicle is disabled or at the direction of a police officer, and then only temporarily for a period not to exceed twenty-four (24) hours; 
(13)  In a space designated with a sign for handicapped persons unless the vehicle displays the distinguishing license plates or placards recognized in the State of Louisiana; 
(14)  In such a location as to obstruct a curb ramp or curb cut for handicapped persons; and 
(15)  Any place where parking will obscure or obstruct visibility of any traffic control device. 
(b)  Exceptions. The prohibitions in this section shall not apply to emergency and public service vehicles whose operators are performing services for which they are responsible, nor do these prohibitions apply to vehicles belonging to persons, firms or corporations under contract with the city to perform a public service. These exceptions, however, shall apply only when an emergency situation requires that such vehicles park in the prohibited areas. 
(c)  No person shall move a vehicle not owned by such person into any such prohibited area or away from a curb or edge of a street such a distance as is unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing or parking prohibited in specified places, R.S. 32:143. 
Sec. 33-65. - Parking of motor vehicles in fire lanes, around fire hydrants and fire protection devices on publicly or privately owned property; removal of vehicles; designation, etc., of lanes. 
(a)  The parking, stopping or standing of any motor vehicles in fire lanes or within fifteen (15) feet of the fire hydrants or fire-protection devices on public or private property or within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station, and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy-five (75) feet of said entrance, when properly posted, shall be prohibited at all times to preserve the health, welfare and safety of the citizens of Monroe. Any vehicles or property found to be parked, stopped, standing or otherwise obstructing fire lanes or within fifteen (15) feet of fire hydrants or fire-protection devices or within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station, and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy-five (75) feet of said entrance, when properly posted, shall be immediately towed away or removed, without notice being provided. The owner of such vehicle or personal property shall be responsible for all penalties or fines, towing charges and resulting storage charges. 
(b)  Commissioned fire department personnel, with the authority of the fire chief, along with other law enforcement agencies, are authorized to issue a citation or to take whatever law enforcement action is deemed necessary or both. Furthermore, when an individual found to be in violation of these provisions refuses a request by an agent of the fire department or a law enforcement officer to move the vehicle found in violation, the officer shall be authorized to have such vehicle towed. 
(c)  The citation shall contain information concerning the nature, date, time, and location of the alleged violation, the state vehicle license plate number, and the make of vehicle. In those cases where a license plate is not visible or legible, the vehicle identification number shall be used in lieu of the state vehicle plate number. The citation shall also contain information advising the person charged of the manner and the time in which he may contest the violation charged in the citation. The citation shall also provide that a failure to timely answer or appear before a court of competent jurisdiction shall be considered a prima facie admission of the violation set forth in the citation, in which the court may assess the appropriate fine or fines and all penalties incidental thereto. 
(d)  The citation issued pursuant to the provisions of this subsection shall be personally served upon the operator of the vehicle by affixing the parking citation to the vehicle in a conspicuous place thereon. The original parking citation shall bear the name or initials and identification number of the issuing officer who shall affirm the truth of the facts set forth therein. An operator of a vehicle who is not the owner, but who uses or operates the vehicle with permission of the owner, expressed or implied, shall be considered the agent of the owner to receive the citation required to be served upon the operator or registered owner of a vehicle in accordance with the provisions of this subsection. When a citation is issued for an alleged violation of this section, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that a person in whose name the vehicle is registered was the operator of the vehicle when the alleged violation was committed. 
(e)  In the event that the registered owner or operator of a vehicle drives the vehicle away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation while the issuing officer is preparing the citation, or refuses service of the parking citation and drives away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation, this fact shall be duly noted on the original and all copies of the parking citation. This original and all copies of a parking citation shall constitute a business record of the law enforcement agency issuing the citation and shall constitute prima facie evidence that the citation was issued and that an attempt at service was made in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(1)  The first violation of the provisions of this section shall be punished by a fine of three hundred dollars ($300.00). A subsequent violation shall be punished by a fine of six hundred dollars ($600.00). Each occurrence of a violation of the provisions hereof shall constitute a separate offense. 
(2)  If the violator is other than an individual, a fine of six hundred dollars ($600.00) shall be imposed for the first violation. A subsequent violation shall be punished by a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Each occurrence of a violation of the provisions hereof shall constitute a separate offense. 
(3)  In addition to such fine, the violator shall also be required to pay the towing fee and any storage costs which are incurred. 
(4)  No fine issued pursuant to this section shall be reduced or suspended. 
(f)  The establishment and designation of fire lanes and other areas for emergency vehicles shall be the responsibility of the Fire Chief of the City of Monroe, along with the cooperation of the owners and/or managers of private property. It shall be the responsibility of the owners and/or managers of the private property to pay for and erect suitable signs as approved by the City of Monroe in the designated fire lanes and areas. 
(g)  (1)  The owner or proprietor of any business establishment as covered in this section is hereby authorized to utilize the area immediately adjacent to his loading dock or service entrance for the purpose of loading and unloading delivery trucks, service vehicles or other vehicles used in conduction of his business. Said loading dock or service entrance shall not interfere with or prohibit the immediate access of emergency vehicles. 
(2)  The owner or proprietor of any business establishment is authorized to utilize the area adjacent to an entrance to load or unload customer vehicles where heavy or bulky merchandise must be handled. However, in all cases the driver of a customer vehicle must attend the vehicle while the merchandise is being loaded or unloaded and such loading and unloading area must be designated and marked as such. 
(3)  The above service vehicles, trucks, customer vehicles, etc., shall be moved immediately after being loaded and/or unloaded. 
(h)  The owner of any personal property or motor vehicle found interfering with or prohibiting the immediate access of emergency vehicles shall be subject to fines as set forth in section 33-84. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-66. - Parking on public property. 
    When official signs or traffic-control devices are erected or installed, giving notice of restrictions on parking, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except as permitted by such signs or traffic-control devices, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic-control device on any public property owned or leased by the city, or any department or administrative unit there or on driveways located thereon. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-67. - Median strip; neutral ground. 
(a)  The median strip or the neutral ground is the area between the dual traffic lanes for the purpose of separating traffic proceeding in opposite directions. 
(b)  Crossing, driving, stopping, standing or parking on the median strip or the neutral ground, other than for official use of maintenance, operational or emergency vehicles, is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-68. - Taxicabs and taxicab zones. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park any taxicab on any street for a longer period than is actually necessary to answer a call for service by such vehicle or to receive or discharge a passenger in fulfilling a call, such waiting time in no instance to exceed twenty (20) minutes; this subsection shall not apply to taxicabs standing in regularly designated taxicab stands in accordance with subsection (b). 
(b)  Stands or spaces within which taxicabs may stop, park and stand shall be provided by the city traffic engineer, where necessary for the public convenience and shall be marked with appropriate signs or by lines painted on the curb or street, and it shall be unlawful for any person, other than the driver of a taxicab designated for such space, to stop, park or stand a vehicle within such designated taxicab stands. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-69. - Distances from buildings frequented by public. 
    No vehicle shall be parked at any time within a distance of twelve and one-half (121/2) feet measured along the curb or edge of the street in each direction from the center of the main door or entrance of buildings or business locations where the curb or edge of the street is so marked. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-70. - Prohibited parking; leased or rented motor vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever a leased or rented motor vehicle, identified as provided in subsection (b) of this section, is parked in violation of any state law, local ordinance or regulation, and a citation is issued at a time when the driver is not present to receive the citation, prior to any proceedings on the citation, the city shall request an affidavit from the registered owner attesting to the name, address and driver's license number of the person to whom the vehicle was leased or rented at the time the citation was issued. 
(b)  The owner of each leased or rented motor vehicle may place an identification tag attached to the inside of the bottom right side of the windshield of such vehicle. The identification tag shall state that the vehicle is rented or leased and shall list the name and address of the registered owner. All such information shall be clearly visible from the outside of the vehicle. The department of public safety shall approve the forms for the identification tags. 
(c)  Upon the request to furnish the affidavit pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, the owner shall within seven (7) days after the receipt of the request, mail or deliver to the requesting authority an affidavit attesting to the name, address and driver's license number of the person to whom the vehicle was rented or leased. The affidavit shall create the presumption that the person to whom the vehicle was leased or rented was the driver who parked the vehicle in violation of the law, ordinance or regulation, and the requesting authority shall notify the driver of his responsibility for the violation. 
(d)  Whenever a leased or rented motor vehicle is not identified as provided in subsection (b) of this section or when the requested owner of a properly identified leased or rented vehicle fails to furnish the affidavit, the presumption created under subsection (c) of this section shall not apply and the citation shall be treated as any other regular parking citation. 
(e)  A lessor who fails to comply with the foregoing provisions shall be treated as any other owner and shall be solidarily liable with the operator. 
(f)  If any owner of a motor vehicle receives a notice of violation for a period during which the illegally parked vehicle was reported to any police or law enforcement department as having been stolen, it shall be a valid defense to any charge of a parking violation that the motor vehicle has been reported to the police as stolen prior to the time the violation occurred and had not been recovered by such time. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
State Law reference- Prohibited parking; leased or rented motor vehicles, R.S. 32:146. 
Sec. 33-71. - Standing for loading only. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger loading zone during the hours specified for a period not to exceed three (3) minutes. 
(b)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pick-up and loading of materials within the block and any place marked as a loading zone during the hours when the provisions applicable to loading zones are in effect. In no case shall a stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed the posted time limit, which time shall be no more than thirty (30) minutes as determined and posted by the city traffic engineer or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-72. - Certain vehicles to be parked only for loading and unloading. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be able to park any of the following vehicles on streets within the corporate limits of the city at any time except when engaged in loading and unloading or otherwise lawfully and actively engaged in conducting the business for which they are intended and only for the duration of such activities: Inter-urban and intra-urban motorbuses and vans operating as passenger carriers and property hauling vehicles licensed by the state as common carriers. 
(b)  Because of public necessity to transport students to elementary and secondary schools, all school buses are exempted from subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-73. - Parking regulations and violations. 
(a)  Each hour a vehicle remains illegally parked in an on-street parking space is a separate offense, and the violator may be given a ticket for each offense. 
(b)  Any vehicle that has been towed for a parking violation is to be held until the towing fee and penalties related to all outstanding parking tickets and parking penalties owed to the city are paid in full, or a bond is posted in the amount of the towing fee and all outstanding parking tickets and parking penalties. Payment of the towing fee and all outstanding parking tickets and parking penalties shall not constitute a waiver of a person's right to contest the towing or the outstanding parking tickets and parking penalties. 
(c)  (1)  Wheel locks, or "boots," may be used on illegally parked vehicles for which there are three (3) or more outstanding, unpaid and overdue parking tickets within a period of ninety (90) days. The notice of the immobilization, towing, impoundment and appeal hearing shall be affixed to the vehicle. The immobilization fee shall not exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), excluding charges for towing and storage. If payment is not made to remove the boot at the City of Monroe Taxation and Revenue Division, 316 Breard Street, Monroe, Louisiana 71201, by the end of the business day (5:00 p.m.), the vehicle will be towed by 6:00 p.m. The city shall not be responsible for any damage to an immobilized illegally parked vehicle resulting from unauthorized attempts to free or move that vehicle. 
(2)  Notice of an impoundment shall be mailed by certified mail to the owner of the vehicle in violation within forty-eight (48) hours of impoundment. 
(3)  The notice shall inform the owner of the procedure necessary for the release of the vehicle, where to report, the fact that he has the options of paying the fines and/or penalty for each violation, the fines and/or penalty under protest and then appeal, and of his right to a hearing without the immediate release of the vehicle. The owner shall be responsible for all court costs if his appeal is denied. 
(4)  If an owner desires to contest the impoundment, then he has ten (10) days, from receipt of the notice of impoundment, to file a written demand for hearing, which has to be heard within forty-eight (48) hours of the filing of the written request. If a written demand is filed on a Thursday or a Friday, a hearing shall be granted on the following business day. If the forty-eight (48) hours expires on a holiday, then a hearing shall be had on the following business day. The notice shall be given to the owner by a sign or other marker placed on the vehicle at the time it is booted. Notice of the right to request a hearing also may be given on the back of the receipt if the owner pays for the immediate release of the vehicle. Further notice shall be given by a sign posted at the desk where fines are paid or where wheel locking or "booting" inquiries are made. 
(d)  Any ordinance adopted pursuant to this article may be enforced by law enforcement officers and any person or persons authorized by ordinance or by the chief of police, or his designees, the fire chief, or his designees, whether or not the vehicle is parked on public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-74. - Reserved handicapped parking. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized to designate handicapped spaces and to erect signs indicating parking zones reserved for handicapped persons. 
(b)  When official signs are erected indicating a parking zone reserved for the handicapped as authorized herein, no person shall park a vehicle in or otherwise deny access to, such designated place (whether on public or private property) unless that person is handicapped. 
(c)  The law enforcement officer shall be authorized to issue a citation or take whatever law enforcement action is deemed necessary or both. Furthermore, when an individual found to be in violation of these provisions refuses a request by a law enforcement officer to move the vehicle found in violation, the officer shall be authorized to have such vehicle towed. 
(d)  The citation shall contain information concerning the nature, date, time, and location of the alleged violation, the state vehicle license plate number, and the make of vehicle. In those cases where a license plate is not visible or legible, the vehicle identification number shall be used in lieu of the state vehicle plate number. The citation shall also contain information advising the person charged of the manner and the time in which he may contest the violation charged in the citation. The citation shall also provide that a failure to timely answer or appear before a court of competent jurisdiction shall be considered a prima facie admission of the violation set forth in the citation, in which the court may assess the appropriate fine or fines and all penalties incidental thereto. 
(e)  The citation issued pursuant to the provisions of this subsection shall be personally served upon the operator of the vehicle by affixing the parking citation to the vehicle in a conspicuous place thereon. The original parking citation shall bear the name or initials and identification number of the issuing officer who shall affirm the truth of the facts set forth therein. An operator of a vehicle who is not the owner, but who uses or operates the vehicle with permission of the owner, expressed or implied, shall be considered the agent of the owner to receive the citation required to be served upon the operator or registered owner of a vehicle in accordance with the provisions of this subsection. When a citation is issued for an alleged violation of the laws governing parking in a handicapped parking space, loading and unloading areas, access aisles, access ramps, and curb cuts, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that a person in whose name the vehicle is registered was the operator of the vehicle when the alleged violation was committed. 
(f)  In the event that the registered owner or operator of a vehicle drives the vehicle away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation while the issuing officer is preparing the citation, or refuses service of the parking citation and drives away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation, this fact shall be duly noted on the original and all copies of the parking citation. This original and all copies of a parking citation shall constitute a business record of the law enforcement agency issuing the citation and shall constitute prima facie evidence that the citation was issued and that an attempt at service was made in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(g)  The first violation of the provisions of this section shall be punished by a fine of two hundred seventy-five dollars ($275.00). A subsequent violation shall be punished by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each occurrence of a violation of the provisions hereof shall constitute a separate offense. 
(h)  If the violator is other than an individual, a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be imposed for the first violation. A subsequent violation shall be punished by a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Each occurrence of a violation of the provisions hereof shall constitute a separate offense. 
(i)  In addition to such fine, the violator shall also be required to pay the towing fee and any storage costs which are incurred. 
(j)  The City of Monroe shall recognize parking cards or other removable windshield placards and special license plates which have been issued by authorities of other states and countries for the purpose of identifying vehicles permitted to utilize parking spaces reserved for the handicapped. 
(k)  Handicapped parking fines may be reduced or dismissed by the city attorney, or his designee, for just cause. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,612, 8-8-06) 
State Law reference- Parking spaces for disabled persons, R.S. 40:1742; Fee imposed in addition to fines, fees, costs for violations of mobility-impaired parking restrictions established by local ordinance, R.S. 46:2583(A)(2). 
Sec. 33-75. - Parking citation form. 
(a)  The parking citation shall be the notice of violation for purposes of this article. 
(b)  The parking citation shall contain information concerning the nature, date, time and location of the alleged violation, the state vehicle license plate number, and make of car. In those cases where a license plate is not visible and/or legible, either the vehicle identification number or the brake inspection tag number shall be in lieu of the state vehicle license plate number. In the case of delivery vehicles, the certificate of public necessity and convenience number (CPNC) shall be used in lieu of the state vehicle license plate number. 
(c)  The parking citation shall also contain information advising the person charged of the manner and the time in which he may contest the violation charged in the notice. The parking citation shall also provide that a failure to timely answer or appear before a court shall be considered a prima facie admission of the violation set forth on the parking citation, in which event the court may assess the appropriate fine or fines and all penalties incidental thereto. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
State Law reference- Traffic citations; form; issuance, R.S. 32:398.1. 
Sec. 33-76. - Service of parking citation. 
(a)  A parking citation shall be served personally upon the operator of a vehicle who is present at the time of service. If the operator is not so served, or is not present, the parking citation shall be served upon the registered owner of the vehicle by affixing the parking citation to the vehicle in a conspicuous place thereon. The original parking citation shall be signed by the issuing officer who shall affirm the truth of the facts set forth therein. An operator of a vehicle who is not the owner thereof, but who uses or operates the vehicle with permission of the owner, express or implied, shall be considered the agent of the owner to receive a parking citation required to be served upon the operator or registered owner of a vehicle in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  If the registered owner or operator of a vehicle drives the vehicle away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation while the issuing officer is preparing the parking citation, or refuses service of the parking citation and drives away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation, this fact shall be duly noted on the original and all copies of the parking citation. This original and all copies of a parking citation shall constitute a business record of the city and shall constitute prima facie evidence that the parking citation was issued and that an attempt at service thereof was made in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-77. - Disposition of parking citations. 
(a)  The original parking citation shall be signed by the issuing officer, and shall be processed in accordance with this article and such other procedures as may be established and promulgated by the City of Monroe. 
(b)  A parking citation may be dismissed by the city attorney, or his designee, only upon his written statement for good cause shown, which statement shall be made a part of the disposition record thereof. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-78. - Citation as legal demand and prima facie evidence. 
    The original parking citation or any true copy thereof shall constitute an ordinary business record of the city and prima facie evidence of the facts contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-79. - Answering parking citation; failure to answer. 
(a)  A person to whom a parking citation has been issued under this article may answer to the same in the manner and within the delays indicated on the citation. An answer may take the form of: 
(1)  Admission of the violation with payment of the scheduled penalty; or 
(2)  Request for administrative review; or 
(3)  Appeal of administrative review findings. 
(b)  If the owner, his agent or the operator fails to appear on or prior to the court date, there shall be assessed additional delinquent penalties, as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-79.1. - Failure to pay; civil action. 
(a)  Whenever a person charged with a parking violation fails to pay his penalty, the city attorney, or his designee, may file a civil action against the accused violator in the Monroe City Court. 
(b)  Service of process and all other civil procedures and delays shall be followed as in other civil matters before the Monroe City Court. 
(Ord. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-80. - Notice of hearing. 
    The parking citation shall provide information as to the time and place of a hearing. Whenever a person charged with a parking violation denies liability with explanation, the city attorney, or his designee, shall advise such person, personally or by United States mail, postage prepaid, of the date of which he must appear to answer the charge at a hearing. The form and content of such notice shall be prescribed by the city attorney, or his designee, and shall contain a warning to advise the person that failure to appear on the date designated, or on any subsequent date, to which the hearing is adjourned, shall be deemed an admission of liability. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04) 
Sec. 33-81. - Response to citation generally. 
    The owner or operator of a vehicle to which a notice has been affixed for a violation of this article shall discharge the summons within ten (10) days after the time such notice was attached to such vehicle by delivering or mailing the appropriate sum to the City of Monroe's Taxation and Revenue Division, 316 Breard Street, Monroe, Louisiana 71201 or Post Office Box 123, Monroe, Louisiana 71210. Such payment may be made only by cash, money order or credit card and made payable to the City of Monroe. Payment of the penalty established herein shall operate as a final disposition of the case. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,511, 7-12-05; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-81.1. - Citation challenges. 
(a)  Administrative review. 
(1)  If the alleged violator wishes to challenge the issued citation, he should request an administrative review, which is conducted by the city attorney, or his designee, who is well-versed in the City of Monroe Traffic Code. Said request must be made within three (3) days of receipt of the citation. The purpose of this step is to screen out those citations where the alleged violator is clearly not liable for the citation. 
(2)  If administrative review is requested, the alleged violator will be required to post the penalty amount of his citation and a nonrefundable five dollar ($5.00) processing fee prior to being scheduled for review. He must submit a written declaration to the city attorney or his designee. Request for administrative review; forms will be available at the City of Monroe's Taxation and Revenue Division, 316 Breard Street, Monroe, Louisiana 71201. The form must be completed and returned, along with a copy of the citation and any other applicable proof to the Office of the City Attorney, Civil Division, at Post Office Box 123, Monroe, Louisiana 71210. Any documentation submitted with the administrative review request form will not be returned nor will copies be provided for the requestor. 
(3)  A self-addressed stamped envelope must also be included for notification of the finding of the review. An accused violator will be notified in writing of the finding of the review. 
(4)  If the alleged violator is found not liable, then his penalty funds will be refunded. If the citation is upheld, the alleged violator may appeal the findings of the review to the Monroe City Court. If he chooses not to appeal, then the penalty amount previously posted will be forfeited. 
(5)  A parking citation may be dismissed if it is determined, after review, it was either factually incorrect or issued in error. The following reasons, which are not exhaustive, do not warrant dismissal of a parking citation: 
a.  I was only gone for a minute. 
b.  I did not know that I could not park there. 
c.  I think the fine is too high. 
d.  I did not see the sign or curb marking. 
e.  I cannot afford to pay the fine. 
f.  I have never had a ticket before. 
g.  I have a perfect driving record. 
h.  I will never do it again. 
i.  My car was the only one cited. 
j.  I did not know it was against the law. 
(b)  Appeal. 
(1)  The final step in the challenge process is an appeal to the Civil Division of the Monroe City Court. The appeal must be filed at least fifteen (15) days after the findings of the administrative review are completed. 
(2)  The appellant will be responsible for paying any necessary filing fees for the appeal hearing. If he prevails, his posted penalty amount will be refunded. If the citation is upheld, the parking penalty will be forfeited. 
(3)  Parking penalties are to be remitted to the City of Monroe's Taxation and Revenue Division, 316 Breard Street, Monroe, Louisiana 71201. 
(Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-82. - Failure to respond to citation. 
(a)  Any person guilty of violating the provisions of this article, unless otherwise stated, shall be subject to a fine of ten dollars ($10.00) if paid within ten (10) days from the date of receipt of the citation. However, any person guilty of violating the provisions of this section more than once in any day shall be subject to a fine of ten dollars ($10.00) for each violation, if paid within ten (10) days. 
(b)  If said fine(s) is/are not paid within ten (10) days, then each violation will result in a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00). This amount shall be paid within twenty (20) days from the date of receipt of the citation. 
(c)  Upon the lapse of twenty (20) days, and if payment has not been received by the city, a certified letter will be mailed to the registered owner of the vehicle in violation, notifying said registered owner of a fine increase of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each violation 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,511, 7-12-05; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06; Ord. No. 10,612, 8-8-06) 
Sec. 33-83. - Failure to respond to citation; loading zone. 
(a)  Any person guilty of violating the loading zone provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine of twenty dollars ($20.00) if paid within ten (10) days from the date of receipt of the citation. However, any person guilty of violating the provisions of this section more than once in any day shall be subject to a fine of twenty dollars ($20.00) for each violation, if paid within ten (10) days. 
(b)  If said fine(s) is/are not paid within ten (10) days, then each violation will result in a fine of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). This amount shall be paid within twenty (20) days from the date of receipt of the citation. 
(c)  Upon the lapse of twenty (20) days, and if payment has not been received by the city, a certified letter will be mailed to the registered owner of the vehicle in violation, notifying said registered owner of a fine increase to one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,511, 7-12-05; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06; Ord. No. 10,612, 8-8-06) 
Sec. 33-84. - Presumption as to ownership of illegally parked vehicle. 
    In any prosecution charging a violation of any of the provisions of this article regulating the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of the provisions of this division, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was, at the time of such parking, the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-85. - Record of violations. 
    It shall be the duty of the Parking Tickets Department of the Monroe Police Department to keep account of all violations of the parking regulations contained in this article. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-86. - Towing generally. 
(a)  Any illegally parked vehicle may be towed. Any vehicle that has been towed for a parking violation is to be held until the towing fee and penalties related to all outstanding parking tickets and penalties owed to the city are paid in full, or a bond is posted in the amount of the towing fee and all outstanding parking tickets and penalties. Payment of the towing fee and all outstanding parking tickets and penalties shall not constitute a waiver of a person's right to contest the towing or the outstanding parking tickets and penalties. 
(b)  Towing and impoundment charges must be paid in cash. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-86.1. - Release of vehicle in process of being removed. 
(a)  When a vehicle has been hooked to a tow truck in preparation for removal to a pound but the owner or other person lawfully entitled to possession of such vehicle appears and requests the release of such vehicle before the tow truck is in motion, such vehicle shall be unhooked and released, provided, however, that the person to whom such vehicle is released must pay the vehicle release penalty as set forth in section 33-86.2 at the time the release request is made. Payment shall be in the form required by the towing company. 
(b)  The person by whom the release request is made shall present a current valid driver's license and either registration for the vehicle, title to the vehicle, insurance identification and keys for the vehicle, a rental agreement and keys for the vehicle in case of a rental vehicle, or company identification and keys for the vehicle in the case of a commercial vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-86.2. - Vehicle release penalty. 
(a)  The penalty for the release of an illegally parked vehicle shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for illegally parked vehicles which meet the criteria contained in sections 33-82 and 33-83, and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for illegally parked vehicles which meet the criteria listed in sections 33-65, 33-74 and 33-86.4. 
(b)  This fee is in addition to any other monetary fine(s) and penalty(-ies) permitted by law for the underlying parking violation(s); provided, however, that in no event shall a vehicle release penalty be imposed if the underlying parking violation or, in the case of multiple underlying parking violations, all underlying parking violations, are dismissed by the city attorney or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-86.3. - Towing and storage of illegally parked vehicles; tow away zones established; non-applicability to abandoned vehicles. 
(a)  In addition to any punishment for the violation of the Code, any motor vehicle parked in violation of this article shall be subject to removal, impoundment and detention when such parked vehicle creates or constitutes a traffic hazard, obstructs or may obstruct the movement of traffic or of emergency vehicles, including fire department equipment, and parks, stops or stands in fire lanes or within fifteen (15) feet of the fire hydrants or fire-protection devices on public or private property or within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station, and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy-five (75) feet of said entrance; blocks a driveway; or has been on two (2) or more prior occasions parked in violation of a section of this Code or of law for which the towing is ordered; or where two (2) or more parking tickets which have become delinquent are outstanding as to any vehicle and said vehicle is illegally parked on a street, alley or highway at the time of removal; or when such vehicle is illegally parked in areas posted and designated in subsection (b) of this section as "NO PARKING TOW AWAY ZONE." A motor vehicle which is impounded under this section shall be subject to immediate towing or removal without notice. 
(b)  Whenever a motor vehicle has been removed, impounded or detained in accordance with this section, the Monroe Police Department shall as soon as practical, but within one business day, send a certified letter, return receipt requested, to the last known owner of said vehicle, notifying such owners of the following: 
(1)  That the vehicle has been impounded; 
(2)  The amount or rate of assessed charges for towing, storage or other costs incident to the impoundment, the applicable fine amount and that the release of the vehicle may be obtained by paying the stated charges and showing proof of ownership of said vehicle; 
(3)  That in the alternative he may obtain the release of the vehicle by posting an appearance bond; 
(4)  A statement of the procedure to be followed in obtaining and posting such bond; 
(5)  That he has the opportunity for a hearing if he so requests, concerning the propriety of the impoundment; 
(6)  A statement of the procedure to be followed in requesting such a hearing. 
(c)  The charges for the towing, impoundment and detention of said vehicle shall be paid by the owner of said vehicle, or the person who shall have violated any provisions of this article; and provided that if a motor vehicle is presumed or found to be abandoned pursuant to the provisions of section 24.5-72, then the provisions of this section shall not apply. 
(d)  The owner of any motor vehicle impounded under this section may obtain its release either upon payment of the assessed charges for towing and storage, or upon execution of an appearance bond, in the amount of one and one-quarter (11/4) times the amount of towing and storage charges, with good and solvent surety approved by the City Court of the City of Monroe. 
(e)  A hearing, when requested, shall be conducted before a judge of Monroe City Court on the propriety of any tow made in accordance with this section. Such hearings shall be held within forty-eight (48) hours of any request for a hearing. The hearing shall be limited to the question of whether the city had probable cause to tow the vehicle. If a request is made on a Thursday or a Friday, a hearing shall be granted on the following business day. If the forty-eight (48) hours expires on a holiday, then a hearing shall be had on the following business day.
