(f)  The owner of any motor vehicle which has been impounded in accordance with this section shall be entitled to a hearing before a judge of Monroe City Court if he so requests, provided that such a request for a hearing is made in writing within five (5) days of receipt of notice. 
(g)  The Monroe City Court judges shall have the power to order the release of the motor vehicle, prior to the hearing, upon execution of an appearance bond as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-87. - Airport. 
(a)  This article shall be applicable to stopping, standing or parking at the Monroe Regional Airport, except in parking areas specifically providing for extended and limited parking, passenger loading and unloading zones, and any other designated airport-regulated zones. 
(b)  No person shall park any vehicle on a public parking lot posted as thirty-minute or one-hour parking and leave the same continuously parked for a period greater than thirty (30) minutes or one hour, respectively. 
(c)  Parking hang tags described in this article shall not be utilized at the Monroe Regional Airport. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-88. - Off-street parking in public lots. 
(a)  No person shall park any motor vehicle on or within city-owned public off-street parking lots and leave the same continuously parked for a period greater than twenty-four (24) hours, or as otherwise posted by the authority of the city traffic engineer. This provision shall exclude city-owned vehicles. 
(b)  No person shall park or leave any trailer or non-motorized vehicle on or within a city-owned public parking lot for more than seventy-two (72) consecutive hours, or as otherwise posted by the authority of the city traffic engineer. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-89. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Posted on-street parking and public parking lot limits shall not be applicable to elected officials, judges, state officials, fire and police personnel, jurors and witnesses in trials, and service or utility workers who are in readily identifiable vehicles who are engaged in legitimate business. 
(b)  The City of Monroe shall recognize parking cards, hang tags or other removable windshield placards and special license plates for the purposes of identifying vehicles permitted to utilize on-street parking spaces and public parking lot spaces otherwise designated for time-limited parking. 
(c)  Elected officials, judges, state officials, fire and police personnel, jurors and witnesses in trials, and service or utility workers who are in readily identifiable vehicles identified in this section shall not be exempt from any other parking restrictions, prohibitions or penalties set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT PARKING 

Sec. 33-90. - Permit parking regulations generally. 
(a)  The City of Monroe may issue appropriate monthly or yearly permits and shall cause parking signs to be erected in the area indicating the times and conditions under which parking shall be allowed. A permit shall be issued upon application and payment of the applicable fee, only to the owner or operator of a motor vehicle which is appropriately registered with the State of Louisiana. 
(b)  Parking permits may be purchased at the City of Monroe Taxation and Revenue Division Division, 316 Breard Street, Monroe, Louisiana 71201. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-90.1. - Display of permit. 
(a)  All City of Monroe permits are hang-tag type permits which shall be displayed by hanging from the rearview mirror, with the front side facing the windshield. 
(b)  Failure to properly display the hang tag will be subject to citation and penalties set forth in section 33-90.7. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-90.2. - Permit parking exemption. 
(a)  A vehicle in which a valid parking permit is displayed as provided for herein shall be permitted to stand or be parked in the area for which the permit has been issued without being limited by time restrictions established pursuant to this article. However, said vehicle shall not be exempt from parking restrictions, prohibitions or penalties set forth in this chapter. 
(b)  A City of Monroe parking permit shall not guarantee or reserve to the holder thereof an on-street parking space or public parking lot space. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-90.3 - Duration of and application for permit. 
(a)  Parking permits shall be valid as follows: 
(1)  Monthly permit: Valid for thirty (30) days from the date of purchase. 
(2)  Yearly permit: Valid for one year from the date of purchase. 
No grace period will be granted by the City of Monroe. 
(b)  Each application or reapplication for a parking permit shall contain information sufficient to identify the applicant, his residence address or address of business owner and such other information that may be deemed relevant by the City of Monroe. If an applicant sells or otherwise transfers a vehicle bearing a permit, he shall remove the permit before transfer, and the applicant shall return to the City of Monroe Police Department to have his application information updated. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,520, 8-9-05; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-90.4. - Permit fees. 
(a)  Parking permits can be purchased at the Taxation and Revenue Division of the City of Monroe. 
(b)  The City of Monroe may make such changes to said fees, from time to time, as it sees fit. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,520, 8-9-05; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06; Ord. No. 10,612, 8-8-06) 
Sec. 33-90.5. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  The City of Monroe is authorized to revoke the parking permit of any person found to be in violation of this article and, upon written notification thereof, the person shall surrender such permit to the City of Monroe Police Department. An applicant whose permit is revoked shall not be entitled to a refund of his or her permit cost. 
(b)  Failure, when so requested, to surrender a parking permit so revoked shall constitute a violation of law and of this article. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-90.6 - Regulations and procedures. 
(a)  Time restriction on parking. Except as otherwise designated, on-street parking will be restricted to a two-hour time limit on streets that are so designated. Vehicles bearing valid parking permits in the designated areas shall be exempt from the two-hour time limit. The City of Monroe Parking [Department] will erect, or cause, to be erected, signs. These signs shall indicate the two-hour time limit. The two-hour time limit shall be enforced at such times as the City of Monroe shall see fit. 
(b)  Existing parking regulations. All existing parking regulations shall remain in effect. These include but are not limited to: prohibited parking areas, fire lanes, handicapped parking spaces and loading zones. Holders of parking permits will not be exempt from these regulations. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for a person to falsely represent himself as eligible for a parking permit or to furnish information in an application therefore. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for a person holding a valid parking permit issued pursuant hereto to permit the use or display of such permit on a motor vehicle other than that for which the permit is issued. Such conduct shall constitute an unlawful act and violation of this article both by the person holding the valid parking permit and the person who so uses or displays the permit on a motor vehicle other than that for which it is issued. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for a person to copy, produce or otherwise bring into existence a facsimile or counterfeit parking permit in order to evade time limitations or parking applicable in the City of Monroe. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
Sec. 33-90.7. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this permit parking division shall be subject to the following penalties: 
(1)  First violation-$100.00 fine. 
(2)  Second violation-$200.00 fine. 
(3)  Third and each subsequent violation-$300.00 fine. 
(b)  Each violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Any permit holder who is in violation of sections 33-65, 33-74, 33-82 and 33-83 shall be subject to the fines and penalties set forth in those provisions, in addition to any violations of this permit parking division, and conversely. 
(Ord. No. 10,442, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 10,574, 3-28-06) 
ARTICLE IV. - PARADES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7449, adopted Oct. 26, 1982, added  33-80-33-91 to the Code. Inasmuch as Ord. No. 7266 had previously added  33-80, and for convenience' sake and purposes of classification, the editor has designated the applicable provisions as art. IV,  33-91-33-102, as authorized by  1-8 of this Code. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate parades and processions, R.S. 32:41(A)(3). 

Sec. 33-91. - Definitions. 
(a)  Chief of police is the chief of police of the city. 
(b)  Parade is any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other public place in the city. 
(c)  Parade permit is a permit as required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Sec. 33-92. - Permit-Required; exceptions. 
(a)  Required. No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the chief of police. 
(b)  Exceptions. This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions; 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, providing such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities; 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its function. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Sec. 33-93. - Same-Application. 
    A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the chief of police on forms provided by such office. 
(1)  Filing period. An application for a parade permit shall be filed with the chief of police not less than six (6) days nor more than fifteen (15) days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(2)  Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
(a)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade; 
(b)  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization; 
(c)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct; 
(d)  The date when the parade is to be conducted; 
(e)  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point; 
(f)  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade; the type animals, and description of the vehicles; 
(g)  The hours when such parade will start and terminate; 
(h)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed; 
(i)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade; 
(j)  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area or areas; 
(k)  The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade; 
(l)  If the parade is designed to be held by and on behalf of or for any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the chief of police a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf; 
(m)  Any additional information which the chief of police shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should issue. 
(3)  Late applications. The chief of police, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application hereunder which is filed less than six (6) days before the date such parade is proposed to be conducted. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Sec. 33-94. - Same-Standards for issuance. 
    The chief of police shall issue a permit as provided for hereunder when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous of its route; 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city; 
(3)  The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto; 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at the assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas; 
(5)  The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of fire-fighting equipment en route to a fire; 
(6)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to person or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance; 
(7)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Sec. 33-95. - Same-Notice of rejection. 
    The chief of police shall act upon the application for a parade permit within two (2) days after the filing thereof. If the chief of police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant within two (2) days after the date upon which the application was filed a notice of his action, stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Sec. 33-96. - Same-Appeal procedure. 
    Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade permit to the city council. The appeal shall be taken within two (2) days after notice. The council shall act upon the appeal within two (2) days after its receipt. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Sec. 33-97. - Same-Alternative permit. 
    The chief of police, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within two (2) days after notice of the action of the chief of police, file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Sec. 33-98. - Same-Notice to city and other officials. 
    Immediately upon the issuance of a parade permit, the chief of police shall send a copy thereof to the mayor and members of the city council and to the fire chief of the city. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Sec. 33-99. - Same-Contents. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time; 
(2)  Minimum speed; 
(3)  Maximum speed; 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade; 
(5)  The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade; 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof; 
(7)  Such other information as the chief of police shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Sec. 33-100. - Duties of permittee. 
    A permittee hereunder shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
    The parade chairman or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Sec. 33-101. - Public conduct during parades. 
(a)  Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct or impede, or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. 
(b)  Driving through parades. No driver of a vehicle, street car or trackless trolley shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. 
(c)  Parking on parade route. The chief of police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The chief of police shall post signs to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street unposted in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Sec. 33-102. - Revocation of permit. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued hereunder if he hereafter finds that the parade fails to meet the standards for issuance hereon or if he finds that the permittee has failed to comply with all permit directions and conditions set forth in the permit as provided in section hereof. 
(Ord. No. 7449, 10-26-82) 
Chapter 34 - TREES AND SHRUBS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7993, adopted Apr. 28, 1987, amended former Ch. 34, Trees,  34-1-34-3, in its entirety to read as set out herein. The former provisions derived from Code 1958  23-11, 23-13, 23-14. 
Cross reference- Height limitations relative to trees in certain zones at airport,  7-96; filling, etc. of trees without approval, within right-of-way of state highway deemed criminal mischief,  12-87(4); pickup of trees by city,  16-19(9); landscaping within Monroe Air-Industrial Park,  22-26; weeds and noxious growths,  24-16 et. seq.; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 31; subdivisions, Ch. 32; zoning, Ch. 37. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Trimming of trees, etc., that overhang public ways. 
(a)  Public nuisance declared. All persons owning or maintaining shade or ornamental trees, shrubs or hedges upon or abutting the sidewalks or banquettes of the city shall keep such trees, shrubs and hedges trimmed and in such condition so as not to interrupt the clear vision of both vehicle and foot traffic and so as not to be an obstruction to vehicle or foot traffic, and so as not to interfere with the proper diffusion of light from any street light or standard light. Owning or maintaining any trees, shrubs or light hedges violating the above is hereby declared to be public nuisance. 
(b)  Planting location restrictions. It shall be unlawful for any person to plant, or cause to be planted, any kind of trees, shrubs or hedges on the streets, curb lines or sidewalks of the city. 
(c)  Trimming of overhanging limbs. All trees, shrubs and hedges located on public right-of-way or located on private property but hanging or encroaching onto public right-of-way shall be trimmed of all limbs and foliage to a height of at least ten (10) feet above the sidewalk and curb level and shall be trimmed or planted in such a manner so as to result in a single trunk or stem. 
(d)  Modification of regulations. The regulations set forth in subsection (b) above may be modified by the city as they pertain to certain specific locations which are of a sufficient distance from public streets, alleys and sidewalks so as to allow such modification without resulting in any interference with the use of the public right-of-way. 
(e)  Compliance required. Any trees, shrubs or hedges which are not maintained in accordance with the regulations contained above shall be forthwith brought into compliance with said regulations by the owners thereof. 
(f)  Notification to comply. The city may notify any owner who is not maintaining his trees, shrubs or hedges in accordance with the provisions of this section to do so within ten (10) days. 
(g)  Failure to comply with notice; violation; penalty. Any person owning trees who is notified by the city to maintain such trees, shrubs and hedges in accordance with provisions of this section and fails to comply with the notice within ten (10) days from receipt thereof shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined an amount not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Each day that the violation is allowed to continue by the owner shall constitute a separate offense. 
(h)  Additional remedies. When the owner of trees, shrubs and hedges located on public right-of-way fails to maintain such trees, shrubs and hedges in accordance with the provisions of this section, resulting in interference with the use of public right-of-way, in addition to the remedies contained in subsection (g) above, the city may, after serving the notice called for in subsection (f) above, trim the trees, shrubs and hedges in the manner herein provided, at the expense of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 7993, 4-28-87) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 31; traffic, Ch. 33. 
Sec. 34-2. - Use of climbing spikes regulated. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any person engaged in the business of servicing trees, including, but not limited to, arborists and public utility firms, to employ the use of climbing spikes in order to climb trees unless the condition of the tree is such that it is impossible to climb, without the use of such device. If climbing spikes must be utilized, that person seeking to utilize them must first obtain written permission from the owner to utilize said devices. Additionally, after such devices are used, the duty is incumbent upon the person using such devices to spray any tree climbed with climbing spikes with a spray consisting of the proper pesticide and fungicide. 
(Ord. No. 7993, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 34-3. - Arborists, tree trimmers required to remove debris; retention of logs, limbs, etc., by property owner. 
(a)  Unlawful. It is hereby declared to be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any person, firm, or corporation engaged in the business of servicing trees and shrubs including, but not limited to, arborists, tree removers and line clearance personnel employed by or working under contract for utility companies, to perform such services without removing all logs, limbs and other debris from the premises at the same time the services are performed, except as provided in subsection (b). 
(b)  Notice. The requirements and obligations contained in subsection (a) hereof may be and are therefore exclusively assumed by the owner or occupant of the property by notifying the person, firm or corporation performing said services in writing that he desired to retain the logs, limbs or other debris for his own personnel use. Such written notice shall be retained by the person, firm, or corporation performing such service for not less than thirty (30) days, and a copy thereof shall be furnished to the city. Provided that an owner, upon assuming such obligation, shall not be entitled to dispose of such log, limbs or debris through the city garbage or trash departments. 
(Ord. No. 7993, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 34-4. - Attaching wires to trees prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to attach to any tree on the streets of the city any electric light, telegraph, telephone or other wire, or to use any tree on the streets of the city as support for or to carry any electric light, telegraph, telephone or other wire; or to use any of the trees for any guy wire or any other purpose. 
(Ord. No. 7993, 4-28-87) 
Cross reference- Electricity, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 34-5. - Transportation of logs, limbs, debris, etc., regulated. 
    It shall be unlawful to transport logs, limbs and other debris through or upon the city streets, alleys and/or right-of-ways unless the same is contained in sealed containers, tarpaulins or nets in such a manner as to prevent the same from falling, spilling, blowing, trailing or dragging on the city streets, city alleys, city rights-of-way or adjacent properties. 
(Ord. No. 7993, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 34-6. - Penalty. 
    Violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, except as specifically provided herein, shall be fined an amount not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or six (6) months in jail or both, for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 7993, 4-28-87) 
Secs. 34-7-34-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ARBORISTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Occupational license tax,  20-21 et seq. 

Sec. 34-16. - Definitions. 
    [For the purpose of this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:] 
    Arborist: Any person servicing trees other than one working on his own property. 
    Person: An individual, firm, association, partnership or corporation. 
    Shrub: A woody plant with more than one stem or trunk at the ground level. 
    Tree: A woody perennial plant that has a single trunk or stem. 
    Tree service: Work performed on trees specifically excluding shrubbery and including tree removals, tree trimming and cavity work, spraying for pest and disease control, and fertilizing of trees. 
(Ord. No. 7993, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 34-17. - License-Required; responsibility of licensee; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit or engage within the city in the business of servicing trees, except tree removal work only, unless such person shall have first procured a license to do so from the director of administration. This requirement is in addition to any other local licenses, and also in addition to the license required by the horticulture commission of the Louisiana Department of Agriculture. All persons holding an arborist's license issued pursuant to the terms of this section shall be responsible for the conduct of his employees, as well as himself, in fulfilling all requirements of this section. It shall be the responsibility of all persons holding an arborist's license and their employees to cause such license, or a legible copy thereof, to be available for inspection by representatives of the city at every location where persons holding an arborist's license and/or their employees are engaged in the business of servicing trees. 
(Ord. No. 7993, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 34-18. - Same-Vehicles used in tree service to be marked with licensee's name. 
    All vehicles used in tree service shall be clearly marked with the name of the person holding a valid arborist's license from the city. 
(Ord. No. 7993, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 34-19. - Same-Application. 
(a)  No arborist's license shall be issued to a person until such person shall have filed with the director of administration, in writing, an application therefor, accompanied by a photostatic copy of that person's license issued by the Louisiana Horticulture Commission. The application shall give the exact location from which the business is to be conducted. 
(b)  No license shall be issued by the director of administration until the applicant shall have complied with all the requirements of this article and any future requirements affecting arborists that may be enacted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 7993, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 34-20. - Same-Not transferable. 
    It shall be unlawful to transfer any arborist license to any other person or for any arborist to knowingly allow any other person to use his license. 
(Ord. No. 7993, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 34-21. - Same-Fee. 
    The license fee for an arborist license shall be equal to the fee that the arborist would pay for a state license. 
(Ord. No. 7993, 4-28-87) 
Sec. 34-22. - Penalty. 
    Violation of any of provisions of this article shall be deemed a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall subject the violator to a fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first conviction and five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each subsequent conviction, and/or six (6) months in jail, or both. 
(Ord. No. 7993, 4-28-87) 
Secs. 34-23-34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TREE BOARD 

Sec. 34-31. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Park trees are herein defined as trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names and all areas owned by the city. 
    Street trees are herein defined as trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues and ways within the city. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Sec. 34-32. - Creation of tree board. 
    There is hereby established a tree board for the City of Monroe, Louisiana, which shall consist of seven (7) members, who are citizens and residents of the City of Monroe, Louisiana, and who shall be appointed by the mayor, with representatives from each city council district. 
    The term of office of the members of the tree board shall be three (3) years, except that upon the appointment of the first board, two (2) members shall be appointed for one year, two (2) members shall be appointed for two (2) years and three (3) members shall be appointed for three (3) years. 
    In the event that a vacancy occurs during the term of any member, his or her successor shall be appointed in the same manner for the unexpired portion of the term. Members may be reappointed. 
    Members of the tree board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Sec. 34-33. - Duties of board. 
    It shall be the duty and responsibility of the board to assist in the enforcement and implementation of Chapter 34 of the City of Monroe Code and to study, investigate, advise, develop, update annually and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees, shrubs, bushes or other woody vegetation along streets, in parks, and in other public places in the city. 
    Such plan shall be annually presented to the city council in the form of an ordinance and upon adoption shall constitute the official comprehensive tree plan for the City of Monroe, Louisiana. 
    The board shall also assist in the enforcement of all of the provisions of section 34-1 of this chapter. 
    The board, when requested by the mayor or the city council, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report, and recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work. 
    The board shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and regulations, subject to the requirements of due process and the Louisiana laws governing public bodies, and shall keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of its members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Sec. 34-34. - Tree list. 
    The board shall propose an official street tree list, which upon adoption by the city council in ordinance form shall constitute the official street tree list for the City of Monroe, which shall be numbered herein as section 34-45 when enacted. Said list shall be divided into size categories (small, medium and large) and provide spacing requirements between trees of the various size classes. No species other than those included in this list may be planted as street trees without the written permission of the tree board and all trees planted after the effective date of the street tree ordinance shall conform to the spacing requirements therein. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Sec. 34-35. - Distance from street corners and fireplugs. 
    No street trees shall be planted closer than thirty-five (35) feet from any street corner, measured from the point nearest intersecting curbs or curblines and/or intersecting streets or street lines. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten (10) feet of any fireplug. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Sec. 34-36. - Utilities. 
    No trees, shrubs, bushes or other woody vegetation shall be planted under or within ten (10) lateral feet of any overhead utility wire. No trees shall be planted over or within five (5) lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, storm water drain, transmission line or other utility line without the written permission of the tree board, after a hearing on the request. 
    No trees shall be planted over or within five (5) lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, storm water drain, transmission line or other utility line. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Sec. 34-37. - Public tree care. 
    The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants, shrubs, bushes and other woody vegetation within the lines of all public streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares, parks and public grounds as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. 
    The board may remove or cause to be removed any tree, plant, shrub, bush or other woody vegetation, or part thereof, within the lines of all public streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares, parks and public grounds which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, water lines, gas lines or other public improvements or is affected or infected with any injurious fungus, insect, disease or other pest. 
    These provisions shall not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of said trees are in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and in accordance with the zoning ordinance of the City of Monroe. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Cross reference- Zoning, Ch. 37. 
Sec. 34-38. - Other restrictions on location. 
    In the event that the zoning ordinances of the City of Monroe contain more stringent restrictions on the spacing and/or location of trees, shrubs, bushes and other woody vegetation than the provisions herein, the more stringent restrictions shall apply and take precedence. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Sec. 34-39. - Tree topping. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, company, partnership or corporation to top any street tree, park tree or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three (3) inches in diameter within the trees crown to such a degree so as to remove normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility lines or other obstructions where pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this provision at the determination of the tree board. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Sec. 34-40. - Removal of stumps. 
    All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Sec. 34-41. - Interference with tree board. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, company, partnership or corporation to prevent, delay or interfere with the tree board, or any of its agents, while engaged in the planting, cultivation, mulching, pruning, spraying or removing of any street trees, park trees or trees on private property as authorized under this article and any amendments or additions thereto. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Sec. 34-42. - Review by city council. 
    The city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and/or decisions of the tree board. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Sec. 34-43. - Appeal. 
    Any person may appeal any ruling, act or decision of the tree board to the city council, within ten (10) days of the decision, who shall hear the matter and render a final decision thereon. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Sec. 34-44. - Penalty. 
    Violation of any provisions of this article shall be deemed a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall subject the violator to a fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first conviction and five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each subsequent conviction, and/or up to six (6) months in jail, or both. 
(Ord. No. 9100, 10-10-89) 
Chapter 35 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Former Ch. 35, pertaining to similar subject matter, was deleted as superseded by the provisions of Ord. No. 7943 adopted Aug. 26, 1986, which amended Ch. 35 to read as set out herein. Former Ch. 35 contained substantive sections numbered  35-16-35-19, 35-31-35-39, 35-51-35-59, 35-71-35-74, 35-86-35-90, 35-101-35-110, 35-126, 35-127, 35-141-35-144, which derived from Code 1958  25-2-25-8.2, 25-9-25-20.2, 25-21, 25-22, 25-25-25-27, 25-31, 25-46, 25-47, 25-51-25-59; Ord. No. 7072, adopted July 10, 1979, and Ord. No. 7317, adopted Oct. 13, 1981. 
Cross reference- Occupational licenses,  12-21 et seq.; traffic, Ch. 33. 
State Law reference- The Public Passenger Motor Vehicle Responsibility Law, R.S. 45:200.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 35-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended: 
    Airport taxi: A public carrier vehicle. A taxicab used for the transportation of passengers for hire from the Monroe Regional Airport terminal building to destinations in the city by a route controlled by the holder of a certificate. 
    Bus: A motor vehicle designed to carry more than twelve (12) persons and used to carry passengers on fixed routes for hire, or fare, on a scheduled basis. 
    Call box stand: A place alongside of a street or elsewhere that the council has authorized a holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity to install a telephone or call box for the taking of calls and the dispatching of a vehicle for hire. 
    Certificate: A certificate of public convenience and necessity issued by the council, authorizing the holder thereof to conduct a vehicle for hire business in the city. 
    City: The City of Monroe. 
    Cruising: The driving of a vehicle for hire on the streets, alleys or public places of the city in search of, or soliciting, prospective passengers for hire. 
    Driver's license: The permission granted by the city to a person to drive a vehicle for hire upon the streets of the city. 
    Holder: A person to whom a certificate of public convenience and necessity has been issued. 
    Jitney: A motor vehicle designed to carry not more than twelve (12) and not less than eight (8) persons, including the driver, and used to carry passengers on fixed routes for hire. 
    Limousine: A luxurious chauffeur-driven sedan used for the transportation of passengers for hire. 
    Limousine service: A service providing or offering to provide transportation in a limousine by prior reservation, but not including service in connection with funerals. 
    Limousine service license: A license issued by the city for operation of a limousine service. 
    Manifest: A daily record prepared by the driver of a vehicle for hire of all trips made by such driver showing time and place of origin, destination, number of passengers, and the amount of fare of each trip. 
    Open stand: A public place alongside the curb of a street or elsewhere in the city, which has been designated by the city council as reserved exclusively for the use of a vehicle for hire. 
    Rate card: A card for display in each vehicle for hire which card contains the rates of fare then in force. 
    Taximeter: A meter instrument or device attached to a vehicle for hire which is connected with, and operated from, the front wheel or axle and/or transmission of the vehicle for hire to which it is attached which measures mechanically the distance driven and the waiting time upon which the fare is based. 
    Vehicle for hire: A motor vehicle having a normal seating capacity of less than twelve (12) passengers, used for the transportation of passengers for hire over any streets by a route and/or to a destination controlled by the passenger. 
    Waiting time: The time when a vehicle for hire is not in motion from the time of acceptance of a passenger or passengers to the time of discharge, but does not include any time that the vehicle for hire is not in motion if due to any case other than the request, act or fault of a passenger or passengers. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
State Law reference- Relevant definitions under state law, R.S. 45:200.2. 
Sec. 35-2. - Enforcement of chapter. 
    The police department shall enforce this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-3. - Violations. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by state law or city ordinance, any owner, driver, chauffeur or other person in charge of any vehicle for hire who shall fail to comply with, or in any way violate, the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for not less than sixty (60) days nor more than six (6) months, or both. 
(b)  Conviction hereunder may result in the revocation of the certificate or certificates involved, permanently or for a fixed period, by the city council. No such certificate shall be reissued in favor of the person in whose name it stood, except by authority of the city council. 
(c)  Violation by a partnership, corporation or association shall be presumptive evidence of such violation by all partners, officers and directors thereof, and any such partner, officer or director who knowingly, or without exercise of due and reasonable care and inquiry, consented to, permitted or approved, directly or indirectly, such violation, in whole or in part, shall be subject to the penalties hereinabove provided. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 35-4-35-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUSES (RESERVED) 

Secs. 35-11-35-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - JITNEY (RESERVED) 

Secs. 35-51-35-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LIMOUSINE SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY 

Sec. 35-101. - Required. 
    No person shall operate or permit a vehicle owned or controlled by him to be operated as a limousine for hire upon the streets of the city without having first obtained a certificate of public convenience and necessity from the council. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-102. - Application. 
    An application for a certificate shall be filed with the police department upon forms provided by the city; and such application shall be verified under oath and shall furnish the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  The financial status of the applicant, including the amounts of all unpaid judgments against the applicant and the nature of the transaction or acts giving rise to such judgments; 
(3)  The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers; 
(4)  Any facts which the applicant believes tend to prove that public convenience and necessity require the granting of a certificate; 
(5)  The number of vehicles to be operated or controlled by the applicant and the location of proposed depots and terminals; 
(6)  The color scheme or insignia to be used to designate the vehicle or vehicles of the applicant; and 
(7)  Such further information as the council may require. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-103. - Character of applicant. 
    No such license shall be issued to or held by any person who is not a person of good character or who has been convicted of a felony; nor shall such license be issued to or held by any corporation if any officer thereof would be inelgible for a license under the foregoing conditions [sic]. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-104. - Hearing and issuance. 
(a)  Upon the filing of an application for a certificate, the city council shall fix a time and place for public hearing thereon. Notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant and to all persons to whom certificates of public convenience and necessity have been theretofore issued. Due notice shall also be given the general public by posting a notice of such hearing in a daily newspaper published in the city. Any interested person may file with the city council a memorandum in support of or opposition to the issuance of a certificate. 
(b)  If the council finds that further service in the city is required by public convenience and necessity and that the applicant is fit, willing and able to perform such public transportation and to conform to the provisions of this article and the rules promulgated by the council, then the council shall issue a certificate stating the name and address of the applicant, the number of vehicles authorized under such certificate, and the date of issuance; otherwise, the application shall be denied. 
(c)  In making the above findings, the city council shall take into consideration the number of vehicles for hire already in operation, whether existing transportation is adequate to meet the public need, the probable effect of increased service on local traffic conditions, and the character, experience, and responsibility of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-105. - Transfer. 
    No certificate of public convenience and necessity may be sold, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise transferred without the consent of the council. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-106. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Grounds. A certificate issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked or suspended by the city council if the holder thereof has: 
(1)  Violated any of the provisions of this article. 
(2)  Discontinued operations for more than fifteen (15) days. 
(3)  Has violated any ordinance of the city, or law of the United States or of this state, the violation of which reflects unfavorably on the fitness of the holder to offer public transportation. 
(b)  Notice. Prior to suspension or revocation, the holder shall be given notice of the proposed action to be taken and shall have an opportunity to be heard. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-107. - Insurance requirements. 
    No certificate of public convenience and necessity shall be issued until the owner of the public carrier vehicle shall first have filed with the officer in charge of the traffic division of the police department a policy of liability insurance issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in this state. Such insurance policy shall provide for the payment of a sum not less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) to satisfy all claims for damages by reason of bodily injury to or death of any one person resulting from any one accident, and subject to such limit for one person, for payment of a sum not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) to satisfy all claims for damages by reason of bodily injury to, or death of, two (2) or more persons, resulting from any one accident, and for a payment of a sum not less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) to satisfy all claims for damages to property resulting form any one accident, by reason of the ownership operation, maintenance or use of such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-108. - Reports to secretary of state. 
    The officer in charge of the traffic division of the police department shall make and deliver, in January of each year, to the secretary of state, printed or typed certified lists giving in alphabetical order the full names and addresses of all owners of public carrier vehicles holding valid certificates issued by the council. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-109. - Certificate of compliance. 
    Upon filing by the owner of a public carrier vehicle or vehicles of the insurance policy, the officer in charge of the traffic division of the police department shall issue a certificate of compliance for each such vehicle. This certificate of compliance shall show that the owner of such vehicle has complied with the requirements of section 35-107, and shall recite the full name of the owner of the vehicle and of the insurer, together with the number and date of expiration of the policy, a description of the vehicle insured thereunder, and the number thereof. The original certificate of compliance shall be posted within the vehicle. The issuing officer shall retain and preserve a duplicate of the certificate of compliance. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-110. - Annual fee. 
    A person to whom a certificate has been issued shall pay an annual fee to the city equal to one per cent of the gross receipts derived from the limousine for the year for which the certificate was issued. Such fee shall be paid prior to April 1 of the subsequent year. Upon request each certificate holder shall exhibit manifests, tax returns, bank records and such other documents as may be necessary to verify the correctness of the fee paid. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 35-111-35-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 35-121. - Periodic inspections. 
    Every vehicle operating under this article shall be periodically inspected by the police department at such intervals as shall be established by the city council to insure the continued maintenance of safe operating conditions, but no less than once each year. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-122. - Sanitation. 
    Every vehicle operating under this article shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 35-123. - Identifying markings on vehicle. 
    The city shall issue a card or decal for each vehicle covered by a limousine certificate and such card or decal shall be displayed by affixing to the inside of the vehicle. If more than one vehicle is operated by a licensee each vehicle shall be designated by a different number, and the number also shall so appear on each side of such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-124. - State vehicle license. 
    Each vehicle hereunder shall be properly licensed under the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-125. - Advertising. 
    Subject to the rules and regulations of the council, it shall be lawful for any person owning or operating a limousine for hire to permit advertising matter to be affixed to or installed in or on such motor vehicles for hire. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Cross reference- Advertising and signs, Ch. 3. 
Secs. 35-126-35-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 35-141. - Established. 
    No owner or driver of a limousine shall charge a greater sum for the use of a limousine than in accordance with the following rates: 
(1)  Per trip ..... $20.00 
(2)  Per hour ..... 30.00 
(3)  Out of town, per mile ..... 1.50 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-142. - Change of rates. 
    Rates shall only be changed upon application to and approval by city council. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-143. - Refusal to pay fare. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the legal fare of any limousine after having hired the same. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-144. - Receipts. 
    The driver of any limousine shall, upon demand by the passenger, render to such passenger a receipt for the amount charged, either by a mechanically printed receipt or by a specially prepared receipt on which shall be the name of the owner, name of the driver, certified number, charges and date of transaction. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 35-145-35-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DRIVER'S LICENSE 

Sec. 35-171. - State driver's license. 
    All drivers shall be required to have at all times a driver's license as required by the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-172. - City driver's license. 
    No person shall operate or drive a limousine for hire upon the streets of the city, and no person who owns or controls a limousine shall permit same to be so operated or driven, and no limousine licensed by the city shall be so operated or driven at any time for hire, unless the driver of such limousine shall have first obtained and shall have then in force a limousine driver's license issued under the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-173. - Application. 
(a)  An application for a limousine driver's license shall be filed with the police department on forms provided by the city; such applications shall be verified under oath and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The names and addresses of four (4) residents of the city who have known the applicant for a period of two (2) years and who will vouch for the sobriety, honesty and general good character of the applicant. 
(2)  The experience of the applicant in transportation of passengers. 
(3)  The educational background of the applicant. 
(4)  A concise history of the employment of the applicant. 
(b)  Each application shall be accompanied by a certificate from a reputable physician of the city, certifying that, in his opinion, the applicant is not afflicted with any disease or infirmity which might make him an unsafe or unsatisfactory driver. At the time the application is filed, the applicant shall pay the license fee provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-174. - Qualifications. 
    No such license shall be issued to any person who is not competent to operate a motor vehicle or is not familiar with the traffic laws and ordinances. Before issuing a limousine driver's license the chief of police shall examine the applicant with a written test and/or a driving test to determine the competency of the applicant as a driver. The chief of police may delegate the giving of such tests to a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-175. - Examination of applicant. 
    Before any application for a limousine driver's license is finally passed upon by the police chief the applicant shall be required to pass a satisfactory examination as to his knowledge of the city and to show that he has a current motor vehicle operator's permit issued by the state. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-176. - Investigation of applicant. 
    The police department shall conduct an investigation of each applicant for a limousine driver's license a report of such investigation and a copy of the traffic and police record of the applicant, if any, shall be attached to the application. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-177. - Issuance. 
(a)  The police department shall, upon consideration of the application for a limousine driver's license and the reports and certificate required to be attached thereto, approve or reject the application. If the application is rejected, the applicant may request a personal appearance before the police chief to offer evidence why his application should be reconsidered. The applicant may appeal an adverse consideration to the city council. 
(b)  Upon approval of an application for a limousine driver's license the police department shall issue a license to the applicant which shall bear the name, address, color, age, signature and photograph of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-178. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for a limousine driver's license shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per year or any part of a year. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-179. - Expiration and renewal. 
    Limousine driver's licenses shall expire at the end of each calendar year, and may be renewed upon payment of the required fee unless the license for the preceding year has been revoked. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-180. - Display. 
    Every driver licensed under this division shall post his driver's license in such a place as to be if full view of all passengers while such driver is operating a limousine. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-181. - Suspension or revocation; notice. 
    The police chief may suspend any driver's license issued under this division for a driver's failing or refusing to comply with the provisions of this article, such suspension to last for a period of not more than fifteen (15) days. The department may revoke any driver's license for failure to comply with the provisions of this article. A license may not be revoked unless the driver has received notice and has had an opportunity to present evidence in his behalf. Any suspension or revocation under this section may be appealed to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 35-182-35-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - OPERATIONAL RULES AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 35-201. - Compliance with laws. 
    Every driver licensed under this article shall comply with all city, state and federal laws, including all traffic laws, rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-202. - Quality of service. 
    All persons engaged in the limousine business in the city operating under the provisions of this article shall render an overall service to the public desiring to use limousines. Holders of certificates of public convenience and necessity shall maintain a central place of business and keep the same open twenty-four (24) hours a day for the purpose of receiving calls and dispatching limousines. They shall answer all calls received by them for services inside the corporate limits of the city as soon as they can do so and, if such services cannot be rendered within a reasonable time, they shall then notify the prospective passengers how long it will be before the call can be answered and give the reason therefor. Any holder who shall refuse to accept a call anywhere in the corporate limits of the city at any time when such holder has available limousines, or who shall fail or refuse to give overall service, shall be deemed a violator of this article and the certificate granted to such holder may be revoked at the discretion of the council. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-203. - Service by reservation only. 
(a)  All limousine service shall be by reservation only. 
(b)  No driver shall refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person, by prior reservation, unless previously engaged or unable or forbidden by the provisions of this article to do so. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-204. - Solicitation of passengers by driver. 
(a)  No limousine driver shall solicit passengers for a limousine. The driver of any limousine shall remain in the driver's compartment or immediately adjacent to his vehicle at all times when such vehicle is upon the public street, except that, when necessary, a driver may be absent from his limousine for not more than ten (10) consecutive minutes, and provided further, nothing herein contained shall be held to prohibit any driver from alighting to the street or sidewalk for the purpose of assisting passengers into or out of such vehicle. 
(b)  No driver shall solicit patronage in a loud or annoying tone of voice or by sign, or in any manner annoy any person or obstruct the movement of any persons, or follow any person for the purpose of soliciting patronage. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-205. - Cruising. 
    No limousine driver shall cruise in search of passengers. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-206. - Receipt and discharge of passengers. 
    Drivers of limousines shall not receive or discharge passengers in the roadway but shall pull up to the right-hand sidewalk as nearly as possible or in the absence of a sidewalk, to the extreme right-hand side of the road and there receive or discharge passengers, except upon one-way streets where passengers may be discharged at either the right-or left-hand sidewalk, or side or the roadway in the absence of a sidewalk. Drivers shall assist passengers in and out of limousines. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-207. - Restriction on number of passengers. 
    No driver shall permit more persons to be carried in a limousine as passengers than the rated seating capacity of his limousine as stated in the license for such vehicle issued by the police department. A child in arms shall not be counted as a passenger. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7960, 10-28-86) 
Sec. 35-208. - Records and reports-Generally. 
(a)  Every holder shall keep accurate records of receipts from operations, operating, and other expenses, capital expenditures, and such other operating information as may be required by the council. Every holder shall maintain the records containing such information and other data required by this article at a place readily accessible for examination by the council. 
(b)  Every holder shall submit reports of receipts, expenses and statistics of operation to the council for each calendar year, in accordance with a uniform system prescribed by the director of administration. Such reports shall reach the director on or before the fifteenth day of March of the year following the calendar year for which such reports are prepared. 
(c)  All accidents arising from or in connection with the operation of limousines which result in death or injury to any person, or in damage to any vehicle, or to any property in an amount exceeding the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be reported within twenty-four (24) hours from the time of occurrence to the police department in a form of report to be furnished by such department. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-209. - Same-Driver's manifests. 
    Each driver of a limousine shall maintain a daily manifest on which shall be recorded the time and place of origin, designation of each trip, time and place of termination, the amount of the fare, the name of the driver, and identity of the limousine. The manifest form shall be furnished to the driver by the licensee. The licensee shall preserve each daily manifest for a period of four (4) years and shall submit any information contained in the manifest forms at the request of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-210. - Immoral purposes. 
    It is unlawful for a limousine service driver to permit any person to occupy or use a limousine for the purpose of prostitution, lewdness, indecent conduct or other unlawful use. And it is unlawful for a driver to direct or offer or agree to direct any person to any place or person for the purpose of prostitution, lewdness or indecent conduct. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 35-211-35-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TAXICAB SERVICE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Taxicabs and taxicab zones,  33-47. 

DIVISION 1. - CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 45:200.3. 

Sec. 35-251. - Required. 
    No person shall operate or permit a vehicle owned or controlled by him to be operated as a taxi for hire upon the streets of the city without having first obtained a certificate of public convenience and necessity from the council. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-252. - Application. 
    An application for a certificate shall be filed with the police department upon forms provided by the city; and such application shall be verified under oath and shall furnish the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  The financial status of the applicant, including the amounts of all unpaid judgments against the applicant and the nature of the transaction or acts giving rise to such judgments; 
(3)  The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers; 
(4)  Any facts which the applicant believes tend to provide that public convenience and necessity require the granting of a certificate; 
(5)  The number of vehicles to be operated or controlled by the applicant and the location of proposed deposits and terminals; 
(6)  The color scheme or insignia to be used to designate the vehicle or vehicles of the applicant; and 
(7)  Such further information as the council may require. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-253. - Character of applicant. 
    No such license shall be issued to or held by any person who is not a person of good character; nor shall such license be issued to or held by any corporation if any officer thereof would be ineligible for a license under the foregoing conditions. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 10,059, 7-25-00) 
Sec. 35-254. - Hearing and issuance. 
(a)  Upon the filing of an application for a certificate, the city council shall fix a time and place for public hearing thereon. Notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant and to all persons to whom certificates of public convenience and necessity have been theretofore issued. Due notice shall also be given the general public by posting a notice of such hearing in a daily newspaper published in the city. Any interested person may file with the city council a memorandum in support of or opposition to the issuance of a certificate. 
(b)  If the council finds that further service in the city is required by public convenience and necessity and that the applicant is fit, willing and able to perform such public transportation and to conform to the provisions of this article and the rules promulgated by the council, then the council shall issue a certificate stating the name and address of the applicant, the number of vehicles authorized under such certificate, and the date of issuance; otherwise, the application shall be denied. 
(c)  In making the above findings, the city council shall take into consideration the number of vehicles for hire already in operation, whether existing transportation is adequate to meet the public need, the probable effect of increased service on local traffic conditions, and the character, experience, and responsibility of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-255. - Transfer. 
    No certificate of public convenience and necessity may be sold, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise transferred without the consent of the council. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-256. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Grounds. A certificate issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked or suspended by the city council if the holder thereof has: 
(1)  Violated any of the provisions of this article; 
(2)  Discontinued operations for more than fifteen (15) days; 
(3)  Has violated any ordinance of the city, or law of the United States or of this state, the violation of which reflects unfavorably on the fitness of the holder to offer public transportation. 
(b)  Notice. Prior to suspension or revocation, the holder shall be given notice of the proposed action to be taken and shall have an opportunity to be heard. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-257. - Insurance requirements. 
    No certificate of public convenience and necessity shall be issued until the owner of the public carrier vehicle shall first have filed with the officer in charge of the traffic division of the police department a policy of liability insurance issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in this state. Such insurance policy shall provide for the payment of a sum not less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) to satisfy all claims for damages by reason of bodily injury to or death of any one person resulting from any one accident, and subject to such limit for one person, for payment of a sum not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) to satisfy all claims for damages by reason of bodily injury to, or death of, two (2) or more persons, resulting from any one accident, and for a payment of a sum not less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) to satisfy all claims for damages to property resulting from any one accident, by reason of the ownership operation, maintenance or use of such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 45:200.4-45:200.7. 
Sec. 35-258. - Reports to secretary of state. 
    The officer in charge of the traffic division of the police department shall make and deliver, in January of each year, to the secretary of state printed or typed certified lists giving in alphabetical order the full names and addresses of all owners of public carrier vehicles holding valid certificates issued by the council. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-259. - Certificate of compliance. 
    Upon filing by the owner of a public carrier vehicle or vehicles, of the insurance policy, the officer in charge of the traffic division of the police department shall issue a certificate of compliance for each such vehicle. This certificate of compliance shall show that the owner of such vehicle has complied with the requirements of section 35-257, and shall recite the full name of the owner of the vehicle and of the insurer, together with the number and date of expiration of the policy, a description of the vehicle insured thereunder, and the number thereof. The original certificate of compliance shall be posted within the vehicle. The issuing officer shall retain and preserve a duplicate of the certificate of compliance. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 45:200.9. 
Sec. 35-260. - Fee. 
    A person to whom a certificate has been issued shall pay an annual fee to the city equal to one per cent of the gross receipts derived from the taxicab for the year for which the certificate was issued. Such fee shall be paid prior to April 1 of the subsequent year. Upon request each certificate holder shall exhibit manifests, tax returns, bank records and such other documents as may be necessary to verify the correctness of the fee paid. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 35-261-35-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 35-271. - Periodic inspections. 
    Every vehicle operating under this article shall be periodically inspected by the police department at such intervals as shall be established by the city council to insure the continued maintenance of safe operating conditions, but no less than once each year. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-272. - Sanitation. 
    Every vehicle operating under this article shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 35-273. - Identifying markings on vehicle. 
(a)  Each taxicab shall bear on each side of the vehicle, in painted letters and figures not less than two (2) inches or more than six (6) inches in height, and in a conspicuous position approved by the traffic division of the police department: 
(1)  The full name of the owner of the certificate under which said vehicle is being operated; and 
(2)  The number of the certificate for such vehicle. 
(b)  In addition, the vehicle shall bear an identifying design approved the city council. No vehicle covered by the terms of this article shall be licensed whose color scheme, identifying design, monogram or insignia to be used thereon shall, in the opinion of the council, conflict with or imitate any color scheme, identifying design, monogram or insignia used on a vehicle or vehicles already misleading or tend to deceive or defraud the public. If the color scheme, identifying design, monogram or insignia thereof is changed so as to be, in the opinion of the council, in conflict with or imitation of any color scheme, identifying design, monogram or insignia used by any other person, owner or operator, in such a manner as to be misleading or tending to deceive the public, the certificate covering such taxicab shall be suspend or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-274. - State vehicle license. 
    Each vehicle hereunder shall be properly licensed under the laws of the State. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-275. - Advertising. 
    Subject to the rules and regulations of the council, it shall be lawful for any person owning or operating a taxi for hire to permit advertising matter to be affixed to or installed in or on such motor vehicles for hire. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Cross reference- Advertising and signs, Ch. 3. 
Secs. 35-276-35-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 35-301. - Established. 
    No owner or driver of a taxicab shall charge a greater sum for the use of a taxicab than in accordance with the following rates: 
(1)  Mileage rates: One dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) for the first one-fifth mile or fraction thereof; thirty-six cents ($0.36) for each additional one-fifth mile or fraction thereof. 
(2)  Waiting time: Thirty cents ($0.30) for each one minute of waiting time or fraction thereof. 
(3)  Luggage: No charge for each two (2) suitcases per paying passenger; fifty cents ($0.50) for each additional suitcase. 
(4)  Additional passengers. Only one fare shall be charged for two (2) passengers or less, where the point of destination of the passengers is the same. For each additional passenger in excess of two (2) passengers, an additional charge of fifty cents ($0.50) may be made. No charge will be made for children twelve (12) years of age and under when accompanied by an adult. 
(5)  Airport taxicab. The owner or driver of the airport taxicab shall charge a rate consistent with zoning map on file in the office of the clerk and made a part hereof. The rates will be as follows, for each passenger, no charge for children under twelve (12) years of age when accompanied by an adult: 
Local motels, not more than ..... $5.00 
Zone No. 1, not more than ..... 6.00 
Zone No. 2, not more than ..... 7.00 
Zone No. 3, not more than ..... 8.00 
Zone No. 4, not more than ..... 9.00 
New zones, not more than ..... 10.00 
No comparable rates, not more than ..... 10.00 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7959, 10-28-86; Ord. No. 10,021, 3-28-00) 
Cross reference- Monroe Regional Airport,  7-46 et seq. 
Sec. 35-302. - Change of rates. 
    Rates shall only be changed upon application to and approval by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-303. - Refusal to pay fare. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the legal fare of any taxicab after having hired the same. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-304. - Receipts. 
    The driver of any taxicab shall, upon demand by the passenger, render to such passenger a receipt for the amount charged, either by a mechanically printed receipt or by a specially prepared receipt on which shall be the name of the owner, name of the driver, certified number, charges and date of transaction. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-305. - Taximeter. 
    All taxicabs operated under the authority of this article shall be equipped with taximeters fastened in front of the passengers, visible to them at all times day and night and, after sundown, the face of the taximeter shall be illuminated. Such taximeter shall be operated mechanically by a mechanism of standard design and construction, driven either from the transmission or from one of the front wheels by a flexible and permanently attached driving mechanism. They shall be sealed at all points and connections which, if manipulated, would affect their correct reading and recording. Each taximeter shall have thereon a flag to denote when the vehicle is employed and when it is not employed; and it shall be the duty of the driver to throw the flag of such taximeter into a nonrecording position at the termination of each trip. The taximeters shall be subject to inspection from time to time by the police department. Any inspector or other officer of the department is hereby authorized, either on complaint of any person or without any such complaint, to inspect any meter and, upon discovery of any inaccuracy therein, to notify the person operating the taxicab to cease operation. Thereupon such taxicab shall be kept off the highways until the taximeter is repaired and in the required working condition. 
(Ord. No. 7959, 10-28-86) 
Secs. 35-306-35-335. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DRIVER'S LICENSE 

Sec. 35-336. - State driver's license. 
    All drivers shall be required to have at all times a driver's license as required by the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-337. - City driver's license. 
    No person shall operate or drive a taxicab for hire upon the streets of the city, and no person who owns or controls a taxicab shall permit same to be so operated or driven, and no taxicab licensed by the city shall be so operated or driven at any time for hire, unless the driver of such taxicab shall have first obtained and shall have then in force a taxicab driver's license issued under the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-338. - Application. 
(a)  An application for a limousine driver's license shall be filed with the police department on forms provided by the city; such applications shall be verified under oath and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The names and addresses of four (4) residents of the city who have known the applicant for a period of two (2) years and who will vouch for the sobriety, honesty and general good character of the applicant. 
(2)  The experience of the applicant in transportation of passengers. 
(3)  The educational background of the applicant. 
(4)  A concise history of the employment of the applicant. 
(b)  Each application shall be accompanied by a certificate from a reputable physician of the city, certifying that, in his opinion, the applicant is not afflicted with any disease or infirmity which might make him an unsafe or unsatisfactory driver. At the time the application is filed, the applicant shall pay the license fee provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-339. - Qualifications. 
    No such license shall be issued to any person who is not competent to operate a motor vehicle or is not familiar with the traffic laws and ordinances. Before issuing a taxicab driver's license the chief of police shall examine the applicant with a written test and/or a driving test to determine the competency of the applicant as a driver. The chief of police may delegate the giving of such tests to a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-340. - Examination of applicant. 
    Before any application for a taxicab driver's license is finally passed upon by the police chief the applicant shall be required to pass a satisfactory examination as to his knowledge of the city and to show that he has a current motor vehicle operator's permit issued by the state. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-341. - Investigation of applicant. 
    The police department shall conduct an investigation of each applicant for a taxicab driver's license a report of such investigation and a copy of the traffic and police record of the applicant, if any, shall be attached to the application. 
(Ord. No. 7943, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 35-342. - Issuance.
