(h)  To develop and propose to the commission a uniform classification and pay plan and maintain it on a continuing basis by recommending amendments thereto. 
(i)  To provide high morale among city employees by fostering good working relationships and by providing uniform personnel policies, opportunities for advancement, and consideration of employee need and desires. 
(j)  To develop training, educational and safety programs. 
(k)  To make and publish annual reports as requested by the commission, mayor or city council. 
(l)  To make investigations into alleged violations of these rules. 
(m)  To establish mandatory uniform grievance procedures within the departments of the city. 
(n)  To perform any other acts and functions which he may consider necessary or desirable to carry out the purpose of administration. 
2.2. - Promotion of affirmative action. 
    The director shall perform all is duties in an effort to promote affirmative action. 
2.3. - Equal employment opportunity. 
    Affirmative action shall be taken by the director to ensure equal employment opportunity in the city's classified service. 
CHAPTER 3. - PERSONS GOVERNED BY THESE RULES 

3.1. - Classified and unclassified positions. 
(a)  All employees of the city shall be members of the classified service, except the following: 
(1)  All elected city officials. 
(2)  The mayor's secretary and any assistants to the mayor. 
(3)  Persons employed on a temporary or contractual basis. 
(4)  The city attorney and any assistant city attorneys. 
(5)  Heads of departments created by or under the home rule charter of the City of Monroe. 
(6)  Any employee appointed directly by the council. 
(7)  Employees governed under the State of Louisiana Fire and Police Civil Service. 
(b)  Upon the changing of the Charter, state law or court decision, the city may add additional positions to the unclassified service. 
(c)  The commission, upon submission of adequate justification by the mayor or city council and after considering the recommendations of the director of personnel, may recommend to the city council the addition of positions to the unclassified service or the revocation of any positions in the unclassified service which is not covered by the City Charter, state law or court decision. 
(d)  All temporary personnel services which are for a period under thirty (30) days unless approved by the Commission. 
CHAPTER 4. - EQUAL OPPORTUNITY POLICY 

4.1. - Established. 
    Affirmative action shall be taken to ensure equal employment opportunity in the city service. Discrimination against any person in recruitment, examination, appointment, training, promotion, discipline, or any other aspect of personnel administration because of political or religious opinions or affiliations, membership or nonmembership in employee organization, or because of race, color, creed, national origin, marital status or other nonmerit factors are prohibited. Discrimination on the basis of age, sex or physical disability is prohibited except where specific age, sex or physical requirement constitutes a bona fide occupational qualification necessary to proper and efficient administration. 
CHAPTER 5. - CLASSIFICATION PLAN 

5.1. - Preparation by director. 
    The director, after consultation with the departments concerned, shall cause to be prepared a classification plan and from time to time, amendments thereto for presentation to the commission for its approval following public hearings. This plan shall consist of job specifications, designated standard class titles, designed to provide for all classes in the classified service. 
5.2. - Submittal to mayor and council. 
    All approved plans and amendments thereof shall be submitted after approval of the commission through the director of administration to the mayor and then to the city council. 
5.3. - Approval by commission. 
    An original classification plan or amendments thereto shall become effective only after the approval of the commission and after adoption as an ordinance of the City of Monroe, provided funds are available and appropriated by the governing authorities for implementation of the plan. 
5.4. - Allocation of positions. 
    The director, as soon as practicable after adoption of a classification plan hereunder, after consultation with the departments concerned, shall allocate each position in the classified service to its appropriate class, and thereafter shall allocate each new position in such service to its appropriate class, and may reallocate position from class to class. In making such allocations, he shall provide uniform application of the classification plan to positions under different departments. 
5.5. - Appointment only to allocated positions. 
    No person may be appointed until the position is allocated by the director. 
5.6. - Approval of new classes. 
    If new classes are requested, the classification system will be viewed as changed and the approval must be in accordance with rule 2 and 3 of this chapter. 
5.7. - Right of appeal to director regarding allocation or reallocation. 
    An employee affected by allocation or reallocation of a position to a class shall have thirty (30) days to have his case reviewed by the director or by a representative of the director. The director's decision shall be final in these matters unless there is an allegation that his ruling has been discriminatory in which case, the employee may appeal the decision to the commission in accord with chapter 12. 
5.8. - Titles of classes. 
    The title of each class will be the official title of every position allocated to the class. The department may use any working title of a position he deems necessary with the approval of the director. 
5.9. - Employment only under class title. 
    No employee in the classified service shall be appointed, employed or paid under any title other than of the class to which the position [is] allocated or reallocated. 
5.10. - Force and effect of classes. 
(a)  The specification of classes will have the following parts: 
(1)  Definitions will be descriptive and not restrictive. 
(2)  List or example of duties and responsibilities: 
a.  General duties. 
b.  Specific tasks. 
c.  Responsibilities. 
d.  Qualifications requirements. 
e.  Relations to other similar classes. 
f.  Statement of necessary special qualifications. 
5.11. - Reallocations and title change. 
(a)  When an employee's position or class title is changed or reallocated, he is entitled to serve therein without change in status if he meets the requirements set forth for the class. 
CHAPTER 6. - UNIFORM MERIT PAY PLAN 

6.1. - Preparation. 
    The director, after consultation with departments and director of administration and affording such investigations and research as deemed desirable, shall cause to be prepared a uniform merit pay plan. The submission and approval of such plan will be in accordance with rules 5.1., 5.2, and 5.3. 
6.2. - Amendments. 
    Any amendments thereof shall be submitted and approved in accordance with rules 5.1., 5.2 and 5.3 and rule 6.1. 
6.3. - Rates of pay-Types. 
    The rates of pay in the uniform pay plan shall consist of the following: 
(a)  A minimum rate. 
(b)  A maximum rate. 
(c)  Such intermediate rates as may be adopted by the commission and approved by the mayor and city council. 
6.4. - Same-Determination. 
    Rates of pay upon employment shall be fixed at the entrance rate of the class to which the position is allocated except that: 
(a)  When economic or employment condition makes recruitment of eligibles at the minimum rate for the class difficult, the director may request special entrance rates for that class with the approval of the director of administration and commission. 
(b)  If a special entrance rate is approved, all employees in the class must be raised to the new entrance rate of the class. 
(c)  No employee can, because of the rule, exceed the maximum step of the pay plan for the class which his position is allocated. 
6.5. - Persons reentering service-Generally. 
    A person reentering city service within a period of three (3) years except for military service may be placed in the corresponding step in which he left as long as it does not exceed the maximum amount of pay which he was earning when he left. 
6.6. - Same-Upon returning from military service. 
    A person returning from military service shall be restored to duty in compliance with the Universal Military Training and Service Act. 
6.7. - Transfer, reassignment. 
    Pay upon transfer or reassignment will be the same as the position they are transferring from. 
6.8. - Promotion. 
    Pay upon promotion will be established at the next higher step in the range of the new class. 
6.9. - Demotion. 
    Pay upon demotion may be set at any lower step within the lower class but cannot exceed or be equal to the amount being paid before demotion. 
6.10. - Merit increase. 
    Each employee is eligible for, but not automatically entitled to, a merit increase after the first six (6) months of employment and each year thereafter until the maximum step is achieved. These increases are merit increases and in no way should be viewed as longevity or cost-of-living increase. 
6.11. - Maximum rate. 
    All increases herein authorized are subject to the requirement that no employee's pay shall exceed the maximum rate of pay established for the class of position the employee occupies. 
6.12. - Compensation of part-time employees. 
    Compensation of part-time employees will be set as a full-time [employee] except that all benefits including pay will be prorated to his percentage of time. 
6.13. - Change of pay plan. 
    When the pay plan is changed, the rate of pay will be established in accordance to the next higher step of the plan. 
6.14. - Individual increases. 
    A department head may, after presenting justifiable reasons in writing to the commission and with its approval, increase an employee's pay at any time to any step in the range for the class but not beyond the maximum for the class. The department head must have approval of the director of administration and mayor before submitting this request to the commission. 
6.15. - Certification and payment. 
    No payment for personal service shall be made by the director of administration without the certification of personnel action forms from the director of personnel. 
6.16. - Rates for reallocation. 
    Rates of pay for reallocation will be the same as promotion, demotion, reassignment, whichever is applicable. 
6.17. - Rules for overtime pay. 
    The director shall set the rules of payment for overtime, holidays, and other fringe benefits with the concurrence of the director of administration and present them for approval of the commission, the mayor and council. 
6.18. - Uniformity. 
    All compensation will be treated uniformly throughout the city departments. 
6.19. - Cost-of-living raises. 
    Cost-of-living raises will not become part of the pay plan and will be administered by the mayor and city council. 
CHAPTER 7. - CERTIFICATION AND APPOINTMENT 

7.1. - Filling of vacancies. 
    Vacancies in the classified service may be filled by original appointment, promotion, reassignment, demotion, transfer, reinstatement following an appeal, restoration to duty following military service or by noncompetitive reemployment. 
7.2. - New positions. 
    When the need for a new position exists, the department will request through the director of administration, who will certify the availability of funds, to the director for a list of eligibles to make such an appointment. 
7.3. - Anticipation of vacancies. 
    The department should anticipate as far in advance as practicable the vacancy to permit the director to prepare a list of eligibles for filling of the vacancy. 
7.4. - Certification of eligibles. 
    The director shall certify to the department the names of the eligibles from the appropriate list for the class in which the vacant position exists. 
7.5. - Selective certification. 
    Selective certification may be requested and approved by the director when: 
(a)  The department requests and adequately justifies that to perform certain duties of a class a person must possess particular qualifications. 
(b)  In specific instances, and pursuant to and in conformity with an order of the court, commission, or agency of competent jurisdiction, the director may make selective certification. 
7.6. - Certification only of available applicants. 
    The director shall make the determination of availability for appointment and certify only the available applicants to the department. 
7.7. - Recommendation. 
    The department [director] will recommend the person whom he wishes for appointment to the position. The director will appoint and certify the appointment to the director of administration. 
7.8. - Emergency appointments. 
(a)  All appoints [appointments] of less than thirty (30) days will be filled as a temporary appointment. 
(b)  The director may approve an emergency appointment to exceed one hundred eighty (180) days; however no employee may serve over one hundred eighty (180) [days] without being appointed in conformity of these rules. 
7.9. - Temporary positions, time span. 
    No position appointed over thirty (30) days will be classed as a temporary position and must have the approval of the commission. Temporary positions are for thirty (30) days or less. 
7.10. - Cancellation of employment. 
    The director may cancel the employment of any applicant or of any employee serving with other than permanent status following certification or employment if: 
(a)  His employment in the classified service would be prohibited by law. 
(b)  His conduct has been infamous or disgraceful. 
(c)  He lacks the qualifications for the class or position. 
(d)  He is physically unfit for the position. 
(e)  He is addicted to habitual use of drugs or intoxicating liquors. 
(f)  He has been adjudged guilty in court of a crime involving moral turpitude. 
(g)  He has been dismissed from public service for cause. 
(h)  He has made false statement concerning his qualifications or prior employment status or other material information which caused his certification to examination or employment. 
7.11. - Types of appointment. 
    In the classified service, there will be seven (7) types of appointments certified by the director: 
(a)  Emergency appointments: An appointment for thirty-one (31) days to one hundred eighty (180) days with the approval of the commission. No fringe benefits will be given for these types of position. 
(b)  Temporary position: An appointment for less than thirty (30) days. This position will be part of the classified service. However, if an appointment of any individual is for over thirty (30) days, it will become an emergency appointment and must come under the classified service. 
(c)  Probationary appointment: When a position is filled by original appointment, the employee serves a six-month period of probation. 
(d)  Provisional appointment: When a person is appointed from a list of eligibles of less than five (5) applicants. The director may rule this as a provisional appointment and in the event a list of eligibles are recorded within ninety (90) days, he may rule that the position must be competitive. If the director has not made such ruling within ninety (90) days the position will become classified as probationary and the employee will be treated as a probationary employee and be given credit of time served in this status. 
(e)  Permanent appointment: When an employee has served his six (6) months' probationary appointment, he becomes a permanent classified employee. 
(f)  Job appointment: This is an appointment with a period of appointment with beginning and ending date. This employee is entitled to fringe benefits and the appointment cannot extend over eighteen (18) months. An appointment must be made from a list of eligibles. 
(g)  Noncompetitive reemployment: When an employee is reappointed within three (3) years after he has left city service. The employee is reemployed at no greater rate than he earned before he left the classified service. The type appointment is also a probational appointment. 
7.12. - Rights of department-Director's approval required. 
    The department may, with the approval of the director: 
(a)  Reassign an employee to another position for which the employee is qualified as long as the position has the same entrance level. 
(b)  Demote an employee to another position for cause provided the employee is qualified. 
(c)  Detail to another position for a period not to exceed one hundred eighty (180) days with pay, an employee who is qualified for the position to be detailed to. 
7.13. - Same-Report to director. 
    The department may, by reporting to the director: 
(a)  Change the duty station. 
(b)  Change the working hours. 
(c)  Transfer to the same class or to a comparable class with the same entrance rate that the employee is qualified. 
CHAPTER 8. - PROBATIONARY PERIOD 

8.1. - Appointments affected. 
    Probationary periods will be served for the following appointments: 
(a)  Probationary appointments. 
(b)  Noncompetitive reemployments. 
(c)  Provisional appointments which, after ninety (90) days, have been changed to probationary appointments. 
    The probationary period shall be an essential part of the employment process and shall be utilized for the most effective adjustment of a new employee and for the elimination of any probationary employee whose performance does not meet the requirements standard of work. 
8.2. - Exceptions. 
    A permanent employee who has been promoted, transferred, reassigned or demoted to another position shall not be required to serve another probationary period. 
8.3. - Removal of probationary employees. 
    A probationary employee may be removed by the department with written reason being provided to the director and the employee. 
8.4. - Probationary period for part-time employees. 
    A probationary period for a part-time employee will be six (6) months. 
8.5. - When permanent appointment begins. 
    A permanent appointment will begin at the end of a probationary appointment. 
8.6. - Extension. 
    The director may extend the probationary period up to twelve (12) months upon written request from the department giving reason for the request extension. No probationary period will be granted over twelve (12) months. 
CHAPTER 9. - PERFORMANCE APPRAISAL 

9.1. - Authorized. 
    Performance appraisals will be made on all employees who have been in a position for ninety (90) days during the period of January 1 through December 31. Each employee will receive his or her evaluation by February 1 of each year. 
9.2. - Procedure. 
    The performance appraisals will be made as follows: 
(a)  The supervisor will evaluate each employee under their supervision on the appropriate form provided by the director. 
(b)  The supervisor, the department head or his designee, and the employee will review the annual appraisal and sign, and the employee will be given a copy thereof. 
(c)  The department head will forward all appraisals to the director by February 1 of each year. 
9.3. - Final rating. 
    The final rating on all performance appraisals will be one of the five (5) following categories as provided for on the performance appraisal form provided by the director: 
(a)  Excellent. 
(b)  Good. 
(c)  Satisfactory. 
(d)  Fair. 
(e)  Unsatisfactory. 
9.4. - Appeal. 
    Appeal of an unsatisfactory evaluation will be as follows: 
(a)  An employee will appeal his evaluation to his department head within thirty (30) days from the date on which he signed and received a copy of said evaluation. This appeal will be in writing and give reason thereof why they feel the evaluation should be changed. 
(b)  The department head will review the evaluation and give his determination within ten (10) days of the receipt of the appeal to the employee. 
(c)  Upon the receipt of the answer, the employee has the right to appeal the decision of the department head to the mayor within ten (10) days of the receipt of the department head's decision. 
(d)  The mayor or his designee will review the appeal and have a hearing concerning the appeal and issue a written answer to the employee within fifteen (15) days of the hearing. 
(e)  Within thirty (30) days of the notification, an employee may appeal to the commission after the above appeals have been exhausted. 
9.5. - Effect of unsatisfactory evaluation. 
    The effect of an unsatisfactory evaluation is: 
(a)  The employee becomes ineligible for: 
(1)  Any promotion; or 
(2)  Any salary increase. 
(b)  The employee may be subject to further disciplinary actions including discharge. 
9.6. - Re-rating after unsatisfactory evaluation. 
    In the case of an employee receiving an unsatisfactory evaluation they must be re-rated by September 1 of that year. This also must be reported to the director. 
9.7. - Effect of lack of appraisal. 
    If a permanent employee does not have any official performance appraisal record in the director's office, they shall be considered as having a "satisfactory" rating. 
CHAPTER 10. - HOURS OF WORK AND FORMS OF LEAVE 

10.1. - Workweek established. 
    Each employee shall have a workweek established as forty (40) hours per week. 
10.2. - Longer workweek. 
    The city may specify a workweek exceeding forty (40) hours for employees in specific classes of position with the approval of the commission, for employees in specific departments. 
10.3. - Recording of hours. 
    The director shall record the number of hours and days which will constitute the regular workweek. 
10.4. - Part-time employees. 
    Part-time employees shall have the work established for part-time work and rules 1, 2 and 3 shall be used. 
10.5. - Intermittent employees. 
    When the services are not needed on a regular basis, the commission shall authorize intermittent workers, the director may appoint an employee to serve on an intermittent basis on an hourly, daily, weekly or monthly basis. 
10.6. - Overtime. 
    An employee in classified service may be required by the city to work overtime. Any time the department requires the employee to work overtime, they must perform the hours of work. 
10.7. - Types of leave. 
    All full-time employees shall earn sick and vacation (annual leave) by the following schedule: 
(a)  Vacation (annual leave). A full-time employee is guaranteed a paid vacation (annual leave) drawable in advance as per the following schedule: 
(1)  6 months-1 year: 5 days (working). 
(2)  1 year-5 years: 10 days (working). 
(3)  6 years-10 years: 15 days (working). 
(4)  11 years-20 years; 20 days (working). 
(5)  21 years and over: 25 days (working). 
No vacation (annual leave) may be taken by an employee until he/she has been in the service of the city continuously for a period of six (6) months. 
The employee can accrue up to one hundred twenty (120) days' vacation and will be paid for all accruals at retirement, separation or death. 
Holidays occurring during an employee's scheduled vacation shall not be charged to his/her vacation time in any case. 
(b)  Sick leave. 
Any employee contracting or incurring any non-service-connected sickness or disability, which renders such employee unable to perform the duties of his employment, shall receive sick leave with pay. 
Employees shall be eligible for sick leave after ninety (90) days service with the employer. 
Employees shall be allowed one (1) day sick leave for each month of service. Sick leave shall be earned by an employee for any month in which the employee is compensated for five (5) or more hours of work. 
Employees shall start to earn sick leave from their date of hire, and they shall accumulate sick leave as long as they are in the service of the employer. Sick leave may be accumulated up to a maximum of one hundred twenty (120) days. 
When an employee finds it necessary to be absent for any of the reasons specified herein, he/she shall cause the facts to be reported to his/her department head thirty (30) minutes prior to the regular time for reporting to work. 
An employee must keep his department head informed of his/her condition if the absence is of more than three (3) days' duration. An employee may be required to submit a medical certificate for any absence after the third day in any one usage. 
After an employee has banked twelve (12) unused sick days, he/she has the option to either continue accruing such time or receiving in cash in December on a 1 to 2 ratio, all time which he/she elects to cash in for accumulated sick leave all over twelve (12) days he/she must keep banked at all times. 
10.8. - Activities not earning sick or annual leave. 
    No employee shall earn annual or sick leave for: 
(a)  Overtime hours. 
(b)  For any hours of leave without pay. 
(c)  While he is on leave with or without pay, until such time as he returns to active work except where inability to return to work is caused by illness or disability. 
(d)  For any hours of on-call status. 
(e)  For hours of travel outside of his normal work hours. 
(f)  For any hours of a holiday or other non-work day. 
10.9. - Request for annual leave. 
    When an employee requests annual leave, it must be applied for in advance by the employee and may only be used with the approval of the department head or his designated representative. 
10.10. - Effect of non-work days on annual leave. 
    No annual leave shall be charged for a non-work day. 
10.11. - Reduction of annual leave. 
    No employee shall be required to reduce his annual leave below thirty (30) days, however, the employee may be required to reduce his annual leave to this amount by the department. 
10.12. - Payment of annual and sick leave upon separation. 
    Annual and sick leave shall be paid upon separation as follows: 
(a)  Employees shall be compensated in cash for any accumulated unused leave when they are permanently separated from employment as a result of voluntary resignation, discharge, retirement, or death. In the event of death, payment is to be made to the estate of the employee. 
(b)  The amount of payment of all unused leave is to be calculated at the employee's rate of pay in effect on the pay day immediately preceding the employee's separation. 
10.13. - Payment beyond last day of work disallowed. 
    No payment for annual leave may be used to continue the employee as a classified employee beyond the last day of work. 
10.14. - Grounds for sick leave. 
    Sick leave may be utilized by an employee for absence of duty for the following: 
(a)  Illness or injury. 
(b)  Medical, dental, or optical consultation or treatment. 
10.15. - Minimum charges of leave. 
    All charges of sick or annual leave will be for a minimum of one-half hour. 
10.16. - Physician's certification authorized. 
    The department may require the employee to file a certification from a registered physician or some other acceptable proof that the employee is unable to perform because of illness. 
10.17. - Advance leave prohibited. 
    Advance of sick or annual leave to an employee is prohibited. 
10.18. - Special leave. 
    Employees shall be given special leave for the following: 
(a)  Performing jury duty. 
(b)  Summoned to appear in court as long as they are not the plaintiff or defendant in an action separate from their city employment. 
(c)  The city determines that he is prevented from doing his duties because of an act of God. 
(d)  The city determines that because of local celebrations, it is impracticable to work. 
(e)  The employee is ordered to active training for the Army Reserve or National Guard. 
(f)  For special needs of certain relatives. 
(g)  Education leave if it is within the scope of employment and is limited to thirty (30) days per year. The city may give additional education leave to employees with the approval of the commission. 
10.19. - Leave without pay. 
    No leave without pay shall be approved for any employee over one (1) year without the approval of the commission. All leave without pay over thirty (30) days will be sent to the director in writing. 
10.20. - Termination authorized after sick leave exhausted. 
    When an employee has exhausted all sick leave, they may be terminated without prejudice if the department certifies that the position must be filled. No position will be doubly encumbered as a permanent position in the classified service. However, he shall retain his reemployment status upon release from a doctor to the director that he is available for reemployment. 
10.21. - Curtailment authorized. 
    The city may curtail any leave of absence it has granted provided that the city gives the employee fifteen (15) days to return to work. If the employee does not return to work on the requested day, he can be removed from the classified service. 
10.22. - Holidays. 
    All classified employees will have the following holiday schedule and will be paid in accordance with the amount of the working hours or workweek they are to perform: 
(a)  New Year's Day. 
(b)  Good Friday. 
(c)  Memorial Day. 
(d)  Independence Day. 
(e)  Labor Day. 
(f)  Veteran's Day. 
(g)  Thanksgiving Day. 
(h)  Christmas Day. 
(i)  Employee's Birthday. 
10.23. - Payment of overtime. 
    The city may pay overtime hours within this rule in compensatory time, on an hour for hour basis, provided that all time is used or paid for on a one and one-half (11/2) times basis within six (6) months of the time it is accumulated. 
CHAPTER 11. - DISCIPLINARY ACTIONS, SEPARATION AND LAYOFF 

11.1. - Authorized. 
    The city may take action to suspend, remove, demote, reduce in pay reassign or reprimand any classified employee for cause. 
11.2. - Suspensions. 
(a)  Any employee suspended without pay shall be notified on or before the effective date of the suspension. 
(b)  Any employee suspended shall be furnished detailed reason of the suspension in writing within ten (10) days of the effective date of the suspension. 
(c)  Any employee who has been suspended without pay may be paid for time lost if after investigation the commission decides that disciplinary action was not warranted. The director shall authorize the reimbursement with the approval of the director of administration. 
11.3. - Adverse actions for cause-Reasons; appeal. 
    [In] all adverse actions for cause, the department must furnish the employee in writing the following: 
(a)  Detailed reason must be furnished for the action on or before the action is taken. 
(b)  In the written notice the statement "you may appeal this action to the personnel merit commission within thirty (30) days" shall be placed on all adverse actions. 
(c)  All adverse actions must be sent to director within five (5) days of the action. 
11.4. - Same-Delivery. 
    All actions for cause shall be delivered to the employee by: 
(a)  Personal service to the employee on the job or at their residence; or 
(b)  Sent to the employee's last-known address on file in the personnel office, mailed certified mail, return receipt requested. 
11.5. - Layoff. 
    When the city determines that a reduction in the work force is necessary, the following procedures will be followed: 
(a)  The director of administration will notify the director of the intent of layoff and the number of personnel and department by class, to be laid off. 
(b)  The director will prepare a layoff list by department by laying off employees in seniority order by classification in the following order: 
(1)  Temporary employees. 
(2)  Job appointment employees. 
(3)  Probationary employees. 
(4)  Permanent employees. 
(c)  This layoff will be made in seniority order by class and will be city-wide and not limited to one (1) department. 
(d)  No permanent employee will be laid off while the city has other types of appointments which could be laid off within the city. 
(e)  If a permanent employee is laid off, his name will be placed in the first available position in the class in which he qualifies. 
(f)  When a layoff is in progress, an employee must be offered any available position for which he qualifies on a seniority basis; however, once offered a position and the position is declined, the employee, no matter what the status, will be laid off and placed on the preferred hire list. 
11.6. - Resignation-Letter required. 
    When an employee voluntarily resigns, he or she must give the personnel office a written letter of resignation. 
11.7. - Same-Withdrawal requirements. 
    Any employee who resigns may not receive or withdraw such resignation without mutual agreement between the employee and the department. 
CHAPTER 12. - APPEALS AND HEARINGS 

12.1. - Authorized. 
    Any action taken by the city or department thereof may be appealed to the commission through the grievance procedure by the following: 
(a)  Any person who feels that they have been discriminated against because of any adverse action from employment. 
(b)  Any employee, serving in permanent status who has had adverse action taken against them. 
(c)  Any person in the classified service that alleges that they have been deprived of any right, discriminated against, or adversely affected by the violation of any rule or provision of these rules. 
12.2. - Definition. 
    A grievance is hereby defined to mean a dispute concerning the meaning, interpretation, or application of any of the provisions of the personnel merit system which may not be covered by a current labor agreement and shall be settled in accord with the following grievance procedure hereinafter set forth; provided, however, that the discussion and settlement of the grievance shall in no way disrupt the city's work schedules. 
12.3. - Procedure. 
    The grievance procedure is as follows: 
Step No. 1:  A grievance shall be presented orally to the aggrieved employee's immediate supervisor within five (5) working days from the act or omission giving rise to the grievance. An earnest attempt will be made to arrive at a settlement thereof. Failing satisfactory adjustment within three (3) working days, the grievance may be submitted to the employee's department head by the aggrieved employee and/or a representative of his choice within five (5) working days. 
Step No. 2:  The grievance, when referred to the department head shall be in writing and shall state the specific reasons for the grievance and specify the pertinent details of the act or omission giving rise to said grievance. The department head or his designee shall conduct a hearing on the grievance within five (5) working days. If the department head or his designee fails to adjust the grievance in a satisfactory manner within five (5) working days after the hearing, the employee and/or his representative may appeal the grievance to the mayor within five (5) days. 
Step No. 3:  The mayor or his designee shall conduct a hearing on the grievance within ten (10) working days. If the mayor or his designee fails to adjust the grievance satisfactorily within five (5) working days, the employee and/or his representative may appeal the grievance to the personnel merit system commission. 
Step No. 4:  Appeal to personnel merit system commission. 
12.4. - Filing of appeals. 
    All appeals to the commission must: 
(a)  Be filed within thirty (30) days following the action taken by the mayor and be filed in the director's office. 
(b)  Be in writing. 
(c)  Be signed by the employee or appellant or by an attorney on his or her behalf. 
(d)  Have the name and mailing address of the appellant or employee. 
(e)  Contain a clear and concise statement of the actions and the basis for which the appeal is being made. 
(f)  If discrimination is alleged as a basis for appeal, show the specific facts supporting the discrimination and must be in detail. 
(g)  Give the date the action occurred and the date the employee or appellant learned of the action. 
(h)  Indicate the relief sought. 
12.5. - Time of appeals. 
    All appeals shall run for thirty (30) calendar days and will not be delayed for holidays or weekends or other types of leave given to an employee except when the thirtieth day falls on a city non-work day, the period will be extended to the next city work day. 
12.6. - Docketing of appeals. 
    The director will note the date of filing in his office and forward copies to the mayor, director of administration, and department head concerned. He will cause all appeals to be docketed for hearing by the commission within thirty (30) days from the date of filing with at least ten (10) days' advance notice of the hearing. 
12.7. - Dismissal of appeals. 
    The city may request any appeal not meeting the specification of this chapter or the rules to be summarily dismissed. 
12.8. - Hearings by commission. 
    All docketed appeals will be heard by the commission at a place assigned and both parties shall be present either voluntarily or through subpoenas. 
12.9. - Hearings to be public. 
    All hearings shall be public, and all parties have the right of counsel or representation of their choice. All hearings will be held in accord with chapter 1, paragraph 1.5. 
12.10. - Oath. 
    All testimony will be under oath. 
12.11. - Decisions-Status. 
    The decision rendered by the commission will be the official position of the commission. 
12.12. - Same-Appeal-Authorized. 
    The parties have the legal right to appeal this decision to the next court of jurisdiction within thirty (30) days of the decision of the commission. 
12.13. - Same-Same-Payment of cost. 
    All cost of such appeals will be borne by the individuals. 
12.14. - Issuance of written decision. 
    A written decision will be issued by the commission containing its findings of facts and conclusions. The decision shall be final on the day that it is filed with the director. If the commission orders a reinstatement, the city will reinstate on the day which is ordered. 
12.15. - Settlement. 
    The city and employee may reach an amicable settlement after an appeal is docketed. The city must report such settlement to the director. 
CHAPTER 13. - RECORDS AND REPORTS 

13.1. - Payroll and attendance records-Maintenance. 
    It shall be the duty of the director with the approval of the director of administration and mayor to design a system to facilitate the maintenance of adequate personnel records and to eliminate duplication of accounting and reporting to the fullest extent practicable. 
13.2. - Same-Certification. 
    All payroll and attendance records will be certified by the employee and the department head. 
13.3. - Personnel action. 
    All personnel action will be reported on the prescribed personnel action forms and these forms signed by the director shall constitute authorization under the classified system. 
13.4. - Leave records. 
    Leave records will be maintained by the director. 
13.5. - Audit of payroll and leave records authorized. 
    The director may, from time to time, audit any and all payroll and leave records of the city in the classified service. 
CHAPTER 14. - DEFINITIONS 
    The following words and phrases when uses in these rules shall have the following meanings: 
14.1. Abandonment of position means the desertion by a classified employee of his position. 14.2. Allocation means the determination of the class to which a position in the classified service shall be deemed to pertain. 14.3. Annual leave is leave with pay granted an employee for the purpose of rehabilitation, restoration and maintenance of work efficiency, or transaction of personal affairs. 14.4. Appointment means an offer to a qualified person of employment in a classified position and the acceptance of such offer. 14.5. Bona fide student means a person enrolled in an accredited high school, college or university in the state, or person enrolled in a state-operated vocational-technical school, in a sufficient number of courses and classes in such institution to be classified as a full-time regular student under the criteria used by the institution in which he is enrolled; enrolled in an institution of higher education as defined in section 461(b) of the Higher Education Act. A bona fide student shall not lose his status for vacation during an academic year or summer recess. 14.6. Class means one (1) or more positions in the classified service so nearly alike in essential characteristics as to warrant like treatment for all personnel purposes. 14.7. Classified position means any office or position in the classified service. 14.8. Classified service is defined as that body of employees performing personal services to and for the City of monroe except those rendering such services who are specifically exempt from the classified service by the City Charter and these rules. 14.9. Commission means the city of Monroe Personnel Merit Systems Commission. 14.10. Continuing position means an office or position of employment in the classified service which reasonably can be expected to continue for more than twelve (12) months. 14.11. Continuous city service means uninterrupted status of a classified employee of the city exclusive of interruption caused by authorized leave of absence, layoff of not more than one (1) year, military service consisting of active duty in the armed forces of the United States for not more than six (6) years of voluntary service or an indefinite period of involuntary service. 14.12. Demotion means a change of a permanent or probationary employee from a position of one class to a position of another class for which a lower minimum rate of pay is prescribed. 14.13. Preferred reemployment list means a list containing the names of former classified employees who have noncompetitive reemployment rights in a particular class or classes in a certain department. 14.14. Designated holiday means a holiday or part of a holiday an employee observes, in lieu of a regular holiday observed by the city, because the regular holiday or a portion thereof fell on the employee's regular day off. 14.15. Director means the director of the department of personnel. 14.16. Detail to special duty means the temporary assignment of an employee to perform the duties and responsibilities of a position other than the one to which he is regularly assigned, without prejudice to his rights in and to his regular position. 14.17. Discrimination means consideration of religious or political beliefs, sex, race, or any other nonmerit factors. 14.18. Eligible means any person who is currently on an eligible list for employment with the city. 14.19. Emergency appointment means a temporary appointment made necessary by an emergency work situation which will not exceed ninety (90) days. 14.20. Job appointment means a temporary appointment of an employee for work of a temporary nature or to substitute for another employee not to exceed six (6) months. 14.21. Layoff means the removal of an employee from a position because of lack of work, lack of funds, or for other causes other than disciplinary actions. 14.22. Leave of absence without pay is leave or time off from work granted by the city for which period the employee receives no pay. 14.23. Original appointment means initial appointment of a person to a classified position by provisional, probationary or job appointment. 14.24. Pay means salary, wages, fees, allowances and all other forms of valuable consideration, or the amount of any one (1) or more of them earned by or paid to any employee, for service rendered in any position, but does not include any allowance for expense authorized and incurred as incidence to employment. 14.25. Pay plan means all the rates of compensation prescribed by the commission and approved by the mayor and city council for classes of positions in the classified service. 14.26. Political activity means an effort to support or oppose the election of a candidate for political office in an election in the city. 14.27. Position means any employment in the classified service. 14.28. Probationary appointment means appointment to test the employee's ability to perform the job duties assigned. 14.29. Promotion means a change of a permanent employee in the classified service from a position of one class to a position of another class for which a higher minimum rate of pay is provided in the pay plan. 14.30. Promotional list means a list, established in conformity with these rules, of permanent employees who have demonstrated their fitness for a higher class position by successfully meeting the requirement of the commission for such higher class position and are eligible for promotion. 14.31. Public hearing means a hearing held after public notice of at least ten (10) days, at which any person may have a reasonable opportunity to be heard, in accordance with such rules and regulations as may be adopted by the commission. 14.32. Reallocation means a change in the allocation of a position from one class to another class where in the duties of the position have undergone a change. 14.33. Reassignment means the change of a probationary or permanent employee from a position in one class to another position in a different class, both classes of which have the same minimum rate of pay. 14.34. Reemployment means the noncompetitive appointment of a person based on permanent status attained in former employment in the classified service for a period of three (3) years. 14.35. Regular or permanent appointment means the status attained by a classified employee upon the successful completion of his probationary period. 14.36. Reinstatement means the restoration of a former classified employee to duty and pay status pursuant to an order issued by the commission or an appellate court. 14.37. Removal or dismissal means the termination of employment of an employee for cause. 14.38. Resignation means the voluntary termination, by an employee, of his employment in the classified service. 14.39. Seniority means an employee's length of continuous service with the city since his last date of hire. 14.40. Service rating means the individual rating of an employee, made in accordance with the uniform service rating system established by these rules. 14.41. Sick leave is leave with pay granted an employee who is suffering with a sickness or disability which prevents him from performing his usual duties and responsibilities or who requires dental or optical consultation or treatment. 14.42. Suspension means the enforced leave of absence without pay of an employee for disciplinary purposes, or during an investigation of alleged misconduct by the employee. 14.43. Title change means a change in the title of the class to which a position is allocated without change in the position's duty and responsibility content. 14.44. Transfer means the change of an employee from a position in one department to a position in another department without change in probational or permanent status and without a break in service of one (1) or more working days. 14.45. Uniform pay plan means a pay plan which is uniform in all respects within all departments of the city for position in the classified service.  
CHAPTER 15. - COLLECTIVE BARGAINING UNIT RECOGNITION 

15.1 - Preamble. 
    In order to provide for the orderly certification and decertification of labor organizations seeking to enter into collective bargaining agreements with the City of Monroe and as required by Section 7-06 of the Charter of the City of Monroe, the following rules and procedures shall apply whenever there is no federal or state law providing such procedures which would be applicable to city employees. 
(Ord. No. 11,046, 3-23-10) 
15.2. - Bargaining units. 
    Any group of employees of the City of Monroe may seek to establish units for the purpose of bargaining collectively with the City of Monroe in respect to rates of pay, wages, hours of employment, employee grievances, discipline and other conditions of employment. All employees within a unit shall have common economic and working condition interests. Each unit shall consist of not less than fifteen (15) employees of the City of Monroe. No unit shall be recognized without the written approval of a majority of the employees contained within the proposed bargaining unit. Only full time employees employed by the City of Monroe for more than ninety (90) days at the time of petitioning or voting shall be considered eligible to vote or petition. 
(Ord. No. 11,046, 3-23-10) 
15.3. - Procedure to be recognized as a bargaining unit. 
    Should any group of employees, or any labor organization acting on their behalf, desire to be recognized as a bargaining unit, they shall submit a petition for recognition on a form to be promulgated by the department of administration, division of human resources of the city. Bargaining units, once recognized, may not be divided without the decertification of the union for the entire bargaining unit. The department of administration, division of human resources will review the petition and approve or disapprove the definition of the bargaining unit. Written reasons shall be given for disapproval. Should the petition not be approved, the employees may appeal, within thirty (30) days, to the city council and its decision on whether to approve or disapprove the proposed bargaining unit shall be final. Within thirty (30) days of approval of the bargaining unit definition, or contemporaneously with the request for recognition of a bargaining unit, the proposed representative of the unit or any employee within the bargaining unit shall submit a written request for an election signed by thirty (30) per cent of the employees of the proposed unit, on a form promulgated by the department of administration, division of human resources. Should the employees fail to submit the written request for election contemporaneously with the petition for formation of a bargaining unit or within thirty (30) days, the proposed bargaining unit shall not be recognized and no requests for recognition of a bargaining unit covering the employees shall be entertained for a period of twelve (12) months from the last day the written request for election could have been submitted. Any person signing in favor of an election may withdraw his request at any time prior to fifteen (15) days before any election to recognize a bargaining unit and its representative by personally notifying, in writing, the director of human resources who shall note the time and date of delivery to him on the written withdrawal. Should a person withdraw his request, his signature shall not be counted towards the number needed to hold the recognition election. 
(Ord. No. 11,046, 3-23-10) 
15.4. - Elections. 
    After approval of the bargaining unit and submission of written consent of thirty (30) per cent of the employees of the unit, an election by secret ballot shall be conducted by the department of administration, division of human resources, or its designee, for the purpose of approving the creation of the bargaining unit and the recognition of a bargaining unit representative. All permanent employees employed by the city for a period of more than ninety (90) days prior to the election and assigned to work on the date of the election within the proposed unit shall have the right to vote. All ballots shall be opened in public at such place as designated by the department of administration, division of human resources which place shall be reasonably calculated to accommodate all interested parties and such representatives of the news media as may wish to attend. All ballots shall be counted by the department of administration, division of human resources, with the director of human resources determining the validity vel non of each ballot. Should any person desire to appeal the decision of the director of human resources as to the validity of a ballot, such appeal shall be taken to the city council of the City of Monroe within ten (10) days of the decision to either accept or reject the disputed ballot and the decision of the city council shall be final. A majority vote of all employees within the bargaining unit shall be necessary for the creation of a bargaining unit and/or recognition of the bargaining unit representative. 
(Ord. No. 11,046, 3-23-10) 
15.5. - Confirmation of results. 
    The results of any election shall be confirmed in writing by the director of human resources to the city council. Upon confirmation of the results of the election, such confirmation shall be presented to the city council of the City of Monroe which body will recognize the bargaining representative if approved by a majority of the employees eligible to vote within the bargaining unit. 
(Ord. No. 11,046, 3-23-10) 
15.6. - Decertification of representative. 
    Should any employee or group of employees, or any labor organization acting in their behalf, desire to decertify a representative for a bargaining unit, they shall submit a petition for decertification on a form to be promulgated by the department of administration, division of human resources of the city together with the written request of thirty (30) per cent of the employees of the bargaining unit eligible to vote in an election for decertification. The department of administration, division of human resources will review the petition and signatures and approve or disapprove the decertification petition of the bargaining unit. Written reasons shall be given for disapproval. Should the petition be disapproved, the employees may appeal within ten (10) days to the city council and its decision on whether to approve or disapprove the decertification petition shall be final. Within thirty (30) days of approval of the decertification petition a secret ballot election shall be conducted by the department of administration, division of human resources, or its designee, for the purpose of approving or disapproving the decertification of a collective bargaining unit representative. All permanent employees employed by the city for a period of more than ninety (90) days prior to the election and assigned to work within the bargaining unit shall have the right to vote. All ballots shall be opened in public at such place as designated by the department of administration, division of human resources as reasonably calculated to accommodate all interested parties and such representatives of the news media as may be interested. All ballots shall be counted by the department of administration, division of human resources, with the director of human resources determining the validity vel non of each ballot. Should any person within the bargaining unit desire to appeal the decision of the director of human resources, such appeal shall be taken to the city council of the City of Monroe within ten (10) days of the decision to either accept or reject the disputed ballot and the decision of the city council shall be final. A majority vote of all employees within the bargaining unit shall be necessary for the decertification of a bargaining unit representative. 
(Ord. No. 11,046, 3-23-10) 
15.7. - Disputed ballots for certification and decertification elections. 
    All disputed ballots shall be placed in sealed envelopes, one for ballots allowed, one for ballots rejected, and delivered to the clerk of the city council. Such ballots shall remain in the sealed envelopes until such time as the city council may take up the appeal of the ballots, if any appeal is taken. At any appeal of disputed ballots, the director of human resources shall state the nature of the dispute concerning the ballots and the council shall act upon all ballots in accordance with its procedures. 
(Ord. No. 11,046, 3-23-10) 
15.8. - Presentation of decertification results to council and effect of decertification on existing contracts. 
    Upon the vote of a majority of the employees within a bargaining unit to decertify a representative, the result of such election shall be transmitted to the city council fifteen (15) days after the election or fifteen (15) days after the council acts upon any disputed ballots, whichever comes last. Should a representative be decertified, any contract between that representative and the City of Monroe shall be deemed null and void as of the date of the election for decertification. No action of the council shall be necessary to formalize decertification or the lapse of any contract. Should the election result in less than a majority of eligible voters voting to decertify or a tie, no further action shall be necessary and the vote for decertification shall be deemed to have failed. 
(Ord. No. 11,046, 3-23-10) 
15.9. - Limitation on elections. 
    Should a representative be certified or a bargaining unit not be recognized or a representative for a bargaining unit be decertified, no election concerning that bargaining unit, or any unit substantially the same as that bargaining unit, for certification or decertification shall be held until twelve (12) months have elapsed after certification, failure of recognition of a bargaining unit, or decertification. 
(Ord. No. 11,046, 3-23-10) 
APPENDIX B - POLICY AND PROCEDURE RELATIVE TO DRUGS AND ALCOHOL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Appendix B is derived from Ord. No. 9315, adopted July 28, 1992. The internal arrangement and numbering of the ordinance have been retained, as has the basic language. Any editorial emendations made for the purpose of clarity have been included in brackets. Future amendments to the ordinance will be included in their proper places; and a history note, showing the derivation of the amendment, will be appended to the section. Lack of such a history note indicates the section is derived from Ord. No. 9315. 

ARTICLE 1. - POLICY 

Sec. 1.1. - Purpose. 
    The City of Monroe, Louisiana (hereinafter referred to as "City") desires to maintain a safe, healthful and productive environment for all of its employees and the public which they serve. 
    The city recognizes that the use of alcoholic beverages and the use of unauthorized drugs by city employees in the work environment is a threat to the public welfare and to the safety of the individual employee, co-workers, and the public in general. 
    In order to protect the health, welfare and safety of the public, the individual employee and co-employees, and to heighten the efficiency and effectiveness of service to the public, the city will act to eliminate any substance abuse which increases the potential for accidents, absenteeism, substandard performance, poor employee morale and damage to the reputation of our community. It is the goal of this policy and procedure to eliminate substance abuse in the city work environment. 
Sec. 1.2. - Policy. 
    The policy of the City of Monroe is to promote and encourage a work environment for its employees which is free from substance abuse. To achieve that end the following rules are implemented: 
A.  The use, possession, concealment, transportation, manufacture, distribution, dispensation, promotion, sale, or purchase of any unauthorized controlled substance or any unauthorized alcohol by any city employee on city premises or while on city business is strictly prohibited and shall subject the employee to adverse disciplinary action. 
B.  No city employee shall be under the influence of or, if subject to testing, test positive for any unauthorized controlled substance or alcohol during the course of his or her employment. 
C.  The use of drugs or medication prescribed by a licensed physician for an individual employee shall be permitted in the work environment subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The drug or medication must be in its original container, must be in the employee's name and have the doctor's name and prescription number on the label; 
(2)  The drug or medication may not be taken more often than is prescribed on the label; 
(3)  The prescription cannot be older than one (1) year; 
(4)  The employee whose name is on the prescription cannot allow the consumption of the drugs or a medication by any other person in the work place; 
(5)  If the employee taking the prescribed drug or medication is aware of any adverse side effects or if the container has such a warning, the employee must inform his or her supervisor prior to using such substances on the job. 
D.  In order to promote and enforce this policy, a comprehensive program of substance abuse testing of city employees and applicants for city employment shall be instituted in accordance with the rules and conditions set forth herein. 
E.  All employees shall be informed of this policy and the procedures set forth herein. 
Sec. 1.3. - Application. 
    This policy shall apply to all regular, part-time, casual or contract employees of the city. This policy shall also apply to all applicants for employment with the city. Compliance with the provisions of this policy and its procedures shall be a condition of employment. 
Sec. 1.4. - Terms. 
    For purposes of this policy and its procedures, the terms "city premises" shall mean and include all property, offices, facilities, land, platforms, buildings, structures, fixtures, installations, boats, automobiles, trucks, other vehicles and equipment, whether owned, leased, used or controlled by the city. 
    The term "work environment" shall mean and include all areas, locations, vehicles or equipment entered, encountered or utilized while in the course and scope of the employee's city duty. 
    The term "accident" refers to any occurrence which causes injury or fatality, produce physical damage to property or material, or interrupts and/or terminates scheduled work assignments. 
    The terms "test" and "screen" may be used interchangeably to describe the procedure utilized to determine the presence of prohibited substances. 
ARTICLE 2. - SUBSTANCE ABUSE TESTING 

Sec. 2.1. - Applicants for employment. 
    All individuals applying for any employment position with the city shall be informed that a preemployment substance abuse test shall be required as part of the application process. 
Sec. 2.2. - Employee testing-Category I. 
A.  Category I. Positions where the health, welfare and/or safety of the public, co-employees and the individual employee is at risk shall be deemed "safety sensitive" positions, including but not limited to the following: 
Firefighters; 
Police officers; 
Jailers; 
Nurses; 
Traffic signal maintenance; 
Draw-bridge operators; 
Positions that require or allow the carrying of a firearm; 
Operation of motorized vehicles, including automobiles, trucks, tractors, or other heavy equipment; 
Positions that require the handling or use of highly volatile or explosive materials; 
Positions that require or allow the operation of dangerous equipment; 
Positions that entail working in dangerous conditions; 
Positions that require the handling or use of chemical substances. 
B.  All applicants for Category I positions shall be required to satisfactorily pass a substance abuse screening prior to employment or promotion into any Category I position. 
C.  All employees who occupy Category I positions shall participate in routine substance abuse screening in accordance with the following: 
(1)  All employees in Category I positions shall be tested at least once every three (3) years; and, 
(2)  All employees in Category I positions shall be subject to random routine substance abuse testing according to the procedures prepared by the Department of Administration, with at least thirty-three and one-third (331/2) percent of the positions being tested each year. 
Sec. 2.3. - Employee testing-Category II. 
    Category II. Whenever an employee has an on-the-job accident or suffers an occupational on-the-job injury requiring immediate treatment by a doctor or absence from work, or causes an injury to a fellow employee or to the general public which requires treatment by a doctor or absence from work, or where the injury was due to the employee's failure to wear required personal protective equipment or where the property damage of said accident is estimated at greater than five hundred dollars ($500.00), said employee shall be required to participate in a substance abuse screening test. 
    For purposes of this section, the term injury shall not include minor injuries such as bee stings, bruises, muscle strains, minor cuts, scrapes, etc. 
Sec. 2.4. - Employee testing-Category III. 
A.  Category III. An employee shall be required to participate in a substance abuse screening test whenever there exists reasonable cause or suspicion to believe that the employee's fitness for duty is impaired by substance abuse based upon the following criteria: 
(1)  An observable work-related behavior or similar pattern of conduct that appears to be abnormal, erratic or otherwise not in conformance with acceptable city policy; 
(2)  An observable work-related behavior or similar pattern of conduct that indicates signs of impairment of normal sensory and/or motor body functions; 
(3)  Any articulable facts or evidence that indicate any possible substance abuse on the job; 
(4)  Any information or evidence that warrants, or emanates from, an authorized investigation of possible drug or alcohol related activity by a specific individual or group; 
(5)  Any pattern of behavior, conduct or activity that is alcohol and/or drug related that is violative of municipal, state or federal law. 
(6)  Any employee who tests positive during a drug screening required by any licensing or certification requirement. Provided however, if the drug screen required for the license or certification was conducted or paid for by the city said results shall be sent to the medical review offices for confirmation and the employee shall be subject to the provisions of Section 5.2 without the necessity of additional initial screening. 
B.  Such information shall be reviewed by the office of the city attorney and approved as to reasonable cause or suspicion prior to a testing order. 
Sec. 2.5. - Employee testing-Category IV. 
A.  Category IV. Whenever any employee voluntarily enrolls in and successfully completes a certified program of substance abuse counseling or rehabilitation, which is in conformance with standards normally accepted within the healthcare industry, as a condition of continued employment, said employee must agree in writing to remain alcohol and drug free, and to undergo unannounced, post-treatment substance abuse screening for a period of twenty-four (24) months from the date of re-entry into active work status with the city. 
B.  In order to claim the benefits of Section 2.5 A., an employee must notify his department head and enroll in the certified substance abuse counseling and/or rehabilitation program prior to being selected, chosen, ordered, or scheduled for a substance abuse screening. 
ARTICLE 3. - DRUG SCREENING PROCEDURE. 

Sec. 3.1. - Testing method. 
A.  Alcohol. 
(1)  Testing for alcohol shall be by those methods and recognized by the State of Louisiana for cases concerning driving while intoxicated. Such test may be conducted by: (1) the laboratory selected under Section 3.2, herein (2) the medical review officer selected under Section 3.6, herein; or by the Monroe Police Department. 
(2)  The cut-off limit for alcohol shall be .01% or more by weight based on grams of alcohol per one hundred (100) cubic centimeters of blood. 
B.  Drugs. 
(1)  Testing for prohibited drugs shall be by immunoassay screen, with confirmation of positive tests by gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS) techniques. 
(2)  All drug testing procedures shall conform to applicable state and federal regulations and laws. The cut-off limits for drug screening shall be in accordance with NIDA guidelines, except that the initial testing for marijuana shall be fifty (50) nanograms. 
(3)  Drug testing shall be for any or all unauthorized controlled substances but shall include the following classes of drugs: marijuana, opiods, cocaine, amphetamines, and phencyclidine. 
C.  All testing procedures shall conform to applicable state and federal regulations and laws. 
Sec. 3.2. - Certified laboratories for drug testing. 
    The mayor shall determine the appropriate laboratory to perform the substance abuse screening test subject to the following criteria: 
(a)  The laboratory shall be certified by the National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA) or by the college of American Pathologists for forensic urine drug testing (CAP-FUDT); 
(b)  The laboratory uses NIDA guidelines for the collection, storage and transportation of the samples; 
(c)  The laboratory follows the strict guidelines of Louisiana R.S. 49:1001, et seq (Public Employees Drug Testing Act), including but not limited to the collection, storage, chain of custody procedures, review of results and reports of results; 
(d)  The laboratory guarantees a minimum confidence level of ninety-five (95) percent, by which is meant no false positive results and less than five (5) percent false negative results; 
(e)  The laboratory maintains strict confidentiality of all sample results so that at no time will the laboratory release results from any substance abuse test to anyone except as authorized herein. 
Sec. 3.3. - Collection procedure for urine drug specimens. 
A.  All collections of urine specimens for drug testing shall be collected, stored, and transported in compliance with NIDA guidelines or pursuant to statutory or regulatory authority granted under Louisiana R.S. 23:1081 et seq., 23:1601 et seq. and/or 49:1001 et seq. 
B.  (1) All collection of urine specimens shall be collected with regard to the privacy of the individual. 
(2)  Direct observation of the individual during collection of the urine specimen will be required under any of the following conditions: 
(a)  There is reason to believe that the individual may alter or substitute the specimen to be provided. 
(b)  The individual has provided a urine specimen that falls outside of the acceptable temperature range as listed in the NIDA guidelines. 
(c)  The last urine specimen provided by the individual was verified by the medical review officer as being adulterated based upon determinations of the laboratory. 
(d)  The collection site person observes conduct indicating an attempt to substitute or adulterate the sample. 
(e)  The individual has previously been determined to have urine specimen positive for one or more of the drugs the testing of which is regulated by this Chapter [Appendix], and is being tested for purposes of follow-up testing or after return to service. 
(f)  The type of drug testing is post-accident or reasonable suspicion/cause. 
(3)  A designated representative of the city shall review and concur in advance with any decision by a collection site person to obtain a specimen under direct observation. All direct observation shall be conducted by a same gender collection site person. 
C.  Every collection site person shall be responsible for sanitary collection of urine specimens while maintaining privacy, security, and the chain of custody. Every collection site person shall be responsible for the proper disposal of biohazardous waste and dispose of all biohazardous waste in accordance with proper safety procedures. 
D.  The collection site person shall collect split samples, according to the following: 
(1)  The donor shall urinate into a collection container, which the collection site person, in the presence of the donor, after the initial examination, pours into two (2) specimen bottles. Both specimen bottles shall be properly sealed and labeled in the presence of the donor. 
(2)  The first bottle is to be used for the city mandated test and at a minimum shall contain the quantity specified by the NIDA guidelines. If there is no additional urine available for the second specimen bottle, the first specimen shall nevertheless be processed for testing. 
(3)  Up to sixty (60) ml of the remainder of the urine shall be poured in the second specimen bottle. 
(4)  All requirements of this Chapter [Appendix] shall be followed with respect to both samples, including the requirement that a copy of the chain of custody form accompany each bottle processed under split sample procedures. 
(5)  The first sample of the split sample collection shall be tested by the laboratory selected under the provisions of Section 3.2 above, in compliance with the NIDA guidelines for initial and confirmatory testing in compliance with the regulations of this Chapter [Appendix], Louisiana R.S. 23:1081 et seq., 23:1601 et seq., and 49:1001 et seq. 
(6)  The second sample shall be stored for future use or used for testing for drugs not listed in the regulations of this Chapter [Appendix]. Any specimen collected under split sample procedures must be stored in a secured, refrigerated environment and an appropriate entry made in the chain of custody form. 
(7)  If the test of the first bottle is confirmed as positive, and a split sample is collected, the employee may request that the medical review officer direct that the second bottle be tested, at the employee's own expense, in a NIDA-certified or CAP-FUNDT-certified laboratory for the presence of the drugs(s) for which a positive result was obtained in the test of the first bottle. The result of this test is transmitted to the medical review officer who shall honor such a request if made within seventy-two (72) hours of the employee's having actual notice that he or she tested positive. 
(8)  Action taken by the city as the result of a positive drug test such as removal from performing a safety-sensitive function (Category I) shall not be stayed pending the result of the second test. 
(9)  If the result of the second test is negative, the medical review officer shall cancel the positive results of the first test and the employee shall be restored to his or her previous position. 
E.  All samples collected for drug testing shall be packaged, sealed, labeled, and transported with the proper chain of custody procedures for analysis to an NIDA-certified or CAP-FUNDT-certified laboratory in strict accordance with the NIDA guidelines. 
F.  The collection site person shall provide a written form and the opportunity for the individual to provide notification of any information which he or she considers relevant to the test, including identification of currently or recently used prescription or nonprescription drugs, or other relevant medical information. A copy of such information shall be attached to each chain of custody form. 
Sec. 3.4. - Appointments for pre-employment drug screening. 
A.  All applicants for employment with the city shall be advised that the city requires pre-employment substance abuse screening test prior to receiving an application form. Upon the completion of and the return of the application form to the personnel office, the personnel office shall make an appointment with the laboratory for the applicant to submit a urine specimen for the drug screening test and shall make an appointment for the alcohol test, prior to processing said application for an employment position. 
B.  The applicant shall submit picture identification to the laboratory to verify his or her identity at the time the specimen is collected. 
C.  Any applicant who attempts to evade the screening process shall not be considered for employment by the city for a period of twelve (12) months. 
Sec. 3.5. - Appointments for employee drug screening. 
A.  Each department head shall be responsible for arranging and transporting employees under his supervision to and from: (1) The site for alcohol testing, and (2) The laboratory for collection of urine specimens. In the event of a category II test, in which the employee is unable to be transported to the laboratory within a reasonable time due to injuries received, the department head shall make arrangements to have personnel from the laboratory come to the employee to take the specimen. 
B.  The identity of the employee participating in the screening procedure shall be verified by picture identification. If circumstances make such identification too onerous or impractical, the employee's identity may be confirmed by the department head or his designated representative. 
C.  Any employee who attempts to evade the drug screening process shall be dismissed from employment with the city and shall not be considered for future employment by the city for a period of twelve (12) months. 
ARTICLE 4. - REVIEW OF TEST RESULTS 

Sec. 4.1. - Medical review officer. 
    The mayor shall select a medical review officer, who shall be a licensed physician responsible for receiving laboratory results generated by the drug testing procedure who has knowledge of substance abuse disorders and has appropriate medical training to interpret and evaluate an individual's positive test result together with his medical history and any other relevant biomedical information. 
Sec. 4.2. - Review of drug testing results. 
A.  All positive results from drug testing, except pre-employment testing, shall be reported directly to the medical review officer as provided in this Chapter [Appendix]. 
B.  Positive results on pre-employment drug testing may be reviewed by the medical review officer. If the city chooses not to confirm a positive test result of a pre-employment drug screen test, the city shall notify the applicant of the positive result and shall offer the applicant the opportunity to pay for a confirmation of the test and a review of that confirmation by the medical review officer. Negative results need not be reviewed by the medical review officer and shall be reported to the appropriate representative of the city. 
C.  The medical review officer shall review all confirmed positive drug testing results of employees and report such results to the city in compliance with NIDA guidelines or pursuant to the authority granted under Louisiana R.S. 23:1081 et seq. and 23:1601 et seq. Negative results need not be reviewed by the medical review officer and shall be reported to the appropriate representative of the city. 
D.  Adulterated specimens shall be reported as such to the medical review officer with clarification as to the specific nature or the adulteration. The medical review officer shall contact the individual who submitted the specimen as outlined in the NIDA guidelines before making a final decision to verify a positive report of an adulteration. 
(Ord. No. 9402, 9-14-93) 
Sec. 4.3. - Rights of the employee. 
    Any employee, confirmed positive, upon his written request, shall have the right of access within seven (7) working days to records relating to his drug tests and any records relating to the results of any relevant certification, review, or suspension/revocation-of-certification proceedings. 
ARTICLE 5. - EFFECT OF POSITIVE RESULTS 

Sec. 5.1. - Applicants for employment. 
    Any applicant for employment who tests positive for alcohol or other unauthorized substances under the above procedures shall not be employed by the city and shall not be considered for employment for a period of twelve (12) months. 
Sec. 5.2. - Employees. 
A.  Any employee who tests positive for alcohol or other unauthorized substance under the above procedures shall be dismissed from city employment and shall not be considered for future employment for a period of at least twelve (12) months and only then after satisfying the requirements of Section 2.5 A. 
B.  Any employee who uses, possesses, conceals, transports, manufactures, distributes, dispenses, solicits, sells or purchases any unauthorized alcohol or other unauthorized substance on city premises or while on city time shall be dismissed from his or her employment with the city and shall not be considered for future employment by the city for a period of twelve (12) months.
